column2: On a recent sunny afternoon, unaware drivers who pulled into the car wash on Central Park Avenue in Yonkers might have thought they had seen an apparition when they saw a 6-foot-9 man in a black T-shirt and jeans vacuuming and wiping down cars.

Last year, M.B.A. students at the Bainbridge Graduate Institute in Seattle began hunting for a business-based solution to the problem of "food deserts" -- low-income neighborhoods lacking access to healthful, affordable food. (More than 23 million Americans live in such places, according to the Department of Agriculture, which maps them here.)
6:28 p.m. | Updated

CAIRO - It has been nearly three months since the last really big, unmanageable crowd converged on Tahrir Square and threatened to stay until its demands were met. On the eve of Ramadan, in early August, the Egyptian military smacked and clubbed that group - a broad but woefully inarticulate coalition opposing the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces' hold on power - out of the square. And much to the protesters' horror, the majority of Egyptians seemed fairly satisfied with the pushback, preferring a return to order even if it came with a military policeman's truncheon.

Though hospitals are eligible for billions of dollars in federal stimulus money to bring their facilities into the digital age to save money and improve the quality of health care, just one in 10 is ready to meet government standards to qualify for the funds, a new analysis shows.

Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book "The Benefit and the Burden."

In Today's TimesHerman Cain rejected as false the past complaints of sexual harassment that have surfaced against him but conflicting statements about how much he knew about the cases have prompted greater scrutiny of the Republican presidential candidate, Michael D. Shear and Jeff Zeleny report.

There's a new stop in Prague for contemporary art - Vernon Depot (U Pruhonu 22) has opened in the industrial-chic Prague 7 neighborhood of Holesovice. Part of the Vernon family of galleries, Vernon Depot will show works by the gallery's artists as well as a rotating schedule of exhibitions.

With two minutes left in the first half, the Bengals led the Seahawks, 10-3, on Sunday. Cincinnati called a play-action pass, but the pocket collapsed on the rookie quarterback Andy Dalton as he began to execute the fake handoff. With multiple Seahawks players crashing toward him, Dalton stepped up and fired a bomb into the end zone. At the same time, the rookie receiver A.J. Green had gained a step on Seattle safety Earl Thomas. As Green reached the end zone, Dalton's pass hit him perfectly in stride for a 46-yard touchdown. It was the fifth touchdown reception for Green this season, and the fourth time he's connected with Dalton for a score (Bruce Gradkowski was responsible for Green's first touchdown catch as a pro).  If Green and Dalton can connect six more times over the next nine weeks, they will become the first pair of rookie teammates to combine for 10 passing touchdowns.

Last week, an academic conference was held where scholars discussed the reality television show "Jersey Shore." Are shows, movies and other elements of popular culture just as worthy of serious study as novels and art films? Would you like to take an academic course focusing on reality TV or mainstream movies?
The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, "Wall St. Protest Isn't Like Ours, Tea Party Says."

The Champions League group stage makes the turn for home with what are essentially second-leg games from Matchday 3. Several of the favorites that won at home that day -- Chelsea, Bayer Leverkusen, A.C. Milan, Barcelona -- will be looking to repeat the feat on the road and lock up places in the knockout stages. Several others will just be looking to make their lives easier, and maybe separate themselves from the pack in their groups.

On Nov. 1, 1952, the United States conducted its first nuclear test of a fusion device, or "hydrogen bomb," at Eniwetok in the Marshall Islands. News of the event surfaced more than two weeks later, when The New York Times reported : "The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight 'satisfactory' experiments in hydrogen weapon research In a three-paragraph announcement, the Commission did not go so far as to state that a full-scale hydrogen bomb had been detonated, but it did say 'experiments contributing' to hydrogen bomb research had been completed."The origins of the hydrogen bomb date to the early 1940s, when the Italian-born physicist Enrico Fermi suggested to the Hungarian-born Edward Teller that a weapon based on nuclear fission was possible. Dr. Teller, a member of the Manhattan Project assigned to build the atomic bomb for the Allies, advocated for a hydrogen "super bomb" instead.

Shah Rukh Khan's manic marketing campaign for his new film "Ra.One" culminated with a whirlwind tour of the globe. The Hindi-film star, who acted in and co-produced the superhero movie, traveled first to Dubai, then went on to London before landing in Toronto. His 1,000-watt charisma appeared to suffer no jet lag. No wonder Cameron Bailey, co-director of the Toronto International Film Festival, which hosted Mr. Khan and his movie "Ra.One," declared on Twitter that Mr. Khan is the hardest-working man in show business.

The political storm created by the 2G spectrum scam continues to dominate headlines, as a joint parliamentary committee meeting devoted to the issue Monday witnessed a fiery exchange (Hindustan Times). Opposition members accused the government of concealing relevant information and, in particular, of having rewritten a word in the internal note of March 25 from the finance ministry to the prime minister's office. That document appeared to blame the previous finance minister, P Chidambaram, for failing to prevent the scam. According to a two-page letter from the current finance minister, Pranab Mukherjee, to the prime minister, Manmohan Singh, the note was drafted after detailed consultations with the prime minister's office and the cabinet secretariat, and issued at the behest of the prime minister's office. (Times of India).

Sean Avery will receive a hero's welcome from the majority of the Madison Square Garden crowd when he makes his expected return to the Rangers' lineup Thursday. There will be a detectable buzz in the arena and jump in the Rangers' step, and for good reason. The feisty shift disturber has an undeniably charismatic presence, whether anyone likes it or not.

10 P.M. (USA) COVERT AFFAIRS Season 2 returns from hiatus to find Annie (Piper Perabo, above) mired in loneliness while taking a break after a failed mission in Venice. But soon enough another assignment comes along, this one involving a chef linked to a separatist movement in the Basque region of Spain. 10 A.M. (Starz) EASY A (2010) Emma Stone plays Olive Penderghast, a good girl who pretends to be bad to improve her social standing in high school, and that of some persecuted class virgins, in this satire from Will Gluck. But when her faked promiscuity generates an unexpected chain reaction, she sews a capital A on her clothes and parades around the school in suggestive outfits. Amanda Bynes is the leader of the Christian club who denounces Olive. Penn Badgley is Olive's prince in waiting, and he's not buying her act. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called Ms. Stone's performance ''the best of its type since Alicia Silverstone's star turn several high school generations ago in Amy Heckerling's 1995 hit, 'Clueless.' ''

A headline for a report in the Business Briefing column on Saturday about investors' flocking to an initial public offering misidentified the company involved. As the report correctly noted, it was Groupon, not Google.

LONDON - As the Continent grapples with the sovereign debt crisis, financial regulatory revision in Europe has been put on the back burner, with some rules delayed until at least 2013. The changing priorities have left investment banks, hedge funds and even nonfinancial companies in a holding pattern about compliance and costs, a situation that is weighing on earnings prospects.

ROSENTHAL--James S.,on October 30, 2011. Devoted husband of Evelyn Tapani-Rosenthal. Dear son of Jerrold and Louise, loving brother of Edward and Julie Rosenthal and Linda and William Popper, loving uncle and friend. Services will be held today at Congregation KTI, Portchester, NY.

An album of material recorded by Amy Winehouse before she died, including new tracks as well as reworked versions of songs made popular by her and other artists, will be released on Dec. 5, an announcement on her Web site said Monday. The album, called ''Lioness: Hidden Treasures,'' will be released by Island Records, which released her two previous albums, ''Frank'' and ''Back to Black,'' and will contain 12 tracks Ms. Winehouse recorded between 2002 and 2008, including covers of ''Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow'' and ''The Girl From Ipanema.'' Other songs include a slower-tempo version of Ms. Winehouse's hit ''Valerie'' and a new composition called ''Between the Cheats'' that Ms. Winehouse planned to include on a possible follow-up to ''Back to Black.'' Ms. Winehouse, who had struggled with substance abuse problems throughout her career, was 27 when she was found dead in her London apartment on July 23. A coroner ruled last week that her death was the unintended result of drinking too much alcohol.

BATON ROUGE, La. - Louisiana is famous for its Cajun French influences, its gumbo, crawfish etoufee and Mardi Gras. It is famous for laissez les bon temps rouler, as the saying goes, or letting the good times roll. But the Cajun French flavor can sometimes have a bad grammatical influence.
COHEN--Suzanne. You will always be remembered with love. Never forgotten. Rest in peace, Gloria and Sherman

WEITZ--Sylvia. It is with deep sadness that we announce the passing of Sylvia Weitz, our beloved mother, grandmother, and sister. Sylvia passed away on Sunday, October 30, in her home. She was surrounded by her loved ones. Sylvia lived a long, fulfilling, and loving life. Devoted mother of Lori Shabtai and Steven Weitz. Cherished by her grandchildren Nicole, Danielle, David, Jonathan, Ashley, and Brandon. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Sylvia was the sixth of seven children of Sarah and Louis Goldstein. She is survived by her sister, Shirley Klang. "You were an exceptional, kind, generous and loving woman. A modest, gentle soul who graced the lives of all who knew her. You will remain with us in our hearts and souls forever. We adore you and love you dearly." Funeral services will be held at Star of David Memorial Chapels, 1236 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY 11704 on Tuesday, November 1 at 10am. For more info go to: www.jewish-funeral-home.com

The markets were haunted this Halloween by the ghosts of the past financial crisis. With MF Global filing for bankruptcy on Monday, investors pummeled many financial stocks, fearful that problems were lurking on the books of other Wall Street firms. It was a crisis of confidence, not unlike in 2008 when the markets punished stocks on mere speculation of trouble.

RYAN--Viviane A. The Department of French of New York University mourns the loss of its good friend and alumna, Viviane Ohayon Ryan (Ph.D., 1970). Thanks to her, many of our best doctoral candidates received fellowship support to finish outstanding dissertations. Her kindness and generosity were a source of encouragement to us, and we shall miss her keen interest in students, her lively presence, her friendship. Denis Hollier Judith Miller Thomas Bishop

HarperCollins Publishers said on Monday that it would acquire Thomas Nelson, a publisher based in Nashville, bolstering the company's strength in the market for inspirational and religious books. Thomas Nelson, which was founded in Scotland in 1798, has published books by Billy Graham, Richard Stearns and Max Lucado, as well as ''Heaven Is for Real,'' the blockbuster story of a Nebraska boy's near-death experience.

Pritzker, a great philanthropist and supporter of Hebrew University. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Mayari, their children and the entire family. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University Martin E. Karlinsky, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

MEYERS--Harold. It is with much sadness that we mourn the passing of Harold Meyers, age 95, at his home in Great Neck, New York, on October 29, 2011. Loving husband to the late Muriel Meyers for more than 50 years. Loving father to Meryl Cohen and Peter Meyers, loving grandfather to Aaron, Ori, Yael, and Lisa, and to four great-grandchildren. Devoted brother to the late Dr. Lawrence Meyers. Devoted brother-in-law and uncle. World War II veteran, attorney, and businessman. He will be dearly missed for his good nature, generosity, and humor.

We'll chalk it up to pure coincidence and nothing more sinister that FX waited until Monday - Halloween - to announce that it is ordering a second season of its macabre series ''American Horror Story'' from creators Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk. The show, which stars Dylan McDermott and Connie Britton as a struggling married couple living in a haunted Los Angeles mansion where people can't seem to stop dying, has been a hit for the cable network, drawing nearly 3.2 million viewers for its Oct. 5 debut and averaging about 2.8 million for each new installment. FX said that, through four episodes, ''American Horror Story'' was on track to become the highest-rated first season of any series it has broadcast, surpassing Mr. Murphy's plastic-surgery drama ''Nip/Tuck,'' which began in 2003. The second season of ''American Horror Story'' will run 13 episodes; no debut was immediately announced, though it will likely run in the fall, at which point we'll know whether it's more or less terrifying than Charlie Sheen's new FX series, ''Anger Management.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Corzine, the former New Jersey governor, several people briefed on the matter said on Monday. The recognition that money was missing scuttled at the 11th hour an agreement to sell a major part of MF Global to a rival brokerage firm. MF Global had staked its survival on completing the deal. Instead, the New York-based firm filed for bankruptcy on Monday.

BARUCH--Jordan. The American Jewish Committee (AJC) is deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished friend and colleague, Jordan Baruch. A longtime member of our National Board of Governors, he, in collaboration with his beloved wife, Rhoda, and the entire Baruch family, established AJC's Transatlantic Institute in Brussels. Jordan and his family were visionaries who understood the vital need to help ensure enduring ties between the United States and Europe. His steadfast and principled commitment to the Jewish people, to democratic values, and to human rights was evident in his lifetime of philanthropic work. And his outstanding professional leadership in science and technological innovation advanced government, academia and industry. They call it Mad Max Stadium, a cleared-out junkyard enclosed by tall walls of corrugated metal. The players, many with grimy mechanics' uniforms, filed in through a bent-back fence panel, past a sign that said ''Enter at your own risk,'' and stepped onto the field: a grimy concrete expanse whose boundaries were clearly demarcated by the mounds of junk and trash that ringed the playing area. A ball was rolled out, and Sunday's junkyard soccer tournament was on.

SARRO--Rudolph (Rudy). Left this world surrounded by family 29 October 2011 in Bronxville, NY, aged 84. Husband of Gioia Sarro, father of Rudolph Jr., Anthony, and Nicholas Sarro. Brother of the late Joseph, Armando, and Lucy Sarro. Grandfather of Jacqueline, Angelique, and Nicholas Sarro; Ayana and Anthony Sarro; and Rudolph III, Christian, Nicole, and Vincent Sarro; and "Uncle Rudy" to 12 nephews and nieces, their families and even their friends. Rudy grew up in a close-knit Italian-American community on 48th St. and 2nd Ave. in Manhattan. Like his beloved twin sister Lucy, he worked at his family's newsstand. After his brothers and his friend Hugo Coruzzi were called up to fight in World War II, Rudy signed up; on the way to Japan, his battalion (7th Division, 31st Infantry) was diverted to guard the smoldering situation in Korea. After his honorable service, he opened a luncheonette in his old neighborhood, where heavyweight boxing champion Rocky Marciano was a customer and good friend. Rudy married the lovely Gioia Franzi and they raised three remarkable sons and the three daughters of his widowed sister Lucy. Family was everything, but there was always a place for more at their dining table. Following his position as a law clerk at Shearman & Sterling, he served as a Senior Inspector and Compliance Officer for the State of New York Department of Agriculture, and in an environment that strewed an inspector's path with temptation and threats, he was a fortress of integrity. He was enormously proud of his three sons, all of them gentlemen, good husbands and fathers. His family and friends knew they could count on him for sage advice, and when anyone was in a tough spot, he would somehow appear at the moment when help was needed most. Protective, wise, vigilant, optimistic, a lover of life and family, a noble soul. The light of his presence will be sorely missed. The wake will be held at Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY 10708, 914-337-6770, Tuesday 6 to 9pm and Wednesday between 2 to 4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Thursday 3 November at 10am, at the Church of St. Joseph, 15 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY 10708.

Aside from playing Bernardo in a sixth-grade production of ''West Side Story'' and singing ''Someone in a Tree'' from ''Pacific Overtures'' in college, Lin-Manuel Miranda hasn't had much of an opportunity to perform the work of Stephen Sondheim. That will change in February, when Mr. Miranda, a Tony Award-winning composer and lyricist, is set to play the role of Charley Kringas in the upcoming Encores! production of Mr. Sondheim's ''Merrily We Roll Along.'' The creative team behind the production broke that news on Monday; they had previously announced that Colin Donnell and Celia Keenan-Bolger would play the other two central roles, Franklin Shepard and Mary Flynn, in the tale of showbiz dreams and disappointments. With a book by George Furth, ''Merrily'' was once one of Mr. Sondheim's biggest flops -- it closed after 16 performances on Broadway -- yet features one of his most celebrated scores, including the standards ''Not a Day Goes By'' and ''Good Thing Going.''

An editorial on Sunday about the nuclear weapons budget incorrectly described the positions of the former secretaries of state, George Shultz, James Baker and Henry Kissinger. All three have endorsed the eventual goal of a world without nuclear weapons. Mr. Kissinger is not a supporter of the Global Zero campaign. Mr. Shultz and Mr. Baker have participated in Global Zero events, but have not endorsed its call for a quick, interim cut to 1,000 nuclear warheads.

Gov. Rick Perry's proposal for an opt-in flat tax would primarily benefit the wealthiest Americans, according to a new analysis from the Tax Policy Center, a nonpartisan research organization. Compared with current tax policy, the plan would most likely reduce federal tax revenue by $570 billion, or about 15 percent. The plan, released last week as part of Mr. Perry's campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, allows taxpayers to calculate their personal income taxes under the existing tax code, which is progressive. But it also allows taxpayers to instead have their income taxed at a flat 20 percent rate. In this alternative system, long-term capital gains, qualified dividends and Social Security benefits would not be taxed, and only a handful of deductions would be allowed. Once a household chooses the new system, it cannot switch back.

We shall deeply miss Dick's energy, leadership, friendship and unwavering support. We extend our sincerest condolences to Dick's family and friends. Douglas D. Broadwater, Chair of the Board Carol Raphael, President & CEO

Sony Pictures Television said on Monday that it will produce the as-yet-untitled show with Flavor Unit Entertainment, the production company of Queen Latifah and Shakim Compere, and Overbrook Entertainment, the company of James Lassiter and Will Smith (who in 1991 gave Queen Latifah one of her earliest screen appearances on his sitcom ''The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air''). Queen Latifah hosted a previous talk show, ''The Queen Latifah Show,'' which ran in syndication from 1999 to 2001. Her new series is planned for a fall 2013 debut.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala. - Students surely choose to attend the University of Alabama for a variety of reasons: its academic reputation, a diverse student body, an accomplished faculty. But there is one perk that may rank above all the others - student football tickets cost just $5. Each season, Alabama students can purchase a package of tickets to home games. Many who are fortunate enough to buy one of the much-coveted student ticket packages do so with the intention of selling every ticket. Some part with some of their tickets but keep others so they can cheer on the Crimson Tide in person at least a few times.

During the first week of November 1861 the worst storm in years struck the Atlantic Seaboard. Lacking modern meteorological equipment and techniques to predict its arrival, millions of people were caught unprepared. Floodwaters swamped Newark, Manhattan and Newport, R.I. Violent winds splintered fishing fleets off New England. On Nov. 3, 26 people on board the 990-ton square-rigger Maritana drowned when their ship capsized near Boston Harbor.

Hollywood is full of weird little jobs. You see some of them on the credits at the end of the movie: Gaffer, Best Boy. In a lot of cases, the people in those mysterious-sounding occupations seem to get there by mistake, side-tracked en route to some other career. In fact, Los Angeles is chockablock with talented people who wound up in an entirely different profession from the one they'd originally started out in. I know painters who became art directors and set designers, a singer who started life as an actress and screenwriter. Two would-be novelists who both ended up film editors, though one of them eventually quit to become a yoga teacher.

Mika Rottenberg's video installations depict dreamlike assembly lines that parse animal, vegetable and mineral elements down to their base materialities, and, through strenuous, ritualized monotony, catalyze the production of weird junk: relatable daily circumstances for most of the world's population. The Buenos Aires-born artist, raised in Israel and based in New York, casts her workers for their unusual corporeal commodities - jumbo figures, endless hair, freaky joints - and they often seem to perform their tasks without the knowledge of why, or of their ornate connections to one another.

Inscrutable? Cryptic? Finding the right word to describe Bradford Cox is not easy. The Atlanta-based musician, lead singer of the popular indie rock band Deerhunter and mastermind behind the more esoteric solo project Atlas Sound, is tall and lanky and moves with a long, excited gait thanks to a genetic condition of the connective tissue called Marfan Syndrome. He's gone through wild periods of provocation involving onstage cross-dressing and fake blood. He's written song lyrics inspired by subversive Dennis Cooper novels. Spending time with him is a roller coaster ride that sweeps those around him up through various random-seeming whims and high-strung emotions. Despite all of this, or more likely because of all this, he is prolific with at least eleven albums and EPs to his name since 2005. His latest album, "Parallax," released under his solo moniker, further proves Cox's lo-fi genius, showcasing his deftness at weaving multilayered lyrics through harmonizing electronic tones and across undulating beats to create catchy but complex pop songs. It's worth noting that the album's title refers to the optical effect wherein our perceptions of various objects' relative positions depend on our distance from them - if you drive down a highway, the tree line whizzes past while faraway objects like the sun barely move at all. It's one of those facts in nature that seems intuitive and yet, upon examination, gets quite confusing quite fast. The same can be said of Cox's songs. Here we present an exclusive stream of the complete "Parallax" album (out next week, Nov. 8, from 4AD), along with a few words from Cox explaining the meaning of and inspiration behind four of his favorite songs - explanations he offers in his own signature fashion, without making any distinction between the technical, musical, literary or lyrical aspects of his work.

Pfizer, the world's largest drug company, surprised Wall Street in a good way Tuesday with higher-than-expected quarterly sales and an aggressive plan to respond to looming generic competition to Lipitor, the top-selling drug in the world. Pfizer also increased its huge share buyback program, and investors responded by bidding the stock up by 0.36 percent, to $19.33 a share, even as all 29 other stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average lost value on European debt concerns. The Dow fell 2.48 percent.

GOLDEN--Thomas E.,Jr, a life-long resident of Darien, CT died October 29, 2011. The cause was pancreatic cancer. He was 82. Mr. Golden, the son of Thomas and Ruth Golden, attended Hindley School and Darien High School and graduated with highest honors from La Salle Military Academy in Oakdale, NY in 1947. He entered Yale University that year with a special interest in civil engineering. As an undergraduate at Yale, Mr. Golden was president of the Yale chapters of the national Tau Beta Pi engineering society and the American Society of Civil Engineers. He was a first-string pitcher for the Silliman College baseball team and a member of Sigma Xi. In 1951, he graduated with highest honors from Yale. At graduation, he was presented with the Yale Engineering High Scholarship Prize and he received a ROTC commission from the Yale Field Artillery program. Mr. Golden received a Master's degree in Civil Engineering from Yale in 1952 before entering military service. He served as Resident Engineer with the Alaska District Office of the Corps of Engineers during construction of the Army Arctic Center at Big Delta, Alaska. In civilian life, Golden worked first as a professional engineer at Parsons Brinckerhoff an engineering and consulting firm. He then worked at The Barney Company, a NYC construction firm where he later became an officer. He later became Executive Vice President of Standard Dredging, an international marine construction company. He was a retired Reserve Officer of the New York District of the Corps of Engineers. He received several commendations from the Corps of Engineers for hurricane flood restoration duties in the greater New York area during the 1955-1956 hurricanes. He was a member of the Yale Club of New York and a retired panelist of the construction division of the American Arbitration Association. For the past forty-four years Mr. Golden was President of the Thomas E. Golden Reality Company and its affiliates in Darien. Mr. Golden was active in a variety of community affairs. He served on the Darien Flood and Erosion Control Board and the building committee for Darien High School. He was an officer or director of several public and private companies. He helped restore the Darien Theater with fellow Darien resident, Arthur Collins. Mr. Golden was generous in his support of Yale University. He endowed The Thomas E. Golden, Jr. Professorship in Engineering and was a Senior Advisory Member of the Yale Engineering School. In 2005, he received the Yale Science & Engineering Award for Meritorious Service to Yale Engineering. Mr. Golden made an unparalleled impact on Catholic life at Yale through his generous support of St. Thomas More Chapel. He provided the programmatic endowment within the 30,000 square foot, Cesar Pelli-designed, Catholic student center that was dedicated in 2006 and that bears his name. Mr. Golden was also responsible for the inauguration of The Thomas E. Golden, Jr. Fellowship in Faith and Science, an annual lecture contributing to the dialogue between faith and the natural sciences. Mr. Golden launched Catholic life at Yale into a new phase of growth and raised the standards for Catholic campus ministry nationally. Mr. Golden is survived by his cousins, Jean Burr of Thousand Oaks, CA, Maureen Brady of Barrington, RI and Sheila Schreyer of Knoxville, TN. Also, Christopher Golden of Marietta, GA, Justin Golden of Watertown, CT and Matthew Golden of Natick, MA. The family will receive friends at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien on Thursday, November 3rd from 4:00 to 8:00pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. John R.C. Church, 1986 Post Road in Darien on Friday, November 4th at 11am and burial with full military honors will follow at Spring Grove Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Carl & Dorothy Bennett Cancer Center, Stamford Hospital, 30 Shelburne Rd., Stamford, CT 06902 or St. Thomas More Chapel, 268 Park St., New Haven, CT 06511.

Most politicians hate loss, but not when it applies to their waistline. Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, who is in a tough re-election fight, has lost 50 pounds over the last few months, largely by trimming her portions and hitting the treadmill for about two miles of fast walking on a steep incline each day, she said.

The four-alarm fire that shut down a Harlem sewage treatment plant in July, sending hundreds of millions of gallons of wastewater into New York City's waterways, was probably caused by a single, improperly tightened nut, according to a report the city's Department of Environmental Protection released on Tuesday. Though equipment damage during the fire at the North River Wastewater Treatment Plant prevented the conclusive identification of a specific culprit, the agency's analysis suggests that a nut connecting a fuel injector to its pump was tightened either too much or too little during routine maintenance in June.

New York City schools reported handing out more suspensions to students last school year than during the previous one, but most of the increase was owed to a rise in less-serious infractions. Reported cases of egregious misbehavior have dropped. Education Department officials announced on Tuesday that the number of suspensions given to students citywide increased to 73,441 during the 2010-11 school year, from 71,721 the year before.

John A. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager who made his fortune betting against subprime mortgages, has been fodder for Wall Street gossip as rivals wondered whether investors would bolt after suffering staggering losses this year. At least for now, pensions, endowments and wealthy individuals are standing by their money manager. Redemption requests, which were due by Oct. 31, totaled less than 8 percent of assets, or roughly $2.4 billion, according to a letter that Mr. Paulson sent to investors on Tuesday.

Hugh Jackman's new concert on Broadway set a house record at the Broadhurst Theater, earning more than of $1.2 million last week, a result of the producers' decision to charge exorbitant prices for tickets to Mr. Jackman's first return to Broadway as a singer since his Tony Award-winning performance in ''The Boy from Oz'' eight years ago. The previous record at the Broadhurst was about $1.18 set by a production of ''Merchant of Venice'' starring Al Pacino during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day last season. Adopting the money-making strategy of ''The Book of Mormon,'' ''Wicked,'' ''The Lion King,'' and other top-grossing Broadway shows, the 10-week engagement of ''Hugh Jackman, Back on Broadway'' is selling tickets for up to $350 a piece - double the top face value of $175 for orchestra seats for that production. Several ticket agents said in interviews that, like airlines, theater producers are now increasing seat prices on a day-to-day, even hour-by-hour basis depending on the tilt of supply and demand. The Jackman show is still in preview performances; it is scheduled to open on Nov. 10.

BATON ROUGE, La. - In 1931, the administration of Louisiana State University was at odds with Huey Long, the state's governor. Long, who pined for a prominent football program, wanted to build more seats at Tiger Stadium, then only seven years old. The administration, most notably the president, James Smith, wanted to build more dormitories. It had even set aside $250,000 to construct more student quarters.

PELLA, Iowa -- Mitt Romney wasn't there. Nor was Herman Cain. But for the five Republican presidential candidates who did appear, Terry E. Branstad, the Republican governor of Iowa, offered encouraging words, as they all gathered on Tuesday at a National Association of Manufacturers forum. The five candidates are trailing in the polls. But with two months to go, the race for the Iowa caucuses is still wide open, Mr. Branstad said, and past campaigns have shown that front-runners can fade.

With two minutes left in the first half, the Bengals led the Seahawks, 10-3, on Sunday. Cincinnati called a play-action pass, but the pocket collapsed on the rookie quarterback Andy Dalton as he began to execute the fake handoff. With multiple Seahawks players crashing toward him, Dalton stepped up and fired a bomb into the end zone. At the same time, the rookie receiver A.J. Green had gained a step on Seattle safety Earl Thomas. As Green reached the end zone, Dalton's pass hit him perfectly in stride for a 46-yard touchdown. It was the fifth touchdown reception for Green this season, and the fourth time he's connected with Dalton for a score (Bruce Gradkowski was responsible for Green's first touchdown catch as a pro). If Green and Dalton can connect six more times over the next nine weeks, they will become the first pair of rookie teammates to combine for 10 passing touchdowns. A.J. Green's success has been a matter of when, not if; Sports Illustrated profiled him after his sophomore season in high school and correctly tabbed that he'd star in the N.F.L. by 2011. As a true freshman, Green led the Southeastern Conference in receiving yards and touchdowns. Against eventual national champion Auburn, Green caught 9 passes for 164 yards and 2 touchdowns. To no one's surprise, he was the first receiver off the board, at No. 4 in the 2011 draft.

AMENDED, AGAIN Groupon, the daily deals Web site run by Andrew Mason, below, disclosed additional changes to its offering document on Tuesday, noting that it completed a 2-for-1 split of its voting common stock. The company did not raise the expected price of $16 to $18 a share for its offering, despite considering such a move because of strong investor demand. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that Coach Inc. would buy over 600,000 square feet in the first tower of the Hudson Yards site - in a major step forward for the long-gestating development project. ''This deal means that the market has spoken: The Far West Side's economic potential has now become an economic reality,'' the mayor said in making the announcement, accompanied by city officials and real estate executives.

The Tennessee Titans answered some questions with a convincing win against the Colts, but a big one remained: What is wrong with Chris Johnson? Johnson rushed for 2,006 yards in 2009, with 14 touchdowns, and for 1,364 last season, with 11 scores. This season, he has 302 yards, with 1 touchdown.

An article on Monday about a dispute between the pianist He--le--ne Grimaud and the conductor Claudio Abbado over the cadenza to be played in a planned recording -- since canceled -- of Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 23, citing information from Ms. Grimaud, misstated her age when she heard a recording of Horowitz playing the cadenza she prefers, by Ferruccio Busoni. While she said she was 12 or 13 when she heard it, the recording was released in 1987, the year she turned 18.

''Everybody into the pool!'' will no longer work so well as a catchphrase for the New Museum's career survey of the adventurous work of the Belgium-born artist Carsten Holler, which opened last week. As one of its showstoppers, the exhibition includes a giant sensory deprivation tank created by Mr. Holler, in which museumgoers are invited to disrobe and lie in heavily salted water with a few friends or strangers to achieve a kind of out-of-body experience. But officials from the city's Department of Health contacted the museum last Friday and told curators that the museum needed city approval and a permit in order for a group of people to collectively enjoy such an experience.

The architect Robert A.M. Stern has been selected to design the American Revolution Center museum just steps from Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia's historic area, the center announced Tuesday. Mr. Stern is very familiar with the project. He was selected to design a new building for the center in Valley Forge National Park in 2002. But plans were thwarted by disputes with the National Park Service, which operates the park, and later with opponents who said the development would diminish the site's landscape and history.

A picture in some editions on Saturday with an article about a decision by John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, to hire Robert Abrams, a former state attorney general, to review Mr. Liu's campaign fundraising practices was published in error. It showed Robert W. Abrams, a defense lawyer who is deceased.

SAN FRANCISCO -- From the cotton field in rural India to the local rag bin, a typical pair of blue jeans consumes 919 gallons of water during its life cycle, Levi Strauss & Company says, or enough to fill about 15 spa-size bathtubs. That includes the water that goes into irrigating the cotton crop, stitching the jeans together and washing them scores of times at home. The company wants to reduce that number any way it can, and not just to project environmental responsibility. It fears that water shortages caused by climate change may jeopardize the company's very existence in the coming decades by making cotton too expensive or scarce.

She is survived by her sister, Shirley Klang. "You were an exceptional, kind, generous and loving woman. A modest, gentle soul who graced the lives of all who knew her. You will remain with us in our hearts and souls forever. We adore you and love you dearly." Funeral services will be held at Star of David Memorial Chapels, 1236 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY 11704 on Tuesday, November 1 at 10am. For more info go to: www.jewish-funeral-home.com

6:28 p.m. | Updated LONDON - Credit Suisse, the second-largest Swiss bank after UBS, said on Tuesday that its third-quarter profit rose 12 percent, to 683 million Swiss francs, even as the bank announced a further 1,500 job cuts as a result of the weak global economy and continued volatility in the financial markets.

HIER--Jean Schrager, died of cancer at the age of 89 on October 31, 2011. She is survived by her loving husband Stanley after 67 years of happy marriage. Jean was born in Monessen, PA, received BA in Economics Northwestern (1943), and worked for the War Labor Board in Chicago. She raised a family in Park Forest, IL, and taught school there after earning an MA in Education. She was an excellent photographer and an avid reader of Proust and other great literature. Enthusiastically moving to New York in 1977, where her passion for the arts grew, she enjoyed the opera, ballet and the symphony and became an American Crafts Museum docent. She leaves behind three loving children, Daniel, Andrew and Deborah, her son-in-law Mark, and four loving grandchildren.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala. - By Tuesday, Alabama football fans had already arrived in anticipation of Saturday's game against top-ranked Louisiana State. Some came early to visit family and friends, and others were here to take in the scenery. The main attractions on campus for any fan are Bryant-Denny Stadium, the Walk of Champions and the five coaches' statues.

The Museum of Modern Art is not getting into the concert promotion business just yet, but its latest commission has, at least on paper, the components and the pedigree of a pop-music spectacle. On Tuesday the museum said that it had commissioned Antony Hegarty, the artist and lead singer of the band Antony and the Johnsons, to create and perform a new work called ''Swanlights'' that will be presented at Radio City Music Hall on Jan. 26. The performance event, which MoMA described in a news release as a ''meditation on light, nature, and femininity,'' will include songs from all four albums by Antony and the Johnsons (including their most recent release, also called ''Swanlights'') with symphonic arrangements by Nico Muhly, Rob Moose, and Maxim Moston and performed by a 60-piece orchestra.

Federal officials are escalating an investigation into MF Global, the bankrupt brokerage firm run by Jon S. Corzine, as the search continues for roughly $600 million in missing customer money. Candice Bergen, Angela Lansbury, John Larroquette and Michael McKean will join James Earl Jones in the Broadway revival of ''Gore Vidal's 'The Best Man,' '' scheduled to open in early April, the producers announced on Tuesday. Timed with the 2012 election in mind, ''The Best Man,'' first staged in 1960, is set during an American presidential convention where a patrician, womanizing former governor (Mr. Larroquette, a Tony Award winner in ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'') is one of the leading candidates for his party's nomination. Ms. Bergen will play his wife, and Mr. McKean (''Superior Donuts'') will be his campaign manager.

Two members of the Tokyo String Quartet, including its founding violist, will retire from the group at the end of next season, in June 2013, the ensemble said in a statement from its public relations firm on Tuesday. The violist, Kazuhide Isomura, 65, helped start the quartet in 1969. Also leaving is the second violinist, Kikuei Ikeda, 64, who joined in 1974. The other two members, the violinist Martin Beaver and the cellist Clive Greensmith, are trying out candidates to take over the other violin and the viola positions. The new members will be announced in the spring, the quartet said. Mr. Ikeda and Mr. Isomura will continue to perform and coach, according to the statement. The original members had studied at the Toho School of Music in Tokyo and went on to the Juilliard School, where they formed the quartet in 1969.

GREENBERG--Alfred. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the loss of our beloved father and grandfather, Alfred Greenberg who died on Tuesday, November 1st. Al was a life-long New Yorker. Devoted father to Marc (Leora) and Joel (Marcy Gringlas). Cherished by his grandchildren Letal (Andrew Ackerman), Tamir, Sara, Erez, Jackson and Ellie. Born in the Bronx on April 9, 1921, the only child of Bessie and Morris Greenberg. After graduating City College in 1941, he served for four years in the US Air Force. He was a certified Public Accountant at Steinbrock Greenberg and Hicks. Al was a lover of books, theater, music and passionate about the opera. He had season tickets to The Metropolitan Opera since 1948, never missing a season. A true friend to many, a wonderful father and grandfather. He will be dearly missed for his smile, his intellect, his encyclopedic memory, his sense of humor and his passion for all things New York. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, November 3rd at 2pm at Adath Israel, 250 N. Highland Ave., Merion Station, PA 19066. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Al's memory to Vineyard House, Inc. (www.vineyardhouse.org) or Friends of the IDF, Philadelphia Chapter (www.fidf.org).

3:30 P.M. (MoreMax) SOMEWHERE (2010) Johnny Marco (Stephen Dorff, above), a movie star existing in a mind-numbing purgatory -- he drinks, he has anonymous sex, he burns rubber in his Ferrari -- at the Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood, finds something to live for after his ex-wife leaves Cleo (Elle Fanning), their 11-year-old daughter, in his care in what A. O. Scott, in The New York Times, called ''Sofia Coppola's exquisite, melancholy and formally audacious fourth feature.'' What happens, Mr. Scott added, ''is something marvelous: a film that never raises its voice (its loudest and most assertive sound is that Ferrari) or panders to your emotions, but that nonetheless has the power to refresh your perceptions and deepen your sympathies. As it proceeds from one careful, watchful, slow shot to the next, a sad and affecting story emerges, about a father's loneliness and a daughter's devotion. But the experience of watching 'Somewhere,' shot in lovely tones of Southern California haze by the great Harris Savides, is like reading a poem. The scenes play off one another like stanzas, producing patterns and echoes that feel like the camera's accidental discoveries, even as they are the surest evidence of Ms. Coppola's formidable and subtle art.'' 10:15 A.M. (IFC) AWAY FROM HER (2007) Fiona and Grant, a long-married couple played by Julie Christie and Gordon Pinsent, below, confront Alzheimer's disease in the feature directorial debut of Sarah Polley, who earned an Oscar nomination for her screenplay, based on an Alice Munro short story. ''There is, in Ms. Munro's mature work, a flinty wisdom about heterosexual love, a skepticism about romantic ideals that does not altogether deny their power or necessity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Ms. Polley, rather remarkably for someone still in her 20s, shows an intuitive grasp of this wisdom and a welcome, unsentimental interest in the puzzles and pleasures of a long, imperfect marriage.'' He added, ''I can't remember the last time the movies yielded up a love story so painful, so tender and so true.''

Some women who drink to their health may want to reconsider. A new study shows that women who routinely have even small amounts of alcohol, as few as three drinks a week, have an elevated risk of breast cancer. The research, which looked at the habits of more than 100,000 women over 30 years, adds to a long line of studies linking alcohol consumption of any kind -- whether beer, wine or spirits -- to an increased risk of breast cancer. But until now the bulk of the research largely focused on higher levels of alcohol intake. The latest study is among the first to assess the effect of relatively small amounts of alcohol over long periods of time, drawing on a large population of women to provide new detail about the breast cancer risks associated with different patterns of drinking.

SARRO--Rudolph (Rudy). Left this world surrounded by family 29 October 2011 in Bronxville, NY, aged 84. Husband of Gioia Sarro, father of Rudolph Jr., Anthony, and Nicholas Sarro. Brother of the late Joseph, Armando, and Lucy Sarro. Grandfather of Jacqueline, Angelique, and Nicholas Sarro; Ayana and Anthony Sarro; and Rudolph III, Christian, Nicole, and Vincent Sarro; and "Uncle Rudy" to 12 nephews and nieces, their families and even their friends. Rudy grew up in a close-knit Italian-American community on 48th St. and 2nd Ave. in Manhattan. Like his beloved twin sister Lucy, he worked at his family's newsstand. After his brothers and his friend Hugo Coruzzi were called up to fight in World War II, Rudy signed up; on the way to Japan, his battalion (7th Division, 31st Infantry) was diverted to guard the smoldering situation in Korea. After his honorable service, he opened a luncheonette in his old neighborhood, where heavyweight boxing champion Rocky Marciano was a customer and good friend. Rudy married the lovely Gioia Franzi and they raised three remarkable sons and the three daughters of his widowed sister Lucy. Family was everything, but there was always a place for more at their dining table. Following his position as a law clerk at Shearman & Sterling, he served as a Senior Inspector and Compliance Officer for the State of New York Department of Agriculture, and in an environment that strewed an inspector's path with temptation and threats, he was a fortress of integrity. He was enormously proud of his three sons, all of them gentlemen, good husbands and fathers. His family and friends knew they could count on him for sage advice, and when anyone was in a tough spot, he would somehow appear at the moment when help was needed most. Protective, wise, vigilant, optimistic, a lover of life and family, a noble soul. The light of his presence will be sorely missed. The wake will be held at Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY 10708, 914-337-6770, Tuesday 6 to 9pm and Wednesday between 2 to 4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Thursday 3 November at 10am, at the Church of St. Joseph, 15 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY 10708.

BERNSTEIN--Allen J. Castle Harlan, Inc. is deeply saddened by the passing of our cherished friend and colleague, Allen J. Bernstein of Manhasset, NY. He was a recognized leader and visionary in the restaurant industry, one of the finest minds in the business and a true friend. He was 65. While earning a Bachelor of Business Administration degree in Marketing from the University of Miami, Allen wrote his senior thesis on the emerging practice of restaurant branding, and in that process, identified his lifelong career. After graduating in 1968, he began purchasing franchises in such companies as Hardee's, Long John Silvers, Wendy's, Godfather's Pizza, Luther's Bar-B-Que and LePeep. His Wendy's outlet across from Penn Station in New York once was the busiest Wendy's in the United States. In 1988, Allen and Castle Harlan formed Quantum Restaurant Group to build national chains around great restaurant concepts. Allen was Chief Executive Officer of Quantum until he retired in 2005. Under his leadership, the company's first acquisition was the Peasant Restaurants in Atlanta. In 1989, the company acquired Morton's of Chicago, the renowned chain of steakhouses, which was one of Allen's proudest career achievements. The restaurant chain grew in number from nine units at acquisition to 79 today, and became so successful that Quantum's name was changed to Morton's Restaurant Group in 1996 to emphasize a focus on the namesake brand. When he retired, Allen remained Chairman Emeritus of Morton's and continued to serve in a significant ongoing advisory role. At the time of his death, he was President of Endeavor Restaurant Group, Inc., Director of the Bravo Brio Restaurant Group and Director of Cheesecake Factory, Inc. He served on the boards of directors of a number of privately held companies, including Caribbean Restaurants, LLC, the exclusive Burger King franchise in Puerto Rico. Previously, he served as a director of Charlie Brown's Steakhouse, McCormick & Schmick's Seafood Restaurants and Dave & Busters, Inc. He also served on the board of trustees of the American Film Institute. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Lori Waltzer Bernstein, sister Helene Morrison, his two children, Stacey Stolar and Adam Bernstein, his daughter-in-law, Jessica Manis Bernstein, and granddaughter Sarah Stolar. A memorial service will be held at 10am on Wednesday, November 2nd at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023. Allen's Colleagues at Castle Harlan, Inc.

If there were any doubt remaining, the scandal surrounding the Olympus Corporation of Japan has proved Michael Crichton wrong. What does the late Mr. Crichton, the author of ''Jurassic Park'' among other books, have to do with this, you may be asking? Mr. Crichton was responsible for ''Rising Sun,'' the popular book and movie that appeared in the early 1990s when Japan was today's China, about to dominate the world. In ''Rising Sun,'' Japanese businessmen were portrayed as crafty, willing to do anything to succeed against the bumbling Americans. Japanese were even stealing our women, arranging for them to serve as sushi platters at their decadent parties (you have to see the movie to believe this one) . ''Rising Sun'' and movies like ''Gung Ho,'' which starred Michael Keaton and involved the Japanese takeover of an American auto plant, created a perception that Japanese businesses were going to dominate the world. The Japanese were consensus driven and without the fractious disputes of American capitalism.

At the Milan Furniture Fair this year, the design mecca Spazio Rossana Orlandi was infested with beetles. The culprit was Thomas Eyck, an adviser at the Zuiderzee Museum in Enkhuizen, the Netherlands, and also the producer of a growing collection of strange and wonderful things, including this set of bug vases called Schwarm. Each year at the time of the fair, Eyck switches gears from curator to editor by selecting a different designer with whom he delves into a traditional material and craft. Past explorations have yielded flax rope furniture and lighting by Christien Meindertsma, brightly colored striped woolen blankets and pillows by Scholten & Baijings, and pewter objects by Studio Job. For Schwarm, he worked with the German artists Beate Reinheimer and Ulrike Rehm, known as RaR, who are fascinated with the dizzying diversity of the animal kingdom, particularly among insects. To wit, Schwarm features 10 different shapes, or genuses, and 63 species, each with a different glaze. They are being sold as a limited-edition set or individually, for the less entomologically inclined. For more information, go to thomaseyck.com.

As one of her singles climbed to the top of the pop music charts in the United States, Rihanna canceled a second show in Sweden because of illness and exhaustion. The pop diva has been touring without a break since early June, performing nearly 60 concerts on three continents to promote her album "Loud" (Def Jam). A concert promoter for Live Nation in Sweden, Kristofer Akesson, told the Associated Press that Rihanna, who is 23, "is exhausted and doesn't feel well." Her publicist in New York said she was suffering from the flu. The singer called off a concert in Malmo in southern Sweden on Monday, and sent a photograph of her arm with the tube from an intravenous drip to her followers on Twitter with a note saying, "Sorry Malmo!!!" She was not hospitalized as some news outlets reported. She performed Tuesday night in Stockholm, then called off a second performance on Wednesday night after consulting with a doctor.Rihanna joins several high-profile performers who have cancelled major concerts for health reasons this year, among them Adele, who is undergoing surgery to repair bleeding in her vocal chords, Taylor Swift, who had a bout of laryngitis, and Caleb Followill, the lead singer for Kings of Leon, who cancelled half his band's tour to rest his voice. Rihanna's decision to cancel two shows came as her single, "We Found Love," featuring Calvin Harris, rose to No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 songs chart. It was the 11th No. 1 single she has recorded, giving her the same number as Whitney Houston and more top singles than Stevie Wonder or Janet Jackson.

Ryan Sutton noticed Wednesday that the city health department had ordered Frankies 457 restaurant in Brooklyn closed after it scored 58 violation points on an inspection on Monday. For the devoted group of New Yorkers who've experienced Takamichi Saeki's scissor work firsthand, there is no going back from the "Takamichi cut." Now this former gallerist, avid soccer player and longtime resident of the Lower East Side is moving his salon and team of eight stylists from the loft on Great Jones Street that's been the home of Takamichi Hair since 2004 to a stylish new studio on the Bowery. Designed by the Belgian architect Sandra van Rolleghem to feel more like an apartment than a designer hair factory, the new space features custom touches, including hand-painted storage cabinets; an origami light fixture by a French designer, Éric Guen; artwork by the downtown pioneer Richard Hambleton and the Barcelona, Spain-born Santi Moix - both friends of Saeki - and a reproduction of a round Hermès mirror with leather trim from the 1920s. "We wanted it to feel like a home," the architect told me on a recent visit. With neighbors like the New Museum, Sperone Westwater gallery and the much-anticipated Bowery Diner, Takamichi Hair's new location fits this stretch of the Bowery like the perfect cut.

But late last year he started NYCutlery and put his hands back to work carving knife handles out of scraps of furniture-grade walnut and grinding blades from reclaimed steel, all in his backyard in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. His eco-conscious knives are made to measure for both fit and function. One evening in 1958, the pianist Dave Brubeck and his quartet gathered in the home of a jazz-loving industrialist on Mumbai's Malabar Hill to chat with a group of Indian musicians led by the sitar maestro, Abdul Halim Jaffer Khan. Then they picked up their instruments and put their new knowledge to work. The jam session with Mr. Khan, the American pianist said later, changed the way he approached his art. "His influence made me play in a different way," Mr. Brubeck told Jazz Journal International. "Although Hindu scales, melodies and harmonies are different, we understood each other The folk origins of music aren't far apart anywhere in the world."

HIER--Jean Schrager, died of cancer at the age of 89 on October 31, 2011. She is survived by her loving husband Stanley after 67 years of happy marriage. Jean was born in Monessen, PA, received BA in Economics Northwestern (1943), and worked for the War Labor Board in Chicago. She raised a family in Park Forest, IL, and taught school there after earning an MA in Education. She was an excellent photographer and an avid reader of Proust and other great literature. Enthusiastically moving to New York in 1977, where her passion for the arts grew, she enjoyed the opera, ballet and the symphony and became an American Crafts Museum docent. She leaves behind three loving children, Daniel, Andrew and Deborah, her son-in-law Mark, and four loving grandchildren.

Federal agents swarmed several medical clinics and homes in New York City on Wednesday, arresting 10 people on charges of running Medicare fraud schemes that bilked the government out of $95 million, federal officials said. Four questions for Frank Pizzurro, the owner of the Brooklyn Denim Company in Williamsburg, which sells a wide-ranging selection of denim, along with hip supporting apparel and accessories. What sells season after season? We have a big following for Tellason, a small brand from San Francisco. Up until three or four months ago, they did only one jean in one raw-denim fabric. It's a simple jean that fits well, $198. Younger people aren't ready for $200 to $300 jeans, so we carry a pretty broad range starting at $85. Thvm, Kill City and Big Star all do well under $100.

Because of an editing error, a review on Oct. 18 about ''A More Perfect Heaven,'' Dava Sobel's biography of the astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus, described incorrectly the religious climate of Frauenberg, Poland, in 1539, when Copernicus and his young acolyte Rheticus began their work together. While the area around Frauenberg remained a bastion of Catholicism as Protestantism swept over Europe, it was not ''one of Europe's last bastions of Catholicism.''

The giant mechanized set for the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle has continued its balky behavior into ''Siegfried,'' the third work in the series. At the performance on Tuesday night a malfunction prevented the set from creating the proper configuration for the final scene between the title character and Brunnhilde, when Siegfried awakens her from sleep amid perpetual fire around her and they sing a love duet, the Met said in a statement. The singers, Jay Hunter Morris and Deborah Voigt, performed the scene in an area at the front of the stage. The set, consisting of a row of revolving planks around an axis that rises and falls, takes on different formations and serves as a backdrop for sophisticated projections. Last season the machine failed in the closing scene of ''Das Rheingold'' on opening night and caused a 45-minute delay of a high-definition broadcast of ''Die Walkure.''

An article last Thursday about making a house safe for young children misstated the Home Depot price for the Leviton Decora tamper-resistant duplex wall outlet. It is about $2.50 -- not $20, which is the store's price for a similar Leviton outlet with surge suppression.

An article on Wednesday about the role of Abbott Laboratories in helping to build a charitable nutrition enterprise in Haiti misstated the United Nations Children's Fund's position on a vitamin-enriched peanut butter, known as Nourimanba, that is used to fight malnutrition. Unicef has not in fact approved Nourimanba. (A proposal to use the product has never been submitted to the organization for consideration.)

SHWEDER--Robert Howard, a sweet, sensitive, loving being. Husband of Martha, father of Gabe and Jaya, son of Bonnie and Jerry, brother of Robin, Ronni and Rick. Your shining eyes, joyful laugh, and warm hugs illuminated our spirits. Go in peace knowing you are loved by everyone you touched.

HEFELE--John Joseph,(Jack) 78, died Sunday, October 30, 2011 at the Legacy Hopewell House Hospice, following a difficult and brave battle with cancer. He leaves his wife of 56 years, Patricia (Pat) Fox Hefele (Portland); his son, Brian Hefele and daughter-in-law, Nici Griffith (Portland); his daughters, Rosanne Miller (Wilmington, DE) and Alison Bonney (Chicago, IL); his daughter-in-law, Lory Hefele (Portland); his brother, George Hefele (Redford, MI); eight grandchildren; and many friends. He is preceded in death by his son, Kenneth Hefele. Jack was born and raised in the Bronx, New York City, and was the son of George and Rosemary (Mallen) Hefele. His career, travel and retirement to Arizona took him far away from New York, but Jack never forgot his Bronx roots or his strong allegiance to the New York Yankees. After graduating from Evander Childs High School, he went on to graduate from Iona College in 1954 with a degree in business administration. He met his wife, Pat Fox, at St. Brendan's parish and in 1955 they were married at St. Philip & James Roman Catholic Church. Shortly thereafter, Jack joined the U.S. Army. He and Pat started their married life in Fort Hood, Texas. In 1956 Jack began working for General Motors Overseas Operations in New York City. During his 35-year career with GM, he was transferred to several locations including posts in Beirut, Lebanon, Honolulu, Hawaii and Detroit, Michigan. On behalf of GM International Marketing & Sales, he traveled extensively throughout the Middle East, Europe and Asia. Jack got satisfaction from his work, pleasure from playing golf and joy from entertaining with stories. He was especially proud of the international experiences and quality education that he, and his wife Pat, provided for their children. Often outspoken but always funny, kind and generous, Jack will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, November 5th at 11:00am at St Mary's Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception 1716 NW Davis St., Portland, OR. A reception for friends and family will immediately follow the service at Northwest Place, 2420 NW Marshall St., Portland, OR. Condolences may be sent to Mrs. Patricia Hefele at this same address. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Legacy Hospice Services Portland Good Samaritan Foundation - PO BOX 4484 - Portland, OR 97208-9964.

DESIGNERS have not been content to confine their use of shearling this season to linings and trim; it's all over their accessories. We like this Jerome Dreyfuss shearling one, with black or burgundy leather. Carrying it is like throwing your favorite shearling-lined leather jacket over your arm. But the pockets are deeper. Shearling and leather carryall, $1,420 at Jerome Dreyfuss, 473-475 Broome Street; (212) 334-6920.

It was a storybook celebrity marriage that captured a public's imagination, and then suddenly it was over before they even had a chance to complete their wedding registry. No, not Kim Kardashian and the N.B.A. player Kris Humphries, who devastated the American populace when Mrs. filed for divorce from Mr. on Monday; we're talking about a couple whose all-too-brief union makes the 72 days of Kardashian-Humphries bliss seem as old as the cosmos itself. That would be Ernest Borgnine and Ethel Merman, who separated after five weeks of marriage in 1964. There have been shorter celebrity couplings -- the actors Mario Lopez and Ali Landry split after about two weeks of marriage in 2004 -- but the Borgnine-Merman marriage reminds us that there were short-lived star pairings long before there was reality television, 24-hour celebrity entertainment coverage or Ryan Seacrest.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the neuroscientist Michael S. Gazzaniga misidentified a program at the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation that had Dr. Gazzaniga as its founding director. It is the Law and Neuroscience Project, not the Research Network on Law and Neuroscience. (The research network, whose founding director is Owen D. Jones, is a more recent program of the foundation.)

MITCHELL--Sidney L. With great sadness, we announce the death of our beloved husband and father at age 88 in Sarasota, Florida. Raised on Long Island, Sid served in the Merchant Marine and the Navy. He was a lawyer, commissioner and judge who helped inaugurate Suffolk County's farmland preservation program. He will always be remembered by his loving wife, Audrey and his children, Alison and Andrew.

They say that fashion is cyclical. The same goes for technology. Sure, most cellphones are the epitome of trendiness, but just think how cool you'll be if you hark back to the 1980s with AirCassette, an app that turns your iPhone into a cassette player. The $1.99 app, available in the iTunes App Store, displays your music in handwritten script on a background designed to resemble a cassette tape. The reels actually spin and you can create and share mixtapes with your friends via e-mail or Facebook, just as we used to do back in 1986. Finnish programming house Majasalmi, known for its Russian Roulette iPhone game, designed and built this decidedly more low-key app.

A little before 2 a.m. on Monday, Jon S. Corzine was in MF Global's offices in Midtown Manhattan, scrambling to cut a deal to save his firm. Haggard from too little sleep, at times pacing the hallways, he at least had a handshake agreement with one suitor for the firm. Then the chief executive was interrupted to handle a brief conversation that would stop the deal talks cold: hundreds of millions of dollars in customer funds, he was told, could not be located.

In a busy week on the music charts Coldplay's new album sailed to No. 1 around the world, Tom Waits reached the Top 10 for the first time, and Rihanna scored her 11th No. 1 single. As expected, Coldplay's ''Mylo Xyloto'' (Capitol) was the week's biggest album, with 447,000 sales in the United States, according to SoundScan. That is significantly less than the band had for its last two releases -- each posted more than 700,000 sales out of the gate -- but it was more than enough for Coldplay to reach No. 1 ahead of new albums by Kelly Clarkson, Michael Buble and Toby Keith.

A theater review on Saturday about ''Sistas: The Musical,'' at St. Luke's Theater on West 46th Street, misidentified the characters played by two actresses. April Nixon plays one of three sisters -- not their mother, who is not a character in the play. Lexi Rhoades plays a daughter of one of the sisters, not one of the sisters. The review also referred incorrectly to the character who was a valedictorian. She is one of the sisters, not their mother.

DUBAI - When Hanan Abdel Meguid started her first technology company in Cairo nearly 20 years ago, the Web was not publicly available in the Middle East and many big global players like Microsoft did not operate there. Now, Ms. Meguid, 42, oversees OTVentures, one of the region's largest technology companies, which operates in 17 countries and maintains exclusive partnerships with Facebook and Microsoft.

Last week I spent some time trying out a set of iLuv City Lights earphones, which list ''Explosive Bass,'' as a feature, as if that were a good thing. I pictured the sound I hear coming from SUVs with fancy rims and low-profile tires.

A new work about feminism from the downtown playwright Young Jean Lee and a show that incorporates music from the band Of Montreal are among the productions to be presented in January at Performance Space 122's Coil festival of contemporary performance. The seventh annual event will run from Jan. 5-29, 2012, at multiple locations across New York City. Vallejo Gantner, the artistic director of P.S. 122, said a common theme in many of the works is ''the real.''

WASHINGTON - A federal appeals court on Wednesday again threw out a $550,000 fine against CBS by the Federal Communications Commission forJanet Jackson's ''wardrobe malfunction'' during the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia had issued a similar ruling in July 2008. But that decision was sent back to the appeals court in May 2009 by the Supreme Court after it ruled in a separate case that the F.C.C. had the right to hold broadcasters accountable even for unscripted and isolated foul language.

A critic's notebook article on Monday about an academic conference at the University of Chicago on the television show ''Jersey Shore'' referred imprecisely to a comment made by Candace Moore, an assistant professor at the University of Michigan who spoke about the friendship between Vinny and Pauly D. She linked the quest for ''stranger sex'' by men on the show to ''some queer and kink cultures,'' not specifically to gay male sexual culture.

ROCHLIN--Renee. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Renee Rochlin of Franklin, Michigan. Together with her husband Morris, a Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents and past member of the Technion International Board of Governors, Mrs. Rochlin was a Technion Guardian, a distinction reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment to the university. Among the significant Technion projects the Rochlins funded are the Morris and Renee Rochlin Neuroprotective Drug Development Laboratory. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Morris, sons Richard Rochlin, Michael Egren, and Robert Egren; daughters Joan Rochlin, Barbara Rochlin, and Elyn Charlupski; and the entire Rochlin family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

An article on Oct. 25 about efforts to preserve beech trees in Newport, R.I., that have been damaged by beech canker misspelled the name of the pathogen that causes the canker. It is phytophthora, not phytopthora.

If you are tired of sending out the same e-mail response from your Gmail account -- say, for an item on eBay that has already sold or directions to your party -- the Canned Responses feature from Gmail Labs can save some time and typing. When you turn on setting, you can save short messages and send them repeatedly as replies with a quick mouse click. To set up Canned Responses, log into your Gmail account on the Web. Click on the gear icon in the upper right corner of the window and select Mail Settings from the menu. Click on the Labs tab, scroll down the list of available options to Canned Responses and click the Enable button. Click the Save Changes button.

BATON ROUGE, La.- A logo is often the visual embodiment of a team, and a point of pride for fans. The logo on L.S.U.'s helmets is simple: a round tiger head with purple stripes, in full growl. The logo seen on printed signs, shirts and other university memorabilia, however, has drawn the ire of fans in recent years. The university, in an effort to modernize the logo, made a change to the tiger head in 2002. The logo looked sharper from a graphic standpoint, but some fans found it cartoonish, and it was dubbed Toonces the Cat after a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch from the 1990s. The disdain has not eased in the ensuing years. There is a Facebook page called ''Toonces Must Die,'' which has been ''liked'' by 242 people.

James Whelan has a little piece of every New York tenant's dream: a rent stabilized apartment. It's a quiet one-bedroom on the Upper East Side where he has lived for 17 years, and it costs him less than $1,500 a month. But Mr. Whelan's landlord, a limited liability company, says that it needs the apartment for a relative of one of the principals, and it is trying to get him out. And if the landlord takes Mr. Whelan to court, Mr. Whelan may end up on a list of troublesome tenants who have been sued for eviction. Even if he wins the case.

FOLLOW THE MONEY With the Federal Bureau of Investigation looking into possible missing customer money at MF Global, executives of the now-bankrupt commodities and securities firm will be hiring lawyers and dealing with questions that go beyond how the firm will be liquidated. White Collar Watch looks at some avenues of investigation the F.B.I. is likely to pursue and the criminal statutes that could be invoked. PETER J. HENNING

All weekend, art lovers flocked to Sotheby's 10th-floor galleries to see the paintings, drawings and sculptures up for auction there this week. Among the stars was the first of a suite of four bronze sculptures of a woman's back that Matisse created over a 23-year period starting in 1908, the works becoming more radical as the years went on. And all weekend there were rumors that the sculpture had been withdrawn from the sale. On Wednesday morning Sotheby's finally confirmed that it had been, and that the auction house was concluding a private sale for all four pieces.

To balance a roomy top, wear textural leggings, or leather, and tough dark boots. Warren E. Buffett, take note. It is not just a few wealthy individuals paying unusually low taxes to the federal government. Corporate America is not far behind. A comprehensive study released on Thursday found that 280 of the biggest publicly traded American companies faced federal income tax bills equal to 18.5 percent of their profits during the last three years -- little more than half the official corporate rate of 35 percent and lower than their competitors in many industrialized countries.

On Nov. 7, 1861, Brig. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant withdrew his federal forces after a creditable but inconclusive battle against Confederates encamped at Belmont, Mo. But as the men withdrew to transports waiting for them along the Mississippi River, four soldiers from the Seventh Iowa Infantry hurried back to the battlefield to rescue their popular lieutenant colonel, Augustus Wentz, who had been struck in the side by a bullet and left behind.

A year from now, Americans will choose whether to reelect President Obama or to replace him; they will pick 33 senators and every member of the House; and they will argue about it with each other all along the way. Campaign Stops will join this ongoing conversation by presenting the sharpest opinion pieces on the 2012 election, just as it did in 2008. We'll hear from Times columnists and contributing writers and many other people who have something to say. Campaign Stops will examine the battle for public opinion state by state, focusing particularly on the ten or twelve states that emerge as key to the election. It will also be a laboratory of sorts for proposals to improve how we make our political choices.

I don't post photos of my daughter online. My feeling is that she's exposed enough in my books, articles and blogs. Maybe that's a rationalization, an arbitrary line, but it's mine and I stand by it. Only once did I override that instinct: I let the "Today" show film her as part of a lead-in piece when my most recent book was released. I have regretted that decision ever since, not so much because they did anything unseemly with the footage - the clip was actually adorable - but because I relinquished control over how she'd be presented. It was a misstep that still stings: I put my professional opportunity ahead of my parenting. But maybe I had to cross that line to know where it was.

If there is an advantage to staging "Gatsby" as a ballet, an art form whose language is largely metaphorical, it might be that the storytelling does not compete with Fitzgerald's lyricism in one's ear. The conductor James Levine is withdrawing from Wagner's "Götterdämmerung," the final installment of the Metropolitan Opera's new "Ring" cycle, as he continues to recover from back surgery prompted by a fall, the Met said on Friday. Fabio Luisi, the Met's principal conductor, will take over the production for performances on Jan. 27 and 31 and Feb. 3, 7 and 11. Mr. Luisi will also conduct the Met Orchestra at its Carnegie Hall concert on Jan. 15. Mr. Levine, the Met's music director, has canceled all his performances so far this season because of the back ailment. The Met said he is still scheduled to lead three full "Ring" cycles in April and May.

The Design and Living issue starts with the house of the artist and alchemist Christian Astuguevieille, a true cabinet of curiosities. Mats Gustafson's Stockholm apartment, on the other hand, is a serene and surprisingly warm example of Scandinavian cool. And the artist Laurie Simmons's classic brick Georgian in northwestern Connecticut is really a dollhouse of magnificent proportions. Elsewhere, we encounter the artist Mika Rottenberg, whose videos transform mundane tasks into exercises in the strange and the sublime; the graphic designer Frith Kerr, whose Calvinist exterior belies a Rococo imagination; and the designer Tino Seubert, whose benches and chairs offer a front-row seat to great moments in history. Before she died in 1996 at age 61, the designer Isabelle Hebey said she would leave nothing undone, no aspirations unfulfilled. (Well, almost none: she always joked about redoing the Vatican.) Hebey even drew up new plans for her Paris apartment, tailored to the son who would inherit it, right down to rearranging the furniture. In planning her funeral, however, she did not go as far as another autocratic designer of her generation, David Hicks, who sketched his own coffin. But she did get to choose hers. "It was very surreal," recalls Emmanuel Hebey, the noted mathematician and Isabelle's son. "The man who sold it to us was rather surprised."
