When you walk into the artist and illustrator Mats Gustafson's apartment in Stockholm, you're not quite sure what era you're in. In the foyer, a turn-of-the-century painting of a bourgeois Swedish interior hangs beneath one of Isamu Noguchi's oversize paper lanterns, and underfoot is a colorful mid-20th-century rug by Barbro Nilsson for the renowned Swedish workshop MMF. Under a midcentury nude painted by Birger Ljungquist, Gustafson's great-uncle, sits a simple 1950s stool by the Swedish designer Carl Malmsten. Walk through an angled doorway into the living room, a high-ceilinged space with the graceful proportions and architectural ornament typical of late-19th-century buildings, and the mix gets even richer. An upholstered 19th-century Swedish bench along the window and a group of slipper chairs, all from Gustafson's family, blend easily with sheepskin-covered wood chairs designed in the 1930s by Bruno Mathsson and tables by Josef Frank. Vases by Scandinavian Modern ceramics masters like Axel Salto and Berndt Friberg are clustered atop a traditional tiled fireplace, and the immaculate plaster walls (which are painted, aptly enough, Stockholm White) are hung with Gustafson's spare, elegant watercolors. Venture into the apartment's long corridor, however, and you'll find up-to-the-minute bathrooms and a sunny, south-facing kitchen in which crisp, utilitarian cabinets provide a clean backdrop for an antique wooden table and chairs. This is an interior that's modern and old-fashioned at the same time, and in all the right ways.

Excess stock market volatility ­ — price moves that get reversed in a few days or weeks — has risen to levels seen only three times before in the past 60 years: after the 1987 stock market crash, near the bottom of the market decline in 2002 and during the financial crisis and recession of 2008 and 2009. The charts show the difference between the amount the Standard & Poor’s 500 moved over each 13-week period and the total of the daily changes, without regard to whether the daily move was up or down, and expresses the amount as a percentage of the index value at the beginning of each 13-week period. In a market that went up every day, or down every day, over a 13-week period, the figure would be zero. Highlighted areas show recessions.

With the opening of the Saguaro hotel in Scottsdale, Ariz., a collaboration between Joie de Vivre Hotels and the Sydell Group, a vibrant design has just blown into "the West's most western town." Standing out from Scottsdale's archetypal gamut of beiges and whites, the Saguaro is a brightly hued haven, with nods to the native flora. The hotel was intended to be about Scottsdale, and, flanked by Old Town and the Civic Center Mall, it very much is, while still managing to look and feel like an oasis. The Moment sat down with the architects, Peter Stamberg and Paul Aferiat of Stamberg Aferiat Architecture, to talk about transforming the Old West into something more luminous and inviting.

The New York City Marathon takes place on Sunday, and throughout the weekend restaurants will reach out to runners looking to load up on carbs, and more sedentary types simply celebrating the race. The Z NYC Hotel, 11-01 43rd Avenue (Vernon Boulevard) in Long Island City, is offering a $16 four-course race-themed menu all day Saturday that includes three pasta dishes and a dessert. Danny Meyer's Union Square Hospitality Group, the official food and beverage partner for the marathon, will hold various events throughout the weekend, including opening the Blue Line Lounge in the marathon pavilion at Central Park West and West 67th Street, where spectators can order food and drinks at the end of the race. Ca Va Restaurant, at the InterContinental New York Times Square Hotel, 300 West 44th Street (Eighth Avenue), will offer a $30 carb menu for dinner on Saturday. On Sunday from 4:30 a.m. to 8 a.m., the restaurant will stock a special buffet for runners and their families, with brown rice, oatmeal, pasta, cereal and other hearty choices. Asellina, at the Gansevoort Park Avenue, 420 Park Avenue South (East 29th Street), will feature extra-large pasta portions for $20 a plate. At Spina, 175 Avenue B (East 11th Street), freshly made pastas will be sold for half-price all day Sunday to runners and their guests who bring a marathon bib.

Perpetually swarmed with tourists, Florence, Italy, is at last trying to make things a little easier for visitors with across-the-board improvements to its tired infrastructure and dated hotel scene. The St. Regis made the biggest splash last month with a $25 million renovation of a 1492 Brunelleschi pile that was once the Grand Hotel Florence.

"A brick Georgian was never my dream house," insists the artist Laurie Simmons. In the fall of 2000, when Simmons was given the opportunity to design a house - O.K., a dollhouse - from the ground up, she collaborated with the architect Peter Wheelwright to create a very colorful, almost Modernist abode filled with works of pint-size contemporary art and design. And yet, the first time she walked through the front door of the near-textbook brick Georgian in northwestern Connecticut that she and her husband, the artist Carroll Dunham, eventually came to own, "something came over me," she recalls. She said to Dunham, "If this house were a man, you'd be toast."

CHICAGO - I came down with my first African disease in America. It happened after I traveled to Nigeria last April to witness my country elect a new government. I landed with notebooks and questions, but not antimalarial medication. I had been more prudent on dozens of prior stays, but, I thought, no matter: I had already been running around the continent for months with no mishaps. After three rounds of free and fair voting, I returned to my apartment in Nairobi, buoyant about democracy in Africa.

The Joyce Theater's programming is always eclectic and the 2012 spring and summer lineups are no different. Choreographers and companies from around the world representing a variety of styles will perform from Feb. 7 to Aug. 18. Highlights include the June appearance of Shantala Shivalingappa, a specialist in the South Indian Kuchipudi classical dance form, whom Claudia La Rocco recently described in The New York Times as ''divine.'' Also in the lineup: the Joyce debut of Les Ballets de Monte Carlo; the Swiss Ballet du Grand Theatre de Geneve, offering an evening-length work choreographed by Emanuel Gat; and ''Last Touch First,'' by Jiri Kylian and the dancer Michael Schumacher. That work is a slow-motion version of Mr. Kylian's ''Last Touch,'' first performed in the Netherlands in 2008.

(13) PBS ARTS FROM THE BLUE RIDGE MOUNTAINS: GIVE ME THE BANJO Steve Martin, above, who has been known to pluck a few strings now and again, narrates this exploration of the roots of American music and the place of the banjo, with its origin in African slavery, within it -- from the minstrel show, ragtime and early jazz, to blues, folk, bluegrass and country. The musicians Pete Seeger, Earl Scruggs, Taj Mahal, Béla Fleck and the Carolina Chocolate Drops weigh in, along with historians, instruments builders and collectors; Rosanne Cash hosts. This is part of the PBS Arts Fall Festival. 4:30 P.M. (HBO) INCEPTION (2010) Leonardo DiCaprio, below, stars as Cobb, a specialist in corporate mental espionage who, using a combination of drugs, wires and other Matrix-y methods penetrates the minds of his sleeping targets to extract information. Ken Watanabe is Saito, the wealthy client who has hired Cobb and his associates (Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Ellen Page, among others) to undertake the trick known as inception, which involves planting an idea in someone's mind that will come to fruition in the real world. Their mission: to induce a young man (Cillian Murphy), whose father (Pete Postlethwaite) is a business rival of Saito's, to break up the company he is about to inherit. Cobb, meanwhile, can't stop thinking about his wife (Marion Cotillard). The movie, directed by Christopher Nolan, ''trades in crafty puzzles rather than profound mysteries, and gestures in the direction of mighty philosophical questions that Mr. Nolan is finally too tactful, too timid or perhaps just too busy to engage,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Still, Mr. Scott said of the film, which won Oscars for cinematography, sound mixing, sound editing and visual effects, ''A lot of this is -- what is the critical term of art I'm looking for? -- pretty cool.''

An article on Wednesday about delays in a program to disband private security companies in Afghanistan and replace them with government forces paraphrased incorrectly from a statement about the plan by the Afghan Interior Ministry. The ministry said it was focused on disbanding a wide range of private security companies, not just those with ties to government officials. The article also misstated the source of $35 million to $40 million that a NATO official said would finance a task force to aid the effort. The Pentagon will ask Congress to reallocate all of it from funds already designated for security in Afghanistan; the program will not use a mix of new and reallocated money.

An article last Friday about Hugh Freeze, the football coach at Arkansas State who was the high school coach of Michael Oher, the subject of the book ''The Blind Side,'' misidentified the position that Oher plays for the Baltimore Ravens. While he played left offensivetackle for the Ravens at one point, he is now a right tackle.

He is the closest surviving relative of the young woman who more than any other has personified the Holocaust. At 86, Buddy Elias, her first cousin, still has the actor's playfulness and flair that so charmed Anne Frank as a young girl, as she recalled at several points in her diary. And Wednesday night Mr. Elias charmed - and sometimes chilled and haunted - an audience in New York as he reminisced about Anne, his childhood hide-and-seek playmate, the girl who was taking ice-skating lessons because she longed to frolic alongside him on her next trip to the Swiss Alps. She had even designed a skating dress.

Months before MF Global teetered on the brink, federal regulators were seeking to rein in the types of risky trades that contributed to the firm's collapse. But they faced opposition from an influential opponent: Jon S. Corzine, the head of the then little-known brokerage firm. As a former United States senator and a former governor of New Jersey, as well as the leader of Goldman Sachs in the 1990s, Mr. Corzine carried significant weight in the worlds of Washington and Wall Street. While other financial firms employed teams of lobbyists to fight the new regulation, MF Global's chief executive in meetings over the last year personally pressed regulators to halt their plans.

van HOOGSTRATEN--Jan Samuel Francois, whose career was spent aiding refugees and displaced persons, died on October 25 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, NY following a heart attack. He was 89. He held senior positions at Church World Service, the overseas relief and reconstruction arm of the National Council of Churches and the Tolstoy Foundation. He later held Chief-of-Mission positions at the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the principal intergovernmental organization promoting assistance of migrants and refugees and based in Geneva. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, the former Eleanor Colson Curtis of Mount Vernon, NY; two sons, David J. van Hoogstraten of Washington, DC and Nicholas van Hoogstraten of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; and four grandchildren. A grave-side funeral service will be held for family members and friends at Kensico Cemetery, Westchester County, on November 5 at 2:00pm.

SAN FRANCISCO - Acknowledging that some searches were giving people stale results, Google revised its methods on Thursday to make the answers timelier. It is one of the biggest tweaks to Google's search algorithm, affecting about 35 percent of all searches. The new algorithm is a recognition that Google, whose dominance depends on providing the most useful results, is being increasingly challenged by services like Twitter and Facebook, which have trained people to expect constant updates with seconds-old news.

The private equity firm TPG Capital has signed a nondisclosure agreement with Yahoo, making it one of the first potential suitors to begin formal due diligence work on the company, which is weighing a sale, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday. TPG's decision comes even as many other private equity shops are balking at signing such an agreement, since its terms include a prohibition on talking with other potential suitors. Many of these possible bidders have argued that such a ''no cross-talk'' provision would limit their ability to cobble together a full takeover offer for Yahoo, given the company's nearly $20 billion market value.

The James Bond franchise has yielded some of cinema's most memorable titles, some taken directly from Ian Fleming's novels - ''From Russia With Love,'' ''The Spy Who Loved Me''; ''Live and Let Die'' - and others spawned from the fertile minds of creative screenwriters and producers - ''The World Is Not Enough.'' (Also, there was one, from a Fleming short story, called ''Octopussy.'' We can't change that.) So it was with some anticipation and some ceremony that the filmmakers behind the 23rd installment in the long-running series revealed the title of their movie on Thursday.

The British drug company GlaxoSmithKline said Thursday that it had agreed to pay $3 billion to settle United States government civil and criminal investigations into its sales practices for numerous drugs. The settlement would be the largest yet in a wave of federal cases against pharmaceutical companies accused of illegal marketing, surpassing the previous record of $2.3 billion paid by Pfizer in 2009. In recent years, drug companies have been prime targets of federal fraud investigations, which have recovered tens of billions of dollars for Medicaid and Medicare.

CORSON--Cornelia Metz, 72, peacefully at home October 9. Wife of 49 years to Richard, loving mother of Peter and Julia. Sister of Thomas, Monica, Claudia, Stephen and Regina. Doting aunt, caring cousin. Dynamic, generous, welcoming, witty, loyal, spiritual, positive, nurturing and articulate. Graduate of Richmond Hill High School, Queens College, Columbia University School of Library Service. Book lover and library advocate, Connie worked at MOMA, FIT, CUNY York, SUNY Purchase. Director of Libraries at Spence School 1981-2001. Active member of The Church-in-the-Gardens, Forest Hills, NY where a memorial service will be held at noon, November 19.

New York City Ballet has joined the corps of cultural institutions presenting performances on the big screen. The company said on Thursday that its Dec. 13 performance of ''George Balanchine's The Nutcracker'' will be transmitted live in high definition to more than 500 movie theaters around the country. In a statement, the company's executive director, Katherine E. Brown, said City Ballet hoped it would be the ''first of many'' such transmissions. A City Ballet neighbor at Lincoln Center, the Metropolitan Opera, pioneered cinema broadcasts of cultural events five years ago and has built an audience of several hundred thousand around the world for each transmission. Other opera, ballet and theater companies and orchestras have started the practice. They include the Royal Opera and National Theater in London; the Paris Opera and Bolshoi ballets; the Los Angeles Philharmonic; the La Scala opera house in Milan; and the Gran Teatre del Liceu opera in Barcelona. Cultural institutions see HD transmissions as a way to vastly enlarge audiences, build revenues and help grow their art forms' popularity. Skeptics wonder whether the experience dilutes the art form, audiences will be siphoned off from live performances and artistic standards will change.

President Obama's re-election campaign has been hammering Mitt Romney from many angles in recent weeks. And now Democrats are beginning a new push against him, this time using the issue of reproductive rights in a bid to raise doubts about Mr. Romney among women. The Democratic National Committee has scheduled a conference call for Thursday with Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida, the party chairwoman, who, according to the committee's press release, will ''slam G.O.P. presidential candidate Mitt Romney for voicing support for such efforts which could endanger women's lives.''

BARTH--Doris Williams, beloved wife of the late Wilbur C. Barth, died at Weill Cornell Medical College in Manhattan on October 25, 2011, at the age of 86. She has no known survivors. A native of San Antonio, Texas, Mrs. Barth was the only child of the late Mary Ficklin Summers and J. Harold Williams. In 1952, she graduated from Trinity University in San Antonio, with a double major in English and Humanities. In the Class of 1952's Last Will and Testament to Trinity University, Doris left "her appreciation of literature to the Humanities Department, because no one else seemed interested." She also earned a Master's in English from Trinity in 1954 and taught in the English Department from 1956-1963. A favorite with both students and colleagues, she was regularly voted Faculty Princess or Duchess during her tenure at Trinity. At Trinity University, she also met and married Wilbur Barth, who was a Trinity Alumnus, holding an undergraduate and Master's degree in mathematics. He died in 1981. Upon their move to Manhattan, Mrs. Barth worked as a commercial writer. She was also a congregant at Saint Bartholomew's Church (NYC) and eventually at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue. At Saint Thomas Church, she volunteered in the soup kitchen for years and made many friends and acquaintances there. She also did volunteer work at The Hospital of Special Surgery, often talking to prospective patients about their upcoming surgeries based on her own knowledge and experiences. The staff at HSS remembers her with great fondness. Mrs. Barth will be interred in the Saint Thomas Church Columbarium, next to her "beloved Wilbur." A Memorial Service for Mrs. Barth will take place on November 8th at 2pm in the Chantry Chapel of Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, 1 West 53rd Street, Manhattan. Instead of flowers, donations should be made to either Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue or The Hospital of Special Surgery.

David Mamet's new play, ''The Anarchist,'' is built for two actresses who are expert at spitting nails. The drama centers on a female inmate with a radical past, pleading for parole with the prison's female warden; a battle of words and wits ensues over politics, money and religion. On Thursday the Broadway producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel said they had found a duo who, no question, know something about stage combat: The Tony Award winner Patti LuPone (''Gypsy,'' ''Evita'') will play the inmate and the Emmy winner Laurie Metcalf (''Roseanne'') will play the warden in a Broadway production scheduled to open in fall 2012. Mr. Mamet, a Pulitzer Prize winner for ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' will direct the play, as he did with his last verbal slugfest on Broadway, ''Race,'' which ran for nine months in a commercial run mounted by Mr. Richards and Mr. Frankel, among others. ''The Anarchist'' will be the sixth time the three men have collaborated. Performance dates and a theater will be announced later.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - People often ask me what the process is for receiving, solving and blogging the New York Times crossword and variety puzzles. The answer is that I get a stack of puzzles about a week ahead of time, then solve them and blog them according to deadline. I often feel like I'm time-traveling into the future, because that's where my head is when I'm working, and the feeling is particularly present when solvers ask me a question about the current day's puzzle, because I have to "travel back" to remember the puzzle in question.

8:15 P.M. (Sundance) MAD BASTARDS (2011) In this debut feature shown at the Sundance Film Festival, where it was a nominee for the grand jury prize, T J (Dean Daley-Jones, above), a hotheaded former prisoner, hitchhikes to a town in northwestern Australia in search of his estranged 13-year-old son, Bullet (Lucas Yeeda). There he meets a policeman, Texas (Greg Tait), who has started a group in which Aboriginal men can discuss their problems. The movie, written and directed by Brendan Fletcher, was filmed with mostly Aboriginal nonactors. The soundtrack features the Pigram Brothers, an indigenous folk-blues band from Broome, also in the northwest. ''It feels authentic,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. 10 A.M. Keith Urban, the country music star, will undergo surgery this month to remove a polyp from his vocal cords and then must rest his voice for an indefinite period, his publicist, Paul Freundlich, said in a statement. Because of the surgery Mr. Urban has postponed a benefit concert for the Country Music Hall of Fame scheduled for Jan. 17. He has also canceled most of his other appearances, among them two concerts at the Grand Ole Opry this month. Still, Mr. Urban, 44, will perform a song next week at the televised awards ceremony for the Country Music Association. He is in the running for best male vocalist and best entertainer of the year.

An art entry in the Listings pages on Friday about ''Field Notation,'' an exhibition of work by Helen Mirra at Peter Freeman, Inc., in SoHo, misidentified her nationality. She is American, not British.

In the last 40 years, the Nos. 1 and 2 teams have met only 12 times in the regular season (not counting conference championship games). The No. 1 team has won seven times; only four times did the winner go on to win a national title. Here are six of the best No. 1 vs. No. 2 matchups. NOV. 18, 2006: NO. 1 OHIO STATE 42, NO. 2 MICHIGAN 39 A shootout that sealed the Heisman Trophy for Troy Smith and a spot in the B.C.S. title game for Ohio State. The Buckeyes lost to Florida in the championship game.

The lead guitarist for the satirical heavy metal band GWAR was found dead on the band's tour bus Thursday after a concert in Minneapolis, the band announced through a statement posted on a metal Web site. Other members of the band discovered that the guitarist, Cory Smoot, was not breathing just before the bus crossed into Canada, where GWAR was scheduled to appear in Edmonton. ''There is no word as to the cause of death and the members of GWAR are completely shocked and devastated that this has occurred,'' the band's lead singer, David Brockie, whose stage name is Oderus Urungus, said in the statement.

CORSON--Cornelia Metz, 72, peacefully at home October 9. Wife of 49 years to Richard, loving mother of Peter and Julia. Sister of Thomas, Monica, Claudia, Stephen and Regina. Doting aunt, caring cousin. Dynamic, generous, welcoming, witty, loyal, spiritual, positive, nurturing and articulate. Graduate of Richmond Hill High School, Queens College, Columbia University School of Library Service. Book lover and library advocate, Connie worked at MOMA, FIT, CUNY York, SUNY Purchase. Director of Libraries at Spence School 1981-2001. Active member of The Church-in-the-Gardens, Forest Hills, NY where a memorial service will be held at noon, November 19.

11/4/11 | Updated with fuller results. Just 17 percent of Americans say they are better off financially than they were last year at this time, according to a new Bankrate.com survey. Thirty-one percent consider themselves worse off and 49 percent say they are financially about the same as a year ago.

After a months-long journey filled with blunders, Groupon punched its ticket to the public markets on Friday. And the daily deals site got a warm reception, a welcome sign for Internet start-ups still waiting to go public. The initial public offering, which was priced at $20 the night before, soared 40 percent at the opening bell to hit $28. Shares breached $31, before settling at $26.11 at the close, valuing the three-year old company at $16.5 billion.

MASTROROCCO--V. Peter, OD, on November 3, 2011. Member, Board of Trustees, New York Methodist Hospital. Practiced in Park Slope for over 50 years. Charter member, South Brooklyn Lions Club. Beloved husband of the late Ruth (nee Flynn). Devoted father of Susan and Diane. Cherished brother of A. Ralph. Also survived by many nephews. Family will receive friends, Saturday and Sunday from 2-4:30pm and 7-9pm at the Ralph Aievoli and Sons Funeral Home, 1275 65th St., (corner 13th Ave.) Brooklyn, 11219. Funeral Mass: Monday, 11am, St. Saviour Church. Interment: St. Thomas Cemetery, Underhill, VT. In lieu of flowers, donations to NY Methodist Hospital, 506 Sixth St., Brooklyn, NY, 11215, Attn: Development Office, would be greatly appreciated.

David Hallberg, 29, a native of Rapid City, S.D., is the first American ever to be named a principal dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet. He arrived in Moscow two weeks ago and was given an apartment a few steps from the theater. He has, he says, ''no social life to speak of'' - just his work and a book he is reading - and is still struggling with jet lag. On Friday, he will make his debut at the Bolshoi Theater as Albrecht in''Giselle.''

TUSCALOOSA, Ala. - Chuck Leavell has traveled the world with the Rolling Stones, but he still calls Tuscaloosa home. And he still counts himself as a die-hard fan of Alabama football. ''You can't be from Tuscaloosa and not be a Crimson Tide fan,'' Leavell said in a telephone interview Friday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. - Bill Mott likes Churchill Downs. He should, as he is this storied racetrack's leading trainer with more than 650 career victories. He likes the Breeders' Cup Ladies' Classic even better. No wonder: when Royal Delta rolled past the finish line Friday it was Mott's fourth victory in the $2 million race and his second in a row. Mott, a 58-year-old native of Mobridge, S.D., saddled his first winner at Churchill Downs in 1978. Under the lights Friday, Royal Delta not only wrapped up the 3-year-old filly championship, she delivered one more record for Mott - his 81st stakes victory under the twin spires, the most for any trainer.

STEIN--Sylvia K. She died on November 2nd. Wife of Hyman Stein, loving mother of Diana and Andrew and his wife Diane. Grandmother of Isaac and Benjamin. Services held at Riverside North Shore Chapel, Great Neck, Sunday, November 6 at 10am. Her exuberance and love for life will always be remembered.

BATON ROUGE, La. - While success on the field usually materializes because of work ethic and talent, a little boost from the gene pool never hurts. For top-ranked Louisiana State, family connections to the N.F.L. are plentiful.

6:20 p.m. | Updated LONDON - Royal Bank of Scotland on Friday reported a 63 percent drop in operating profit, to 267 million, or $428 million, in the three months through September as volatility in European financial markets continued to hit its investment banking operations.

SPINELLI--Lillian Pinero, on November 5, 1968. Lilly left those who loved her. Michael, her husband; daughters Lucille O'Dwyer and Gloria Bohan; Jack O'Dwyer, her son-law, and grandchildren, Christine and John O'Dwyer. Lillian was a spirited pianist and harpist who came from a family of violinists. She loved to laugh and enjoyed reminiscing about fun in the Poconos in the 1920's. She lived for her husband and children and we remember her dedication to us each day for the strength it has given us. She loved New York and the Yankees. She will remain in our hearts.

Even though the country's largest banks have dropped plans to charge fees for debit card use, a movement encouraging customers to consider switching to community banks or credit unions remains energized. Promoters of Bank Transfer Day are urging dissatisfied big bank customers to open accounts at smaller institutions on Saturday. So if you want to consider alternatives to a big national bank, where should you look? Here are some Web-based tools aimed at helping you narrow your search.

NO. 1 LOUISIANA STATE AT NO. 2 ALABAMA 8 p.m. Eastern, CBS With both teams coming off byes, the hype leading up to this game feels more like Super Bowl Sunday than a Saturday in November. It is No. 1 vs. No. 2 in the regular season for the first time since Michigan and Ohio State played a classic in 2006. It matches division rivals, with the winner becoming the heavy favorite for the Southeastern Conference title and a berth in the national title game. It also matches two of the best defenses in the nation, squaring off in prime time in front of a packed house in Tuscaloosa, Ala., and two of the most successful coaches in college football in Nick Saban and Les Miles, vying for any advantage they can muster. There is a lot to look forward to.

Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Friday disclosed new travel-related campaign debts of almost $230,000 that appear to largely stem from improper underpayments to owners of private jets used by his presidential campaign. According to a filing with the Federal Election Commission, the new travel debts include $66,362.50 owed to Javaid Anwar, the head of a West Texas energy company; $45,435.16 that appears to be owed to a company owned by Dan Friedkin, a major supporter whom Mr. Perry appointed chairman of the Texas Parks & Wildlife Commission; and $22,931.15 owed to Brian Pardo, a Waco businessman and Perry donor who is under investigation by federal and state securities regulators.
GOLBERT--Raymond. November 5, 2005. Dearest Ray, Love, missed, cherished, always. Alice, Maury and Joshua

EVANS--Martin. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Hon. Martin Evans and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City
ROTHSTEIN--Blanche W.,honored actress and director, beloved great-grandmother, grandmother, mother and wife, on November 3.

The conductor James Levine is withdrawing from Wagner's ''Gotterdammerung,'' the final installment of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Ring'' cycle, as he continues to recover from back surgery prompted by a fall, the Met said on Friday. Fabio Luisi, the Met's principal conductor, will take over the production for performances on Jan. 27 and 31 and Feb. 3, 7 and 11. Mr. Luisi will also conduct the Met Orchestra at its Carnegie Hall concert on Jan. 15. Mr. Levine, the Met's music director, has canceled all his performances so far this season because of the back ailment. The Met said he is still scheduled to lead three full ''Ring'' cycles in April and May. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A year out from Election Day: an eon in political time, sufficient to alter circumstances substantially for or against either party. But Friday's tepid jobs report brings a fresh reminder of the stubborn difficulty President Obama and his team face in overcoming one of their most enduring mistakes, one made before he even took office. Ten days prior to Mr. Obama's taking the oath of office in January 2009, his economic team released a report outlining the estimated benefits of the $775 billion stimulus plan he was seeking. The projections were quite specific. The stimulus legislation passed just a few weeks later at about the size the White House had sought. Had all gone as promised by the report, the unemployment rate right now would have been around 6.5 percent, heading down to around 6 percent by the end of this year and a little over 5 percent at the end of next year.
MOSCOT--Kenneth Charles, January 9,1970-November 5, 2010. Your absence is profound. All of us who love you

SMOLUCHOWSKI--Louise R.,daughter of the late Rear Admiral Charles E. Riggs, USN, Ret. and Louise C. Riggs, died October 20th. Born in Washington, DC, she graduated from NCS. During the war she worked for the British monitoring cables and then joined the Red Cross, serving in Italy. Louise worked at MOMA and later at Physics Today, where she met her husband Roman. She served on the Princeton Civil Rights Commission. In 1987 G.P. Putnam's Sons published her book, "Lev and Sonya: the Story of the Tolstoy Marriage." She leaves children, Peter Smoluchowski and wife Alexis Quinlan and Irena Smoluchowski; a brother, Edward B. Riggs; and three grandchildren.

A cover profile this weekend about the actor Leonardo DiCaprio, who stars in the coming film ''J. Edgar,'' misidentifies the film for which he received his third Oscar nomination. It is ''Blood Diamond,'' not ''The Departed.'' (His other two were for ''What's Eating Gilbert Grape'' and ''The Aviator.'')

SHUTTLEWORTH--Patricia Driver, formerly of Quogue, died November 1 in Greenport, NY, at age 83. Wife of the late Ted, mother of Daphne, Teddy and Wes, and sister of Daphne McGill, David, Bruce and the late Frank Driver. Service to be held on December 10, 1pm, at Westhampton Presbyterian Church, NY. Donations in her honor may be made to Quogue Historical Society or Westhampton Presbyterian Church.

The hits keep coming for private equity firms, as Kohlberg Kravis Roberts can attest. The private equity giant said on Friday that it lost $621.7 million for its third quarter, as it marked down the value of its portfolio companies low enough to reverse some of performance fees. Rose Kerr is the principal of the Staten Island School of Civic Leadership, Staten Island's first K-8 school, which opened its doors in 2009. Its curriculum is based on the philosophy of Stephen Covey, the author of ''The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People.'' In a recent interview, Ms. Kerr, 57, who grew up in East New York, Brooklyn, and earned a salary of $140,000 in 2010, talked about the challenge of creating a rich curriculum for students while they face pressure to do well on standardized tests. This interview was edited and condensed.

Horton, Shelley Brown, Cathryn Keller Glass, Diane Glass Neumann, Bobbie Glass, Blair Weiss, Marybeth Shultz and Aylin Guney Glass. Godmother to Kristy Thompson and Alli Murr. On the clear, crisp morning of Nov. 7, 1861, Sam Mitchell, a young slave living on the island of Port Royal off the coast of South Carolina, thought he heard thunder - which seemed odd, since there was not a cloud in the sky. He asked his mother, Tyra, what he'd heard. It wasn't thunder, she said. The Yankees had come to give them freedom. A few miles away the largest fleet ever assembled by the United States was bombarding Fort Walker and Fort Beauregard, the two forts on either side of the entrance to Port Royal Sound.

Has India's growth and development been an "unprecedented success or extraordinary failure," ask Jean Dreze and Amartya Sen in Outlook Magazine this week. Both are true, they conclude. India has fallen behind Bangladesh on a number of important social indicators, and is "quite far behind China in terms of the use of public resources for social support."

The economic collapse of 2008 transformed American politics. In place of shared abundance, battles at every level of government now focus on picking the losers who will bear the costs of deficit reduction and austerity. Fights in Washington are over inflicting pain on antagonists either through spending cuts or tax increases, a struggle over who will get a smaller piece of a shrinking pie. This hostile climate stands in sharp contrast to the post-World-War II history of economic growth. Worse, current income and employment trends suggest that this is not a temporary shift.

Ford began taking orders for its Focus Electric on Tuesday, pricing the purely electric hatchback at $39,995, inclusive of a $795 destination charge. While not as closely watched by the industry as the pricing announcements of the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf, two plug-in vehicles that went on sale in a staggered rollout last year, Tuesday's announcement indicated where Ford imagined its first mass-produced E.V. should sit in the marketplace.

A picture caption on Oct. 23 with the cover article about a cross-country bike trip misidentified the state in which Glacier National Park is located. The park, shown in the picture of the writer taking a break from a climb over the Continental Divide, is in Montana -- not in Wyoming. And a picture showing the writer crossing a bridge on the Great Allegheny Passage in Pennsylvania carried an erroneous credit. It was taken by Jeff Swensen, not by Marcus Yam (A picture by Mr. Yam was one of several featured with the continuation of the article.)

CARHARTT WORK IN PROGRESS, which recently opened its first United States store on Crosby Street in SoHo, is a division of the classic company most often associated with construction workers and 1990s skaters. Based in Basel, Switzerland, the label shares the same sturdy spirit as its brother brand, but the fabrics are more refined, the collaborations more high end, and the silhouettes much slimmer. For example, the company's famed canvas work pants are in the line, but they come in an Italian duck canvas milled for Work in Progress. At the SoHo store, a wall is dedicated to slim, tapered trousers, and the sweaters, once built tooth-and-nail tough, come in a soft, brushed cotton. The best thing about the shop (besides the roughly hewn wood floor boards and the meticulous merchandising) is the staff. Each member is tremendously helpful, and the adopted uniform of canvas pants, pocket tees and woolen beanies worn high suggests that the '90s spirit of Carhartt is still very much alive. Shown: coat, $268; shirt, $168; and pants, $125. Carhartt Work in Progress, 119 Crosby Street; (212) 219-2934; carhartt-wip.com. ISAAC HINDIN MILLER

THERE isn't a sign, let alone a window, in the storefront of 64 Kenmare Street. But the curious knitted facade and a Day-Glo orange door turn out to be as good a sign as any as to what you can expect inside. Ramdane is a new line of clothing and accessories for men and women, a concept store with locations planned for Paris, Rome, London and Tokyo, and the brainchild of Ramdane Touhami, who conceived the space, designs the merchandise and, as its recent week's soft opening, could be found working the sales floor of this genuinely lo-fi and coyly highbrow operation. A profile of the actor Woody Harrelson in the special Holiday Movies section last Sunday misstated Mr. Harrelson's Oscar honors. He was nominated for best actor for ''The People vs. Larry Flynt'' (1996), not for best supporting actor, and he did not win the Oscar. And he was nominated for best supporting actor for ''The Messenger'' (2009), not for best actor.

NORA KOGAN, the Brooklyn jewelry designer behind St. Kilda, is best known for costume pieces like the Surrealist-inspired Man Ray lip cuffs that are favored by fashion insiders like the blogger Garance Doré. Now she's designing higher-end baubles under her own name. The first Nora Kogan collection, called Anastasia, is inspired by a Fabergé egg that, according to family lore, her Russian grandfather acquired during World War II in exchange for a box of chocolates. The egg disappeared, presumably into the pockets of a Soviet customs official, when the family immigrated to Australia in the '70s, but Ms. Kogan retains clear memories of it. ''It opened up into three sections, and in the center was a hand-painted icon,'' said Ms. Kogan, who riffs on Fabergé's legendary craftsmanship and stylized nature motifs in pieces like these diamond drop earrings and ring. ''Designing this collection has been therapeutic for me, as I'm still often haunted by this loss.'' NANCY MacDONELL

EVANS--Martin, Retired NYS Supreme Court Justice. Distinguished jurist, scholar, leader, colleague, decorated WWII veteran, cherished friend to all. We will deeply miss a very special person we were privileged to know. Board of Justices, NY County

In 1948, the architect and inventor Buckminster Fuller gathered a group of his students at Black Mountain College to build a life-size geodesic dome. The dome was a flop. It succeeded, however, in planting the seed for the sculptor Kenneth Snelson, a student of Fuller's, to develop the principle of tensegrity that would allow Fuller to build a dome for the United States Pavilion at Expo 67 in Montreal. For the Performa 11 biennial (11.performa-arts.org), the Los Angeles artist Liz Glynn will retrace Fuller's steps, pratfalls and all. Part 1 of her performance - a loosely choreographed re-enactment of Fuller's failed attempt - takes place on the first Sunday of the biennial in locations throughout New York City, including Times Square; for Part 2, 25 volunteers will assist in building a dome. Whether it will stand remains to be seen. But Glynn's cast-concrete dome sculptures (above), on view at the Performa Hub through Nov. 21, are objects of perfection of which even Fuller might have approved. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

After scoring a touchdown, football teams can choose between attempting an easy kick for 1 point or going for a more difficult play for 2 points. You are the coach, and your kicker makes the extra-point kick 99 percent of the time, while your offense succeeds on a two-point conversion 50 percent of the time. Over time, which strategy will result in more points? a. Extra point.

Reims, France, Sept. 19, 2011 While visiting the Notre-Dame Cathedral in Reims, I sat on a stone bench across from this little prayer area. After a couple of minutes, this lady walked up to the little altar. She just stood there, motionless. Her hair, her dress, her white high heels all seemed to be such a contrast with the rest of the environment. I took about four shots before she walked away. I never did see her face.VINCE LUPO, Baltimore

The thing that always got me about Muammar el-Qaddafi: all those years in power and why only a colonel? Wasn't it a little awkward ordering all those generals around? (He acceded only to an honorary promotion from his underlings.) I suppose this was Qaddafi's way of demonstrating his populist impulse. Or maybe when he looked in the mirror, Colonel Qaddafi just didn't see general material. Who among us can't sympathize with that.

A four-bedroom penthouse at the Laureate, which opened this past spring, sold for $8.5 million, making it the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

Mr. Drumm served as the chief executive officer of Nyack Hospital from 1956 to 1978.

Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). While the Carson Palmer (Oakland, vs. DEN) era in Oakland officially began in Week 7, and boy was it ugly, this game will be his first start for the Silver and Black. In fantasy terms, the matchup doesn't get any better, with the Broncos allowing the most fantasy points to the position through the first eight weeks. Still, starting Palmer does mean you are pretty desperate, even more desperate than the guy rolling with Seattle's Tarvaris Jackson. But with the bye weeks still hovering over many of you, you can do worse than rolling the dice with Palmer, who claims to be comfortable now with Oakland's playbook and his new receivers. He's among our favorable quarterback matchups for Week 9.

Cooke Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St., NYC Monday, November 7, 10am-12pm. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to American Cancer Society.

Here are some responses from readers of the Bats blog. Of all the M.L.B. players involved in the continuing scandal of using performance-enhancing drugs, none disgraced himself and the game more than Mark McGwire did. Because of how he lapped up the adulation he received during the fraudulent chase of Maris's home run record, he should have had to pay a proportionate price -- lifetime banishment from any official connection with M.L.B. Every camera shot of McGwire made during the M.L.B. postseason was like a mocking insult to all of us that he betrayed. The abstract paintings shown here are not by Kazimir Malevich or Paul Klee but by Hindu tantra devotees from Indian cities like Jodhpur and Chomu, the anonymous heirs to a pictorial tradition that dates to the 1600s. Painted on salvaged paper and rarely measuring more than a foot high, the images possess a strange kinship with 20th-century art. And their agelessness cast a spell over Franck Andre Jamme, a French poet who nearly got himself killed tracking down these works across the deserts of Rajasthan. In 1985, Jamme was on a bus to Jaipur when his driver fell asleep and smashed into an oncoming truck, killing seven people. Jamme suffered a series of comas but eventually returned to India. After consulting a soothsayer, he resumed his quest to befriend tantrikas and understand their meditative art form, which originated in handwritten religious texts but is today mostly neglected on the subcontinent. ''I needed around 20 years to find the good nests, the good families where people were still making these marvels,'' Jamme said. His discoveries are newly collected in ''Tantra Song'' (Siglio, $40). They were first exhibited in 1994 at the gallery of Agnes b. in Paris, where Jamme hung this triumphant notice: ''Perhaps rarely in the universal history of painting have works at once so mysterious and simple, yet so powerful and pure, ever been produced - a bit as if, here, man's genius had been able to assemble almost everything in almost nothing.''

A parish priest on the Faeroe Islands in the 17th century left behind an account of a grindadrap -- Faeroese for ''whale hunt'' -- a grisly spectacle in which pilot whales were killed ''with such fury on both sides,'' he wrote, ''that the water becometh as red as blood.'' For generations, the grindadrap has been a mainstay of life on the Faeroes, an archipelago roughly equidistant from Norway, Iceland and Scotland, and the practice continues today, over the protests of animal rights groups, which call it cruel. But the islanders, most of them descendants of Viking settlers, bristle at outside interference. The Faeroese maintain that the hunting of pilot whales is sustainable and regulated, and the whales are killed with a grindaknivur -- a traditional knife that severs the spinal cord and causes the animals to lose consciousness within seconds. But the grindadrap is more than a cultural institution. The whale meat and blubber are part of the national diet, dried and salted and distributed across the islands. And there's no guarantee of a successful hunt: in 2008, possibly because of changes in water temperature, ocean currents and the distribution of prey, no whales were caught at all. ''The Faeroese people,'' says Kate Sanderson, director of fisheries in the Faeroe Islands, ''are entirely dependent on the sea.'' total coastline of faeroe islands: 694 miles on 18 islands (17 inhabited)

HE may have been Belgian, but the singer-songwriter Bobbejaan Schoepen, who died last year at 85, was pure Nashville. A mega-star in his homeland and the founder of the Bobbejaanland theme park in Lichtaart, Mr. Schoepen performed at the Grand Ole Opry and favored the rhinestone-encrusted suits of Nudie Cohn, with whom he collaborated for more than 20 years. ''Dreamsuits,'' an exhibition of the clothes and accessories that Cohn made for Mr. Schoepen and his wife, Josée, is on view at the Mode Museum in Antwerp. ''Nudie called Bobbejaan 'the cowboy from over there,' '' said Mairi MacKenzie, a curator of the show. ''The first time they met, Nudie took him for a ride in one of his famous Nudiemobiles. When you started the engine, you heard the sound of horses' hooves and gunfire. Bobbejaan was so impressed that he got one to display at Bobbejaanland. He always said it was the most lucrative ride he ever had.'' Until Feb. 12; at momu.be. NANCY MacDONELL

Aboriginal Music Society The percussionist and bassist Juma Sultan is a link between free jazz and Jimi Hendrix, and a puzzle piece in the history of musicians' cooperatives. He moved to New York City from California in 1966 and a few years later to Woodstock, N.Y., joining an artists' group called Group 212 Intermedia Workshop. With the multi-instrumentalist Ali Abuwi he helped form the Aboriginal Music Society, a loose assembly of players who prided themselves on absolute inclusiveness; you could join in, no matter what you did. (''Any Song, Any Key, Anywhere,'' was their motto.) Hendrix dropped by to play with him in 1969, a few days before the Woodstock festival, resulting in a much-bootlegged jam session. Then Mr. Sultan returned to Manhattan and moved into Studio We, the performance space on Eldridge Street, recording and resuming his playing with Mr. Abuwi and whomever else.

EVERYONE -- conservative and liberal -- agrees that $2.6 trillion a year is too much to spend on health care, and that we have to cut costs. But they don't agree on who is to blame or what is to be done. Everett M. Dirksen, the Republican senator from Illinois, reportedly said, ''a billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon you're talking about real money.'' But health care spending in the United States typically increases by about $100 billion per year. Cutting a billion here or there from something that large is undetectable. In health care, you have to be talking about tens of billions of dollars before you are talking about real money. A useful threshold for savings is 1 percent of costs, which comes to $26 billion a year. Anything less is simply not meaningful.

IF Athena Calderone has a fashion signature, it's her tiny jean jacket. ''I wear it with almost everything,'' said Ms. Calderone, an interior designer. ''With black jeans and a shirt by day, and with a dress at night.'' That she found it at Gap Kids is a bonus. It's a perfect fit for her slender frame, she said, its shrunken 1990s-style proportions lending it unexpected cachet. Better still, it confers bragging rights. ''If people compliment you on the look,'' she said, ''it implies you're slim and cool and crafty.''

Christopher Harth has always been good with his hands. After moving to Manhattan, Harth, who was raised on a farm in Minnesota, found his skills proved less than useful and ended up working as a model and producer for the photographer Ryan McGinley. But late last year he started NYCutlery and put his hands back to work carving knife handles out of scraps of furniture-grade walnut and grinding blades from reclaimed steel, all in his backyard in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. His eco-conscious knives are made to measure for both fit and function. A few days after finishing a foraging knife with a short, curved blade for cutting back toward the thumb, Harth used it himself to gather chanterelles for a delicious ravioli. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Rose was a doer, a role model for working for the benefit of family, community, and in government service at HEW, where she achieved executive responsibilities, at a time when women were not readily given such opportunities. Rose is also survived by her children Frank, Dan and Kayle, her grandchildren Oden, Shaina, Michael and Maya, and four great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at noon on Monday, November 7, at Grammercy Chapel, 353 2nd Avenue, Manhattan. Donations in Rose's honor may be made to Birch Family Services in support of the education, housing and training of children and young adults with autism and other challenging conditions (www.hgbirch.org).

The humble incandescent bulb, now a symbol of unbridled energy consumption, has long illuminated the artistic imagination. Pablo Picasso's 1962 ''Nature Morte Au Verre Sous la Lampe,'' Roy Lichtenstein's 1977 ''Lamp on a Table,'' Tim Noble and Sue Webster's ''Special Edition Silver $'' from 2007 and other proverbial light-bulb moments are on view in ''Burning, Bright: A Short History of the Light Bulb,'' at Pace Gallery in Chelsea from Oct. 29 through Nov. 26. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DAVIDSON--Neil. Noted author Mr. Neil Davidson passed away on Saturday, October 8, 2011 at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Bryn Mawr, PA. Mr. Davidson is survived by his wife Pascale Davidson, his brothers James Davidson of Thomaston, CT, William Davidson of Chicopee, MA, two sisters Lisbeth Zajac of Bailey, NC and Barbara Parker of South Hadley, MA. He is also survived by his sister-in-law Dominique Besse and his father-in-law, Andre Besse, both of Paris, France. Mr. Davidson was born in Holyoke, MA on May 23, 1946 and resided in South Hadley before volunteering for VISTA. Mr. Davidson was a professional musician and composer prior to founding, publishing and editing the Music Independent, a nationally syndicated magazine devoted to the review of independent music and artists. He owned a record store in Oakland, CA and produced a record album of his own music. A member of ASCAP and the Authors' Guild, Mr. Davidson published his first novel entitled "The Sweet Revenge of Melissa Chavez" in 1996 and several literary articles thereafter. He was under consideration for a Pulitzer Prize for feature writing and one of his short stories was included in the Beacon Best of 1999.

Like San Francisco and other European countries, Switzerland has been tightening its animal-welfare laws, and because guinea pigs are prone to loneliness, it's now illegal to own just one. This leaves you in a tight spot if you own two guinea pigs and one dies. You could buy a new one, but then, when the next guinea pig died? You might get stuck buying guinea pigs for the rest of your life. Fortunately, a market-driven solution has emerged. Priska Küng of Hadlikon, a town just outside of Zurich, now rents guinea pigs -- a castrated male goes for about $30 -- for as long as you need them.

FOR decades, Main Street in Vancouver, British Columbia, has had little of the wholesomeness or the centrality that its name implies. Its lower end, close to the city's notorious downtown skid row, is one of the city's seediest strips, while the rest of Main Street stretches off into tidy, slightly dull, residential neighborhoods that are off the radar of most visitors. One of those areas, Riley Park, is changing that. In the last few years, the strip of Main Street that goes through this quiet neighborhood has emerged as one of the city's most vibrant, with boutiques featuring the work of creative local designers and small, innovative restaurants and cafes. YIGAL SCHLEIFER

Before she died in 1996 at age 61, the designer Isabelle Hebey said she would leave nothing undone, no aspirations unfulfilled. (Well, almost none: she always joked about redoing the Vatican.) Hebey even drew up new plans for her Paris apartment, tailored to the son who would inherit it, right down to rearranging the furniture. In planning her funeral, however, she did not go as far as another autocratic designer of her generation, David Hicks, who sketched his own coffin. But she did get to choose hers. ''It was very surreal,'' recalls Emmanuel Hebey, the noted mathematician and Isabelle's son. ''The man who sold it to us was rather surprised.'' That she sought to control the visual world from beyond the grave shocks no one who knew her. Born on the island of Martinique into a French colonial family whose conservatism she would look back on with horror, Hebey began working in Paris in the 1950s, creating everything from pens, watches and public housing to modular bathrooms, car interiors and cribs for the likes of Sophia Loren, the culinary writer Christian Millau and Bao Long, the last crown prince of Vietnam.
The Designer Frith Kerr, the go-to graphic designer for creative clients from the artist Philippe Parreno to the fashion designer Hussein Chalayan, has a way with words.

''A brick Georgian was never my dream house,'' insists the artist Laurie Simmons. In the fall of 2000, when Simmons was given the opportunity to design a house - O.K., a dollhouse - from the ground up, she collaborated with the architect Peter Wheelwright to create a very colorful, almost Modernist abode filled with works of pint-size contemporary art and design. And yet, the first time she walked through the front door of the near-textbook brick Georgian in northwestern Connecticut that she and her husband, the artist Carroll Dunham, eventually came to own, ''something came over me,'' she recalls. She said to Dunham, ''If this house were a man, you'd be toast.'' The house, which was built around the turn of the last century, had been used until recently as the administration building for the Marvelwood School, a private boarding school. An adjacent barn once contained a cafeteria, science labs, music-rehearsal rooms and a half basketball court, where dances were occasionally held.

A picture caption with the November listings in the special Holiday Movies section last Sunday misidentified the role played by Dougray Scott in ''My Week With Marilyn.'' Mr. Scott, shown with the actress Michelle Williams, portrays the playwright Arthur Miller, not a production assistant.

WITH their sabers, shako caps and 19th-century uniforms with tasseled epaulettes, the members of the Veteran Corps of Artillery of the State of New York could easily be mistaken, even while marching in last month's Columbus Day parade, for Napoleonic soldiers heading toward the Austerlitz front lines. In fact, the unit is quite American, a remnant of George Washington's Continental Army, created in 1790 to defend the homeland of New York. The photographer Christopher Lane first spotted the men -- and their eye-catching military wear -- at a Veterans Day parade three years ago and knew at once that he had to visit them at their headquarters, the Park Avenue Armory, to make formal portraits.

''Talk about sausages for a style magazine based in New York? Tremendous!'' wrote Sam Baron in response to our questions about the T he created for our Design and Living issue. Turns out Baron, who is the design director at Fabrica, is also an avid foodie, and splitting his time between Paris, Portugal and Treviso, Italy, where Fabrica's headquarters are located, has taught him quite a lot on the subject of sausages (glass and otherwise). Here, the designer indulges in some of his favorite saucisson. You've made glass sausages before. Tell us about the project that preceded this T. Two years ago, Monica Khemsurov and Jill Singer of Sight Unseen invited me to participate in the Noho Design District, part of which they were organizing in a building once owned by Andy Warhol and that's now occupied by a Japanese butcher shop called Japan Premium Beef. The butchers there sell this very rarefied meat, and since I am a French designer and come from saucisson country, I thought that the best and most interesting way to connect my work with the butcher shop was to dress their windows with a generous group of iconic sausage shapes.

The British design doyen Sir Terence Conran is showing signs of his 80 years. He sits in one of the Finnish designer Yrjo Kukkapuro's Karuselli chairs not just because it's a design classic, but also because its curves soothe his bones. ''I have a fairly bad back,'' he admits. But don't make the mistake of assuming that his retrospective exhibition, ''Terence Conran: The Way We Live Now,'' at the Design Museum in London from Nov. 16 through March 4, 2012, is a swan song. ''I suppose they might see it like that,'' says Conran, the chairman of Conran Holdings, whose work spans product design, branding, architecture, retail outlets and restaurants. ''But it clearly is not.'' He points to the recent debut of the Conran exclusive design collection, a line of furniture for Marks & Spencer, one of Britain's biggest midmarket chains, as further proof that he is still very much responsible for the Way Britons Live Now.

An article last Sunday about plans to bolster the American military presence in the Persian Gulf after withdrawal from Iraq described incorrectly the political affiliations of a group of senators requesting hearings on the negotiations that led to the withdrawal. The group is made up of 11 Republicans and one independent (Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut) -- not 12 Republicans.

Packers (7-0) at Chargers (4-3) Sunday, 4:15 p.m. Line: Packers by 5 .5. The Chargers' Monday night loss to the Chiefs was so heartbreaking that San Diego State men's basketball coach Steve Fisher offered Norv Turner his services as a psychoanalyst. Fisher coached the Michigan's Fab Five in 1993, the year Chris Webber lost the championship game when he incurred a technical foul for calling a timeout his team did not have. (The N.C.A.A. swears none of this ever happened, of course, because the Fab Five never existed to them.) Parallels to the fourth-quarter fumble by Philip Rivers are obvious, and Fisher told The San Diego Union-Tribune that the Chargers could benefit from Turner's patented not-so-tough love. ''Most of the time you get there because your best player is your best player,'' he said. ''And then when things happen, you still have to wrap an arm around him and say, 'You're our best player.' '' Unfortunately, Turner must identify his best player before hugging it out. Rivers is in a wicked slump that goes beyond fourth quarter fumbles. Receiver Vincent Jackson (four catches on 16 throws in two games) is doing everything possible to not get open. Antonio Gates is battling through injuries. The defense is now populated by no-names. Kicker Nick Novak leads the Chargers in scoring, but no one wants to wrap an arm around a kicker. Turner must identify and embrace said ''best player'' before facing the Packers, a team too predictably excellent to talk about. The Packers just win, with no Dream Team acquisitions, mysterious commissioner's office meetings, or polarizing, bumbling, cult hero quarterbacks to obsess about. That makes it more fun to write about the Lions' goon squad nouveau reputation, the Cowboys' never-ending quest to convince the world that they are still relevant or Turner wandering through the Chargers' clubhouse with his arms outstretched and a message of reassurance on his lips. Pick: Packers.

In Metropolitan's cover article last week, ''Storing the Stuff of Dreams,'' Mark Lamster profiled Day & Meyer, Murray & Young, a company that has warehoused the art, furniture and bric-a-brac of elite Manhattan residents in its Upper East Side tower since 1928. Readers wrote to NYTimes.com to share their thoughts on the acquisitiveness of the rich and the not so rich; below is a sampling. They also debated Ginia Bellafante's Big City column about the latest in a succession of status objects that have fostered urban crime: the iPhone. Fascinating story. But just after scouring our house and garage for things we no longer use, and then taking them to a fund-raising yard sale, I have to wonder: what's the point of having beautiful and valuable things if you can't enjoy them in your daily life?
TROVATI--Vincent. You'll always be my daddy and I'll always be your little girl. I'll miss you each and every day. Joslyn Faith

Print may be dying, but not in the design world. The exhibition ''Archizines,'' at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London from Nov. 5 through Dec. 14, features 60 contemporary architecture magazines, fanzines and journals from more than 20 countries. The show's curator, Elias Redstone, who writes the London Underground column for T's blog, The Moment, collected the publications on his travels, compiling them first as an online project (archizines.com), with art direction by Folch Studio in Barcelona. But an exhibition of the print versions makes perfect sense: the power of the Internet notwithstanding, it's more fun to turn real pages than digital ones. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
Film Rachel Saltz

SIEGEL--Marian (Mascha). On October 25, 2011, at the age of 86. Predeceased by the Alarming Lou Siegel. After six years of uncertainty following the end of the war, Wallis still felt rootless and ''homeless on the face of the earth.'' The Windsors rented and borrowed houses until there could be no possible doubt that returning to England was out of the question. It was Wallis who finally recognized that there would never be meaningful work offered to the duke and that they would never be able to make their home in England. She had always shown remarkable self-awareness of her own shortcomings, even if she was unable to change them, and now she tried to give the duke some of the courage she was scraping together as he, often depressed or ill, faced a still-hostile family and an ever colder world. Their first trip to England together in the fall of 1946 was a disaster. They stayed with their friends the Earl and Countess of Dudley at Ednam Lodge. On Oct. 16 a burglar broke into the house and stole Wallis's jewelry, which she had left unsecured when they went out for the evening. Wallis was distraught; the jewelry had defined her romance with the then prince and given her security. An exotic bird of paradise brooch, with a cabochon sapphire breast and a plumage of diamonds, had just been made for her by Cartier that year. She never saw it, or any of the other stolen pieces, again.

Ten years is the length of an average commercial lease, but it's also, as the designer Ted Muehling has discovered, the approximate life span of a neighborhood. Back in 2001, Muehling moved his storefront workshop from a formerly desolate block on Greene Street to Howard Street - at the time SoHo's final frontier. But when a Mondrian hotel went up nearby, so did Muehling's rent, and the designer moved on once again. His new store, on White Street in TriBeCa, is grander in proportion and there is more selling space, but also more space for Muehling to display the many things he collects and that inspire him, from natural wonders like seashells or insects to the work of his partner, the artist Mats Gustafson, or that of his friend Jan Baracz, who carves bellybuttons into large stones. And while his workrooms are smaller, for the first time Muehling has a little studio all his own - an ''attic'' tucked into a mezzanine under a skylight in the back. The timing could not have been better. With his product collaborations with Nymphenburg and Steuben winding down, Muehling is eager to get back to making jewelry. On a recent morning, a pair of canaries twittered joyfully, and an installation of monarch butterflies on a dried mullein stem was magically animated by a breeze from the air-conditioner. As with his previous store, this one is livened by sounds from behind the scenes - the bang of metal on metal, the murmur of NPR - evidence that this is a place where things are made and not just sold. It's the kind of neighborhood place, Muehling points out, where you can walk in and they'll make a new wire for your earring if you don't mind waiting 20 minutes. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments about Michael Cieply's profile of Steven Spielberg in the Holiday Movies section. ''He wants to be loved, and so he has movies that dumb down, that explain everything, that give audiences what he thinks they want. (Apparently they do.) But he never makes the really tough artistic decisions that truly great directors make; often pictures that aren't easy aren't lovable. There's no question about his technical expertise, but his artistic judgment is, it seems to me, cheap, easy, kitschy.''

The original version of the ''Invitation to a Dialogue'' letter, published on Wednesday, described Bernard L. Weinstein's affiliation incompletely. He is associate director of the Maguire Energy Institute at Cox School of Business, Southern Methodist University. The institute was founded by Cary M. Maguire, president of Maguire Oil Company, and receives money from the energy industry. Its advisory board includes several executives in the energy industry, and it prepares students for jobs in the field.

Two great tastes don't always taste great together. The same can be true for design collaborations. Heath Ceramics are beautiful. Alabama Chanin textiles are beautiful. Their respective designers, Catherine Bailey and Natalie Chanin, are friends. But could the twain meet? First attempts were not promising. Alabama Chanin clothes and linens deploy embroidery and applique in a modern, layered, bohemian way. The embellishments are frequently mapped out with a stencil, and Bailey initially thought they might use the stencils on her company's classic Coupe dinnerware.''Natalie transfers graphical images by making a stencil and spraying paint on it, but when we stenciled the plates it didn't look crafted,'' Bailey says. ''It looked like spray-painted graphics.'' Bailey quickly realized she needed a better way to translate the exacting techniques used by Chanin's cast of local talent in and around Florence, Ala.

The new Natural History Museum of Utah is so in tune with its environment that it almost blends into the landscape. Called the Rio Tinto Center, the museum sits on 17 acres, terraced along the foothills of the Wasatch mountain range in Salt Lake City. ''We tried not to disturb the site too much because the building is really about the land,'' Todd Schliemann of Ennead Architects, who designed the museum, said. ''It's like a great rock outcrop covered in copper.'' The museum, part of the University of Utah, is to open Nov. 18. In addition to using local resources, elements of sustainable architecture further connect the building to its environment. The water catchment and management system uses a pervious parking lot and plants on the roof's edge to filter storm water slowly into the ground, preventing runoff from washing away large amounts of soil.

Looking to the stars for guidance is considered dodgy these days. As recently as the 19th century, though, it was deemed science, and in the Middle Ages, Chaucer depicted it as the province of intellectuals. AstrologyZone.com's Susan Miller posts predictions, tweets clarifications and continues to emphasize the math. She contends that Occupy Wall Street is a result of a harsh aspect between Uranus and Pluto that will recur into 2015. ''I don't see the demonstrations stopping anytime soon,'' she says.

During the recent freakish October snowstorm, you could hear the tree limbs cracking all night. In the morning, the trees on the north end of Grand Army Plaza on Fifth Avenue, left, looked as if a tornado had done the pruning, not the weight of wet, heavy snow on branches thick with leaves. The trees on the south end of the plaza remained unscathed. The weather's influence on fashion was immediate. Certainly there was the expected surge in all-black, but more important were the neutrals mixed with fur vests and yards of scarves. The storm brought a first look at winter coats, right. The swirl of a pleated back was as much about swagger as warmth, and one-piece coats fooled the eye with the look of layers. An early color direction is cobalt blue. Ankle-high boot shoes were everywhere, as was the sight of people pulling on winter gloves.

Living in a van, or ''vandwelling,'' is now fashionable. The data firm RealtyTrac predicts 1.2 million homes will be repossessed this year, but van sales are up 24 percent, according to the auto-information company Edmunds.com. The singer Sly Stone lived in a van in Los Angeles, though his lawyer reportedly rented him a four-bedroom home. Jessica Spaulding owns two apartment buildings in Arizona but lives in a car. ''People always think that's crazy,'' she says dismissively. Jason Odom, author of ''Vanabode,'' says nonvan homes lead to ''crushed dreams, boredom, obesity, poor health and a house to sleep away the pain in.'' He lives with his wife in a white Chevy van in Florida, where ''it's not muggy this time of year.''

As the creative director of Chez Panisse, the Kyoto-born chef Sylvan Mishima Brackett learned a thing or two about catering intimate events with élan. Add to this his mother's down-to-earth cooking and the artful presentation at the restaurants where he apprenticed in Japan, and you've got the influences behind Peko-Peko, the catering business Brackett opened in 2008. ''I wanted to cook food that was relaxed and delicious and easy to appreciate,'' he says. Brackett has gained a following with his seasonal bento -- dishes include pickled plum, Dungeness crab rice and miso-cured black cod -- delivered in bamboo husk boxes.

Cars that prevent intoxicated drivers from operating them may be rolling a little closer to reality, if only legislatively. The American Beverage Institute, a restaurant trade association, noted the Senate's approval this week of an appropriation, by a vote of 60 to 39, that would allot $5 million for further research into alcohol-detection devices known as interlocks.

Hundreds of Occupy Wall Street demonstrators streamed into a desolate part of Foley Square on Saturday afternoon, but their slow-moving march turned chaotic as a phalanx of police officers issued orders to vacate the sidewalks - and then swept in to force the issue. One police official said that at least 20 protesters were arrested in a series of fast-moving encounters with officers outside the public square in Lower Manhattan that is hemmed in by several government buildings: the State Supreme Court building, a United States courthouse and 26 Federal Plaza, where the Federal Bureau of Investigation has its New York headquarters.

This issue's ''cover house'' resides in Bayonne, France. It is owned by an artist, designer and ''nose'' named Christian Astuguevieille, and it is filled with objects covered in rope, cloth and stuffing, and brilliantly hued paint. There is a wooden temple in its palatial air shaft and a room crammed mostly with porcelain. It is a gorgeous, sensual and layered interior ///-- ''I love to mystify'' is how Astuguevieille describes his aesthetic to Guy Trebay (Page 68) -- and one that I find utterly bewitching. The three homes featured in these pages are all owned by artists -- Astuguevieille, Mats Gustafson, Laurie Simmons -- and it would therefore be tempting to label this an art edition of T. I tend to avoid such tags; they always seem banal and commercially driven. What I would say, however, is that all three spaces are disorienting, dramatic and disarmingly beautiful, qualities that one may associate with art. The Stockholm apartment (Page 78) that Mats Gustafson and his partner, Ted Muehling, escape to from New York, writes Pilar Viladas, is like a 19th-century Scandinavian painting -- all light and shadow and moody palette /-- but entirely contemporary. Laurie Simmons's country retreat (Page 84), as Alix Browne discovers, is a larger-than-even-life-size version of the dollhouse that occupies her work and her dreams. It's a magnificent mix of the vernacular and the visionary.

When you walk into the artist and illustrator Mats Gustafson's apartment in Stockholm, you're not quite sure what era you're in. In the foyer, a turn-of-the-century painting of a bourgeois Swedish interior hangs beneath one of Isamu Noguchi's oversize paper lanterns, and underfoot is a colorful mid-20th-century rug by Barbro Nilsson for the renowned Swedish workshop MMF. Under a midcentury nude painted by Birger Ljungquist, Gustafson's great-uncle, sits a simple 1950s stool by the Swedish designer Carl Malmsten. Walk through an angled doorway into the living room, a high-ceilinged space with the graceful proportions and architectural ornament typical of late-19th-century buildings, and the mix gets even richer. An upholstered 19th-century Swedish bench along the window and a group of slipper chairs, all from Gustafson's family, blend easily with sheepskin-covered wood chairs designed in the 1930s by Bruno Mathsson and tables by Josef Frank. Vases by Scandinavian Modern ceramics masters like Axel Salto and Berndt Friberg are clustered atop a traditional tiled fireplace, and the immaculate plaster walls (which are painted, aptly enough, Stockholm White) are hung with Gustafson's spare, elegant watercolors. Venture into the apartment's long corridor, however, and you'll find up-to-the-minute bathrooms and a sunny, south-facing kitchen in which crisp, utilitarian cabinets provide a clean backdrop for an antique wooden table and chairs. This is an interior that's modern and old-fashioned at the same time, and in all the right ways. Gustafson, a Swede who moved to New York in 1980 (and who now lives in a 19th-century farmhouse in Sag Harbor), had kept a small apartment in this building - an imposing structure in Stockholm's Sodermalm neighborhood - since the 1970s, but when a two-bedroom apartment became available, he couldn't resist. ''I needed a more mature place,'' he said, one that would give him a space to work, and which would also provide comfortable living quarters for him and his partner, the jewelry and product designer Ted Muehling. Gustafson treasured the Old World graciousness of the space and wanted to make it more functional while protecting its considerable charms, ''not to make it into something it wasn't,'' he explained.

The Polish princess Sarah Lavoine -- nee Poniatowski -- is France's decorator du jour, a designer of perfectly imperfect interiors as well as seriously sleek home décor (go to sarahlavoine.com). Her Paris crib, high above the Tuileries, is an art-filled nest feathered for her children, Yasmine, Roman and Milo, and her husband, the French pop star Marc Lavoine. 1. b. The chance that the Phillies win three consecutive games is 0.60 x 0.60 x 0.60 = 0.216. But the Phillies can also win the series in four games: bettors should multiply 3 (possible outcomes CPPP, PCPP, PPCP) x 0.40 x 0.60 x 0.60 x 0.60 = 0.259 probability. They can also win in five games: 6 (possible outcomes) x 0.40 x 0.40 x 0.60 x 0.60 x 0.60 = 0.207. Adding up these three numbers, 0.216 + 0.259 + 0.207, equals the total probability of the Phillies winning the series: 0.682, or 68.2 percent. 2. b. Over 100 tries, you would expect to score 99 extra points (99 points total) with a kick, but to successfully convert 50 two-point conversions (100 points total).

The record-breaking late-October snowstorm, which buried some northern New England towns in snow (up to 31 inches) and snapped trees like twigs, may be the final blow to an already lackluster foliage season. It started with Tropical Storm Irene, which washed out roads and flooded towns in Vermont, New Hampshire and upstate New York, scaring off potential visitors. Still, there was hope for color. But rain and warm weather kept leaves in limbo. When they finally turned, it was often to brown. That meant discounts, from hotels to bed and breakfasts. Now, seizing an opportunity to use the snowstorm to their advantage, resorts are rebranding the offers as ... ski deals!
