SHOPPERS come in many forms, just as fashion critics do. Facebook has become a marketplace, joining eBay, Etsy and members-only sites, not to mention big-box e-commerce. Personally, I have enough stuff, and yard sales and Dumpsters have taken care of the rest. When I see a statistic for the amount of rented storage space in the United States, I'm inclined to nod and say, ''Makes sense.'' We are an overbought nation.

Sam Baron The French designer Sam Baron composed a quartet of handblown glass sausages into the shape of a ''T'' for ''For Better or Wurst'' (Page 67). The piece that inspired it -- titled ''Dans le cochon tout est bon,'' which translates as ''everything in the pig is good'' -- pays homage to the French countryside, where butchers live by the nose-to-tail credo, says Baron, who hails from France's Jura region. Baron is the design director of Benetton's self-described ''talent incubator,'' Fabrica, and he recently unveiled a limited-edition tableware collection for Vista Alegre.

IT gurgles. It oozes. And it can eat you for breakfast -- especially if your name is Marilyn Minter. It's ''I'm Not Much but I'm All I Think About,'' a slow-motion video by the artist, known for excessively close-up paintings in which freckles, open pores and beads of sweat all look like glorious costume jewels. In the self-mocking video, now playing 24/7 in the street window of Salon 94 Bowery, Ms. Minter stirs up a voluptuous brew of narcissistic pleasure that swallows her initials (in the form of M&M candies) and a silver charm spelling ''me'' that keeps coming back for another plunge. The ingredients of her omnivorous pool are vodka and silver cake frosting suspended in glycerin, a delectable goo that coats or splatters through the faces and objects in four large, aqueous paintings inside the gallery. ''Everything I do is wet and sweaty,'' Ms. Minter said. ''I don't know why -- maybe because I sweat so much? But my mother used to tell me that when I was a baby I'd turn on the water in the tub and watch it run for hours.'' LINDA YABLONSKY

An article on Oct. 23 about the local art scene in Yangon, Myanmar, misstated the name of an award received by the artist Aye Ko, who founded a nonprofit gallery and art school, New Zero Art Space. It is the Asian Cultural Council Award, not Asia Cultural Council Award.

-Honey, they've done it again. They've gone out and shrunk the city. This time it's the Census Bureau. According to its latest calculations, New York City has shrunk by more than two square miles, or the equivalent of Central and Prospect Parks combined. -In 2008, the Department of City Planning recalculated the city's land area at 304.8 square miles, 17 square miles smaller than the figure stated definitively for decades in, among other places, the city's official directory. Now, employing the most sophisticated mapping techniques available, the Census Bureau says the city actually measures 302.643 square miles. Brooklyn and Queens appear to have borne the brunt of the shrinkage.

I was struck, though, by the advice she dispenses regarding how to become thinner: run more and eat less.

RITT--Alisha. January 24, 1926-November 1, 2011. Born Rosamonde Lewin in New York. Juilliard graduate, taught piano and ear training. Poet, musician, artist and activist, she had a great zest for life. Survived by son David Ritt (Deborah Bagg), granddaughter Sarah Ritt, and niece Jana Nishida.

An article on Oct. 23 about unmarked and unnoticed landmarks in baseball history misstated the title of Morris Eckhouse, who traveled to the University of Southern California campus to find the position of home plate at Bovard Field, where on March 26, 1951, the rookie Mickey Mantle drove in seven runs. And a correction in this space last Sunday repeated the error. Mr. Eckhouse is a past executive director of the Society for American Baseball Research, not a past executive president.

You'll have to find your own spot at the folding metal table that Deirdre Foley-Mendelssohn and Peter Stella use when entertaining at their apartment on Christopher Street. Neither believes in seating charts, opting instead to let guests fend for themselves among the mismatched plates, found silverware and batik napkins from Indonesia. Stella, 29, a medical and M.B.A. graduate student, grew up in the neighborhood, and the couple takes full advantage of their local farmers' market and the many West Village specialty stores. ''Super-simple ingredients make everything better,'' says the 28-year-old Foley-Mendelssohn, a senior editor at The Paris Review, who carries provisions in a wicker basket on her vintage Schwinn bike. ''Peter's more of a traditionalist when it comes to cooking, inclined to think that a pasta with too many ingredients is actually a salad.''

''This is your nemesis calling,'' Will Arnett tells me in his distinctive, grovelly, mock-sinister voice after spending the morning filming his hit NBC sitcom, ''Up All Night'' (and brushing up on his hockey skills for a future episode). But a funny thing happened to the ''Arrested Development'' alum en route to becoming Hollywood's go-to guy for arch comedy roles: Arnett became a father twice, at least. By day, he and his TV wife, Christina Applegate, raise a newborn daughter; by night, he and his real-life wife, Amy Poehler, raise two boys: Archie, 3, and Abel, 1. ''I'm pretty childlike,'' Arnett explains from his Los Angeles home. ''I live a fairly goofy existence. My job requires I mess around a lot and make light of every situation. It turns out, that's how kids live.'' Oh, baby -- or should we say, Oh, babies?

In a recent article in Landscape and Urban Planning, researchers found that placing an aquarium in the window of an Austrian furnishings store enticed more people to stop and look. They surmised it was part ''biophilia'' -- humans are drawn to nature -- and the fact that other people were looking. A researcher at Case Western also found that cramped aquariums can make fish more aggressive. Someone should get these folks together.

An award winner in France, the cookbook ''Testicles'' (Prospect Books, $40) sounds like a gag gift, but it's a remarkably straight-faced effort - by a woman, Blandine Vie - that combines recipes (lamb fries tagine and bull's testicles pate), droll cultural notes and an etymology of scrotal slang.

BERKWIT--Joseph C.,died October 23, 2011. A long-time resident of Gramercy Park and East Hampton, LI, he was 80. An accomplished pilot, he flew his prized Mooney and Dutchess airplanes out of Teterboro and East Hampton airports. His successful career in ocean shipping took him on travels around the world. Joe owned and operated two charter shipping companies, loved performance sports cars, fine food and the Philharmonic. He served in the U.S. Army in Germany at the US/USSR border 1952-54. He is greatly missed by his close friend Barbara Burns her family and his many friends. He is survived by sister Ann Marie Lewis of Boston. A Memorial Service will be held Tuesday, November 29 at 4pm at the Cornell Club, 6 East 44th St., New York.

An article last Sunday about the British Museum's choice of objects that define the history of the world misstated part of the title of the book based upon the project. It is ''A History of the World in 100 Objects,'' not ''The History of the World in 100 Objects.'' And a picture caption with a sculpture of a swimming reindeer misstated the age of the artwork. It dates from 11,000 B.C., not 1,100.

SHAW--Carolyn J.,80, died on October 26, 2011 at home in New York City. Born on February 26, 1931, to Charles J. Bauerle, Jr. and Alice H. F. Bauerle, Carolyn grew up in West Hartford, CT. Noah Chilton and Jackson Kroopf made a fine cup of coffee, and the choices at Vassar weren't cutting it. So they built a pushcart to rove the campus. While brewing, cart-istas might tell you about the women's collective that grew the Ethiopian coffee you just ordered. ''We speak of different processing methods, the 'terroir' associated with different coffees, farms and certification programs,'' says Mr. Chilton, above, a senior. Vassar gives half credits to two interns for taking on a reading list and giving a lecture about the coffees at Tree City gatherings; other helpers get half-pounds of coffee as pay. Samantha Wolffis's one-of-a-kind mittens are crafted of patches of old sweaters and buttons. Now a senior at Hope College in Holland, Mich., Ms. Wolffis, left, learned to sew in her sophomore year. After making a pair of mittens for herself, admirers wanted more. ''My entire basement is my factory and it has moved into my living room and dining room,'' she says. She's hired her first employee, begun some outsourcing and delayed grad school plans to see how much further mittens might take her.

An article last Sunday about Curry Without Worry, a boutique soup kitchen in San Francisco, referred incorrectly to the increase in the number of people who receive food from the San Francisco Food Bank and the Marin Food Bank. The number had grown to 225,000 people, which is up from 132,000 three years earlier, not in the previous year.

After 24 years in the same rent-controlled apartment that I had used as my office (but absolutely not as a mortuary or dental practice, which everyone knows is against code, if you're reading this, L.A. Housing Department), I got the heave-ho when the owners informed me that they needed the place for family. Having been in this one spot for so long, I actually began to look forward to moving, exploring a new part of town, and even gave some mild thought to deaccessioning some pieces I had collected over the years. On my first day of packing, however, I found a New Yorker cartoon that helped me make up my mind. It showed an old man lying on his deathbed. Looking up at a visitor, he says, ''I should have bought more crap.'' The sentiment touched me deeply, so I called my friend Scott Roberts of Fuller & Roberts Company, an antiques shop in West Hollywood. I had thought it through logically: I love his taste, he's got to love mine; he'll sell what I'm not going to miss; and I'll be able to buy more new old stuff. When he arrived to look at my things, though, I was struck with remorse over breaking up what I thought was a very cool assortment of urbane furniture and accessories. Half-jokingly, I told him, ''You should just recreate my office in your window.'' Oddly, he immediately agreed to do just that.

If it bleeds, it leads, goes the journalistic dictum. But the reverse is also true, which is why, through all the millions of words published in the last nine months about Libya, you've never heard of UNASOG, the United Nations Aouzou Strip Observation Group. Stuck along the Libyan-Chadian border, the 1994 peacekeeping mission has neither suffered casualties nor inflicted any, but it does have one particular claim to fame: at a duration of only one month, with a mere nine observers and a $64,000 price tag, it is reputed [1] to have been the United Nations's shortest, smallest and cheapest peacekeeping mission ever.

My Shortcuts column on Saturday, "Pursuing Self-Improvement, at the Risk of Self- Acceptance," looked at the notion, embedded in American culture, that we should constantly strive to make ourselves better. I talked to several experts who noted that there are limits to self-improvement, including one who found that mothers who were constantly striving to be the best at everything were often unhappier than those who accepted being good enough.

In this week's Critics' Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Sam Peckinpah's 1969 western "The Wild Bunch." The film, which was controversial when it was released because of its violence, is sometimes thought of as a revisionist western -- an effort to update a time-worn genre. But Mr. Scott sees it more as a "terminal western, a final flowering of the dusty, epic spirit that had dominated American cinema in the '40s and '50s."

Stomach acid has long been blamed for acid reflux, heartburn and other ills. But now some experts are starting to think that the problems may lie not just in the acid coming up from the stomach but in the food going down.

The three-time Breeders' Cup winner Goldikova was unable to take home a fourth championship, but she is returning to France in style, nonetheless. After shipping from Churchill Downs to Chicago on Monday, Goldikova will fly home in a comfortable jet stall on Air France on Tuesday.

Jerry Sandusky, a former defensive coach for Joe Paterno at Penn State University, has been charged with 40 counts of sexually abusing children over 15 years, including during his tenure on Paterno's staff. Tim Curley, the athletic director at Penn State, and Gary Schultz, an administrator at the university, have been charged with lying to a grand jury about what they had been told about Sandusky's behavior. (Curley has since taken an administrative leave and Schultz has retired.)

IN 2003, 8-year-old Alex Ellison and his family set sail in the Caribbean on their 46-foot Beneteau 473, Promise. They had intended to take a one-year trip from Essex, Conn., through the Caribbean to South America and back, but ended up spending almost five years living in the islands, celebrating birthdays in Grenada, Christmas in the Pitons and spending three years in the rain forest of Nevis. "The world was now our classroom," Mr. Ellison wrote in his memoir, "A Star to Sail Her By" (May 2011, iUniverse).

D.C. fast chargers are being installed. And in August, a block on the campus of Portland State University became Electric Avenue.

The first time I visited Bogotá, Colombia, I bought a colorful handmade mochila satchel from a street vendor. I confess, my desire for one was spurred after seeing Lauren Santo Domingo carrying a similarly vibrant woven bucket bag alongside the sleekest of Proenza Schouler looks. "It's becoming more common to see them everywhere - from the beaches of Formentera to the streets of Paris," says Santo Domingo, who's bringing more of these bags to market through her work with the Wayuu Mochila Project.Combining the craft of the Wayuu tribeswomen of La Guajira, Colombia, with the creative force of 40 designers - the Colombia native Nancy Gonzalez, Givenchy and Helmut Lang, among them - Santo Domingo has assembled a collection, some of which will go on sale on Nov. 9 (the rest will be sold at auction on November 17th at the BeLive Gala at the Ritz-Carlton in Miami, FL). The range includes evening clutches from Herve Leger, hot pink tribal etched styles from Diane Von Furstenberg and ones with gold-studded straps from Valentino. "A portion of this year's proceeds go to La Guajira for the construction of a new classroom and the purchase of materials like blackboards and textbooks," says Santo Domingo, who helped raise over $100,000 when she first spearheaded the initiative in 2009. Muy bueno.

When the Broadway revival of "Godspell" opens Monday night, it will likely trigger memories of rainbow suspenders and recorder solos for many a former drama club member. The 1971 musical, conceived and first directed by John-Michael Tebelak, is a retelling of the story of Jesus and his disciples, told through parables and a rock-pop score by Stephen Schwartz ("Wicked"). As Mark Oppenheimer wrote in his Arts & Leisure essay: "One school-gym performance after another of 'Bless the Lord' and 'Save the People,' among other hard-to-shake tunes, helped American religion accept contemporary music, even welcome it. It was what the kids wanted."

This weekend I set all the clocks back. About 7 on Sunday night (which was feeling a whole lot like 8 to me and four cranky children), I set them forward again. But not all the way. About half an hour. Just enough to give the children a little edge on what's always a sleepy week without my having to declare an early bedtime - and then listen to a chorus of complaint. I admit it: I lied, or at least, I created an atmosphere in which a lie was implied. But it was all for an excellent cause.

After nearly a month of blowouts and less-than-appealing matchups, "Sunday Night Football" on NBC returned to form on Sunday in a hotly contested rivalry game in which the Baltimore Ravens defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 23-20, with a touchdown in the final seconds. Henry Miller said of Big Sur, Calif., that it is "a region where extremes meet," and the same might be said of its hotels: there have long been only a handful of options between the luxurious Post Ranch Inn and the charming but ramshackle Deetjen's Big Sur Inn. Enter Glen Oaks Big Sur. A 1950s motor lodge that's been under renovation since 2008, Glen Oaks offers guests the feel of a cabin in the redwoods with some major differences: comfort and style. The owners, Basil and Tracy Sanborn, did not give the structure a face-lift so much as an upgrade, keeping its original adobe walls but adding bamboo floors, designer sinks, double walk-in showers, heated bathroom tiles, modern gas fireplaces and fire pits, Internet access, organic bedding and Pendleton throws. "We always felt there was an untapped niche here," says Basil, who was born in Big Sur. "Reasonable, high-quality rooms that would attract a demographic not unlike ourselves." The Sanborns also added cabins to the property, which sit along the Big Sur River on what was previously a campground. Visitors who want to savor one of the most undisturbed forests along the California coast needn't worry: televisions are still a no-no.

Tonight the second annual Project Art fund-raiser hosted by Project Paz to benefit the community of Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, takes place at 83 Mercer Street in New York City. In partnership with the e-commerce site L-atitude, the event will introduce a selection of one-off pieces made by American designers using traditional Mexican textiles, all of which will be sold during the event and exclusively at shoplatitude.com, with 100 percent of the proceeds going directly to Project Paz. Participating designers include Thakoon, Eddie Borgo, 3.1. Phillip Lim, Peter Som and Michael Bastian. "I wanted this biker jacket to embrace the Mexican rebozo," said Phillip Lim of the piece he contributed. Other designers, like Christian Cota, who grew up in Mexico and has seen firsthand how the organization has transformed the gang-ridden community of Juárez, have more direct ties to the project. Of his dress he says, "I really wanted the purple embroidery to pop in a clean, easy 1920s silhouette." New and noteworthy on this year's roster are David Neville and Marcus Wainwright of Rag & Bone, who stuck to their signature style. "The angular lines, strong tailoring and leather accent are all traditional Rag & Bone," say the designers.

ISTANBUL - In 1990, the year that globalization shifted into high gear and McDonald's opened an outlet in Moscow, a paper delivered at the Oxford Symposium on Food and Cookery entitled "The Bayeux Tapestry Shish Kebab Mystery" had French academics reaching for indigestion tablets. Its author, the textile specialist Robert Chenciner, pointed to a panel of that famous embroidery in which Norman knights celebrate their victory over the Saxons by grilling skewers of meat over an open fire. From this, Chenciner drew the bold conclusion that the tapestry must be a forgery or at least a much oversewn bit of cloth. There were no kebab takeaways in the Hastings of 1066, he reasoned, and it wasn't until the Ottomans visited Versailles in the mid-18th century that Turkish food came to France.

Thailand is under water, and as a result, some Internet companies could be facing problems. Flooding in the country has now shuttered more than 1,000 factories - some of which make computer hard drives. The government has warned that waters could continue to rise until the end of the year. When the rains do finally stop, it is estimated that factories could take months to clean up computer equipment damaged by floods and to re-calibrated tooling.

HEARST--John Randolph, Jr.,A trustee of The Hearst Family Trust and a member of the Board of Directors of Hearst Corporation and the two Hearst Foundations, died November 4 in New York City. He was 77. A grandson of William Randolph Hearst, John R. Bunky Hearst, Jr., as he was called most of his life, served as a member of the company's Board of Directors for 44 years. He was appointed a trustee of The Hearst Family Trust in April 1972, the same year he joined the Hearst Foundations as a director. John was always very devoted to the company founded by his grandfather, said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. He was equally devoted to a number of charitable organizations in the New York area. Those of us who served with him on the various Hearst Boards remember his great wit and interest in everything the company and Foundations were doing. Bunky will be greatly missed. Hearst enjoyed a long career with the Corporation, starting as a news photographer for the Hearst-owned New York Daily Mirror in the 1950s, as well as for the Hearst Newspapers division. In recognition of his interest in photojournalism, Hearst Newspapers commissioned a traveling trophy, the John R. Hearst Jr. Prize for Photo Excellence, awarded to photographers for Hearst Newspapers. An ardent boating enthusiast most of his life, he also served as an editor for Motor Boating & Sailing magazine, which was a Hearst publication. Born in New York City on December 8, 1933, to John Randolph Hearst, the third son of William Randolph Hearst, and Gretchen Wilson, Hearst often spent time in his youth at Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif., and greatly valued his time personally spent with his grandfather, the legendary W.R. Hearst. In 1960, John Hearst wrote an article for Reader's Digest entitled Life With Grandfather, in which he detailed their relationship. The younger Hearst's uncle, William Randolph Hearst, Jr., noted: The two talked newspapering a lot. Hearst said that if he learned one thing from his grandfather, it was the power of newspapers. Known for his sense of humor, Hearst enjoyed telling the story of how he had acquired his unusual nickname. He told the New York Times in 1983 that a cartoon character in his grandfather's newspaper, the New York Journal-American, was to blame. I used to wear huge baby bonnets, Hearst was quoted as saying. And my godfather took one look at me and said, He looks like Bunky in the funny papers.' The name stuck. On his 21st birthday, Hearst decided that he no longer resembled a Bunky, he told the Times. But it was too late; the nickname was his for life. I may as well wallow in it, Hearst said. Besides, I'd rather be a Bunky than a Junior. He is survived by his daughter Lisa Hearst Hagerman and his grandchildren, Tenney Hearst Espy, John Hearst Espy and Henry Hearst Hagerman. Services are pending. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. With appreciation, The Hearst Board of Directors

RITT--Alisha. January 24, 1926-November 1, 2011. Born Rosamonde Lewin in New York. Juilliard graduate, taught piano and ear training. Poet, musician, artist and activist, she had a great zest for life. Survived by son David Ritt (Deborah Bagg), granddaughter Sarah Ritt, and niece Jana Nishida.

Nobody killed more people, with more regret, than Lewis E. Lawes. The warden of the Sing Sing Correctional Facility for 21 years, Lawes supervised the executions of 303 prisoners, all the while condemning the practice of capital punishment as barbaric, inequitable and futile.

KRESTON--Judith Stern. 69, passed away gracefully at her home in New York surrounded by her loving family. Predeceased by her beloved husband Martin Kreston and survived by first husband Evan Stern. Daughter of the late Babe and Harry Goldner. Treasured mother of Russell Stern, Mark Stern and Douglas Stern. Adored step-mother to Rebecca McKinnon and Mark Kreston. Admired mother-in-law to Jennifer, Lisa, Andrew and Kim. Proud grandmother of Michael, Rachel, Zachary, Isabella, Matthew, Oliver, Ryan, Tyler, Connor and Caroline. Dearest sister of David Goldner. Judie attended New York University and was Vice President of Operations for National Office Supply in South Hackensack, New Jersey for 20 years. A respected leader, Judie was embraced by her staff and fellow workers. She was a devoted advocate and much-admired fundraiser for New York's Mount Sinai SAVI (Sexual Assault and Violence Intervention) program, as well as an appointed member of the Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board. Judie was embraced by a multitude of life-long friends. She exuded kindness, elegance, warmth, compassion and generosity to all she knew and loved. She embraced life and had a zest for living that will be missed by all. The happiest times in her life were when she was surrounded by family and friends. She had a rich appetite for learning, was a lover and collector of fine art, an avid reader, writer of poetry and she enriched the lives of everyone who knew her. Forever in our hearts, she will always be with us. Funeral services will be held at Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey on Tuesday, November 8th, 2011 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in memory of Judith Stern Kreston to Mount Sinai SAVI, Box 1670, One Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029.

Steve Mendelsohn is not a luminary to the many thousands of spectators of the New York City Marathon, but he is a familiar sight to its legions of officials and volunteers, having worked every race since 1976, when it first came to encompass all five boroughs. As the marathon's communications director, Mendelsohn, 67, organizes roughly 400 ham radio operators - volunteers who come from as far as Denver - and deploys them along the course to help with communications and to serve as a backup in case cellphones fail.

EVANS--Martin. The attorneys and staff of Herzfeld and Rubin, P.C. mourn the loss of this unique human being, our colleague and friend. Our hearts go out to his wife Meryle, to his son Steve, and grandchildren Arielle, Samuel and Danielle. Martin served as an Infantry Captain at Normandy for which he was awarded the Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor. This was a prelude to a career in the law in which honor and service were preeminent. The law truly was his life. As a lawyer and long time Supreme Court Justice, he was distinguished for his wisdom, learning, judgment, unflappable temperament and integrity. He was President of the Supreme Court Justices Association and an active participant in Bar Association projects, national and local. Until his last breath he was at work on projects to improve the judicial system, including as a member of the hard working Pattern Jury Instructions Committee. It was a privilege to have had him as a colleague after his retirement from the judiciary. Herbert Rubin, President

BP's plan to sell its majority stake in the Argentine oil producer Pan American Energy for $7.1 billion collapsed on Sunday after the would-be buyer, the Bridas Corporation, backed out. But BP, the British oil giant, said that the deal's collapse should have little significant effect on its financial health.

PARIS - Adored by many, reviled by some, offensive to most everyone, the French satirical weekly called Charlie Hebdo has long reveled in the arch, if simple, art of provocation. Its pages are filled with vulgar caricatures and caustic humor, lampooning politicians, entertainers and media personalities of all stripes, and the newspaper has found itself a frequent presence at Paris courts, accused on several dozen occasions of defamation or inciting hate. The world's religions have also been favorite targets of the paper, this being France, where state-mandated secularism is a sort of religion of its own. The cover page of one recent issue featured a cartoon of three rolls of toilet paper, labeled Bible, Koran and Torah, and the headline: ''In the toilet, all the religions.''

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. -- Like many states and local governments struggling to cut costs, Michigan hopes to replace some government employees with contract workers who will do the same job for less. Ginny Townsend, 41, took a job in January as a nursing assistant in the state-run home for veterans here. Technically, she works for a private company that supplies some employees to the veterans home under a state contract. She makes $10 an hour, about half the wage of the public employees working at the facility.

10 P.M. (Flix) ANTONIA'S LINE (1995) Part fable, part pastoral fantasy, this winner of the Oscar for best foreign film, written and directed by Marleen Gorris, follows the magically feminist bloodline of a Dutch matriarch (Willeke van Ammelrooy, above, with Jan Decleir) as she reflects, over the course of a single day, on her life after World War II. Els Dottermans portrays Danielle, Antonia's daughter, an introvert who isn't too shy to stab the village rapist with a pitchfork. Carolien Spoor, Esther Vriesendorp and Veerle van Overloop play Danielle's intellectually precocious daughter, Therese, at various points in her life. And Elsie de Brauw is Lara, Therese's tutor, with whom Danielle falls in love as she imagines her to be a living version of Botticelli's Venus. ''While the film rejects and even mocks ideas of organized religion, it has a solid faith in nature and destiny, as well as in the fundamental goodness of its women,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. ''It expresses that faith with serene confidence in the cycles of birth, death and replenishment that play out during the story.'' 3 P.M. (Cinemax) HOUSE OF SAND AND FOG (2003) Massoud Behrani (Ben Kingsley, left, in an Oscar-nominated role), an exiled Iranian military officer reduced to menial labor in his adopted homeland, and Kathy Nicolo (Jennifer Connelly), a house cleaner recovering from years of addiction and the breakup of her marriage, spar -- with tragic consequences -- over a modest piece of coastal California real estate to which both seem to have an equally legitimate claim in this directorial debut from Vadim Perelman, based on the novel by Andre Dubus III. Shohreh Aghdashloo is Nadi, the wife over whom Behrani exercises a brutal tyranny; Ron Eldard is Lester Burdon, the sheriff's deputy who evicted Kathy from her house and now wants to help her get it back. None of the central characters ''are particularly likable, but they all seem worthy of sympathy, in part because they remain capable of showing it,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Even as the conflict over the house escalates, Behrani, Lester and Kathy all hold on to compassion and decency, and even show signs of a willingness to relent. They seem to agree that no house is worth a human life, which makes the heavily foreshadowed final cataclysm especially painful and powerful.''

Sunday's race was dedicated to the memory of Grete Waitz, the nine-time winner who died of cancer in April at 57. Her husband, Jack, ran in her honor, his seventh marathon in New York. He finished in 3:50:41, his slowest clocked time but about a half-hour faster than he expected. ''The other six I raced; this one I just ran,'' he said. ''But I just wanted to finish.''

''Tower Heist,'' an $85 million action comedy starring Eddie Murphy and Ben Stiller, was clawed at the weekend box office, landing in second place behind the animated holdover ''Puss in Boots.'' The upset -- ''Tower Heist,'' co-financed by Universal Pictures and Relativity Media, was supposed to easily win the weekend -- does not bode well for the next Academy Awards. Mr. Murphy was tapped to host the February ceremony, an eyebrow-arching move justified in part because ''Tower Heist'' was expected to give him a career lift after a series of duds. And the movie's director, Brett Ratner, is a producer of the next Oscars.

KEY PERFORMANCE The 36-yard punt by T. J. Conley that pinned the Bills at their 1 did more than ultimately improve the Jets' field position on their ensuing drive, which ended in a 50-yard field goal by Nick Folk. It symbolized the Jets' outstanding special-teams performances. Folk made 2 of 3 field goals. Joe McKnight averaged 41.5 yards on two kickoff returns. And the Jets' kickoff coverage held their old friend Brad Smith in check, never allowing him to break a long run.

A 16th century painting on loan to a Florida museum was seized Friday by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents because it is suspected of having been looted during World War II. The Pinacoteca di Brera in Milan, Italy, had loaned Girolamo Romano's 1538 painting, ''Christ Carrying the Cross Dragged by a Rogue,'' to the Mary Brogan Museum of Art and Science in Tallahassee in March as part of an exhibition of Baroque painting. Once on display, descendants of a former owner, Giuseppe Gentili, identified the painting as one that had been looted by the collaborationist Vichy government in France and illegally sold at auction in 1941, after the Gentili family had been forced to flee the Nazis. The Pinacoteca acquired the painting in 1998.

History was made Sunday in the New York City Marathon wheelchair divisions. Masazumi Soejima became the first Japanese champion in any of the marathon's races by winning the men's division in 1 hour 31 minutes 41 seconds, his personal best in New York. Soejima's previous best time was 1:37:31 last year, when he finished second to David Weir of Britain by two seconds. In the women's race, Amanda McGrory of Champaign, Ill., set the course record in 1:50:24.

Nothing causes New Orleanians to wake up in night sweats like the prospect of their beloved city turning into a Houston or an Atlanta or some other well-adjusted city. While the city itself is still trying to find the balance, a wave of new cocktail bars, gastropubs and hotels are striking it in their own way.

Patti Stoecker is a hoarder, the rarefied kind. In the 1980s, Ms. Stoecker, then a model, used to party all night at the Mudd Club, wearing, as often as not, one of her mother's silky old slips. By the early '90s, she had begun collecting her own '40s-era variations, amassing them by the score and tie-dyeing them on her stove top in Easter-egg hues. For a time she consigned her slinky designs to local secondhand shops, but before long she was selling them from her house, against a dreamy backdrop of mottled peach-tone walls.

David Strettell, the proprietor of Dashwood Books, is a quiet champion of self-published material by photographers and artists of nearly every aesthetic persuasion. He is now cementing his growing reputation as a publisher in his own right with a limited-edition series of bite-size monographs - think a zine with the production values of a book - that he plans to put out more or less annually. The 7-by-9.5-inch format is fixed; the agenda, on the other hand, is entirely open-ended - an opportunity for Strettell to introduce new work, shine a light on older work and to let his eye wander. (Contributors are even encouraged to bring their own art director.) Among the first seven titles are "Back to Mystery City," Andreas Laszlo Konrath's photos of the Perus crew, a posse of Helsinki skaters; "Color'd," Jim Mangan's scenic nudes; and Strettell's personal selection, "Soviet Beauty Queens From the Archive of Modern Conflict," anonymous images from various pageants and the Leningrad Beauty Institute during the height of perestroika.

Norbert Leo Butz ("Catch Me if You Can") and Elizabeth Reaser ("Twilight") will co-star in Second Stage's production of Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize-winning play "How I Learned to Drive," the theater announced Tuesday. Directing duties will go to Kate Whoriskey, the former artistic director of Seattle's Intiman Theater, which laid off its entire staff and closed its doors in April. (In August the theater took a step toward reopening when it hired a consulting artistic director.) The show is to begin previews on Jan. 24, 2012, with opening night set for Feb. 13.

ABC was the most-watched network Monday night, and CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic as ratings for almost the entire network programming slate improved from last week's poor Halloween performance. A two-hour edition of "Dancing With the Stars" on ABC averaged just over 18 million total viewers, by far the largest audience on the night. Meanwhile, "Two and a Half Men" on CBS has leveled out nicely at 14.5 million viewers while remaining the highest-rated Monday program in the 18-to-49 demo.

Karen Crouse points out in this column that Steve Williams's recent statement about his former boss Tiger Woods revealed a number of problems for professional golf, not the least of which was the acceptance by the PGA and European tours and Williams's current boss, Adam Scott, of what many saw as a racist comment. The incident did manage to take the focus away from Fred Couples's decision to skip over Keegan Bradley, a three-time winner this year, to give Woods a spot on the Presidents Cup team. So, should Williams's alleged joke be seen as just part of bawdy awards dinner banter, or should he have been suspended, fined or fired?

AT the Fivestory pop-up, on the third floor of an Upper East Side town house, shoppers will get a sneak peek at what Claire Distenfeld plans for the boutique she will open there in February. Ms. Distenfeld, who was raised on the U.E.S., fled an art-world job to hone her sophisticated retail aesthetic. For the preview, she filled two rooms with contemporary wares in a range of prices that includes, yes, affordable. There are leather dresses by Lyn Devon, a peplum dress by the Russian designer Vika Gazinskaya, Jerome Rousseau pumps, Mawi jewelry and playful gifts like Seletti porcelain tableware. "Everyone asks why I chose a retail boutique and not e-commerce," she said. "I have a romantic idea that the one-on-one experience with products needs to be revived." Hiring the interior designer Ryan Korban, known for the Alexander Wang shop, and who has already added a downtown finish with polished black floors, shows that the lady means business.

Today, the Demisch Danant gallery in New York opens "Mobilier National," the first American exhibition to examine the furniture that was created in the 20th century for the Mobilier National, a centuries-old entity of the French Republic that was conceived for the decoration of its palaces and official residences, and to promote the best in French decorative arts and design. Among the more than 20 pieces on display (which were made between 1964 and 1981) are Olivier Mourgue's Montreal chair and table, which were designed for Expo 67, and furnishings designed by Pierre Paulin for Georges Pompidou's private apartments at the Élysée Palace.

Networks broke in for live coverage, cable networks hit the hyperdrive button and pundits played Ping-Pong with the verdict deep into the night, but audiences seem to shrug. The popular perception is that the Green Bay Packers are great because of Aaron Rodgers and the passing offense. And for good reason: Rodgers (and by extension, the entire Green Bay passing offense) is on a record-breaking pace. Rodgers leads the league in completion percentage, touchdowns, touchdown percentage, yards per attempt, adjusted net yards per attempt and adjusted yards per attempt. He's averaging 11.2 adjusted yards per attempt, the highest mark after a team's first eight games of any quarterback in over 50 years.

Wall Street bonuses are set to fall by an average of 20 to 30 percent this year from a year ago, according to a closely watched compensation survey - the weakest bonus season since the financial crisis and a reflection of the leaner times confronting the industry. Those who work in trading and investment banking - usually Wall Street's most profitable businesses, although struggling this year - will experience the sharpest drops in pay, said Alan Johnson, managing director of Johnson Associates, the firm that conducted the survey.

CRANE--Edward M. Died peacefully on November 6. Husband of Jean. Service to be held on November 12, 2011 at 12 noon at Trinity Church, Princeton, NJ.

DEFENDING THEIR DECISION Citigroup and the Securities and Exchange Commission filed legal papers on Monday defending their settlement of accusations of fraud in the bank's sale of mortgage-backed securities. The two sides filed responses to questions raised by Judge Jed S. Rakoff, left, last month over the propriety of the agreement. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Citigroup paid $285 million to settle civil charges that it had misled customers by selling them bad mortgage securities at the peak of the housing bubble. A hearing on the settlement before Judge Rakoff is set for Wednesday. PETER LATTMAN

A nationwide study has found that previously healthy children hospitalized with flu were significantly more likely to die if they were also infected with MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The findings are important because MRSA, which can cause skin and internal infections, is a growing concern among healthy children. MRSA ''used to be seen only in hospitalized people or people who worked in health care facilities,'' said Dr. Michael Cappello, a professor of pediatric infectious disease at Yale. ''This is no longer the case.''

REMER--Michael D. Passed away November 6, 2011. Devoted husband to Patricia, beloved father to Abby and Harry, cherished brother to Rita Mendelsohn. Donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering or Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

TIETZ--Albert U.,91, of Forest Hills, NY and most recently of New Rochelle, NY passed away peacefully on November 6, 2011 at his residence. Mr. Tietz was born on February 13, 1920 in Cologne, Germany to Alfred Leonhard and Margaret C. Tietz. Albert received his formal education in Germany and The Netherlands. During World War ll Albert served with the R.A.F. in the Middle East. On May 28, 1949 Mr. Tietz married Esther Faerber in Neuilly, France. They resided in Forest Hills, NY for over 50 years. By profession, Albert was an Assistant Treasurer with Associated Metals and Minerals Corp. He was also active in numerous social welfare and elder care organizations relating to Jewish refugees and Nazi persecutees, such as SelfHelp, the Leo Baeck Institute, the American Federation of Jews from Central Europe, and the New York Foundation for Nursing Homes, now known as the New York Foundation for Eldercare. He was instrumental in establishing the Margaret Tietz Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, founded in 1971 to care for aging Holocaust survivors, where he served as an officer and board member until 2005. Survivors of Mr. Tietz include his wife Esther, son Michael F. Tietz and his wife Amy, daughter Monica A. Lewis and her husband Peter, and three grandchildren, Jeremy, Amanda, and Benjamin. Albert was predeceased by a brother, Leonard Deeds, and a sister, Herta Frenkel-Tietz. A memorial service will be held on November 9, 2011 at 11:00am at George T. Davis Funeral Home in New Rochelle, NY to honor Albert's life. The family will be sitting shiva at the home of Michael and Amy Tietz immediately after the service until 8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Albert Tietz's memory to the New York Foundation for Eldercare, P.O. Box 750236, Forest Hills, NY 11375-0236.

The 2013 mayoral election is still two years away, but the first television advertisement of the campaign will make its debut on Tuesday. Tom Allon, a newspaper publisher who is something of a long-shot candidate, is running the ad in an attempt to gain some much-needed name recognition to establish himself as an outsider and a pragmatist who is not beholden to political bosses.

IKEDA--Kentaro. Longtime resident of Larchmont, NY, and well know tea importer, passed away suddenly at his home on November 6, 2011. He was 92 years old. Kentaro was the oldest son of Kenzo Ikeda who was the first man to bring Japanese green tea to the United States market while representing Japan at the Expo in St. Louis in 1918. After seeing the U.S. on that trip he decided to educate his sons here. Kentaro entered the Lawrenceville Preparatory School in New Jersey in 1938. He then went on to Princeton University and graduated in the class of 1944. After teaching Japanese language for nine years at Yale University, Kentaro decided to follow in his father's footsteps. He imported tea for the US market and supplied major packers including Lipton Tea, Tetley Tea and Nestle tea companies. Kentaro earned a reputation for being an extremely honest and dedicated, as well as respected, and recognized his contribution to the tea industry. He is survived by his beloved wife Yoko Ikeda (professionally known as: Young Yang Chung) a well-known writer and textile historian who established the Embroidery Museum and holds PhD from NYU. Funeral services are private.

The board of the Public Theater announced its new executive director on Monday, entrusting its $18.5 million operating budget and other business operations to a somewhat unusual pick: Patrick Willingham, the former president and chief operating officer of Blue Man Productions, a for-profit company that turned the Off Broadway production ''Blue Man Group'' into an international entertainment attraction. Both the Public's artistic director, Oskar Eustis, and Mr. Willingham said in telephone interviews on Monday that he was a counterintuitive selection: Mr. Willingham has never been a senior executive or financial officer at a nonprofit theater before, nor does he have experience in theater fund-raising or producing a season.

1:30 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble answered Amazon's challenge in the tablet wars on Monday, introducing a $249 color device called the Nook Tablet. Speaking at Barnes & Noble's store in Manhattan's Union Square, William Lynch, the company's chief executive, set the new Nook directly up against Amazon's recently released Kindle Fire, promoting what he described as the Nook's advantages in memory and multimedia capability.

FAULKNER--Walter Thomas, of Larchmont, NY, died November 4, 2011 at the age of 83. Mr. Faulkner was born September 17, 1928 in New Haven, CT to Walter and Alice (McGushin) Faulkner. Raised in Hamden, CT, he graduated from Hopkins School in New Haven, after which he joined the U.S. Army and served in Japan during the postwar occupation. He then obtained his undergraduate degree at Providence College and his law degree from Columbia Law School. He had a long and distinguished career practicing corporate and securities law with the law firms Rogers, Hoge & Hills and Kelley Drye & Warren. He served for many years as a member of the Boards of Directors of Bacardi Corporation and Raymond International, Inc. and as Corporate Secretary of Bacardi and Sterling Drug, Inc. He was active in his community, serving as a member of the Board of Governors of Sound Shore Medical Center, a member of the Village of Larchmont Planning Commission and in many other capacities. He was a longtime member of the Larchmont Yacht Club, where he served as Secretary for 22 years under nine different Commodores. His wise counsel, good humor, warmth, judgment and generosity will be greatly missed by family, friends and colleagues. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Joan, of Larchmont, NY; sons John of New York, NY, Andy of New York, NY, and George of Pleasantville, NY; daughter Susan of Portland, OR; eight grandchildren, Stephen, Brian, Elizabeth, Patrick, Anna, Lucy, Henry, and Lily; and brothers Richard of North Haven, CT, and David of New Haven, CT. Funeral service will be held Thursday, November 10 at 11am at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont. Visiting hours are Wednesday, November 9 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Augustine's Church, 18 Cherry Avenue, Larchmont, 10538; the Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, 10538; or Sound Shore Medical Center Foundation, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, NY, 10802.

HEARST--John Randolph, Jr.,A trustee of The Hearst Family Trust and a member of the Board of Directors of Hearst Corporation and the two Hearst Foundations, died November 4 in New York City. He was 77. A grandson of William Randolph Hearst, John R. Bunky Hearst, Jr., as he was called most of his life, served as a member of the company's Board of Directors for 44 years. He was appointed a trustee of The Hearst Family Trust in April 1972, the same year he joined the Hearst Foundations as a director. John was always very devoted to the company founded by his grandfather, said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. He was equally devoted to a number of charitable organizations in the New York area. Those of us who served with him on the various Hearst Boards remember his great wit and interest in everything the company and Foundations were doing. Bunky will be greatly missed. Hearst enjoyed a long career with the Corporation, starting as a news photographer for the Hearst-owned New York Daily Mirror in the 1950s, as well as for the Hearst Newspapers division. In recognition of his interest in photojournalism, Hearst Newspapers commissioned a traveling trophy, the John R. Hearst Jr. Prize for Photo Excellence, awarded to photographers for Hearst Newspapers. An ardent boating enthusiast most of his life, he also served as an editor for Motor Boating & Sailing magazine, which was a Hearst publication. Born in New York City on December 8, 1933, to John Randolph Hearst, the third son of William Randolph Hearst, and Gretchen Wilson, Hearst often spent time in his youth at Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif., and greatly valued his time personally spent with his grandfather, the legendary W.R. Hearst. In 1960, John Hearst wrote an article for Reader's Digest entitled Life With Grandfather, in which he detailed their relationship. The younger Hearst's uncle, William Randolph Hearst, Jr., noted: The two talked newspapering a lot. Hearst said that if he learned one thing from his grandfather, it was the power of newspapers. Known for his sense of humor, Hearst enjoyed telling the story of how he had acquired his unusual nickname. He told the New York Times in 1983 that a cartoon character in his grandfather's newspaper, the New York Journal-American, was to blame. I used to wear huge baby bonnets, Hearst was quoted as saying. And my godfather took one look at me and said, He looks like Bunky in the funny papers.' The name stuck. On his 21st birthday, Hearst decided that he no longer resembled a Bunky, he told the Times. But it was too late; the nickname was his for life. I may as well wallow in it, Hearst said. Besides, I'd rather be a Bunky than a Junior. He is survived by his daughter Lisa Hearst Hagerman and his grandchildren, Tenney Hearst Espy, John Hearst Espy and Henry Hearst Hagerman. Services are pending. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. With appreciation, The Hearst Board of Directors
REDPATH--Nancy Shaw Miller, died November 1, age 104 years. Beloved wife of Robert and mother of Rob, Nancy, Bill and Jeannie.

JANOVIC--Joseph, dear son of Florence and Evan, devoted father of Valerie and Max, beloved brother of Adam, sister in law of Jules and fun game-playing uncle to Phoebe, Graham and Luka. DUBUQUE, Iowa - Mitt Romney, clad in Tommy Bahama blue jeans and a blue plaid work shirt, took that stage at a metal fabrication shop here and offered two different scenarios a year from now. Referring to the ''Obama great recession,'' Mr. Romney told the crowd at Giese Manufacturing that that they could turn on their television sets a year from now to the headline: ''President Obama has been reelected to a second term.'' Or, he explained, ''the alternative, of course, is that you turn on your TV about a year from now, and instead of seeing the Obama camp celebrating, you'll see something on the TV that says 'Mitt is It.'''

An obituary on March 15 about Owsley Stanley, one of the first people to mass-produce LSD, misstated the date of his death, using information from his family. It was March 12, not March 13. Mr. Stanley's son pointed out the error in an e-mail on Friday. (The error was repeated in an Op-Ed article on March 19 and in a report in the Week in Review section on March 20.)

PECK--Barbara. With deep sadness, JBFCS mourns the passing of Barbara Peck, a trustee and supporter for over two decades. The curtain could once again come down on a resuscitated version of ''At the Movies,'' Roger Ebert warned in a blog post on Sunday night, writing that the long-running film criticism program will end after its current season unless it finds new funding. The public television series, which Mr. Ebert hosted in various incarnations with Gene Siskel from the 1970s through the 1990s, was canceled by the studio that produced it in March of 2010. (At that time, its hosts were Michael Phillips of The Chicago Tribune and A. O. Scott of The New York Times.) After many months of lamentations for ''At the Movies'' and its democratizing effects, for good or ill, on cinema and on criticism, Mr. Ebert announced that September that he was giving a thumb's up to a new version of the series, called ''Ebert Presents At The Movies.'' It made its premiere in January, and has featured regular reviews by Christy Lemire of The Associated Press and Ignatiy Vishnevetsky, a writer for Mubi.com, as well as segments with Mr. Ebert.

Martin A. Nisenholtz, a senior vice president at The New York Times Company who helped start the Web site for the company's namesake newspaper and later carried out a plan to charge online readers, is retiring at the end of the year, the company announced Monday. In a message to the staff, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the chairman, and Janet L. Robinson, the chief executive, noted Mr. Nisenholtz's role in shaping The Times's Web strategy from its infancy. When Mr. Nisenholtz joined the company in 1995, they said, ''we had zero Web page views. Indeed, we had zero Web users. Further, we had no Web revenue. Today, thanks in large measure to Martin's vision and leadership, our digital numbers are dramatically different.''

FRANKEL--Harriet S.,born February 8, 1928 in Ventnor, New Jersey, passed away on October 25, 2011. She is survived by her loving, beloved husband and best friend of 56 years, Irv, and two children; Dana Kraus and Jim Frankel, three grandsons; Nick Kraus, Nate Kraus and Preston Frankel. Harriet's was a life fully lived. A beautiful, vivacious woman, she studied acting at Bennington College, and moved rapidly in to television roles in such early dramas as "Martin Kane Private Eye." She also hosted a radio program called the "Harriet Lord Show", and was a spokeswoman for Sano Cigarettes. Harriet was an early executive in the Mad Men era of advertising, which she navigated with flair, both at advertising agencies and in sales for national publications. Always a theater-lover, Harriet served on the Board of Manhattan Theater Club and was a member of the Players Club. She was an avid gardener and volunteered at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park. She loved painting, her dogs and cooking, and pursued all interests with passion, making wonderful friends along the way. "Verve" sums up her actions as a professional, an enthusiast, a friend, a wife, a mother and a grandmother. We miss her dearly. Harriet's family ask that donations be made to: The Central Park Conservancy Conservatory Garden Fund in Memory of Harriet Frankel, and sent to; Central Park Conservancy, c/o Development, 14 East 60th Street, New York City 10022.

FAIRECHILD--Diana. November 5, 2011. Author and early pioneer activist for airline passenger safety, died in New York City following a brief illness. She was 67. For over 20 years, Diana steadfastly advocated for passengers' right to nontoxic conditions aboard airplanes. Her 21-year career as an international flight attendant was cut short in 1987 when she was medically grounded with injuries from unregulated pesticide spraying in aircraft cabins. In 1992, she published the best-selling book Jet Smart which exposed the previously unknown health hazards of flying and forced government mandated changes in airline policies. Diana was born in NYC in 1944. She graduated from Boston University after spending a year at the Sorbonne in Paris. She lived in Hawaii for 23 years before moving back to Manhattan in 2007. Diana was well-known for her wit, her charm and her lifetime love affair with writing books, teaching seminars and dancing the tango.
KRESTON--Judith Stern. To my great friend of 50 years. Your sensitivity, compassion, grace and elegance will always remain in our hearts. Love, Debra and Saul Martin Posner

After a long struggle, ownership of a Bronx building known as the birthplace of hip-hop, which had fallen into neglect and foreclosure, was taken over on Monday by a group that specializes in preserving working-class housing. The building at 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the Morris Heights neighborhood was, in the early 1970s, the home of D.J. Kool Herc, whose community room parties were pivotal to the early development of hip-hop. But in recent years, the 102-unit complex had become a symbol for aggressive investment practices and property neglect, so much so that Senator Charles E. Schumer recently called it ''the birthplace of predatory equity.''

It is probably news to her rival Republicans, but in Michele Bachmann's eyes their policies mark them as no better than ''frugal socialists.'' Mrs. Bachmann made the assertion in an attempt to position herself as the true conservative standard-bearer in a speech on Monday, a role she has lost to a succession of other candidates. Addressing the Family Research Council, a socially conservative Christian group, she said, ''We cannot preserve liberty for ourselves and our posterity if the choice in next November is between a frugal socialist and an out-of-control socialist.''

A few days before MF Global's collapse, regulators stationed at the firm were assured its books were in order. Their boss, Gary Gensler, was not convinced. A former Goldman Sachs partner who once passed the test for certified public accountants, he bore into the numbers himself and grew uneasy with the firm's finances.

Robert De Niro, who has played all manner of menace to society, may next play Bernard L. Madoff. HBO confirmed Monday that Mr. De Niro is attached to play the Ponzi-schemer in a made-for-television film that is in development for the cable channel. But it cautioned that the film has not yet been put into production. Mr. De Niro and Jane Rosenthal, of Tribeca Productions, are executive producers of the project, which is based in part on ''The Wizard of Lies: Bernie Madoff and the Death of Trust,'' a book by Diana B. Henriques of The New York Times. The producers also recently obtained the rights to use another book, ''Truth and Consequences: Life Inside the Madoff Family,'' as source material. That book, by Laurie Sandell, was written with the cooperation of Mr. Madoff's son Andrew. John Burnham Schwartz, best-known for the novel ''Reservation Road,'' is writing the screenplay.

The revolving door of justice continued to spin for Lindsay Lohan as the troubled actress spent about five hours in a Los Angeles County jail before her release on Monday morning, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, who has lately made more headlines for the amount of nudity she will or will not show in a coming Playboy pictorial than for her film work, was booked into the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif., at 8:50 p.m. on Sunday, The A.P. said. She was sentenced on Wednesday to a 30-day jail sentence after she was kicked out of a community service program at a women's shelter, but was not expected to serve the full sentence because of overcrowding.

9 P.M. (13) SYRIA UNDERCOVER As the death toll from the revolution in Syria nears 3,000, Ramita Navai, above, a reporter for ''Frontline,'' travels incognito to meet with members of the opposition movement and experiences life as a fugitive when she is trapped in a safe house with three coordinators on the government's most-wanted list. Also, Anthony Shadid, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times, talks about how President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has managed to hold on amid the Arab unrest. In ''Women, War & Peace,'' at 10 on Channels 13 and 49, modern warfare and the unprecedented uses of women as primary targets is discussed by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and her predecessors Condoleezza Rice and Madeleine K. Albright; Leymah Gbowee, the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize winner; Fadila Memisevic, the Bosnian war crimes investigator; and Zainab Salbi, founder of Women for Women International, which helps female war survivors rebuild their lives. Geena Davis narrates. 11:35 A.M. (Cinemax) AVATAR (2009) This ''trippy joy ride about the end of life -- our moviegoing life included,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times, took decades of dreaming and four years of making (with a $230 million production budget) by the director James Cameron. Sam Worthington plays a paraplegic former Marine who is transported from a wheelchair into a 10-foot, blue-skinned, part-alien and part-human body, the better to infiltrate a distant moon that harbors a valuable substance called unobtainium. Alas, he falls in love with both this lush dreamscape and one of its slinky inhabitants (Zoë Saldana). ''If the story of a paradise found and potentially lost feels resonant, it's because 'Avatar' is as much about our Earth as the universe that Mr. Cameron has invented,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''But the movie's truer meaning is in the audacity of its filmmaking.''

Nathan Horton had two goals and an assist to lead the Boston Bruins to a 6-2 victory over the visiting Islanders. Forward Wojtek Wolski will have surgery Tuesday to repair a sports hernia and is expected to be out for four weeks, the Rangers announced. JEFF Z. KLEIN
THE FACTS The old saw about drinking eight glasses of water a day for overall health is widely considered a myth.

Stomach acid has long been blamed for acid reflux, heartburn and other ills. But now some experts are starting to think that the problems may lie not just in the acid coming up from the stomach but in the food going down. The idea has been getting a lot of attention lately, notably in popular books like ''Crazy Sexy Diet'' and ''The Acid Alkaline Food Guide'' -- which claim that readers can improve their health by focusing on the balance of acid and alkaline in the diet, mostly by eating more vegetables and certain fruits and fewer meats and processed foods.

An article in some editions on Saturday about a complaint by dozens of organizations that represent disabled people over New York City's threat to withdraw Medicaid services misstated the time period during which the city was sometimes spending $150,000 to keep people at home when another program would cost less, according to a whistle-blower. That was the cost for a year, not a day.

JONAS--Dr. Arthur Herbert Writer, composer, musician, educator, foodie, Dr. Arthur Herbert Jonas died October 26 of natural causes. He was 81. Grew up on Christopher Street, New York City. Educated at Little Red Schoolhouse, Elizabeth Irwin, Allegheny, Harvard, NYU. Collaborated with illustrator Aliki on children's books: "Archimedes and His Wonderful Discoveries;" "New Ways in Math;" "More New Ways in Math." Reprinted for decades. Translated into 14 languages, from Chinese to Norwegian. Co-author of "Teaching for Thinking." Beloved educator: 6th grade teacher in Scarsdale, NY; Principal of Wilson School, West Caldwell, NJ; Principal of Kean University Demonstration School; Chairman of Kean University Special Education Department. Played piano, guitar, banjo, accordion, harmonica. Composed music for piano set to Lord Byron's poem "She Walks in Beauty." Multi-talented across platforms. Would regularly recite poetry while on the treadmill. As his own sound app, could identify conductor and artist while listening to WQXR. Thought analogy was the highest form of intelligent communication and was its most gifted practitioner. Inspired by Julia Child to enter and win many recipe contests. Baseball fan always, passionate Mets fan from their beginning. Taught his children Nicole, Timothy, and Daniel to keep score. Memorial feast held at Mile End officiated by his daughter Nicole, who dearly loved him. At his request, listened to "Cavalleria Rusticana," his favorite.

How much would you pay for advice that turned out to be questionable? Would about $81 million sound unreasonable? That's how much Hewlett-Packard is estimated to have paid out in fees to its investment bankers in the last two years for advising it on a series acquisitions that have all been vocally scrutinized by investors. During the same period, Hewlett-Packard's market value has fallen by more than $40 billion.

An article on Monday about the possibility that San Francisco voters may elect the city's first Chinese-American mayor today misstated the name of the news organization that reported on the possible issues in the campaign of Edwin M. Lee, a longtime city official now serving as interim mayor. It is The Bay Citizen, not The Bay Observer. (The Bay Citizen produces a twice-weekly local section in the Bay Area editions of The New York Times.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by state and local governments to save money by using contract workers misstated, in some copies, the financial hardships of one such contract worker, Ginny Townsend. She said she was raising four grandchildren under 11 with her unemployed sister and could not support them without the $300 in food stamps she collects every month; she did not say that she could support them without the food stamps.

A picture caption last Tuesday with a review of the second program of the Fall for Dance Festival, at City Center, misidentified the dancers shown. They are Anneli Binder and Nathan Goodman -- not Liam Riddick and Hannah Kidd, who are fellow members of the Richard Alston Dance Company.

Two years ago, the state of Indiana cut off funds to a museum in Dana, Ind., that honors Ernie Pyle, the acclaimed war correspondent. A local group is now managing the site, which still has a lot to offer.

Almost immediately after what will probably be remembered as the Bill Buckner moment of primary debates, when Gov. Rick Perry of Texas literally forgot which governmental agencies he would cut and concluded his answer with a sheepish "Oops," Mr. Perry's stock on the betting market Intrade dropped in half. My Thursday column argues that we need to absorb more of an education culture, like the one so common in the Confucian belt of East Asia. I make the argument partly through the story of a teenage girl named Phung who won my heart with her amazing work ethic and vaulting ambition. I'm pretty sure that I'll be deluged with readers who want to help Phung, and so an aid group named Room to Read -- the subject of my Sunday article about it and its founder, John Wood -- has set up a fund to help Phung and girls like her. You can find out more at its website here.

By the end of the Civil War, William T. Sherman was one of the most important and celebrated Union commanders, and the most reviled in the Confederacy. During the last year of the conflict, his army conquered Atlanta, reversing a flagging Union war effort and securing Abraham Lincoln's re-election. After that his men scorched much of Georgia in his famous March to the Sea, then cut a huge swath up through the Carolinas. Not only did his army destroy men and material, but Sherman articulated a ruthless policy of destruction that deeply demoralized Southern morale. He gained perpetual infamy in the South as the grim reaper of the Union war effort, a task he undertook quite consciously, with both anger and joy.

"Youth & Beauty: the Art of America in the 20s" is an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum (till Jan. 29) full of low-key charms and even some revelations. Take Gerald Murphy's 1924 painting "Razor": a vividly rendered matchbox, Parker fountain pen, and Gillette safety razor, looking so fresh and modern, and yet, it's an elegy to everyday tools beautifully rendered but quaint in today's plastic, junk-tastic universe.

When Jill Demling was a little girl growing up in Boston, she would cry so hysterically if the Celtics lost that her mother threatened to take the TV away. "It's only a game," Mom would say. "I knew everything about him."

Last night Donatella Versace presented her highly anticipated collection for H&M to a full house that included many of fashion's most valuable players (the photographers Bruce Weber and Patrick Demarchelier; the makeup artist Pat McGrath; the designers Christopher Kane and Alexander Wang; the model Coco Rochas) and a handful of best-dressed celebrities (Blake Lively, Sofia Coppola, Jessica Alba) at the "Versace for H&M Hall on the Hudson," a converted pier on Manhattan's West Side Highway. The collection, studded with gold medallions and covered in loud, tropical prints, gave a respectful nod to Versace's 1980s self while simultaneously clocking a lot of what's trending now, namely dynamic prints, minibags, head scarves, chokers and flouro pastels. The men's clothes were equally colorful - a hot pink suit was the standout - and made the best use of the collection's signature menacing-preppy alligator print. After the show, guests were ushered into a glittering disco ball hall and treated to performances by Nicki Minaj and Prince (Prince!), who sang odes to the Italian fashion house and its signora before finishing the set with an epic "Purple Rain" singalong.

While his 2010 feature "Black Swan" could have presaged a career transition into ballet, Darren Aronofsky is sticking with the cinema for the time being. NAIROBI - When on Oct. 16 Kenya sent hundreds of troops into Somalia, its perennially problematic neighbor, it was going to war for the first time in three decades. The operation was ostensibly a response to recent raids by Somali militants into northern Kenya to kidnap tourists and aid workers. More likely, though, the Kenyan government seized the occasion to try to root out the Shabab, a group of Islamist insurgents, which has become increasingly meddlesome and dangerous. But it is stepping into a political mess, and for the moment the Kenyan government seems to be shooting from the hip.

How often do you think hard about the adults who work with your children? The teachers and coaches who lead sports teams, church groups and other programs make our lives as parents easier, and they make our children's lives better. They're often parents themselves, and many of us find ourselves in coaching roles, working with other people's children. I tend to take for granted my children's safety when I send them off to a hockey game in a coach's car, or to an after-school club run by a teacher - until something happens to remind me to be less sanguine.

The 5,000 employees of the Central Bureau of Investigation, India's anti-corruption agency, seem to have an ever-expanding portfolio of high-profile cases. The agency's investigations run the gamut from the illegal mining case in the Bellary district of Karnataka state, to the tumultuous 2G spectrum allocation scam, to a new probe in the airline industry.For more than three decades the C.B.I. headquarters sat nestled next to the ministries it sometimes targeted, in the North Block of the government secretariat, a sandstone labyrinth of offices built during the British Raj era. But this April, the C.B.I. moved into a swanky, modern 11-story glass building, modeled after the Interpol headquarters in Lyons, France. The building houses 2,000 employees, and looks more like a multinational company's headquarters than a typical Delhi government office.

JOHANNESBURG - On April 28, 2008, the partially clothed body of Eudy Simelane was found in a ditch in Kwa Thema, a black township near Johannesburg. A national soccer star and a well-known lesbian human rights activist, she had been beaten up, gang-raped and stabbed 25 times in the face, chest and legs - even under the feet. This past April, in a case remarkably similar, the body of another lesbian was found in an alley in Kwa Thema. Noxolo Nogwaza's head had been bashed to a pulp. Her eyeballs were found outside their sockets.

In what may turn out to be one of the abiding ironies of global geopolitics, leadership on climate change seems to have suddenly passed from the developed to the developing world, as has public anxiety about the damaging effects of a changing climate.As recently as the Copenhagen summit in late 2009, the West blamed large developing countries such as China and India for scuppering the chances of a "grand agreement" to curb the emission of greenhouse gases. Poor developing countries argued they needed the right to pollute in order to catch up to the West in terms of economic development, while the rich nations clucked that the world could ill afford more carbon emissions.On the flip side, at the Cancun summit a year later, India's then environment minister, Jairam Ramesh, was pilloried in the domestic press, and accused, by his own admission, of "caving in to the United States" in the final near-consensus plan that was agreed.

Is physical frailty inevitable as we grow older? That question preoccupies scientists and the middle-aged, particularly when they become the same people. Until recently, the evidence was disheartening. A large number of studies in the past few years showed that after age 40, people typically lose 8 percent or more of their muscle mass each decade, a process that accelerates significantly after age 70. Less muscle mass generally means less strength, mobility and among the elderly, independence. It also has been linked with premature mortality.

STERN--Joanne. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of their beloved and long time trustee Joanne M. Stern. Joanne joined the Board of Trustees in 1970 and served on a myriad of committees over her forty-one year association with the Museum. She Chaired the Prints and Illustrated Books Committee (1973-1998), and served on the Executive Committee, the Development Committee, the House Committee, the Committees on Drawings, Film, Publications, Education, Archives and Exhibitions. Additionally, Joanne was the President of the International Council from 1971-86, and later served as a Vice Chairman and President Emerita. Her long time devotion was especially felt and warmly appreciated by the staff of the Department of Prints and Illustrated Books throughout her twenty-five year tenure as their Committee Chair. Her service on these committees and others was always exemplary and she brought a level of wit and dedication that will be sorely missed. In addition to her many commitments to MoMA, Joanne served on the Board of Trustees for the School of American Ballet, the Citizens Committee for Children, and the Visiting Committee for the Smith College Museum of Art. Additionally, Joanne was a trustee for the American Association of University Women Educational Foundation. We will miss not only her devotion to MoMA but we will miss her delightful stories about her years working as a photo editor for LOOK Magazine as well as her vast knowledge of and passion for the art world. We send our condolences to her children Nicholas, Thomas and Peggy, her step-children Chris and Catherine, and their children and families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

REMER--Michael. Cowan DeBaets Abrahams & Sheppard profoundly mourns the death of our colleague and dear friend, Michael Remer. Mike has been Of Counsel to our firm for nearly 20 years, during which time he represented his clients as a trusted advisor and served as a mentor to his colleagues here, drawing on his many years of experience and sound judgment. His clients included some of the most important theater, recording, and publishing artists of the past half century, many of whom he had represented for most of his and their careers, and many of whom he counted as life-long friends. Mike was an impeccable lawyer--careful, thorough, and patient--and, more important, was a thoroughly civilized man who appreciated a beautiful turn of phrase by Mark Twain or Groucho Marx and a perfectly executed relay throw from right field to nail a runner at home plate with equal admiration and respect. We'll be the poorer without him.

A report in the World Briefing column on Oct. 13 about criticism by the European Union enlargement office of Turkey's reaction to Cyprus's drilling for gas in the Mediterranean misstated Turkey's position on the future of Cyprus. Turkey, which refuses to recognize the Greek Cypriot government as the sole representative of the disputed island, has called for a two-nation state in a federal structure that would include Turkish Cypriots in the north and Greek Cypriots in the south; it has not called for two separate states.

The easy explanation for MF Global's downfall is that it was killed by Jon S. Corzine's risky trading bets. Yet MF Global was torpedoed not only by Mr. Corzine but by its board. The board at MF Global is highly sophisticated and experienced. It includes two former senior executives from HSBC, the former chief financial officer of the Aon Corporation and a top member of the private equity firm J. C. Flowers & Company.
