10:17 p.m. | Updated Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that it was time for Washington to take serious steps to address the federal deficit, starting with a measure certain to be unpopular with some of his financial industry friends: a change to the way that hedge fund managers are taxed. Mr. Bloomberg, in a speech in Washington at the liberal research group the Center for American Progress, said both parties were merely tinkering around the edges of a major problem that threatened the economy. He urged them to hammer out an agreement on spending cuts and tax increases to balance the budget in 10 years.

The popular perception is that the Green Bay Packers are great because of Aaron Rodgers and the passing offense. And for good reason: Rodgers (and by extension, the entire Green Bay passing offense) is on a record-breaking pace. Rodgers leads the league in completion percentage, touchdowns, touchdown percentage, yards per attempt, adjusted net yards per attempt and adjusted yards per attempt. He's averaging 11.2 adjusted yards per attempt, the highest mark after a team's first eight games of any quarterback in over 50 years. But did you know that the Packers rank 21st in pass attempts this season? I doubt that that jibes with your impression of the Packers as a passing team. The 2007 Patriots -- the year Tom Brady carved up opposing defenses nearly every week -- barely passed more frequently than the average team that season. The 1999 Rams won the Super Bowl and earned the nickname the Greatest Show on Turf, as Kurt Warner, Marshall Faulk, Isaac Bruce and Torry Holt led one of the great passing attacks in football history. That year, the Rams ranked 15th in the league in rush attempts and 19th in pass attempts. In all of these cases, the statistics did not tell the true story. Those teams passed so successfully that they frequently found themselves in run-favorable situations. Every N.F.L. fan knows that trailing teams tend to pass more frequently than winning teams, and the disparity is stronger the larger the lead or deficit. For example, teams this season are passing on 74 percent of plays when trailing by 17 to 24 points, but that drops to 44 percent when leading by such a margin. How a game unfolds has a large impact on the ultimate run/pass ratio of a team. To truly understand a team's offensive philosophy, you need to take into account the scoring flow of the game. I looked at the play-by-play logs of every game this season, courtesy of Footballguys.com. I excluded all plays in which a team was winning or losing by over 24 points because those plays reveal little about a team's gameplan (for example, the Colts called 23 pass plays and 23 runs in their 62-7 loss to the Saints; plays in those types of games are counted, but only until the games get out of hand). I also decided to exclude all rushing plays where the runner was the quarterback; many of those plays were probably designed pass plays, but others were designed runs or draws, along with quarterback sneaks and kneeldowns. Finally, I noted how much the team with the ball was leading or trailing by at the start of each play; that will help to give us a general sense of whether it is a passing or running situation. For example, when the Lions came back from a 20-point deficit against the Vikings, the average scoring margin on Detroit plays was -8.5; not surprisingly, the Lions passed on 74 percent of plays in that game (passing plays include sacks). This past weekend, the Texans jumped out to an early lead against the Browns. Houston's average offensive play was run with a 14.3-point lead; the Texans ran on 37 of 60 plays (this excludes the Matt Schaub touchdown run and his two kneeldowns at the end of the game). Both Arian Foster and Ben Tate rushed for over 100 yards. The table below shows the average scoring margin for each ''play'' by each team this season. Remember, the scoring margin excludes plays where a team has a lead of 25 points or more or trails by such a margin; it also excludes plays that end with the quarterback running. The table will loosely correlate with team strength, but there are several reasons (outside of the scope of this article) to hesitate before using these numbers as a sort of power ranking: [Note: All statistics in this article are from before the Monday Night Football game between the Bears and Eagles.] Team MarginHouston Texans 4.6Green Bay Packers 4.3Pittsburgh Steelers 3.9San Francisco 49ers 2.5Baltimore Ravens 2.5Philadelphia Eagles 2.1New England Patriots 1.9Chicago Bears 1.4Dallas Cowboys 1.2Atlanta Falcons 0.4Buffalo Bills 0.3Minnesota Vikings -0.1New Orleans Saints -0.5Tennessee Titans -0.6Detroit Lions -0.8Cincinnati Bengals -0.8New York Giants -1.1Oakland Raiders -1.3Carolina Panthers -1.8San Diego Chargers -1.9New York Jets -2.4Miami Dolphins -2.5Jacksonville Jaguars -2.8Arizona Cardinals -3.3Kansas City Chiefs -3.4Denver Broncos -3.8Washington Redskins -4.0Tampa Bay Buccaneers -5.0Indianapolis Colts -5.7Cleveland Browns -6.2Seattle Seahawks -6.8St Louis Rams -7.2 As you'd expect, the Packers have been in front most of the time this season. That helps explain why they haven't passed as frequently as you might think. As you can see, they rank just 13th in percentage of plays that were called passes: Team Margin Pass %Tampa Bay Buccaneers -5.0 68.4%Seattle Seahawks -6.8 67.7%Carolina Panthers -1.8 66.6%Detroit Lions -0.8 66.4%Washington Redskins -4.0 66.1%New Orleans Saints -0.5 65.9%Baltimore Ravens 2.5 64.5%St Louis Rams -7.2 64.5%Cleveland Browns -6.2 64.4%New England Patriots 1.9 64.3%Indianapolis Colts -5.7 63.9%Tennessee Titans -0.6 63.2%Green Bay Packers 4.3 62.9%Chicago Bears 1.4 62.8%Arizona Cardinals -3.3 62.8%Philadelphia Eagles 2.1 62.5%San Diego Chargers -1.9 61.4%Pittsburgh Steelers 3.9 61.2%Miami Dolphins -2.5 61.0%Dallas Cowboys 1.2 60.4%New York Giants -1.1 60.2%Atlanta Falcons 0.4 59.4%Buffalo Bills 0.3 59.0%New York Jets -2.4 58.8%Denver Broncos -3.8 58.4%Cincinnati Bengals -0.8 57.5%Oakland Raiders -1.3 54.2%Minnesota Vikings -0.1 53.8%Kansas City Chiefs -3.4 53.7%Jacksonville Jaguars -2.8 52.1%San Francisco 49ers 2.5 52.0%Houston Texans 4.6 50.9% So we know teams like the Steelers and the Packers have played with large leads, and pass more frequently than a team like the Texans. But how would we compare the 49ers to the Falcons? Or the Patriots to the Redskins? We need to convert ''margin'' and ''pass percentage'' to equivalent units. We can do that by looking at each team's standard deviation in each category. As you may recall from math class, standard deviation measures how spread out the observations are in a particular set of data. The actual standard deviations aren't all that interesting here, but the key is that by finding out how far from average (as measured by standard deviation) each team is in each category, we can get a true sense of offensive philosophy. On average, the 32 teams ran offensive plays while trailing by 1.2 points (we would expect the average to be negative, because teams kick off after a touchdown or field goal). The Texans were 1.8 standard deviations above average in the scoring margin category during Houston's average play; the Packers were 1.7 standard deviations above average, the Steelers 1.6, and so on. At the bottom of the list, of course, would be the Rams at -1.9 standard deviations from the average (taking the standard deviation won't change the order of the list; it simply measures the variance in the group.) What about in the pass percentage category? The average team passed on 61 percent of its plays, using the definition of plays from this article. The Bucs were 1.5 standard deviations above average in percentage of plays that were passed; the Texans were -2.1 standard deviations from the average. Once we have the ''margin'' category in the same unit as the ''pass percentage'' category, the rest of the math is easy. If a team has a low margin, that means it has frequently played from behind. If it is high in the pass percentage category, that means it tends to pass often. To measure how frequently a team passes after accounting for game situation, we simply add the standard deviation number in the margin category to the pass percentage standard deviation number. The table below presents the results. After the team name, the first two columns are just the earlier data reprinted. The next two columns show how many standard deviations above or below average each team was in scoring margin and percentage of passes called. Finally, the last column shows how pass-heavy the offense truly is, after adjusting for average scoring margin. Team Margin Pass % Margin Pass% Pass HeavyGNB 4.3 62.9% 1.7 0.4 2.1BAL 2.5 64.5% 1.1 0.7 1.9PIT 3.9 61.2% 1.6 0.0 1.6NWE 1.9 64.3% 1.0 0.7 1.6PHI 2.1 62.5% 1.0 0.3 1.3CHI 1.4 62.8% 0.8 0.4 1.2NOR -0.5 65.9% 0.2 1.0 1.2DET -0.8 66.4% 0.1 1.1 1.2CAR -1.8 66.6% -0.2 1.2 1.0DAL 1.2 60.4% 0.8 -0.1 0.6TEN -0.6 63.2% 0.2 0.5 0.6TAM -5.0 68.4% -1.2 1.5 0.3ATL 0.4 59.4% 0.5 -0.3 0.2WAS -4.0 66.1% -0.9 1.1 0.2BUF 0.3 59.0% 0.5 -0.4 0.0NYG -1.1 60.2% 0.0 -0.1 -0.1SDG -1.9 61.4% -0.2 0.1 -0.2HOU 4.6 50.9% 1.8 -2.1 -0.3ARI -3.3 62.8% -0.7 0.4 -0.3MIA -2.5 61.0% -0.4 0.0 -0.4SEA -6.8 67.7% -1.8 1.4 -0.4CIN -0.8 57.5% 0.1 -0.7 -0.6SFO 2.5 52.0% 1.2 -1.8 -0.7NYJ -2.4 58.8% -0.4 -0.4 -0.8IND -5.7 63.9% -1.4 0.6 -0.8CLE -6.2 64.4% -1.6 0.7 -0.9MIN -0.1 53.8% 0.3 -1.5 -1.2STL -7.2 64.5% -1.9 0.7 -1.2DEN -3.8 58.4% -0.8 -0.5 -1.4OAK -1.3 54.2% -0.1 -1.4 -1.5KAN -3.4 53.7% -0.7 -1.5 -2.2JAX -2.8 52.1% -0.5 -1.8 -2.3 Lo and behold, the Packers now look to be the most pass-happy team in the league. The Steelers and the Patriots are also in the top four, and the Saints are not far behind. Not surprisingly, the Jaguars and Chiefs lead the way when it comes to run-heavy offenses, regardless of situation. The Jets have actually been relatively run-heavy this season, but their game situation (trailing often) has somewhat distorted the numbers. Perhaps the most interesting team? The Ravens. A couple of weeks ago, Terrell Suggs said the Ravens needed to pass less and run more; it's hard to disagree with him. The Ravens have been extremely pass-heavy this season, once you factor in the game situation. Consider that against the Rams, when Baltimore raced out to a 21-0 lead before the first quarter ended, Joe Flaccothrew 48 passes while the running backs had just 17 carries. Suggs's comments came after the Jaguars loss, when Baltimore had 41 dropbacks against just 12 rushes in a game that was close throughout. Against the Steelers this weekend, Baltimore called 50 passing plays despite leading for a majority of the game. Chase Stuart is a contributor to SmartFootball.com, Footballguys.com and Pro-Football-Reference.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A brief article on Saturday about the naming of three new elements referred to Tom Lehrer's academic career incorrectly. He was a Harvard graduate student in mathematics but never completed a doctorate. He also subsequently taught math in the political science department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and then at the University of California, Santa Cruz. But he was not a Harvard math professor.

The number of people leaving or receiving jobs picked up in September, the Labor Department reported Tuesday, a sign that that the labor market may be regaining its health. Both hires and separations have been relatively stagnant in the last year, with companies too nervous to hire or let anyone go, and employees too frightened to leave their jobs. Layoffs in particular had reached record lows earlier this year. But levels of both rose in September.

We can't predict for certain how the coming season of ''Spartacus: Vengeance'' will end, but we're feeling confident that the gladiator hero of its title will live to fight another day. That's because on Monday, the Starz cable channel announced that it has already committed to producing a third season of ''Spartacus'' even before its second season has begun. When it makes its debut on January 27, ''Spartacus: Vengeance'' will be the first season of the popular sword-and-sandals action series to star Liam McIntyre. It was announced in January that he would take over the role of Spartacus from Andy Whitfield, who portrayed the character in its debut season, titled ''Spartacus: Blood and Sand.'' Mr. Whitfield died of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in September.

Adele, the British singer and songwriter, underwent surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston on Monday to stop recurrent bleeding from a benign polyp on her vocal cords, a condition that forced her to cancel more than a dozen concerts this year in the United States and Britain, a spokesman for the hospital said. The procedure was performed by Dr. Steven Zeitels, a specialist in laryngeal surgery at Harvard who has pioneered the use of lasers to stop vocal-cord bleeding. He has performed his procedures on many other professional vocalists, among them Steven Tyler of Aerosmith.

Yelp, the online reviews site for local businesses, has hired Goldman Sachs and Citigroup to lead its initial public offering of stock, according to several people briefed on the situation. The offering, which is expected to value the company at $1.5 billion to $2 billion, will probably come to market in the first quarter of next year, a person close to the company said. Yelp is expected to file its prospectus by the end of this year.

The ''Road to the Derby'' series will be highlighted by a 90-minute live broadcast on NBC featuring the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct and the Santa Anita Derby at Santa Anita Park on April 7, 2012. The series will feature races from six racetracks,

A ramshackle four-story brownstone in mid-20th-century Manhattan. A Lower East Side tenement at the turn of the last century. The woods of Wisconsin in 1964. These are just a few of the landscapes that female readers of children's literature cling to well after they cease reading the books that introduced them. (''The Saturdays,'' ''All-of-a-Kind Family'' and ''Caddie Woodlawn'' for those who somehow missed these greats.) But there may be no world that provokes such profound girlish longing as the bucolic century-old Minnesota of ''Betsy-Tacy.''

CASAGRANDE--Stephanie Worth, after several months of surgery and hospitalization Stephanie's life came to an end on January 5, 2011. She will be sorely missed by her cousins and other relatives as well as a host of friends and co-workers. A generous person, she gave freely of her time to help others in any way she could. She was born to Stephen and Helen Casagrande in Brooklyn, NY. Early in her life Stephanie traveled from the East Coast by rail to join her father in Palm Springs, California where he was serving as a Physician and Surgeon with the US army. Later "Doctor Steve" was sent to the European theater of operations, where he served on the continent as well as in England; meanwhile Stephanie and her mother returned to Brooklyn and later to Belmar, New Jersey to await the return of her father. In 1946 the family moved to Rumson, NJ where Stephanie grew up. During her grammar and high school years she enjoyed horseback riding and was an accomplished jumper. But it was the extended family of aunts, uncles and cousins that was the center of her social life. Holidays, First Communions and Confirmations and especially Sunday centered on the family and provided long memories. After graduating from Red Bank Catholic High School, she entered Rosemont College in Pennsylvania where she majored in mathematics. Upon graduation she entered the data processing field as a computer programmer. She found work in New York City where she continued to work and live for the rest of her life. She enjoyed traveling and visited her mother's home in Nova Scotia as well as making trips to Latin America, Europe and Israel. Those who wish to remember her can send donations to Cooke School of Learning and Development, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 730, New York, NY 10115.

CARSHON--Charles. Actor, director, teacher, Off-Broadway pioneer, died on October 28th. Taught at High School of Performing Arts, Stella Adler Studio, Neighborhood Playhouse, American Academy of Dramatic Art, and was head of Studio Theatre at Sarah Lawrence College for 35 years. Many famous actors passed through his classes. He was 91 and is survived by his wife, Gloria Barret.

HEARST--John Randolph, Jr.,A trustee of The Hearst Family Trust and a member of the Board of Directors of Hearst Corporation and the two Hearst Foundations, died November 4 in New York City. He was 77. A grandson of William Randolph Hearst, John R. Bunky Hearst, Jr., as he was called most of his life, served as a member of the company's Board of Directors for 44 years. He was appointed a trustee of The Hearst Family Trust in April 1972, the same year he joined the Hearst Foundations as a director. John was always very devoted to the company founded by his grandfather, said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. He was equally devoted to a number of charitable organizations in the New York area. Those of us who served with him on the various Hearst Boards remember his great wit and interest in everything the company and Foundations were doing. Bunky will be greatly missed. Hearst enjoyed a long career with the Corporation, starting as a news photographer for the Hearst-owned New York Daily Mirror in the 1950s, as well as for the Hearst Newspapers division. In recognition of his interest in photojournalism, Hearst Newspapers commissioned a traveling trophy, the John R. Hearst Jr. Prize for Photo Excellence, awarded to photographers for Hearst Newspapers. An ardent boating enthusiast most of his life, he also served as an editor for Motor Boating & Sailing magazine, which was a Hearst publication. Born in New York City on December 8, 1933, to John Randolph Hearst, the third son of William Randolph Hearst, and Gretchen Wilson, Hearst often spent time in his youth at Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif., and greatly valued his time personally spent with his grandfather, the legendary W.R. Hearst. In 1960, John Hearst wrote an article for Reader's Digest entitled Life With Grandfather, in which he detailed their relationship. The younger Hearst's uncle, William Randolph Hearst, Jr., noted: The two talked newspapering a lot. Hearst said that if he learned one thing from his grandfather, it was the power of newspapers. Known for his sense of humor, Hearst enjoyed telling the story of how he had acquired his unusual nickname. He told the New York Times in 1983 that a cartoon character in his grandfather's newspaper, the New York Journal-American, was to blame. I used to wear huge baby bonnets, Hearst was quoted as saying. And my godfather took one look at me and said, He looks like Bunky in the funny papers.' The name stuck. On his 21st birthday, Hearst decided that he no longer resembled a Bunky, he told the Times. But it was too late; the nickname was his for life. I may as well wallow in it, Hearst said. Besides, I'd rather be a Bunky than a Junior. He is survived by his daughter Lisa Hearst Hagerman and his grandchildren, Tenney Hearst Espy, John Hearst Espy and Henry Hearst Hagerman. Services are pending. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. With appreciation, The Hearst Board of Directors

4:30 p.m. | Updated Little, Brown & Company has pulled a mystery novel from the shelves after passages in the book were found to have been plagiarized from ''a variety of classic and contemporary spy novels,'' the publisher said on Tuesday. The book, ''Assassin of Secrets,'' a debut novel by Q. R. Markham, was released last week by Mulholland Books, an imprint of Little, Brown. ''We take great pride in the writers and books we publish and tremendous care in every aspect of our publishing process, so it is with deep regret that we have published a book that we can no longer stand behind,'' Michael Pietsch, the publisher of Little, Brown, said in a statement. ''Our goal is to never have this happen, but when it does, it is important to us to communicate with and compensate readers and retailers as quickly as possible.''

You might not arrive at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx knowing who underwrote the lovely restoration of its venerable 50-acre forest along the banks of the Bronx River. But you won't leave ignorant. The generosity of John A. Thain and his wife, Carmen, in helping rehabilitate the forest has been rewarded with its renaming as the Thain Family Forest. The new name has also been worked into the text of almost every sign along the forest's more navigable and informative trails. (This coming weekend will be the second in a festival celebrating the forest's rededication.)

(ABC) THE 45TH ANNUAL CMA AWARDS Brad Paisley, the Country Music Association's entertainer of the year, and Carrie Underwood, a nominee for best female vocalist, return as hosts of this ceremony, broadcast live from the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. (13, 49) JUNGLE EAGLE ''Nature,'' led by the filmmaker Fergus Beeley, journeys to the jungle along the Orinoco River in Venezuela to get close to the world's most powerful birds of prey, the harpy eagles. Standing three feet tall, with a six-foot wingspan and talons the size of bear claws, these predators, who feed on monkeys and sloths, prefer to remain hidden in the rain forest canopy. An article on Tuesday about an imaging project that restored an 1871 diary by the explorer David Livingstone misidentified the country in which he died, two years after the diary was written. He died in what is now Zambia, not in Tanzania.

Less than a month after endorsing Mitt Romney on the day of a Republican debate in New Hampshire, Gov. Chris Christie will make his debut as a surrogate for Mr. Romney, once again on the day of a debate in New Hampshire. On Wednesday, while Mr. Romney prepares for yet another debate that evening in Michigan, Mr. Christie will campaign for him in southern New Hampshire. He will attend a rally at the Romney campaign's New Hampshire headquarters in Manchester, as well as a house party at the Nashua residence of John Stabile, a former state Republican Party chairman who just endorsed Mr. Romney. Mr. Christie will then head to Mr. Romney's national headquarters in Boston for a debate-watching party, where he has been billed as the ''special guest.''

ROTHBLUM--Marcia. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Educational Alliance mourn the passing of Marcia Rothblum, wife of Philip Rothblum and a generous supporter of our work. We offer our sincere condolences to the Rothblum family.

STERN--Joanne M. The Board of Directors and staff of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourn the passing of Joanne M. Stern and extend our condolences to her family and friends who share our deep respect for her lifelong commitment to child advocacy and the arts. This year, Joanne reached her 50th year of service to CCC, which began in 1961 when she attended CCC's very first Community Leadership Course at the suggestion of her then mother-in-law, and CCC founder, Marion Rosenwald Ascoli. Not only did Joanne subsequently adopt CCC as her own, but she served as a generational bridge for the Rosenwald family and CCC, as Joanne's stepdaughter, Chris Stern Hyman, serves as CCC President today. Joanne served on the CCC Board for nearly 50 years; was presented with CCC's Eleanor Roosevelt Award in 2008; and became an Honorary Director in 2011. Her dedication to children was outmatched only by her modesty and sense of humor. Her loyalty to the CCC mission and personal support of CCC staff and fellow Directors will be greatly missed.

It's the British Fashion Council's third year hosting the London Show Rooms at the Soho Grand hotel, where for two days 20 young British designers present their spring collections to the New York set. Between chats with some of the talent on site - the designer Thomas Tait, who arrived with his special-edition TTSS2012-emblazoned Nikes; the brood's newest inductees, Palmer/Harding and Simone Rocha; the men's-wear designers Katie Eary and Lou Dalton - The Moment sat down with Sarah Mower, the BFC's ambassador for emerging talent and an American Vogue contributing editor, to hear more about what makes these designers ones to watch. "We look for people who know who they are, who aren't derivative and who specialize in doing one thing really well. Ideally they'll have a whole imagined world," says Mower, who explained that all of the participating designers are winners of the New Gen sponsorship by Topshop. "A good example is Mary Katrantzou, who started with a rail of six trompe l'oeil print shift dresses in 2009 and now is in her third season of stand-alone runway shows, selling at 110 stores, and has loads of wearers out and about in New York." Well, she - and all of the other designers - are welcome back any time.

The opening of the Brooklyn specialty store Beautiful Dreamers by the stylists April Hughes and Marina Burini answered that question on the tip of everyone's tongue this time of year: Where to go for extraordinary holiday hostess gifts? "We wanted to create a destination for all the beautiful things we find," says Burini, pointing to a twig and plant installation made by Molly Findlay that hangs alongside quirky reads like the 3-D coffee-table book  "Phantograms From Nature" by Barry Rothstein. "I would use something really cool on a shoot and then have no use for it and it would be gone," adds Hughes, who confesses that parting with their one-of-a-kind merchandise is often the hardest part. "Now we can savor and share those special finds with people!" The treehouse-like shop offers everything from Rastafarian wool scarves by Taiana Giefer to Old Field Farm honey and Incense of the West with tepee-shaped burners. Click through for a selection of sure-to-please presents for home, holiday and gracious hostesses alike.

There aren't many film stars who, entering their golden years, endure as icons of sensuality. Charlotte Rampling, 65 years old and un-retouched (both on screen and in real life), is one of them. The daughter of a British colonel and NATO commander, Rampling attended tony girls' schools in France and England. She modeled briefly, before trying films, and burst onto the scene in "Georgy Girl" (1966), in which she played a flirt who is the embodiment of Swinging London. Today, after five decades on screen (including a star turn in Visconti's classic, "The Damned"), and modeling for everyone from Helmut Newton to Juergen Teller, Rampling's career shows no signs of abating. In "The Mill and the Cross" (currently in theaters), the Polish director Lech Majewski's visually ravishing examination of a Breugel painting, she takes on the Virgin Mary; in "Melancholia" (opening Friday), the bad-boy Danish director Lars von Trier's latest, her character is based upon von Trier's despised mother. And in the fashion world, Rampling continues to inspire: Marc Jacobs designed much of his fall 2011 collection for Louis Vuitton after her role in "The Night Porter" (1974), Liliana Calvani's controversial, S&M-infused drama about a death-camp survivor's affair with a Nazi officer (think: leather caps and suspenders).

Walking into the newly expanded Greene Street spot feels like stepping into a big kid's clubhouse: among the trappings are giant tin planes, snappily clad scarecrows, taxidermied goats, books teaching you how to talk to birds (and other woodland creatures) and little figurines that pop up on every available surface. It's obvious that this Mr. Spade is both a hoarder and a born merchandiser, and that his natural inclination for fun is paying off.

Since Coach John Tortorella put center Derek Stepan between Artem Anisimov and Marian Gaborik for parts of the game against Montreal on Nov. 5, the line's brilliant passing, puck-hawking and goal scoring have galvanized an otherwise spotty Rangers attack. In his third season in New York, Gaborik may finally have the linemates to lift him to the top of the scoring charts. Going into Friday's home game against Carolina, the Rangers has won five straight. It's early yet, and Tortorella shuffles lines constantly. But the Stepan-Anisimov-Gaborik troika is lighting the goal lamp like the Rangers' Goal-a-Game (GAG) Line of Jean Ratelle, Vic Hadfield and Rod Gilbert did in the early '70s.

My daughter Margaret's piece in this week's magazine about being home-schooled captures wonderfully a most unusual time in the life of our family - the good, the bad and the ugly. She describes my thoughts about education and how I grew to realize that I wanted to teach the children at home as well as I could. And I loved reading all the children's "horror" stories she recounts about their first few days at school, which have become familiar punch lines to long-running family jokes. But when you think about it, what's so terrible about being a little confused on the first day of school? I've been confused for the first few days of all the jobs I've ever had, and so have my friends. That's part of the process of beginning something new. I'm sure Mary, Margaret, John and James would agree.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

Talk about a makeover. Among the latest offerings at the SoHo design mecca Moss is this pair of vintage Eames Lounge Chairs, which Murray Moss decided to re-cover in Hella Jongerius's Repeat Dot fabric from Maharam. The chairs (which have been manufactured by Herman Miller since 1956) have a built-in pedigree because they're made with Brazilian rosewood veneer, the material that was originally specified by Charles and Ray Eames, but which was discontinued in 1992 when Brazilian rosewood landed on the endangered species list. Jongerius's eye-popping fabric, however, is what really makes them - it takes a design icon from the "Mad Men" era and catapults it into the 21st century. (As with many Moss creations, these don't come cheap: the chairs are $16,000 each, or $30,000 for the pair.) They're just the first (or first two) in a planned series of one-off furniture pieces on which Moss and Maharam will collaborate. And for a glimpse of what other designs Maharam might bring to the project, see "Maharam Agenda" (Lars Müller Publishers), a new book on the innovative textile company by Michael Maharam, who has run the family-owned business with his brother, Stephen, since 1997. The book not only describes the brothers' risk-taking design agenda, but it looks like an agenda, too, complete with a soft cover (an embroidered design by Jongerius) and woven bookmark - a tip-off right there that this isn't going to be your average corporate coffee-table book.

The Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night, which was shown on CNBC and was supposed to be devoted to economic issues, became memorable for a major gaffe by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. His very public, very awkward inability to come up with the name of a third federal agency he would like to eliminate was taken as a devastating error. Gone, for the moment, was the media focus on sexual harassment allegations that have emerged against Herman Cain, who has been leading in public opinion polls. So much so that immediately afterward, when asked on CNBC whether Mr. Perry was doomed by the performance, Mr. Cain was reassuring about a forgiving public. [NYT]

The Gujarat riot decision dominated headlines Thursday, with The Hindu calling it the "First Whiff of Justice" for riot victims. Thirty-one people were convicted on Wednesday of murder and sentenced to life in prison for their involvement in the violence and arson that killed 33 Muslims, mostly women and children, one evening in March of 2002. "Almost all the accused were Patels, people who owned land in the village, while the victims were mostly laborers in their own farms," The Indian Express writes in a recap of the events. As riots in the village escalated, Muslim men "herded their women, children and elders into the locality's only concrete house," the paper writes. "Inside the 10 foot-by-12 foot room in which they were cramped, bales of cotton were stacked. The rioters doused these bales in oil, locked the house from the outside and set it on fire."

Last week, we profiled a dilemma facing J. Hilburn, a Dallas clothing company that uses direct sales and multilevel marketing to sell custom shirts and other menswear. Founded in 2007 by Hil Davis and Veeral Rathod, two Dallas financial industry workers, the company's sales rose from $1 million in 2008 to $3.25 million in 2009 and $8 million in 2010, a year in which it sold 60,000 shirts (starting at $89). As Mr. Davis and Mr. Rathod built their business, they knew they would have to raise money. They wanted to expand the business with an Internet sales channel, and they needed to build their inventory. But as they went about raising capital, they discovered a problem: potential investors questioned their vision for a company that would blend direct sales with an online channel. Direct sales suffered from a historically dodgy reputation, for one thing, and the blend did not have the sizzle of a pure Internet strategy. Of those investors who were interested, some looked at the Internet channel as a way for the company to increase sales while eliminating - or at least cutting - the commissions paid to the direct-sales reps, something Mr. Davis and Mr. Rathod thought would alienate the people who had helped them build the business. And then there was the problem of how to integrate a direct-sales force with an Internet sales channel, not something commonly done in the retail world.

In a week crowded with new music releases, Justin Bieber's new holiday album topped the Billboard chart with more than 200,000 sales. ''Under the Mistletoe,'' Mr. Bieber's second full-length album, sold 210,293 copies in the United States, according to his record label, Island Def Jam. It is the first holiday album by a male solo artist to open at No. 1 in the 55-year history of Billboard's album chart, the magazine reported, although plenty of stars have ridden seasonal music to big sales heights. Josh Groban's ''Noel,'' for example, was the best-selling album of 2007, with 3.7 million copies.

3 p.m. | Updated At 2 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday, all television channels and radio stations in the United States were supposed to be interrupted by a brief test of the nation's Emergency Alert System. But, like most tests, some passed and some failed. Beginning at 2:01 p.m., viewers and listeners in many states said they saw and heard the alerts at the scheduled time, but others said they did not. There was no immediate explanation for the discrepancies, but that was one of the purposes of the test - to find out how well the system would work in an actual emergency.

A Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the inglorious end of Joe Paterno's so-called Grand Experiment, his campaign to prove that football excellence and academic integrity could coexist, misspelled the surname of a former communist dictator in referring to efforts to cling to a sense of normalcy. He was Nicolae Ceausescu, not Ceasescu.

STERN--Joanne M. It is with enormous sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of its great friend and leader Joanne M. Stern. A member of the Council since 1968, Joanne became a MoMA trustee in 1970. She served brilliantly as the Council's President from 1971-1986. Everybody who knew her admired her extraordinary wit, intelligence, warmth, and humor. We will all miss her beyond measure. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Joanne's children Nicholas Stern, Thomas Stern, and Peggy Stern, her stepchildren Chris Stern Hyman and Catherine Stern, her nine grandchildren, and many many friends. Regis Philbin is leaving the daytime talk show ''Live! with Regis and Kelly'' later this month, but his co-host, Kelly Ripa, is planning to stay awhile. Disney-ABC Domestic Television confirmed on Wednesday that Ms. Ripa, who has been Mr. Philbin's co-host for 10 years, had signed a new contract that will have her on the syndicated show through 2017, a five-year extension. The new contract was first reported by Deadline.com. The show is preparing a send-off for Mr. Philbin next week ahead of his Nov. 18 departure. After that day the show will be renamed ''Live! with Kelly'' until a new co-host is named, probably some time in 2012.

ZALAZNICK--Louis, 88, passed away on Monday, November 7. THE collection of knit accessories that Greg Chait is introducing at Barneys this week, Tyro by tes, is less expensive than his luxury knitwear line, The Elder Statesman, but, he'll have you know, it's not a secondary label. ''I like the idea that it's a second brand as opposed to a lower-end brand,'' he said. Mr. Chait sourced baby alpaca for his Tyro caps, scarves and fingerless gloves, rather than the heavy gauge cashmere of Elder. Handcrafted in Peru, the woolly pieces are accessible without being mass-produced. Alpaca cap, $225 at Barneys New York; barneys.com.

WARREN--Goldie. Our beloved Goldie died peacefully on November 9, 2011. She would have turned 98 next month. She was treasured beyond measure, and is survived by Joe, her husband of 70 years, her daughters Hermine Warren and Laura Messing (Fred), her granddaughter Alexis (Kevin) and her great-granddaughters Shoshana and Hava. She was a pioneer in the field of reading, having earned a second Masters Degree from Columbia when she was well into middle age. Her intellectual curiosity was unbounded to the end, as was her devotion to her friends and family. We will always feel her presence, be inspired by her memory, love and miss her. Funeral services will be held at Zion Memorial Chapel,785 East Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck, 914-381-1809 on Friday, November 11, at 12 noon. Contributions may be made to the Brandeis National Committee Central Westchester Chapter, 888-862-8692.

Adored grandmother of Michael, Marc and Heather, Matthew, and Max Gold and Justin and Mariel Kaufman, all of whom lit up her life and made her proud. Sister of Louise Feldman and Bevin Koeppel and the late Selma Friedman, Geraldine Adler, and Alfred Koeppel. Sister-in-law of Dr. Allen Gold and Carl Schwartz. Her warmth, kindness, and generosity will forever be in our hearts. Funeral services: Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY 11023 on November 11, 2011, 11am.

ROTHENBERG--Helen J. Born April 18, 1908 to Herman and Sara Pines of East Setauket, Long Island. Helen was an inspiring teacher in the New York City school system for 35 years. She was predeceased by her husband of 59 years, the late Simon Rothenberg. She is survived by her children Joseph and Lynne Rothenberg, and Jane and Ken Jewel; her grandchildren Jill and Evan Shapiro, Andrew and Shallah Jewel, Brad and Chris Rothenberg, and Dan and Lan Jewel; and by eight great-grandchildren, Jenna, Jamie, Abby, Rachel, Keri, Sara, Zachary and Emma. She will be missed not only by her immediate family for whom she was an inspiration and binding force, but also by her nieces and nephews, cousins and friends who gave so much to her in recent years and who received so much love in return.

STERN--Joanne Melniker. Born in Bayonne, New Jersey on March 11, 1924. Died at home in New York on November 8, 2011. Beloved by her family and her countless friends, she is survived by her children Nicholas Stern, Thomas Stern, and Peggy Stern, her stepchildren Chris Stern Hyman and Catherine Stern, her grandchildren, Sarah, David, Anna, Ian, Noah, Ben, Emma, Alexandra, Arianna, and her great-grandson Henry. A graduate of Smith College, she began a lifelong attachment to New York City with a job as an entertainment editor at LOOK Magazine. Her service as a full-time volunteer to a number of worthy not-for-profit organizations exemplified her caring nature and generosity of spirit. These included Citizens Committee for Children, the Northside Center for Child Development, the School of American Ballet, the New York Landmarks Conservancy, and the Museum of Modern Art where she served as a co-chairman of its Junior Council, as President of its International Council, and as a distinguished member of the Board of Trustees for almost fifty years. Memorial service, Tuesday, November 22, 2011 at 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Citizens Committee for Children, 105 East 22 Street, NY, NY 10010 or to the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53 Street, NY, NY 10019 and sent to the attention of their Directors. Correspondence may be sent to Peggy Stern, 535 West 110th Street, NY, NY 10025.

Even the United States Marshals Service is getting in on the fall auction season. Guccione, the United States Marshal for the Southern District of New York, announced on Wednesday.

A music review on Wednesday about a concert at Lincoln Center by the singer Jackie Evancho, and a picture caption with it, misidentified the site in some editions. It was Avery Fisher Hall, not Alice Tully Hall. The review also misstated, in some editions, Ms. Evancho's relationship to Matthew Evancho, who wrote a song she performed, ''To Believe.'' He is her uncle, not her father.

This is a tragedy. It is one of the great sorrows of my life. With the benefit of hindsight, I wish I had done more. JOE PATERNO,resigning as football coach at Penn State in the wake of a sexual abuse scandal involving one of his former assistants. [B17]

TORONTO - With its stock down about 65 percent this year, Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, has no shortage of unhappy shareholders. But few of its investors have sought and received as much attention over the past few months as Victor P. Alboini, the chairman and chief executive of Jaguar Financial. In several interviews with the media since June, Mr. Alboini has called for the replacement of RIM's co-chief executives, demanded the appointment of an independent chairman and urged the company's board to consider selling or breaking the company into three units.

EVENTS In honor of Veterans Day, the designer GREG LAUREN, nephew of Ralph, has created 30 one-of-a-kind pieces made of vintage military garb, including bags and tents. From Friday to Nov. 18, pieces like a peak-lapel jacket with knapsack-style straps along the back, $2,875, and a long sailor coat made from navy wool shirts, $4,500, will be sold at an installation titled ''Barracks'' at 125-127 Grand Street; (917) 514-8583. A percentage of the proceeds from the collection, handmade at Greg Lauren's Los Angeles studio, will go to Operation Mend, an organization that aids veterans.

FICARO--Mary, formerly of Yonkers passed away on November 7, 2011. She would have been 88 on November 9. Wife of the late Anthony Ficaro Sr., loving mother of Anthony Jr., Joanne and Mary Jo. Grandmother of Christine, Kim, Jason, Kevin, and Stephen, and great grandmother of Jillian, and Rebecca; sister of Michael Fidanza and the late Dr. Joseph Fidanza and Millie Pisacane. Mary was a person of unwavering faith who lived a full life with the love of friends and family. Mary had a passion for gardening and sewing and deep love for Sprain Road Riding Academy in Ardsley which she and Tony owned & operated from 1965 to 1981. This was more than a business to them both and they spent many wonderful years there with family & friends. Calling hours at the Fred H. Need to open a file in a program other than the one that automatically pops open when you double-click? In either Mac OS X or Windows, right-clicking in the file's icon and choosing ''Open With'' lets you select a different program from a list of applications that can also handle that file type. Mac users can open files by dragging them on top of a program's icon in desktop Dock. Windows 7 users typically get a ''Pin to Application'' option if they try to drag a file onto a program icon in the Taskbar, but there is a way to make the file open. Just hold down the Shift key when dragging the file onto a program icon in the Windows 7 Taskbar to get an ''Open With Application'' option instead.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Wal-Mart's expansion into financial services misidentified the organizer of Bank Transfer Day, an initiative to abandon traditional banks. It took shape after Kristen Christian, a banking customer upset by fees, set up a Facebook page. It was not organized by people associated with Occupy Wall Street, though many of those protesters supported her idea.

A headline in some copies on Tuesday with an article about anxiety over Italian bonds misstated the effect on bond transactions. It was the bonds' rates -- not the prices -- that were pushed up by nervous investors.

All right, hope had a good run. It elected a president, made people feel good for a while, and sold some expensive artwork. Three years later, the unemployment rate is still high, most homeowners are still licking their wounds from diminished values, and many companies are not back to where they were before the Great Recession. That's the bad news. Now, here's the good news. For many -- not those who are still unemployed, of course -- things are getting better. No, I am not an economist. Nor am I running for office. And I am not intoxicated. I am, however, an entrepreneur who owns businesses that sell things that are bought with discretionary income. These businesses certainly did see a drop in sales at the end of 2008, and 2009 was not a banner year. But, yes, things have slowly been getting better. In 2011, I hired about five additional people. And I really hired them. No 1099 contract workers, no temporary workers, no part time.

ESPY--Louise Manheim House. Mother of Jonathan House and Penny House. Peacefully at rest on Saturday November 5th at age 92. Widow of the writer Willard Espy and former wife of Martin House, Esq., she is survived also by two grandchildren: Antonia and Gregory House; and by four step-daughters: Freddy, Cassy, Joey and Mona Espy, and six step-grandchildren. Memorial service plans are in formation.

Last Friday night, David Hallberg made his debut as a principal dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet, becoming the first American in history to do so. A leading Russian newspaper critic praised his ''surgically measured pirouettes'' in the role of Prince Albrecht in ''Giselle.'' Another wrote that ''the way he simply walked on stage differentiated him from a mere mortal,'' and noted that the company has not had a ''Nordic beauty'' of his type since 1979, when Aleksandr Godunov defected while on tour with the Bolshoi in New York. What fault they found was with his acting; transports of emotion conveyed by his co-star, Natalia Osipova, were met with no more than ''ideally harmonized and measured gestures and loyal glances,'' one of the critics said.

Merryl H. Tisch, chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, is not interested in running for mayor, despite the buzz that has circulated in recent weeks about her possible candidacy. In an interview on Wednesday, Dr. Tisch categorically denied rumors, newspaper articles and even an item in The New York Post's Page Six column that suggested her as a potential contender in the 2013 race to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

ROST--John S.,whose successful career in Public Relations and Advertising spanned more than fifty years, died Sunday in Wakefield, Rhode Island, of respiratory failure. He was 93. Mr. Rost was born on July 4, 1918 in Kerkoven, Minnesota. He obtained a B.S. in Journalism from the University of Minnesota in 1941 and did post graduate work in Speech and Creative Writing at the University of Houston and Columbia University in New York City. During World War II, he served as a Sergeant in the Army Air Corp, receiving the American Theater Service Medal, Good Conduct Medal and Victory Medal. Mr. Rost began his professional career in 1946 in Houston, Texas with the M.H. Jacobs Public Relations Agency, where he met his future wife, Thelma Bradshaw. In 1948, the couple moved to New York City, where Mr. Rost was employed as the New Jersey State Director of the United Negro College Fund and subsequently as Executive Director of the Morristown New Jersey Community Chest. In 1956, Mr. Rost began working with J. Walter Thompson in New York City, becoming a Vice President in 1967. In 1969, Mr. Rost opened his own Public Relations Agency, John Rost Associates, with offices in New York City and Washington, D.C. Mr. Rost's wife predeceased him in 1973. He is survived by their three children: a daughter, Ann Marie Rost, and sons Arnold Bradshaw Rost (Brad), and John Thomasson Rost (Jack). Heis also survived by two grandchildren, Amanda Haley Rost and Jonathan Bradshaw (Jake) Rost; by nieces, Pat Rost and Janet Anderson Welte; by nephews, Lanny Rost, and Jerry Peterson, Jim Peterson, Joe Peterson and Jack Peterson, and by their children. Funeral services are by the Nardolillo Funeral Home of Narragansett, Rhode Island (401-789-6300), where a memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 12, 2011. Visit www.Nardolillo.com for information and online condolences.

THE watch mavens at Tourneau have teamed up with J. Crew to revive a little-known Swiss watchmaker, Mougin & Piquard. The company, founded in the 1920s by Ernest Mougin and Paul Piquard, had designed traditional mechanical watches with a Parisian sensibility, much in the manner of the Mougin family, which made ornate timepieces in late-19th-century Paris. The company changed hands in 1960, then went out of business the following decade with the advent of the quartz movement. The new watches, with the rare Mougin & Piquard logo, are based on sketches from the company's archives. Swiss-made with a quartz movement and a stainless steel case, they have either a cream face and brown leather strap or a black face and strap. Mougin & Piquard for J. Crew grande seconde watch, $425 at J. Crew Men's stores; jcrew.com.

While his 2010 feature ''Black Swan'' could have presaged a career transition into ballet, Darren Aronofsky is sticking with the cinema for the time being. This month, Mr. Aronofsky, whose films include ''Requiem for a Dream'' and ''The Wrestler'' (as well as a disturbing new series of anti-drug public service announcements) is temporarily trading his director's chair for a different seat at the American Museum of Natural History, where he is heading the jury of its Margaret Mead Film Festival. Now in its 35th year, this annual documentary series, which runs Thursday through Sunday, includes 36 films chosen from more than 1,000 submissions, as well as live music, art exhibitions and a listening party in the Hayden Planetarium dome hosted by WNYC's Radiolab. On Sunday, Mr. Aronofsky and his jury will announce a winner from among seven directors vying for the Margaret Mead Filmmaker Award.

STERN--Joanne M. The Board of Directors and staff of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourn the passing of Joanne M. Stern and extend our condolences to her family and friends who share our deep respect for her lifelong commitment to child advocacy and the arts. This year, Joanne reached her 50th year of service to CCC, which began in 1961 when she attended CCC's very first Community Leadership Course at the suggestion of her then mother-in-law, and CCC founder, Marion Rosenwald Ascoli. Not only did Joanne subsequently adopt CCC as her own, but she served as a generational bridge for the Rosenwald family and CCC, as Joanne's stepdaughter, Chris Stern Hyman, serves as CCC President today. Joanne served on the CCC Board for nearly 50 years; was presented with CCC's Eleanor Roosevelt Award in 2008; and became an Honorary Director in 2011. Her dedication to children was outmatched only by her modesty and sense of humor. Her loyalty to the CCC mission and personal support of CCC staff and fellow Directors will be greatly missed.

Regulation and Housing Crisis There is a basic problem with the argument, made by several candidates, that the government forced mortgage lenders to make bad loans: most subprime loans were made by companies that were not subject to any kind of federal regulation.

In my last post, Carissa Reiniger, a member of our business group and founder of Silver Lining Limited, described the missteps that left her $410,000 in debt by early 2008. We pick up her story here, as she explained it to the group. After two years of trying to ignore her predicament, Ms. Reiniger was forced to acknowledge it. One wake-up call came, she said, from the husband of a creditor who went to Silver Lining's offices in Edmonton, Canada, and threatened her and her employees. Some shell-shocked employees began to quit, and Ms. Reiniger was forced to lay off others. She was soon down to two employees from a high of 25. In a misguided attempt to grow her way out of debt, Ms. Reiniger had expanded from Silver Lining's original Toronto office, adding outposts in Vancouver and Edmonton, Canada, and Las Vegas. In 2008, she decided to close all but the Toronto office.

Remember plunking down your whole allowance in quarters to play Centipede and Asteroids at the local arcade? To help nostalgic fans relive those glory days, Atari Interactive published an app for iOS devices that included a catalog of classic games from the '70s and '80s. The app, Atari's Greatest Hits, recreated the look and sounds of 99 video games created for the arcade and the Atari 2600 game console.

An obituary on Tuesday about the actor Sid Melton misstated the year he began appearing as a recurring character on Danny Thomas's long-running sitcom, and also misstated the name of the show at the time. It was 1959, not 1953, and the show's name had by then been changed to ''The Danny Thomas Show.'' It was no longer called ''Make Room for Daddy.''

AT the Fivestory pop-up, on the third floor of an Upper East Side town house, shoppers will get a sneak peek at what Claire Distenfeld plans for the boutique she will open there in February. Ms. Distenfeld, who was raised on the U.E.S., fled an art-world job to hone her sophisticated retail aesthetic. For the preview, she filled two rooms with contemporary wares in a range of prices that includes, yes, affordable. There are leather dresses by Lyn Devon, a peplum dress by the Russian designer Vika Gazinskaya, Jerome Rousseau pumps, Mawi jewelry and playful gifts like Seletti porcelain tableware. ''Everyone asks why I chose a retail boutique and not e-commerce,'' she said. ''I have a romantic idea that the one-on-one experience with products needs to be revived.'' Hiring the interior designer Ryan Korban, known for the Alexander Wang shop, and who has already added a downtown finish with polished black floors, shows the lady means business. Fivestory, 18 East 69th Street, (212) 288-1338.

The Samsung SH100 camera is remotely interesting. That is, the most interesting thing about it is the remote. The camera can be connected wirelessly to a Samsung Galaxy S phone and the phone will see everything the camera sees, which will be displayed on the phone's OLED screen.

Monday, October 24, 9:36 a.m.: As I explained in my last post, I recently found myself with a surprising new problem: all the work we can handle. Because our backlog of orders is as high as I want it to be, I decided to take the opportunity to run an experiment: What would happen if I stopped running Google AdWords? I have been spending $500 per day on sponsored search, and I believe the results have been well worth the money: $1.8 million in sales as of this morning. But I also believe this is a rare opportunity to see whether AdWords is doing the heavy lifting in our marketing or whether our search engine optimization efforts are yielding results as well.

STERN--Joanne. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of their beloved and long time trustee Joanne M. Stern. Joanne joined the Board of Trustees in 1970 and served on a myriad of committees over her forty-one year association with the Museum. She Chaired the Prints and Illustrated Books Committee (1973-1998), and served on the Executive Committee, the Development Committee, the House Committee, the Committees on Drawings, Film, Publications, Education, Archives and Exhibitions. Additionally, Joanne was the President of the International Council from 1971-86, and later served as a Vice Chairman and President Emerita. Her long time devotion was especially felt and warmly appreciated by the staff of the Department of Prints and Illustrated Books throughout her twenty-five year tenure as their Committee Chair. Her service on these committees and others was always exemplary and she brought a level of wit and dedication that will be sorely missed. In addition to her many commitments to MoMA, Joanne served on the Board of Trustees for the School of American Ballet, the Citizens Committee for Children, and the Visiting Committee for the Smith College Museum of Art. Additionally, Joanne was a trustee for the American Association of University Women Educational Foundation. We will miss not only her devotion to MoMA but we will miss her delightful stories about her years working as a photo editor for LOOK Magazine as well as her vast knowledge of and passion for the art world. We send our condolences to her children Nicholas, Thomas and Peggy, her step-children Chris and Catherine, and their children and families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

A federal judge overseeing a $285 million settlement between Citigroup and the Securities and Exchange Commission expressed major concerns on Wednesday about the agency's enforcement practices. The settlement would effectively close the book on regulators' accusations that the bank deceived investors in the sale of mortgage securities. The judge, Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, reserved judgment on whether he would sign off on it, explaining that he would issue a written opinion at a later date.

Norbert Leo Butz (''Catch Me if You Can'') and Elizabeth Reaser (''Twilight'') will co-star in Second Stage's production of Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''How I Learned to Drive,'' the theater announced Tuesday. Directing duties will go to Kate Whoriskey, the former artistic director of Seattle's Intiman Theater, which laid off its entire staff and closed its doors in April. (In August the theater took a step toward reopening when it hired a consulting artistic director.) The show is to begin previews on Jan. 24, 2012, with opening night set for Feb. 13. Second Stage's revival of ''How I Learned to Drive'' will come 15 years after the show opened at the Vineyard Theater in a production that starred Mary-Louise Parker and David Morse. The play, about a girl who is molested by her uncle, won the Pulitzer for drama in 1998.

The Signature Theater Company has indefinitely postponed its world-premiere production of Edward Albee's play ''Laying an Egg,'' which was to have been a part of its inaugural season at its new Midtown space. Replacing it will be a revival of Mr. Albee's play ''The Lady From Dubuque,'' starring Jane Alexander and directed by David Esbjornson, who was to direct ''Laying an Egg'' and who directed Mr. Albee's ''The Goat, or Who is Sylvia'' on Broadway in 2002. ''Lady From Dubuque'' had a very brief Broadway run in 1980. ''Laying an Egg,'' about a middle-aged woman determined to become pregnant in the face of complications, had been scheduled to open in February at the new Signature Center, a three-theater complex near the company's current home on West 42nd Street. In a statement, James Houghton, the theater's artistic director, said of the postponement: ''All good things are well worth the wait, and most certainly a new play from one of our most treasured playwrights is no exception. Stay tuned.''

The Scene City column on Sept. 22, about an after-party for a dramatization of a trial that challenged California's ban on same-sex marriage, misstated Theodore B. Olson's role in the case. He was a co-counsel for the plaintiffs, who successfully sought to overturn the ban; he did not represent the defendants. This correction was delayed because an e-mail from a reader pointing out the error went astray at The Times.

9:15 A.M. (Showtime) THE ART OF THE STEAL (2009) Don Argott chronicles the contentious history of the Barnes Foundation, a private art collection established in suburban Philadelphia by Albert C. Barnes (1872-1951), above, a chemist who made a fortune by developing an antiseptic drug. Barnes stipulated that the European masterworks, African sculptures, Asian prints and American Indian ceramics valued at more than $25 billion that he amassed should remain in their original locale, far from the urban elite he despised. ''Money, power, race, a mansion stuffed with treasure, a city plagued by scandal -- about all that's missing from 'The Art of the Steal,' a hard-hitting documentary about a high-cultural brawl, is a hot woman with a warm gun,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She added: ''At times the fight comes across as a smackdown between art snobs who want to preserve Barnes's right to exhibit his masterworks however he wanted because, well, he paid for them (a curiously underexamined refrain), and vulgarians who want to turn his patrimony into tourist bait along with the Liberty Bell and an actor in a Ben Franklin getup. What remains unanswered, finally, is the larger question of whether deep pockets ensure custodial rights forever.'' After a 2004 ruling that allowed the foundation to bypass its charter, the collection is expected to move into a new building in downtown Philadelphia early in 2012.

VEREBAY--Mollie. With great sadness Hildi and Walter Black announce the loss of her mother Mollie Verebay. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother who died peacefully on November 7th at the age of 96. Her warmth, grace, gentle, friendly and loving ways will be cherished in the memories of her devoted family.

THE three fetching young women behind Anywho.dk, one of Denmark's first and largest fashion blogs, have combined a minimalist Scandinavian aesthetic with a style blogger street-smart mentality to produce a collection of outerwear they call Brics. ''We want people to think of it as a brick in their wardrobe,'' said Stephanie Gundelach, who with her partners, Elise Born and Ingrid Munch, designed the line. The coats are roomy enough to layer over chunky knits, even a leather jacket. In pastel hues of burnt orange, blue and yellow, they will easily refresh an otherwise muted wardrobe. ''We haven't seen winter garments that are that colorful,'' Ms. Gundelach said, ''so we thought it would be cool to do it ourselves.'' They're worth the international shipping, we say. Brics wool coat in Panama orange, about $364 at brics-store.com.

Join Disunion on Monday, Nov. 14, at 2 p.m. on our Facebook page for a conversation with Edward L. Ayers, a noted Civil War historian and Disunion contributor, about his new book, "America's War: Talking About the Civil War and Emancipation on Their 150th Anniversaries." Dr. Ayers, the president of the University of Richmond, will answer questions about the book, the sesquicentennial and Civil War history.

Emancipation, the idea that lies like a pearl at the center of our understanding of the Civil War, seems simple: it means freedom, the end of slavery. That’s how Booker T. Washington saw it. “Finally,” he wrote in his landmark autobiography, “Up From Slavery,” “the war closed, and the day of freedom came. … Freedom was in the air and had been for months.”

Who knew that all you need to be president of the United States is a modicum of common sense? All year, the candidates for the Republican nomination have been touting their intimate relationship with this humdrum way of seeing the world. Michele Bachmann claimed that “everything I needed to know in life I learned in Iowa,” which she left at the age of 12. Rick Perry told Iowans that unlike the current president, he doesn’t have a lot of interest in “studies” when it comes to restoring economic health. “We know what the problem is,” he said. “It’s not magic, it is actually common sense.” We shouldn’t “spend all the money.” Even decidedly unfolksy Mitt Romney announced this week at a gathering of Americans for Prosperity, “I believe we can save Social Security with a few common-sense reforms.”

It stands to reason that when we put a story on the cover we think it's worthy of your time and effort, and this week there is no doubt about that. With the singularity of purpose that an intelligence officer brings to an interrogation room, Ronen Bergman has powerfully illuminated the past and present of Israeli prisoner exchanges, focusing on the recent swap of 1,027 Palestinians for a single Israeli soldier named Gilad Shalit. How can such a deal be justified in a nation that prides itself on not negotiating with terrorists? What about the citizens who've been killed and maimed by those now being freed? These are the questions that drive Bergman's story.

Wednesday night, beneath an inverted five-pointed star hanging from the ceiling of the Masonic Lodge at the Hollywood Forever Cemetery in Los Angeles, the artists Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe presented "Shadow Pool: A Natural History of the San San International" to a crowd of 350 that included Gus Van Sant and Jeffrey Deitch, who commissioned the piece for the Museum of Contemporary Art. This multimedia extravaganza - part slide show and lecture, part fashion show, part art installation, part rock 'n' roll freakout - is the latest iteration of the fictional parallel universe the duo has been imagining and manifesting since 2008, with installations at Ballroom Marfa, Deitch Projects, Miami Art Basel and Country Club at R.M. Schindler's Buck House in West Hollywood, which they transformed into an artfully ravaged psychedelic laboratory, the onetime site of out-there experiments with a drug called "Marasa." "Shadow Pool" expands upon and then explodes this mythology, holding up the shards for our sensory pleasure, and confusion.

Heroes in half-shells, frogs with banjos and even killer tires are a part of a lively film series being presented by BAMcinématek called Puppets on Film. For two weekends, Nov. 12-14 and 18-20, the Brooklyn Academy of Music will screen a variety of films that trade high-tech computer graphics and special effects for old-fashioned foam and fabric. The series comes just before the Muppets make a big-screen comeback in a new feature film. The Muppets are a part of this series as well, and for those nostalgic for Jim Henson's creations, the series will include both the original "Muppet Movie," "Muppet Treasure Island" and the Henson-directed fantasy film "The Dark Crystal." The slide show above looks at some of the kid-friendly ("Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles") and not-so-kid friendly ("Team America: World Police") movies the festival has to offer. More can be found at the BAM Web site.

The men's-wear designer Adam Kimmel is no stranger to a statement scarf or skinny, bare-chested male models. But Kimmel can also toughen things up, as he proves with his newest collection for Carhartt, a work-wear brand for hardy men with callused hands and steely stares who nevertheless find occasions to don $410 canvas blazers. The Moment recently sneaked a peek at the Adam Kimmel x Carhartt look book, which outfits three roguish, chain-saw-wielding members of the art collective Paintallica. This group, made up mostly of University of Iowa alums, works in nightlong spurts, carving totemic wooden structures with power tools. Paint, fire, beer, a range of motor vehicles and sometimes guns are involved. "We're interested in the same things that guys who shop in Wal-Mart in Des Moines, Iowa, are interested in," said Dan Attoe, a founding member of the group (he's the bearded one pictured above). "But we also know what's out in the world. Adam has a similar approach with Carhartt. He's making something that's fashionable but that someone in a rural area can still appreciate."Adam Kimmel x Carhartt, $40-$425. Available next month at Barneys.

As worries over the safety of some European sovereign bonds grew this year, volume in credit default swaps rose sharply, particularly in September. But the changes in net contracts outstanding rose at a much slower pace. The charts show the daily market rate on 10-year government bonds and the annual cost of a credit default swap to insure against default for a $10 million government bond for five years. They also show the weekly volume in such swaps and the net positions of all holders. The charts begin in July 2010, when information on swap volume became available.

Though, as Jason Zinoman has written, New York is a "something of a sprawling comedy festival the entire year," there is actually a reason for the crush of jokes: the New York Comedy Festival is officially under way through Sunday. Of course, much of the bits you see onstage aren't exactly Times-appropriate, so we decided to pose a challenge to select comedians: tell us your best clean joke. Domingo Milella first saw a bristlecone pine when a friend showed him an iPhone picture of a tree growing along the Methuselah Walk. It was one of the world's oldest living trees, but at the time it didn't interest Milella as a photographic subject. He says, "It came back to me only after a year, as if a presence that lingered, but never disappeared." That's when Milella, whose work has previously appeared in T Magazine, suggested he shoot the tree for the magazine. In our business, a good idea doesn't ordinarily have a shelf life of a year, but given that some trees in the ancient bristlecone pine forest are likely 5,000 years old, we had a little more wiggle room with the publication date than usual. This one gave new meaning to "evergreen," a journalistic term signifying a feature that can run at any time.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 produced a record $400 million in sales and 6.5 million units sold in its the first 24 hours after going on sale in the United States and United Kingdom, Reuters reported. The game, from Activision Blizzard, went on sale at midnight on Tuesday. The figure surpassed the previous record of $360 million set by "Call of Duty: Black Ops," set last year. By contrast, the movie "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2," had gross receipts of $169 million for its opening weekend, tops for the year so far, according to Box Office Mojo.

Nebraska knows there will be a football game Saturday at Penn State. And it's a pretty big game, too, with the Huskers (7-2 over all, 3-2 Big Ten) tied for second in the Legends Division and the Nittany Lions first in the Leaders Division at 5-0, 8-1 over all.

Though the events, all weekend long, are varied -- exhibits, tastings, cooking demonstrations and sales -- they share a single obsession: chocolate. The 14th annual Chocolate Show, at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue), in Chelsea, will feature leading chefs like Jacques Torres, as well as small artisanal producers. This year's show has a Kids' Zone, where children can grab a handful of chocolate and win tickets to a production of "Peter Pan" at Madison Square Garden if they find a specially wrapped sweet. The show runs from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Friday and Saturday, and from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Sunday. Adult tickets are $30 in advance or $35 at the door Friday and Sunday. Saturday tickets are $35 for adults and $40 at the door. Two children ages 5 through 12 can enter free if accompanied by an adult. Each additional child is $8, and children 4 and under are admitted free.

The Dallas Symphony Orchestra will cut back on the number of subscription concerts it performs amid a cash crunch. Orchestra officials said this week that subscription concerts will go from 21 weeks this season to 16 next season; the five weeks instead will be devoted to community concerts. The move will save on production costs and fees paid to guest conductors, said David J. Hyslop, the orchestra's interim president and chief operating officer. The orchestra's musicians have agreed to forgo wages increases for the past two seasons and agreed to a wage freeze for this season and next, reflecting the same straitened circumstances experienced by many orchestras around the country. Mr. Hyslop said the orchestra has projected a $6.5 million budget deficit this season, but after an emergency appeal for donations to the board on Tuesday and the cost-cutting steps, that number should drop.

The American balladeer James Taylor will plunge into the world of Charles Dickens. Mr. Taylor will play the role of Bob Cratchit in a production of "A Christmas Carol" by the Berkshire Theater Group next month. The show is adapted by Eric Hill from Dickens' ghostly tale; Mr. Hill will co-direct along with E. Gray Simons III, the theater group said in an announcement on Friday. "I know that James will bring his inherent charm and gentleness to bear in his portrayal of Bob Cratchit, a good and unpretentious man," Mr. Hill said. "A Christmas Carol" will run Dec. 17-30 at the Colonial Theater in Pittsfield, Mass.

Fitting rooms, sales racks and lines at the register seem to stoke fear in many men, so a surplus of e-commerce sites have popped up to make online shopping not only convenient but appealing. Take, for example, ASOS, the Britain-based e-tailer that stocks a range of labels - from heritage (Filson) to high-end (Prada) to Scandinavian (Henrik Vibskov) - under one URL. The site's extensive mix of prices and styles caters to the male buyer who appreciates one-stop shopping. And streamlining the process even more is ASOS's affordable namesake line, which offers everything from slim, tailored classics (like these houndstooth trousers, $72) to trendier pieces (knit jacket, $198, and Fair Isle hoodie, $87).

Shepard Fairey, the influential street artist who last month designed an invitation for an Occupy Wall Street party in Times Square, is once again unfurling the income equality banner, this time to raise money for the homeless. The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation selected Fairey to inaugurate its Artist as Activist series; 100 signed prints of the new Fairey poster, "The Future is Unwritten," will be available for purchase later today at artnet.com/auctions, starting at $1,250. Almost all of the proceeds benefit the nonprofit organization Coalition for the Homeless, which provides soup kitchens and job training for destitute New Yorkers. Fairey said that his poster references Depression-era styles like Art Deco, and that its title comes from Joe Strummer of the Clash, whom he called "a dedicated advocate for the working class."

A long rope of sweet yeast dough is tightly wrapped in a spiral around a wooden form, something like a rolling pin. It is then baked, slowly turning, often in a hearth. But unless you happen to be from a Transylvanian village, do not try this at home. Anna Kozma, who hails from Romania, said this special-occasion cake (called kurtoskalacs, or chimney cake) was just a provincial treat until after the fall of Communism, when entrepreneurs began opening city shops in Romania, Hungary and elsewhere in Europe.

I didn't think I could love Philip Levine any more than I already did, but then he gave this interview to Andrew Goldman in our Nov. 6 issue (in which, of his diminishing hostility - or at least overt hostility - toward the rich, he says: "I've met them now under silly circumstances, and they seem like hopeless jerks to me, for the most part"). If you've ever worked a terrible job or felt some kinship with people who have to work too hard and who get too little of what they deserve, then Levine was your personal poet laureate long before he became America's official poet laureate.

Patriots (5-3) at Jets (5-3)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Jets by 1.5.The seventh annual Patriots Dynasty Deathwatch is under way. The team has lost two straight games, prompting the usual hand-wringing about eras ending and la belle époque coming to a melancholy fin. We have now endured over a half-decade of laments about how a team that routinely wins 11 to 16 games per year is not what it used to be, simultaneously criticizing Bill Belichick for his recent personnel decisions and genuflecting before the altar of his past accomplishments. No wonder otherwise sane people ardently root against this team.The Patriots' need to prolong their dramatic swoon to William Shatner lengths, coupled with the usual noisy Jets' chest thumping, has turned this into the most torturously overblown rivalry in the N.F.L. Unless you are a lifelong Jets or Patriots fan, you feel you have been clamped to your seat, eyelids taped open, neck immobilized and forced to watch. It's less a battle of two great teams (both are highly flawed this season) than a battle of attention hounds of differing styles. The Jets should win easily - the Patriots have only one starting-caliber cornerback to handle three very good Jets receivers - but "let us again bid fond farewell to the glorious Patriots" conversations that will dominate the following week make it almost not worth the trouble. Pick: Jets.

Rarely do two major museums share their most precious holdings. But in celebration of the Spain-Russia Dual Year -- dedicated to strengthening cultural and economic ties between the two countries -- the Prado National Museum and the  State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg  agreed to exchange treasures, giving visitors to both institutions an unprecedented opportunity to see works outside their usual environment. Last winter, the Prado Museum sent 60 works to St. Petersburg. Now it's Russia's turn.

The two premiers pledged to write a "new chapter" in bilateral relations by resuming dialogue on all issues, including ones that had "bedeviled" ties (The Indian Express). Mr. Singh announced that India has decided to move toward a Preferential Trade Agreement with Pakistan, his return gift for Pakistan's most-favored nation gesture. He also said that a liberalized visa regime would soon be implemented, replacing the current system (The Hindu).
