MEYER--Doris Asiel, 96, died peacefully at home in Delray Beach, FL, on November 5. Born in New York City to Nelson I. Asiel and Ethel Rossin Asiel, she was predeceased by her husband, Blakeman Q. Meyer, and by her brother Robert Asiel. Mrs. Meyer was a graduate of the Knox School in Cooperstown, NY, and Finch College in New York City. During World War II, she served as a nurse's aide, treating hospitalized veterans. Continuing her efforts in public service in the 1950s, she was a regular volunteer for the Arthritis Foundation. In the 1960s, she worked for New York City Mayor John Lindsay and became his liaison with the New York State Federation of Republican Women. An avid golfer, she was a member of the Stanwich Club in Greenwich, CT, and the Little Club in Gulf Stream, FL. She is survived by her brother E. Nelson Asiel, son Robert Gimbel, daughter-in-law Despina Gimbel, granddaughter Alexandra Gimbel, grandsons David Gimbel (Amelia) and Mark Gimbel (Dede Welles) and great-grandchildren Lucas and Lila Gimbel. Funeral services private. Donations in her memory may be made to the Hospice of PBC, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL, 33407 or online at: www.hpbcf.org

BERNSTEIN--Beverly, 99, died peacefully on November 10, 2011. Beverly was a devoted NYC Public School teacher. With her late husband Robert Bernstein, she founded Ivy League Day Camp. She was the loving wife of Bob, dedicated mother of Alison Bernstein, and the adoring grandmother of Emma and Julia Brown-Bernstein. Funeral services will take place on November 11 at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St.

KUNTZ--Mary Kerkvliet, died peacefully, age 90, in West Palm Beach, FL on November 8, 2011. Always an independent and determined spirit, she cherished above all her late husband Bill, her family and friends. She is survived by her children Peggy Crow, William R. Kuntz, Jr., Jane Kellersman and Thomas Kuntz; daughters-in-law Susan Kuntz and Carol Kuntz; son-in-law John Kellersman; ten beloved grandchildren; a great-grandson; sister Mabel Grong and brothers Harold and Richard Kerkvliet. Memorial service, St. Paul of the Cross Church, North Palm Beach, FL on Saturday, November 12, 2011, 9:30am. Contributions can be made to Lost Tree Village Charitable Foundation or Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc.

9:30 P.M. (Showtime) THE LAST PLAY AT SHEA (2010) The histories of Shea Stadium, the Mets, Billy Joel (above) and New York City itself across four and a half decades intersect in this documentary from Paul Crowder, which focuses on Mr. Joel's concerts on July 16 and July 18, 2008 -- the last performances given in the stadium, which was torn down the next year. '' 'The Last Play at Shea' has a built-in happy ending that is almost too good to be true,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, discussing the sudden appearance of Paul McCartney. ''For the July 18 concert, Mr. McCartney miraculously appeared, having been whisked through customs at Kennedy International Airport after a flight from London that had been allowed to land early. He was sped to the stadium by a motorcade in 11 minutes and driven onto the field in time to perform by Pete Flynn, the dedicated groundskeeper who had driven the Beatles to the same stage 43 years earlier,'' on Aug. 15, 1965. Mr. Holden added: '' 'If it weren't for the Beatles,' Mr. Joel declares, 'I wouldn't do what I do.' Call it perfect symmetry. The final number, 'Let It Be,' rings as a sweet valedictory to all the struggle, the teamwork and the glory captured in this wonderful film.'' 8 P.M. (Hallmark) AMERICAN HUMANE ASSOCIATION HERO DOG AWARDS Carson Kressley hosts this ceremony honoring dogs who have displayed exemplary devotion, bravery and companionship in the categories of service, therapy, military, law enforcement and arson, hearing, guide, and search and rescue. The cheering section includes Betty White, Peter Fonda, Paula Abdul, Faith Ford and Olivia Munn.

SELLING A STAKE Anglo American, the British mining giant led by Cynthia Carroll, below, has agreed to sell a 24.5 percent stake in its Chilean copper assets to the Mitsubishi Corporation for $5.39 billion. The deal, which was outlined late on Wednesday, thwarts plans by Chile's state-owned copper producer Codelco to exercise its option early next year to buy a 49 percent stake in Anglo American's local operations, known as Anglo American Sur. MARK SCOTT

PETERSEN--Vita 1915 - 2011. Vita Petersen was an abstract expressionist painter and part of the New York circle of artists that included Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, and Hedda Sterne among others. She was a friend of Mercedes Matter with whom she started the New York Studio School and where she remained Trustee and member of the board of governors until her death at 96 on October 22 at her home in Manhattan. She remained fiercely involved with the students until the end. Born in 1915 in Berlin to a family prominent in German history, her father was German Secretary of State in the 1920s; her mother was a descendant of Moses Mendelssohn. Vita fled the Nazis, in 1938 emigrating to New York with her husband Gustav Petersen to whom she was married for 60 years until his death on October 19, 2002. She began art school at 16 when Max Liebermann, the internationally known artist told her reluctant parents: "Any blind person with a crutch can see she has talent," In New York she studied with Hans Hofmann and exhibited in Berlin and New York at the Stable Gallery and the Betty Parsons Gallery, among others. She had her last solo show when she was 94 Inventive to the end, even as her eyesight dimmed, she changed to black and white from her earlier color. These last paintings, considered some of her finest work will be exhibited this winter. Her ability to grow and experiment was an inspiration to the large number of young artists who constantly sought her advice. She is survived by her daughter Andrea Petersen, granddaughter Jessica Chermayeff, son-in-law Peter Chermayeff, nephews Ernest von Simson and Wolfgang Traber, and a large and loving group of extended family and friends. The family is planning a memorial at the New York Studio School at 2pm on January 29.

The company, which owns MTV Networks and Paramount Pictures, said Thursday its net earnings were $614 million, or $1.06 cents a share, compared with $461 million, or 75 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Total revenue jumped 22 percent to $4 billion, driven by a 46 percent increase at the filmed entertainment unit.

4:06 p.m. | Updated Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist, is stepping down as the host of the ''Piano Jazz'' after more than three decades on the air, said a spokeswoman for NPR, Anna Christopher. Ms. McPartland, who is 93 years old, will stay on as the artistic director of the show, which she began hosting in April 1979, Ms. Christopher said. She has not recorded a new show since September 2010, and the producers have been making new episodes with a guest hosts, among them Elvis Costello, Jon Weber and Bill Charlap. NPR stations have also been re-running shows from Ms. McPartland's vast catalogue.

STERN--Joanne M. It is with enormous sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of its great friend and leader Joanne M. Stern. A member of the Council since 1968, Joanne became a MoMA trustee in 1970. She served brilliantly as the Council's President from 1971-1986. Everybody who knew her admired her extraordinary wit, intelligence, warmth, and humor. We will all miss her beyond measure. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Joanne's children Nicholas Stern, Thomas Stern, and Peggy Stern, her stepchildren Chris Stern Hyman and Catherine Stern, her nine grandchildren, and many many friends. Time and the elements had seriously diminished ''The Arrival of the Halve Maen, 1609,'' a lovely, century-old stained-glass window that depicts Henry Hudson's sailing vessel, the Half Moon, on the river that would bear his name. How seriously? It was possible to work in the library of the New-York Historical Society for weeks at a time - as I have - without being aware that there was a lovely, century-old stained-glass window in the room. In fact, there are two 13-foot-tall stained-glass windows. The other, depicting the revocation of the Edict of Nantes by Louis XIV, is known as the Huguenot Memorial.

Though the United States under-23 men's national team, aka the Olympic team, is training in Germany through Wednesday, come early next year it will (or make that should) benefit from playing regional qualifying matches for the London Olympics in the good old U.S. of A. On Thursday, U.S. Soccer and Concacaf, the regional governing body, announced that the eight-nation qualifying tournament would be played in Nashville; Carson, Calif.; and Kansas City, Kan., March 22 to April 2. The teams will be divided into two groups of four, with the two top teams in each group advancing to the semifinals. The two semifinal winners will earn berths in the London Olympics next summer.

STERN--Joanne. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of their beloved and long time trustee Joanne M. Stern. Joanne joined the Board of Trustees in 1970 and served on a myriad of committees over her forty-one year association with the Museum. She Chaired the Prints and Illustrated Books Committee (1973-1998), and served on the Executive Committee, the Development Committee, the House Committee, the Committees on Drawings, Film, Publications, Education, Archives and Exhibitions. Additionally, Joanne was the President of the International Council from 1971-86, and later served as a Vice Chairman and President Emerita. Her long time devotion was especially felt and warmly appreciated by the staff of the Department of Prints and Illustrated Books throughout her twenty-five year tenure as their Committee Chair. Her service on these committees and others was always exemplary and she brought a level of wit and dedication that will be sorely missed. In addition to her many commitments to MoMA, Joanne served on the Board of Trustees for the School of American Ballet, the Citizens Committee for Children, and the Visiting Committee for the Smith College Museum of Art. Additionally, Joanne was a trustee for the American Association of University Women Educational Foundation. We will miss not only her devotion to MoMA but we will miss her delightful stories about her years working as a photo editor for LOOK Magazine as well as her vast knowledge of and passion for the art world. We send our condolences to her children Nicholas, Thomas and Peggy, her step-children Chris and Catherine, and their children and families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

IT was only a matter of time. Plants have begun texting for help. Thanks to clever new digital devices, a dry philodendron, undernourished hibiscus, or sadly neglected wandering Jew can send its owner a text or Twitter message. Humans like to feel appreciated, so a begonia may also send a simple "Thank-you" text - when it's happy, as gardeners like to say, meaning healthy and well-tended. Picture your Boston fern home alone placing Botanicalls. But why should potted plants be the only ones to reassure their humans? Another company has found a way for crops to send text messages in unison, letting their farmer know if she's doing a good enough job to deserve a robust harvest. What is the sound of one hand of bananas clapping? Probes monitoring the soil can send a range of prerecorded messages specific to each plant's needs.

Theatrical riffs on the 1975 novel ''Looking for Mr. Goodbar'' and on the work of Susan Sontag are among the pieces to be presented at the eighth annual Under the Radar festival, running Jan. 4 to 15 at theaters and performance spaces across New York City. The 12-day festival, which is overseen by the Public Theater, features new shows from nine countries, including Argentina, Italy, Japan and Poland. The festival's producer, Mark Russell, said in a statement that the event ''will directly and indirectly investigate the issues that face us today -- the inequities between the rich and poor; our own history of resistance and radical thought; and the roots of individual freedom and identity.''

An article on Tuesday about payments made by the Olympus Corporation to hide investment losses misstated, at two points, the time frame during which its former chief executive, Michael Woodford, was fired. He was fired on Oct. 14, not in ''mid-September'' and not ''the day after'' he sent a letter dated Oct. 11 calling for an investigation of the matter.

Ed Pauls, whose frustration at running on ice-slick Minnesota roads led him to develop the cross-country skiing simulator known as the NordicTrack, died on Oct. 9 at his home in Montrose, Colo. He was 80. The cause was Alzheimer's disease, his daughter, Terri, said.

The Riff column on Page 54 this weekend, about age and cultural relevance, misstates the author's age in 1998, when a toy with a McDonald's meal made sounds her grandmother could not hear. It was 15, not 8 or 9. The column also misidentifies the children's story in which a mirror answers the question ''Who's the Fairest of Them All?'' It is ''Snow White,'' not ''Sleeping Beauty.''

WARREN--Goldie. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the passing of our cherished friend, Goldie Warren, who, with her beloved husband of 70 years, Joseph Warren, Esq., was a frequent visitor to the University. She will be greatly missed. Mr. and Mrs. Warren's long-standing friendship with our late president emeritus Joshua Lederberg will always be remembered with pride by the campus community. Together with Mr. Warren, she was a longtime and steadfast supporter of the University, a wonderful legacy of their shared belief in the importance of basic scientific research in providing answers to the many health problems that afflict humanity. The Warrens' daughter, Hermine, worked closely with Dr. Lederberg for many years and we are grateful for her continued advocacy on the University's behalf. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joseph, Hermine, Laura and the entire Warren family. Russell Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Marguerite Lederberg, M.D. Marnie Imhoff, V.P. for Development The Rockefeller University

The Dallas Symphony Orchestra will cut back on the number of subscription concerts it performs amid a cash crunch. Orchestra officials said this week that subscription concerts will go from 21 weeks this season to 16 next season; the five weeks instead will be devoted to community concerts. The move will save on production costs and fees paid to guest conductors, said David J. Hyslop, the orchestra's interim president and chief operating officer. The orchestra's musicians have agreed to forgo wages increases for the past two seasons and agreed to a wage freeze for this season and next, reflecting the same straitened circumstances experienced by many orchestras around the country. Mr. Hyslop said the orchestra has projected a $6.5 million budget deficit this season, but after an emergency appeal for donations to the board on Tuesday and the cost-cutting steps, that number should drop. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

COLUMBIA, S.C. - Gov. Rick Perry of Texas strode down Sumter Street in the Veterans Day parade here on Friday morning, a day after doing a series of network interviews and an appearance on the David Letterman show - all meant to atone for his debate flub on Wednesday night. In this state, where Mr. Perry must do well, the question is not whether a lot of Republicans still like or sympathize with him - they do - but how many will vote for him. Voters may now see him as not wanting the presidency badly enough, or as a candidate who would simply get outfoxed by President Obama in the general election.

The housing market may have crashed in many parts of the country, but there is still a contingent of would-be buyers living an alternate reality. They make a decent living, they save, but it's still not enough to break into the gated communities formerly known as New York, Los Angeles and Boston. In these metropolitan areas and their outskirts, pricing is likely to end up higher, relative to local income, than it was before the housing bubble, according to Fiserv Case-Shiller.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 produced a record $400 million in sales and 6.5 million units sold in its the first 24 hours after going on sale in the United States and United Kingdom, Reuters reported. The game, from Activision Blizzard, went on sale at midnight on Tuesday. The figure surpassed the previous record of $360 million set by ''Call of Duty: Black Ops,'' set last year. By contrast, the movie ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2,'' had gross receipts of $169 million for its opening weekend, tops for the year so far, according to Box Office Mojo. The record sales are the second big boost for a sluggish video game industry this fall. Call of Duty's biggest rival, Battlefield 3 (from Electronic Arts), sold 5 million units in its first week in stores last month, making it the fastest-selling game in that company's history, according to The Associated Press.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night in Rochester, Mich., referred incorrectly in some copies to bank bailouts that were cited as an example of the government's overreaching. REICHEK--Morton A.,a senior editor and senior writer for Business Week Magazine, died November 8, 2011. He lived in Boynton Beach, FL and was 87 years old. During his retirement, Reichek became one of the most prolific and well read "elderly bloggers," writing about politics, his childhood, Israel, and his war experiences. His blog www.octogenarian.blogspot.com was highlighted in the NY Times, Wall Street Journal, and AARP magazine. A journalist with very wide interests, Reichek wrote about topics ranging from business to military affairs to Yiddish literature. He was with Business Week, both in Washington, DC and New York for 31 years, retiring in 1988. Prior to joining the magazine in 1952, he was a press officer and editor for the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service. During two periods of absence from Business Week, he was a Washington correspondent for the New house newspaper chain, an associate editor of Forbes Magazine and director of editorial services for Gulf & Western Industries, Inc. Reichek contributed articles to the New York Times, The New York Times Book Review, The New Republic, The New Leader, and the Columbia Journalism Review. He was a former member of the National Press Club, the National Book Critics Circle and the American Society of Journalists and Authors. He is also listed in the Who's Who in America. He was born in the East Harlem section of Manhattan and raised in the Bronx near Yankee Stadium. He attended DeWitt Clinton High School and earned a B.S. in journalism from New York University using the GI Bill. During WWII he served as a staff sergeant in the U.S. Army Signal Corps and was based for more than two years in the China-Burma-India Theater of Operations. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Sybil Reichek, a daughter, Amy Reichek of San Francisco, a son, Jim Reichek of Madison, NJ and three grandsons. Another daughter, Marjorie, predeceased him.

The second live results episode of ''The X Factor'' carried Fox to another Thursday night ratings victory in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic despite falling 11 percent in that demo compared to last week and dropping to 10.2 million total viewers from 11.5 million last week. CBS made the curious choice of filling most of its programming slate with repeats in the middle of November sweeps, but a new episode of ''The Big Bang Theory'' was enough to earn the network second place in the 18-to-49 category and first in overall audience. That geeky comedy was once again the highest-rated show of the night and drew 15.7 million total viewers.

WASSERMAN--Dr. Bernard.,91, of Brooklyn Heights, died November 11. Dearly beloved husband of the late Bernice, cherished father of Harvey and Kim and Andrew and Donna; loving grandfather of Jake and Sarah; beloved uncle, cousin and friend. The American balladeer James Taylor will plunge into the world of Charles Dickens. Mr. Taylor will play the role of Bob Cratchit in a production of ''A Christmas Carol'' by the Berkshire Theater Group next month. The show is adapted by Eric Hill from Dickens' ghostly tale; Mr. Hill will co-direct along with E. Gray Simons III, the theater group said in an announcement on Friday. ''I know that James will bring his inherent charm and gentleness to bear in his portrayal of Bob Cratchit, a good and unpretentious man,'' Mr. Hill said. ''A Christmas Carol'' will run Dec. 17-30 at the Colonial Theater in Pittsfield, Mass. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE VOYAGE OF THE DAWN TREADER (2010) Lucy Pevensie (Georgie Henley, above, with the lion Aslan) and her brother, Edmund (Skandar Keynes), joined by their chatterbox cousin Eustace Scrubb (Will Poulter), are lured back into Narnia by a maritime painting that turns into a Niagara Falls, sweeping the children out to sea in this franchise's third installment, directed by Michael Apted. Soon they've been rescued by their old comrade in arms, King Caspian (Ben Barnes), and brought aboard his ship, now armed with a crew of clean-cut men and talking beasts, including a mouse-kateer named Reepicheep (voiced by Simon Pegg). ''Though there are times when the movie turns into a congested mess, as in a climactic battle that washes the screen in gray, there are moments when you also see a quieter, less industrial production,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Such is the case after Eustace is turned into a grand, ungainly, unhappy dragon. When he lies forlornly on a beach, or as forlornly as dragons do, and a monstrous-size tear slides down his scaly face, you don't just see the wizardry magic, you also see the human touch behind it.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson reports from the United States Army Chaplain Center and School at Fort Jackson, S.C., where counseling is available to help members of the clergy.

The court-appointed trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Global's broker-dealer unit laid off 1,066 employees on Friday, keeping only a skeleton staff to assist in the dissolution of the business. The trustee, James W. Giddens, will rehire 150 to 200 employees to help wind down the broker-dealer and process bankruptcy claims. Not all of these people will be among the staff members who were laid off on Friday, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook.

An analysis of 260 employers that suspended their 401(k) matching contributions in the depths of the recession has found that most have restored them, although some now offer a lower level of benefits. The report, from the professional services firm Towers Watson, found that about three-fourths of the employers that suspended matching contributions after 2008 have now brought them back.

On Monday night, Mark Howe will at long last be where he belongs: in the Hockey Hall of Fame. Howe became eligible for election to the Hall in 1998, three years after his distinguished 22-season career ended, but only now is he being ushered into a club in which he has long deserved membership. Yet even that is somehow fitting for Howe, whose quiet excellence tended to be overlooked throughout his career.

Kashmir's tenuous relationship with Delhi lies at the heart of its political problems, the report says.

Is free will an illusion?  Some leading scientists think so.  For instance, in 2002 the psychologist Daniel Wegner wrote, "It seems we are agents. It seems we cause what we do It is sobering and ultimately accurate to call all this an illusion." More recently, the neuroscientist Patrick Haggard declared, "We certainly don't have free will.  Not in the sense we think."  And in June, the neuroscientist Sam Harris claimed, "You seem to be an agent acting of your own free will. The problem, however, is that this point of view cannot be reconciled with what we know about the human brain."

For five days last week, I blogged about the players eligible for the Hall of Fame on the Golden Era ballot, advocating for three to be inducted and five to be turned away. I feel strongly that Minnie Minoso has been unfairly overlooked, and I'm convinced that Gil Hodges's managerial magic combined with his playing career should put him over the top and that Ron Santo, as one of the 10 best third basemen to play the game before 1990 (despite having the advantage of hitting in Wrigley Field), deserves entry. And while I wouldn't be horrified if Jim Kaat, Allie Reynolds, Louis Tiant, or especially Tony Oliva and Ken Boyer made it in, I don't think they belong.

Via my friend Amy Lipton, a curator at EcoArtspace, I just discovered "The Marcellus Shale Experiment." In this fascinating blog, the Philadelphia-based artist Jennie Shanker is chronicling her efforts to create ceramics using clay from the Marcellus Shale region -- best known as a big new source for natural gas through the much-debated method called fracking, or hydraulic fracturing (recently explored by Times columnist David Brooks).

In "The Fall of the Middlewoman," Open Magazine looks at Niira Radia's decision to "vanish into the blue" by closing up the public relations shop she built. Ms. Radia, who became a central figure in the investigation into the sale of second-generation wireless spectrum after Open published transcripts of her various conversations with businessmen and politicians, closed her business on October 30. In this speculative story, Open suggests, without a named source, that she left at the behest of political establishment types who were eager to see that the name of Tata Group, her largest client, was not dragged through the mud any more than it had been. "Her disappearance would give a legitimate excuse to the CBI and ED to quietly close the relevant 'Radia' files in the near future," the magazine said, referring to the Central Bureau of Investigation and the Enforcement Directorate.

High in the White Mountains of eastern California is a forest of trees that are among the oldest living things on earth. The Great Basin bristlecone pines are so ghostly, gnarled and ashen that they almost look their age: some trees are nearly 5,000 years old. The bristlecone pine thrives where almost nothing else does, in high-altitude ranges in California, Nevada and Utah. Their wood is so dense and full of resin that they are protected from insects and diseases that would easily kill other trees. (Even mighty California redwoods don't live beyond 2,000 years.) The rings of the bristlecones are startlingly accurate, preserving records of volcanic eruptions and celestial events (like meteor showers) and even helping scientists improve their estimates of historical events. The patriarch of the bristlecones -- known as Methuselah -- is older than the Great Pyramid of Giza. (The Methuselah Grove is accessible to hikers, but the tree itself is unmarked.) Yet for all their longevity, they are not invincible. The leading cause of death of ancient bristlecones, said Adelia Barber, a researcher at U.C. Santa Cruz, is fire. ''Some can survive lightning strikes,'' she said. ''But ultimately lightning sets the trees on fire, and they die.'' Maximum height of bristlecone pine: about 30 feet

Patriots (5-3) at Jets (5-3) Sunday, 8:20 p.m. Line: Jets by 1 .5. The seventh annual Patriots Dynasty Deathwatch is under way. The team has lost two straight games, prompting the usual hand-wringing about eras ending and la belle epoque coming to a melancholy fin. We have now endured over a half-decade of laments about how a team that routinely wins 11 to 16 games per year is not what it used to be, simultaneously criticizing Bill Belichick for his recent personnel decisions and genuflecting before the altar of his past accomplishments. No wonder otherwise sane people ardently root against this team. The Patriots' need to prolong their dramatic swoon to William Shatner lengths, coupled with the usual noisy Jets' chest thumping, has turned this into the most torturously overblown rivalry in the N.F.L. Unless you are a lifelong Jets or Patriots fan, you feel you have been clamped to your seat, eyelids taped open, neck immobilized and forced to watch. It's less a battle of two great teams (both are highly flawed this season) than a battle of attention hounds of differing styles. The Jets should win easily - the Patriots have only one starting-caliber cornerback to handle three very good Jets receivers - but ''let us again bid fond farewell to the glorious Patriots'' conversations that will dominate the following week make it almost not worth the trouble. Pick: Jets. Lions (6-2) at Bears (5-3) Sunday, 4:15 p.m. Line: Bears by 2.5 . Lions defensive tackle Ndamukong Suh had a private meeting with Commissioner Roger Goodell on Nov. 1 in which Goodell reportedly clarified the N.F.L.'s rules regarding unnecessary roughness. Suh was later seen walking down Park Avenue with his hair singed and pupils dilated, like Charlton Heston coming down from Mount Sinai in ''The Ten Commandments.'' Suh is now the only person on earth who understands the N.F.L.'s rules regarding unnecessary roughness. Apparently, it is not some arbitrary foul based upon a referee's personal interpretation of unenforceable, over-legislated mandates, sometimes coaxed by convincing method writhing by the quarterback. It only appears that way to the unenlightened. Goodell should meet with all of us, one by one, until everyone understands: the guy who runs your fantasy league next week, then Brian Baldinger, then finally Michael Vick, who will learn about the exceptions that apply only to him. The Suh summit was well timed: the Bears and the Lions combined for 26 penalties in their October meeting, a few of them caused by the exuberance of Suh's teammates and Jay Cutler's pro wrestling reaction to every brush on the elbow. The Bears' offensive line has solidified since that penalty-marred mess, but if Suh spreads his message of peace to his teammates, the Bears will not benefit from the 15-yard freebies the Lions have been handing out all year. Pick: Lions.

GAMPER--David Edwards, 66, of New York, NY, and Landgrove, VT, born on June 15, 1945, in Findlay, OH, died on Tuesday, September 27, 2011, at his home in Landgrove. David leaves a legacy of innovation and imagination, which impacted the worlds of music, the arts and philanthropy. He will be deeply missed by his wife Gisela, his son Christopher and his family, his mother Harriet, his sister Jo Ann Eder and her family, and many friends and colleagues. For a full obituary please visit Legacy.com

LOVGREN--Margaret Mary, passed away peacefully in Kennebunk, ME on October 31, following a brief hospitalization. Born in New York on May 20, 1915, with husband Charles and her mother Peggy Stauble she was one of the original tenants of Peter Cooper Village. Her husband, who served in the Army in Europe during World War II, receiving a bronze star, and who was thereafter with the Pentagon, had joined administrative staff at the United Nations. After his premature death in 1966, and her mother's soon after, she devoted her life to good works, including reading to the blind. A devout member of the Parish of Calvary St. George's, she was honored there in 2009 for long service on the Altar Guild, the Thrift Shop Board, and the telephone ministry. She then relocated to Maine to Huntington Common Retirement Community to be near family. She expressed deep satisfaction with the richness of her 96 years. Following retirement from many years in executive positions, notably with American Thread Company and with Jenkins Brothers, she travelled widely, from China to England, where she as Anglophile could trace maternal Moore family roots to before the time of King Henry VIII. Special memories included childhood visits to her paternal grandfather's farm near Hurley, NY. She loved time with family and her large circle of cherished friends, who have the legacy of her grace, intelligence, elegance, compassionate generosity, and enthusiastic engagement with life and lifelong learning. She is survived by nephews Carl Anderson of Mt. Bethel, PA, and Ralph Anderson of Annapolis, MD; by nieces Elsa van Bergen of Scarborough and Kennebunk, ME, and Darlene DeMarsico, of Brooklyn, NY; by grandnephews and a grandniece; and by several cousins. There will a memorial service at Calvary St George's Church, Park Avenue South and 21st Street, New York City on December 16 at 11am. Interment will be private at a later date. Donations may be made in her name to: Calvary St. George's Church, 61 Gramercy Park North, New York, NY 10010; or to the Salvation Army, or to Doctors Without Borders.

A visit to Store Bay demands stamina. You'll have to fight your way through the crowds -- the small, handsome beach is one of Tobago's most popular -- and wave off all manner of vendor: Boat ride? Aloe vera massage? Bob Marley magnet? Head to the food stalls at the back edge of the beach. The reward is that first bite. Store Bay sells some of the most delicious food on the island, no small feat considering how seriously Tobago takes its cuisine, a mélange of African and East Indian flavors. At Miss Trim's or Miss Jean's stalls, order crab and hefty flour dumplings in curried coconut milk sauce. Leave room fora roti, a sort of curried burrito filled with potatoes, yam and anything from conch to goat; order it ''buss-up-shot''-style and you'll get a plate of fillings with shredded roti skin for dipping. There's coocoo and callaloo, polenta slices smothered in spinach-like soup, and pelau, a stew of rice, pigeon peas, coconut milk and hunks of sugar-seared meats. Corn soup is thick and filling; so is the cow heel soup, usually brimming with ground vegetables like dasheen root, cassava and yam that have long been a staple here. Get dessert to go: bene balls -- sesame seeds congealed with molasses -- and mango or pineapple marinated in spicy pepper sauces and sold in little baggies, perfect for carrying home as a sweet souvenir.

Alan Mootnick once said he felt a certain kinship with gibbons, a small, acrobatic and endangered member of the ape family. Like them, he said, ''I was lean, agile and comical.'' He acted on those feelings by making a Southern California home for the largest gathering of gibbons in the Western Hemisphere; going on ecological missions to their native Asian forests to help save them from extinction; and writing articles for academic journals despite having no formal education in biology.

FINKELSTEIN--Ruth, of NYC. November 10, 2011. She was the beloved sister of Manny and Marilyn Finkelstein and Edward Foster. Loving aunt of Geri and Jerry Zachman, Betsy and Alan Perahia, Steve and Cindy Finkelstein, David and Allison Foster. Cherished great aunt of Joshua, Ashley, Craig, Carly, Ethan, Ross, Reuben, Jude and Miles. A brilliant woman who worked tirelessly as President of her Co-op for 30 years. She retired from the Social Security Service after 35 years. Memorial services will be held on Sunday, November 13th at noon at Boulevard-Riverside Memorial Chapels 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. She was a kind and generous woman who will be sorely missed.

A chart in some editions on Oct. 30 that gave examples of how people in New York City rank by income mislabeled three categories. The category labeled ''Top 10 percent'' contained average income and population for those whose income was greater than 90 percent of Americans, but less than the top 1 percent. Similarly, the category labeled ''Top 1 percent'' contained statistics for those whose income was higher than 99 percent of others, but lower than the top 0.1 percent. And the category labeled ''Top 0.1 percent'' contained statistics for those whose income was higher than 99.9 percent of Americans, but lower than the top 0.01 percent.

''Sweet Violence,'' opening Dec. 18 at the Museum of Modern Art, is the first museum exhibition in the United States of the work of Sanja Ivekovic, who was born in Zagreb in 1949. The show covers four decades of art and includes some 100 photomontages and a group of single-channel videos and media installations, including ''Sweet Violence,'' ''Personal Cuts'' (above) and ''General Alert (Soap Opera)'' (moma.org).

Subject: Erin Judge, 30, a writer in New York. Previous ''Twilight'' exposure: A friend once discussed ''the pregnancy scene'' with Judge because she needed to get it off her chest. Name the four ''Twilight'' books. Something about an apple? The titles are mostly about fruit. One is called ''Breaking Dawn,'' I think, but I could be conflating zombie television. What do you mean? Like, am I mixing up ''Breaking Bad'' or ''Walking Dawn''? Or ''Walking Dead''? You know, to make ''Breaking Dawn''? [Correct answer: ''Twilight,'' ''New Moon,'' ''Eclipse,'' ''Breaking Dawn.''] You might be. Who plays Edward Cullen? Oh! It's that pale kid. Possibly -- is his name Justin? [Correct answer: Robert Pattinson.] Why is Alice in a mental institution? Something about her being pregnant with a vampire baby. [Correct answer: She was having visions of the future.] What are the people in the diner thinking about when Edward reads their minds? How pale he is. [Correct answer: Money, sex and, in one case, a cat.] Who is Jacob? Jacob is a sexy werewolf! [Correct answer: Sexy werewolf.] Everyone knows that one. Yeah! Because of the whole Team Edward vs. Team Jacob thing. Also, Jacob reminds me of Anthony Kiedis in the ''Under the Bridge'' video. Why don't the Cullens eat people? Maybe a person was nice to them once and so they're mainstreamers, like in ''True Blood'' or ''Buffy''? Wait, is Edward's last name Cohen? [Correct answer: They're ''vegetarian'' vampires. They eat animals instead.] Cohen? No. Cullen. With an ''l.' 'Oh, I was going to say maybe it's not kosher. What happens to Twilight vampires in the sun? They're very shiny? They look like marble, like the Lincoln memorial. [Correct answer: They sparkle.] What human sport do vampires play? Lacrosse. Because they're European. [Correct answer: Baseball.] Team Edward or Team Jacob and why? Team Jacob because all of Edward's weird, sappy, sad, virginy, purity, shiny crap is crap. My pro-Jacob stance is at heart an anti-Edward stance.

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about the downfall of the brokerage firm MF Global and the possible exposure of American financial institutions to the debt problems of European countries, quoted incorrectly from a well-known joke by Chico Marx in ''Duck Soup.'' He said, ''Who you gonna believe, me or your own eyes?'' He did not say, ''Who are you going to believe -- me, or your own lying eyes?''

The Economic View column last Sunday, about Republican proposals for a flat tax, defined incorrectly adjusted gross income under the federal tax code. It is the amount earned, minus some expenses and deductions. It does not include other deductions, or exemptions. (Those items are accounted for in what is called taxable income.)

CARSHON--Charles. Actor, director, teacher, Off-Broadway pioneer, died on October 28th. Taught at High School of Performing Arts, Stella Adler Studio, Neighborhood Playhouse, American Academy of Dramatic Art, and was head of Studio Theatre at Sarah Lawrence College for 35 years. Many famous actors passed through his classes. He was 91 and is survived by his wife, Gloria Barret.

When Oscar Hammerstein declared the hills alive with the sound of music, he could have been referring to Jamaican, not Austrian, hills. After all, he's said to have written those lyrics from the terrace of his vacation home in Montego Bay, where he and his wife, Dorothy, hosted lavish dinner parties for the likes of Noël Coward and Richard Burton. His former home is now Highland House, a six-bedroom, fully staffed villa nestled in the rugged mountains above Montego Bay -- and offering a dazzling vista of sea, city lights and lush greenery. The current owner, Brenda Isaacs, meticulously restored the property, merging the past with a New Age present. Much of Dorothy Hammerstein's period furniture remains, but a grand sapphire-colored Buddha now presides over the terrace, and luxurious accommodations like the Zen Room feature four-poster beds and Deco-style décor. The spirituality isn't just aesthetic: Ms. Isaacs runs the One Love Learning Foundation, a partnership between a nearby school and schools in Atlanta and South Africa. Guests at the villa can join her effort by working on the villa's grounds -- 17 acres chockablock with mango trees, papaya groves and an organic vegetable garden -- and personally donating their crop to local schools and orphanages. Highland House, Montego Bay; highlandhouseJamaica.com.

Middle-class Trinidadians talk about going ''down the islands'' with insouciance, as if it were a weekend jaunt to the mall. To those less inured, though, the string of islands between Trinidad and Venezuela will elicit more dramatic reactions. Not only are they a nature-lover's gem -- full of jagged limestone, lush flora, immaculate beaches and neon birds -- they're also brimming with historical remains. You'll marvel at how much history -- from the Amerindian migration from South America, to pirate legacies, Spanish colonization and beyond -- are crammed into so few square miles. Hop on a private speedboat (or one run by local tour companies) and cruise first to the Bocas, a 20-minute ride from northern Trinidad. On the largest of them, Chacachacare, glimpse a tall lighthouse, along with remnants of sundry incarnations: cotton plantation, whaling station, leper colony and, during World War Two, a United States Marine base. Sail on to Monos to spy red howler monkeys, then to Gaspar Grande to explore limestone caves and to relax on Bombshell Bay. The Five Islands are actually six, with Nelson Island most noteworthy. It's an Ellis Island of sorts, embarkation point for indentured laborers from India and China in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Devote time to simply enjoying the ride; many companies are equipped with snorkeling and water-skiing equipment, and all stock Carib beers. DiveTnT offers Down the Island tours; from 2,000 Trinadad Tobago dollars per boat, about $325; divetnt.com.

Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). The Seattle Seahawks unleashed ''Beast Mode'' last week against Dallas and Marshawn Lynch (SEA) owners benefited as the running back trounced the Cowboys for 135 yards and a score, the third-highest fantasy total among RBs in Week 9. The performance prompted Ravens Coach John Harbaugh to say that Lynch is ''definitely a top 2 or 3 running back in the National Football League.'' Was that the same Marshawn Lynch who ran for just 24 yards on 16 carries a week earlier against the Bengals? Let's not get too carried away here. Lynch has been way too inconsistent to be considered a top-rate fantasy running back going forward and he is among our unfavorable matchup picks in Week 10 against Baltimore's third-ranked run defense.

One does not ''party'' in Trinidad, home to the biggest annual carnival in the Caribbean. Instead, one engages in ''liming'': a form of recreation that involves robust quantities of alcohol, droll repartee, frenetic music and, when the tempo demands, equally frenetic dancing. Perfect the art of liming at Smokey & Bunty, a 22-year-old institution in the lively St. James area of Port of Spain, Trinidad's night-life-heavy capital. Locals flock to the place at all hours of the day. Nary is the Trinidadian who has not at some point in her liming career ordered a Stag beer or Johnny Walker and coconut water there, then settled into an outdoor table to chat the night away (inside by the bar, blaring soca tunes -- the irrefutably catchy, ultra- fast-paced music of carnival -- make chitchat a futile endeavor). Yes, there will likely be at least one disorderly customer at some point in the evening, and no, you can't get fancy cocktails. But you can cross the street and order a supremely fresh roti from the woman making them by hand on the same corner she's been on for years. Then return, order another drink and pick up where you left off.

ROSTON--William A. Of New Marlborough, MA and New York, NY, Chairman Emeritus of Prochimie International died on November 5, 2011. He is survived by his wife, MaryAnn, partner and friend for over sixty years, and by his daughters, Alice, Caroline, and Anne. Born February 9, 1923, in Manhattan, he grew up beside the ocean. At age 20, he left Hamilton College to join the US Army's WWII efforts, spending three years in Italy, first as a rifleman, then as a field medic, and ultimately as a code breaker, engaging in top-secret classified intelligence work crucial to uncovering the German army's field positions. After this, he completed degrees in Chemistry and Geography at Middlebury College and played clarinet for the Vermont Symphony Orchestra before studying for his MBA at Columbia University. He was the first international salesman for Dow Chemical Company and was at the forefront in developing international trade in chemicals. Subsequently, he joined the French chemical producer Progil and in 1975 he formed Prochimie, which represents and supplies chemicals to the US market from major producers in Europe and Asia. Bill, as he was known, was an avid athlete and outdoorsman, skiing until his last years, playing tennis competitively, swimming, sailing and treasuring music, books, and poetry. He was an ardent patriot, endlessly inventive, and a natural adventurer who lived with gusto, wit, and passion. His memory will remain indelible with and his spirit carried on by MaryAnn Sanders Roston; Alice Roston; Caroline, Robert, Timothy, and Christopher St. George; Anne, Antti, Susanna, and Laura Korkeakivi; all his other family members, business associates, friends, and any who knew him.

Clo-gin, n. 1. One who blocks an entrance or exit while checking a smartphone. ''A crowd of clogins at the 72nd Street station made Anna miss her train.'' See also: mailingerers (those who pretend to have messages); e-ander (to walk slowly while checking one's messages); sentropy (the tendency to come to a stop to see if a message has been sent).

NOT much more than 20 minutes after hitting the buzzer at Phoebe Stephens's apartment on East 18th Street (after barging in on the upstairs neighbor, who took the intrusion in stride), Ms. Stephens and her sister, Annette, both jewelry designers, were talking about Loulou de la Falaise, a muse to many exotic creatures, who died Nov. 5. ''She was an inspiration,'' Phoebe said. ''A true individual.''

There was an interesting bit of news Friday for the United States men's national team after another goalless outing in an international friendly - it will face a regional minnow, Antigua and Barbuda, when the Americans begin play next June in World Cup qualifying matches in the Concacaf region. With a game to go in the second round of regional qualifying, Antigua and Barbuda (Spanish for ancient and bearded) clinched a spot in the next round with a 1-0 win over visiting Haiti in St. John's, the capital of the two-island nation that lies southeast of Puerto Rico. Jamaica and Guatemala, which also locked down a spot in the next round on Friday, will also be in the qualifying group with the United States. The next round of qualifying in Concacaf consists of three groups of four teams. Games in the third round will be completed in the autumn of 2012. The top two teams in each group advance to the final six-nation qualifying round, which has come to be known as the hexagonal, with play starting early in 2013. The top three finishers earn automatic berths in the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, with the fourth-place team entering a playoff against the winner of the Oceania region, which is likely to be New Zealand. According to the FIFA calendar, the dates for international matches next year are: June 1-5, June 8-12, Sept. 7-11 and Oct. 12-16. The United States' 1-0 loss to France on Friday was already hours old when Antigua and Barbuda (population about 89,000) took the field against Haiti, which could have taken over the group lead with a victory. In a nation where cricket is the most popular sport (the match was played at the cricket stadium, which hosted Cricket World Cup matches in 2007), the 30-year-old midfielder Kerry Skepple, who has played in Finland, scored the game's only goal with eight minutes left in the match. The other three teams in the third round's Group A are most likely already counting on taking 6 points from their two matches (home and home) against the Antiguans. In fact, the composition of all three groups in the third round was settled Friday, with one match day still to be completed. In Group B, El Salvador and surprising Guyana (which is on the South American continent) advanced and join Mexico and Costa Rica. Guyana's upset of Trinidad and Tobago brought to a close a year of soccer turmoil in Trinidad and Tobago: one of the country's most powerful men, Jack Warner, was implicated in a bribery scandal and resigned his positions with FIFA and Concacaf. In Group C, Canada and Panama advanced and will play Honduras and Cuba in the next round. Canada traveled to St. Kitts and Nevis for Friday's game, coming away with a point after a 0-0 tie. ''We knew they needed the 3 points and that they would come out and go for it,'' Canada Coach Stephen Hart told FIFA.com. ''We came here and we knew we had to get a point by playing a road style and we got that, so all in all we're O.K.'' Canada has not played in the World Cup since 1986. Haiti played in the 1974 World Cup in West Germany, and Trinidad and Tobago appeared in the 2006 tournament in Germany. Who do you think has the clearest path to the next round? Canada is in a difficult group with three Latin nations, while the U.S. will face two Caribbean countries. Do we hear road trip? This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

As the beaches south of Cancún become ever more crowded with sprawling resorts, it's getting harder to find a quiet stretch of sand, much less an intimate beachfront inn with fewer than 100 rooms. Which is what makes Hotel Le Rêve, a 25-room boutique hotel about 45 minutes south of Cancún, so special. The chic three-story whitewashed hotel, with its thatched roof and zigzagging infinity pool, draws its share of casual gawkers from nearby all-inclusive resorts -- marked by their plastic wristbands -- who tend to slow down as they stroll past on the beach. Unlike some of its boisterous family-oriented neighbors, Le Rêve caters to grown-ups looking for romance and relaxation. Minimalist rooms accented by dark wood furnishings and hand-painted Mexican tiles have no televisions. Bungalows with mini-infinity pools offer unobscured ocean views. Stake out a white-cushioned lounge chair by the blue-tiled pool and order a drink from the bar. Or grab a book and head for one of the hammocks strung between palm trees on the beach. Rates start at $219 a night, but can often be had for less through online promotions. Hotel Le Rêve, Playa del Carmen, Quintana Roo, Mexico; hotellereve.com.

''Why lie? I need a drink.'' This panhandler request, so distinct from more worthy entreaties, actually works. In a 1994 study, researchers identified the so-called pique technique, which proved that people's standard ''refusal script'' is disrupted by an odd request. It is part of an unofficial field of panhandler studies. Broadly speaking, women are accosted more often than men. Tourists also are particularly good marks, because they are psychologically inclined to spend their money.

You wouldn't find a resort like Amanyara on a busy beach where just anyone can just stroll in uninvited. No, you have to do a little work to get there. This temple of vacation overindulgence sits at the end of a long, unpaved road some 25 minutes outside the main tourist center of Providenciales, the most developed island in the Turks and Caicos chain. While Turks and Caicos sets a pretty high bar for plush accommodations, Amanyara surpasses them all. If you can't afford the $1,250 a night it will cost just to get you into the most basic room this season, consider popping in for lunch or a late-afternoon cocktail so you can avail yourself of the decadence on an à la carte basis. The restaurant, lobby and common areas are all in open-air pagoda-style buildings, arranged around a central reflecting pool. Venture out farther toward the sea (Amanyara sits on Malcolm's Beach, a half-mile of some of the finest and most secluded sand on the island) and you'll find the main infinity swimming pool, where the water appears ink black. You might almost forget that your salad cost $20. www.amanresorts.com/amanyara/home.aspx.
To the Editor: Re ''Mother's New Little Helper,'' by Pamela Paul ( Sunday Styles, Nov. 6):

KALB--Shirley D. (nee Dolinsky). Died on Shabbat, November 4th, 2011. Predeceased by her beloved husband of 42 years, Everett A. Kalb, as well as her husband of 11 years, Nathaniel Kleppel, and cherished brothers Hyman and Morton Dolinsky. Mother of Amy and Albert Schindler and Rebecca Kalb, grandmother of Jessie and Paul Cheney, Sam and Jamie Schindler, great-grandmother of Nicholas and Louis Cheney and Nora Schindler. A pillar of strength of the Jewish community as well as her synagogue, a major force in Hadassah and work on behalf of Israel and the Jewish people. She will be deeply missed by her friends and family and all those who knew her and were touched by her. So grateful for having had you, so saddened at your loss, Shirley will be remembered and loved forever. Contributions may be made in her memory to Yad Sarah, American Jewish World Service or any other organization that does meaningful humanitarian work.
''Contagion is alive and well.''Rebecca Patterson, chief market strategist at J.P.Morgan Asset Management,as the euro crisis worsened in Italy.

The name alone confounds, leaping out from a 1950s-looking billboard along a quiet stretch of road in St. Martin. Is Boo Boo Jam a cartoon character, you might wonder. A term of endearment? In fact, it's a beach bar, a fairly unremarkable one at that, on a tourist-friendly island teeming with flawless beaches and modern amenities. But on weekend nights, the Boo Boo Jam transforms into the ultimate French Caribbean dance party -- a down-home scene that stands in stark contrast to the glitzy nightclubs and frat-style bars on the more commercial Dutch side of the island. The party started in 1995, when Hurricane Luis struck the island and only a few properties were prepared with generators. The Boo Boo Jam was one of them; its owners decided to seize the opportunity, turn up the music and stay open late on Fridays. The crowds came, and they still do: sipping Haitian rum, chatting in French and dancing cheek-to-cheek to the tinny rhythms of compas music. Then the tempo changes and uptempo zouk music livens up the dance floor. The fete lasts until the wee hours, when the woman peddling fish tea in a little booth outside the party has emptied her pot, and a sliver of sun gently emerges over the Caribbean. Boo Boo Jam Orient Bay; (1721) 554-4670.

Here are selected pages -- in some ways as hard to choose as the books themselves -- from the New York Times Best Illustrated Children's Books of 2011. The Book Review annually asks a panel of judges to choose 10 winners from among the thousands of children's books published during the calendar year. Here are the favorites this time around, ranked in no particular order.The judges this year were Jeanne Lamb, coordinator of youth collections at the New York Public Library; Lucy Calkins, Robinson professor in children's literature at Teachers College, Columbia University; and Sophie Blackall, an author and artist who has illustrated 24 books for children, including one of last year's Best Illustrated winners, ''Big Red Lollipop,'' as well as ''Are You Awake?,'' ''The Crows of Pearblossom'' and ''Spinster Goose,'' all in editions published this year. Next year will be the 60th anniversary of these awards. Looking at the fine work here, we think there's a lot to celebrate right now. The Editors

Marielle Anzelone, a botanist and urban ecologist who founded NYC Wildflower Week, has been reporting from a patch of forest in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan once a week, beginning on the first day of autumn, Sept. 23. In her previous dispatch, she found signs of life after the havoc of a late October snowstorm. Read the full series at NYTimes.com/cityroom. For a moment, I am rendered motionless, too much in awe to move. My eyes linger on the forested crest of the park ahead of me at the top of the road. It is a dazzling display of autumnal splendor. Loud, raucous and bright hues welcome us into the woods this Monday morning. The trees themselves seem to say, ''Come in.''

RUSSELL--Richard W.,82 Richard W. Russell has died of complications resulting from cancer. At his death, Mr. Russell was President of James Russell Engineering, an innovative, world-class producer of compressed gas trailers and cryogenic engineering technology. Mr. Russell was also a founding partner of Thermax, Inc., an important manufacturer of vaporizers and other related products. Aside from his work and his family, Mr. Russell's interests were broadly divided into boats and books. He was the "powerplant" of the 1949 Yale crew that shocked Harvard (ending 14 consecutive Crimson victories in the Harvard-Yale Regatta) and set a course record that lasted for decades. The previous year, Mr. Russell had narrowly missed qualifying for the U.S. Olympic rowing team. Moreover, Mr. Russell was also a successful sailor in the Wianno Senior class, competing out of Cotuit, Massachusetts, where he maintained a summer house. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University and a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Mr. Russell pursued his passion for learning, reading and discussing history and politics to the end of his life. His interests ranged from the ancient civilizations of the near East to the writings of Sun Tzu and the films of Kurosawa, from the military history of World War Two to the essays and fiction of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. He also served in U.S. Army Counter-Intelligence from 1952 to 1955 and was a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon. He is survived by Katherine Wehmann Russell, his wife of 56 years; his children Dr. Warren King Russell II, Elizabeth Suzanne Russell, Margaret Warburg and Richard Andrew Russell; as well as seven grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and his beloved dog, "Dude." Services will be held at the Wellesley Village Congregational Church, 2 Central St, Wellesley MA on Friday, November 18 at 2pm, with a reception to follow afterwards. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be sent to the Gastro Intestinal Cancer Research Group headed by Dr. Ramesh Shivdasani at The Dana- Farber Cancer Institute 450 Brookline Ave Boston, MA 02215 or The Salvation Army 25 Shawmut Rd Canton, MA 02021. To share a memory of Mr. Russell please visit www.eatonfuneralhomes.com

TUCKED away behind a unmarked door in NoHo, the jeweler Mish Tworkowski's chic new salon and studio are the perfect backdrop for his fanciful one-of-a-kind designs. The intimate three-room space, conceived by Mr. Tworkowski's longtime partner, the architect Joseph Singer, incorporates midcentury antiques, contemporary art and furniture and enough custom flourishes to make even his most spoiled clients swoon. One of the most striking of these details, the reception room's walls (shown here), were hand-painted by Uriu Studios to look like petrified wood. Mish is open by appointment. Call (212) 734-3500. SANDRA BALLENTINE

For some fans of Antoni Gaudí, the towers going up at the World Trade Center site are a sad reminder of what might have been. The Catalan architect may be best known for Barcelona's Sagrada Família, a neo-gothic cathedral that looks as if it's melting, but in 1908 he designed a pearlescent, glass-studded spaceship of a hotel, which would at that time have been the world's tallest building, for the site that is now ground zero. Although it's unclear whether construction of such a skyscraper was feasible then, Hotel Attraction was intended to rise almost as high as the Empire State Building would 23 years later. In 2003, Spanish artists advocated building it as a 9/11 memorial and a ''present from Barcelona, like the Statue of Liberty.'' An American architect, Paul Laffoley, joined the campaign, saying the hotel could become the New York symbol Gaudí intended.

WHEN bottle and can deposits became a fact of life in New York City almost 20 years ago, some of the first to capitalize on the new law were the homeless. Many who live on the streets still redeem cans and bottles at grocery stores, but in parts of Lower Manhattan, the most prominent collectors are not without homes. They are older Chinese men and women, who often haul immense loads of plastic, aluminum and glass through the streets. For these collectors, most of them recent immigrants with little command of English, recycling, an underground economy in a city of plenty, is a source of income that is not contingent on citizenship. Nobody at a recycling center asks for a Social Security number.

SHEPARD FAIREY, the influential street artist who last month designed an invitation for an Occupy Wall Street party in Times Square, is once again unfurling the income equality banner, this time to raise money for the homeless. The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation selected Mr. Fairey to inaugurate its Artist as Activist series; 100 signed prints of the new Fairey poster, ''The Future Is Unwritten,'' are available for purchase at artnet.com/auctions, starting at $1,250. Almost all the proceeds benefit the nonprofit organization Coalition for the Homeless, which provides soup kitchens and job training for destitute New Yorkers. Mr. Fairey said that his poster references Depression-era styles like Art Deco, and that its title comes from Joe Strummer of the Clash, whom he called ''a dedicated advocate for the working class.'' STEPHEN HEYMAN

LAST year I had to have a minor biopsy. Every time I went in for an appointment, I had to fill out a form requiring my name, address, insurance information, emergency contact person, vaccination history, previous surgical history and current medical problems, medications and allergies. I must have done it four times in just three days. Then, after my procedure, I received bills -- and, even more annoying, statements of charges that said they weren't bills -- almost daily, from the hospital, the surgeon, the primary care doctor, the insurance company. Imagine that repeated millions of times daily and you have one of the biggest money wasters in our health care system. Administration accounts for roughly 14 percent of what the United States spends on health care, or about $360 billion per year. About half of all administrative costs -- $163 billion in 2009 -- are borne by Medicare, Medicaid and insurance companies. The other half pays for the legions employed by doctors and hospitals to fill out billing forms, keep records, apply for credentials and perform the myriad other administrative functions associated with health care.

The Mars Curiosity Rover, a Mini Cooper-size nuclear-powered vehicle that will launch on Nov. 25, doesn't aim to answer David Bowie's burning question, exactly. Having been criticized in owner surveys and quality studies for being unintuitive, slow and buggy, the MyFord Touch telematics system is scheduled to receive what Ford called on Monday a major software upgrade. The company plans to introduce it free to customers early next year in one of the most ambitious user-installed upgrades ever attempted by an automaker. Unlike a minor software change installed by a service technician at a dealership, Ford said it made a major operating system upgrade to its Microsoft-backed telematics system. Improvements included faster switching and response times between tasks, as well as improved ergonomics to ensure drivers received important information with a quick glance, Ford said.

FLYNN--C. Peter, an experimental physicist at the University of Illinois and father of four passed away on October 27, 2011. Colin Peter Flynn was born in Stockton-on-Tees, a small market town in North Yorkshire, England on August 18, 1935. He was the son of Francis Johnson Flynn, a police constable in the village of Hovingham, and his wife, Edith Hannah, a local war-time nurse. At the age of 17, Peter was awarded a full scholarship to the University of Leeds where he received his bachelor's degree and, at the age of 24, his Ph.D. in Physics. In 1960, Peter moved to the United States to take a post-doctoral position with the Physics Department of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. A distinguished experimentalist, Peter spent 51 years at the University, authoring more than 260 peer-reviewed articles, supervising 31 Ph.D. students and serving as the Director of the Frederick Seitz Materials Research Laboratory for nearly a decade. He made seminal contributions to several areas of condensed matter physics. In the 1960s, he utilized magnetic resonance imaging to pursue a fundamental study of the behavior and motion of defects and impurities in solids, an effort that culminated in his 1972 book, "Point Defects and Diffusion", still the definitive source in this field. In the 1990s, he spearheaded the University's acquisition, installation and modification of a low-energy electron microscope ("LEEM") to image real-time changes in atomically clean surfaces, atom-surface interactions, and thin (crystalline) films. He used this tool to research the behavior and motion of surface atoms in crystalline structures in order to further advance the study of surface energetics. As part of his research on the LEEM, he also pioneered the molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) method of growing metallic superlattices which allows researchers to construct ultra-pure structures down to the level of a single atomic layer. To this day, the LEEM at the University of Illinois is one of only a handful of LEEMs operational in the United States. He was a Fellow of both the American Physical Society and of the American Society of Metals, and held a Fellowship at Christ's College, Cambridge, U.K. from 1966 to 1967. In addition to his passion for physics, Peter was a voracious reader and engaged in a rich variety of activities including home building projects, hiking the American West and sports such as tennis, squash and golf. Peter's steady optimism and dedication to an energetic life filled with joyful and serious pursuits will continue to inspire all of those who knew him. Peter is survived by his wife, Janice; son Jim, his wife Kerianne, and their son Declan; son Derek, his wife Elizabeth, and their two children Alice and John; daughter Megan; son John, his fiancee Alix; and sister, Joan. We will all miss Peter's love and guidance.

Dieppe Bay is a sliver of a town on St. Kitts's northern tip. The oldest European settlement in the Eastern Caribbean -- colonized in 1538 by French Huguenots fleeing religious prosecution -- it was the capital of the French-ruled northern part of the island until 1713, when Britain extended its reach over all of St. Kitts. Today the fishing village's legacy lives in the cut-stone structures and ruined walls that stand alongside charming shuttered homes dating back more than two centuries. It doesn't take a history buff, though, to relish Dieppe Bay's volcanic black sand beach, well worth the 40-minute drive from the more commercial south of the island. Protected by a fertile reef, the sea here is calm and the snorkeling, sublime. Views of neighboring Saba and St. Eustatius, rising like volcanoes in the sea, serve as backdrop. Swim, watch fishermen haul in their catch, then eat lunch at the oceanfront Golden Lemon Inn, a hotel decked out in funky furnishings and antiques in a beautifully restored 17th-century home.

RELIEVING the fear felt by many men of fitting rooms, sales racks and lines at the register is a surplus of e-commerce sites that make online shopping not only convenient, but appealing. First on a list that T: The New York Times Style Magazine will continue rolling out next week is ASOS. It is a British-based e-tailer that stocks a range of labels -- from heritage (Filson) to high-end (Prada) to Scandinavian (Henrik Vibskov) -- under one URL. The site's extensive mix of prices and styles caters to the male buyer who appreciates one-stop shopping. And streamlining the process even more is ASOS's affordable namesake line, which offers slim, tailored classics (like these houndstooth trousers, $72) trendier pieces (knit jacket, $198, and Fair Isle hoodie, $87), and more. Go to asos.com. JASON RIDER

Brandon Weeden passed for 423 yards and 5 touchdowns and Joseph Randle, right, ran for 3 scores as Oklahoma State improved to 10-0 with a 66-6 rout of Texas Tech. Weeden, who completed 31 of 37 passes, threw touchdown passes of 2, 27, 28, 48 and 66 yards before leaving late in the third quarter. Randle scored on runs of 2, 1 and 10 yards. Robert Griffin III produced three long scores in a fourth-quarter rally - a 49-yard run and passes of 36 and 67 yards - and then threw a 14-yard touchdown pass in overtime as Baylor won at Kansas, 31-30. Griffin finished with 312 yards passing and 103 running.

VOLCKHAUSEN--June MacLean, died on October 9, 2011 at 97 years of age in Ft. Lauderdale, FL, the eldest of three daughters of Viola Pratt MacLean and Waldo Bross MacLean. After graduating from Sarah Lawrence College she worked as a reporter for the White Plaines Reporter Dispatch, did publicity work for the United Cerebral Palsy Association, Westchester County Hospital, and feature stories. Her poetry is published in the Connecticut Review. Her grandfather, Willis C. Pratt who lived to be 100, was a reporter and city editor for the New York Evening Mail and Express, and writer for the World, Herald and Times. He was friends with Teddy Roosevelt, Henry Ford and Mark Twain. Mrs. Volckhausen was an activist who was ahead of her generation in championing social issues: civil rights, nuclear freeze, League of Women Voters, Planned Parenthood and conservation. With her husband of 53 years, George W. Volckhausen, (1910-'92), she helped found two Unitarian fellowships in Devon, Pennsylvania and Ridgefield, Connecticut. Mrs. Volckhausen inherited her love of music from her mother. As a supporter of the arts she passed her musical talent to her son, a Julliard graduate, pianist and professor at Manhattan School of Music and her grand-daughter, whose band has performed nationally. Her passion for social action is carried on by her daughter, a social worker. June Volckhausen is survived by her daughter Lynn Volckhausen Edinoff, son-in-law Stuart Edinoff (Ft. Lauderdale); son David Volckhausen (Somers, NY); granddaughter Ellie Volckhausen (Boston); and six nieces and nephews. Donations appreciated: Unitarian Universalist Society, National Public Radio, The Nature Conservancy, Hospice-By-the-Sea in Boca Raton, Florida. Memorial Services will be held in Florida and Connecticut.

More than his profession, however, this long-time Park Slope resident loved his family, the Yankees, and the Giants, in that order. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Jean; his sister Suzanne; his children Claire, Jacques, and Philip; and his grandchildren Louis, Selma, and George. A memorial service will be held at Plymouth Church, 75 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, on Sunday, November 20 at 3:00pm.

INTERVIEWS BY ALEXANDRA WOLFE Tara Wixom, 14: I think of the Purity Ball at the Evangelical Free Church as something I go to yearly to remind myself of the commitment I have made to keep myself pure -- physically, morally, sexually -- until I am married. What I really like about my father going is that he is the one that God has put at the head of our household. I'm preparing myself for when I am married, so I think you could call my dad my guinea pig. I'm learning how to serve, respect, love, honor my husband. I practice that by loving, serving and obeying my father. The first year I went, my dad gave me a necklace. This year, he gave me a purity ring, which I wear on my left hand. It is also a reminder. Alexis Wixom, 12: We said that we love each other. I was thinking that I was saving my purity for my husband. Brenden Wixom: When the three of us were dancing together, I was thinking that not too long ago, they were just toddlers and now they're young women. You kind of want time to slow down and be able to relish the moment. We send our kids out into the world, and there's a battle going on. It seemed like a good idea to give the girls a biblical worldview and help them make a commitment to how they want their life to unfold before a precipitous moment happens. They know about the birds and the bees, but they're still fairly innocent. When they go to the ball for the first time, it's a commitment to remain pure and an understanding that it's not going to be easy. In subsequent years, it's about recommitting and taking stock of where they're at and asking their father for support. That evening, I was thinking about how I see things accelerating so quickly. That also brings with it a sense of urgency: you want your children, and particularly your daughters, to be prepared.

Consider it a vacation from your vacation: an island off an island, where the only thing to do is eat lobster, drink wine and swim in warm azure waters. Just off the French side of St. Martin, the petite island of Pinel is rumored to have acquired its name from a Portuguese captain (the word is Portuguese for ''crazy'') in the days when it housed St. Martin's mentally ill. Nowadays what's ''crazy'' about Pinel are the American tourists who elect not to go; this gem of a mini-island is favored by locals and in-the-know French expats. Access is via kayaks or speedboats ($10 round trip) from the charming Cul de Sac area of St. Martin, which -- with its rolling hills and green-and pink-roofed cottages -- is a dead ringer for St. Bart's. Once across, rent a beach chair alongside scantily clad French sunbathers and order the Camembert, served hot, with baguettes for dipping. Or pull up a table at one of Pinel's three restaurants: Le Kariabuni, specializing in lobster; the Yellow Beach, a down-home barbecue joint; or Up on the Key, where the burgers ($10) and tequila-spiked shrimp ($18) go down easy. If doing absolutely nothing grows too taxing, there's always snorkeling, hiking or shopping for shell jewelry and colorful wraps at the Paradiso Gift Shop. The last boat back to the mainland departs at 5 -- when it's time to return, alas, to your regularly scheduled vacation. visitpinel.com.

Lou Maletta, who founded the Gay Cable Network in 1982, when the gay rights movement was not receiving broad media attention, died on Nov. 2 in Kingston, N.Y. He was 74. The cause was liver cancer, said Luke Valenti, his companion of 37 years.

A speaker has to determine what he is trying to do and what is the setting. You give speeches for different reasons, and you've gotta know going in: Am I going in there to inform and inspire or am I going in there to entertain and impress? Then lock down two or three outlined points to inform them or razzle-dazzle them. -- As told to Spencer Bailey

An article last Sunday about the composer Alan Hovhaness misstated Gerald Schwarz's status with the Seattle Symphony Orchestra, which regularly features the Hovhaness repertory. Mr. Schwarz is the orchestra's former musical director, not the current one. (Ludovic Morlot became director on Sept. 1.)

In New York everything is over the top, and the New York City Marathon is no exception. It has become an exuberant three days of festivities, with about 45,000 participants from around the globe. The opening party on Nov. 4 was highlighted by fireworks in Central Park. The next morning was the international run from the United Nations to the park, many of the runners in national costume. Others turned out in the dress of some private universe, like a man in a ram's head. No slouch was the man juggling as he ran. Last Sunday, race day, the disabled runners inspired everyone. The big winners, after the race, were the pedal cabs. On Monday morning, finishers sported gold medallions on Fifth Avenue.

Jamaica has no shortage of sublimely beautiful, impeccably maintained beaches. Hellshire isn't one of them. Sure, its sea strikes a luscious shade of blue and its sand is powdery white. But this city beach -- a 25-minute drive west of Kingston -- isn't quite brochure-ready. In lieu of cushy cabanas and dainty umbrellas are rickety wooden tables and slabs of wood serving as ersatz beach chairs. But therein lies its allure. Hellshire is that rare Jamaican beach scene made by and for locals. Once known as Healthshire on account of its reputation as a health retreat, the beach still offers Kingstonians rejuvenation: the chance to escape the city for a few hours, sip a cool Red Stripe and listen to the reggae music emerging from shacks lining the sand. For about 600 Jamaican dollars, about $7, those shacks, with names like Prendy's and Screechy's, dole out just-caught fish and lobster served steamed or fried, with a vinegary relish of scotch bonnet pepper and onion or slathered in brown stew and topped with okra, carrots and potatoes. On the side: bammy (cassava cakes, fried or steamed) or festival (fried, doughnut-like bread). It's ubiquitous local cuisine, but rare is the Jamaican who wouldn't agree that Hellshire has perfected the art of it.

It's a Caribbean clothing brand with a radical notion: There's more to the Cayman Islands than banks and beaches. One Tree Four Five, playfully named after the islands' area code (Caribbean accents drop the ''h'' in ''three''), is the brainchild of the Caymanian designer Luigi Moxam, who is determined to confer the sort of cultural recognition and coolness factor on his homeland that, say, Puma's Jamaica line bestows on that well-branded island. The result? Locally designed T-shirts, tanks, jewelry, resort and swim wear, most featuring island slang: ''Love Ya Like Cook Food,'' ''Doin Big Tings From a Small Island,'' ''Wha Ya Sayin'' and the ever-handy ''Who You Tink You Is?'' On every item is the One Tree Four Five logo: the endangered Grand Caymanian blue iguana. A portion of profits on some lines is donated to local charities, and last month, the company's first flagship store opened on Grand Cayman. It's actually more than a clothing store: Shop, then enjoy a meal of fresh fish and locally distilled rum at the restaurant on site. George Town, Grand Cayman; onetreefourfive.com.
