Curaçao is the ultimate cultural mashup: a Dutch island just off Venezuela, once an African slave port and now a dynamic country populated by some 50 nationalities. If Curaçao had a soundtrack it would be Papiamentu, the island's Creole language, said to be a hybrid of Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch, English and West African dialects. And if it had a taste, it would be one of a kind. Proof is in the Old Market (Marsche Bieuw), in the heart of Curaçao's picture-perfect capital, Willemstad. There, behind the Queen Wilhelmina Foot Bridge, vendors dole out food from colossal pots. You'll find Dutch favorites like fried bitterballen (fried beef balls) and Spanish-style mondongo (tripe and vegetable soup). Indonesian food comes via Suriname, also a former Dutch colony, and includes bami, long noodles cooked with veggies and meat, and sate, grilled meats doused in peanut sauce. But the kuminda krioyo -- local Creole cuisine -- is the real draw here. Try the iguana, served in a soup or stewed, with a side of rice and peas. The fried fish and funchi (cornmeal paste akin to polenta) is best when doused in pika, a tangy onion-and-pepper relish. Guiambo is a viscous okra and seafood soup, and the slimy yet tasty kadushi soup is made from local cactus. Carry a brimming, ultra-affordable plate to one of the communal picnic tables and dive in.

DAVID STRETTELL, the proprietor of Dashwood Books, is a quiet champion of self-published material by photographers of nearly every aesthetic persuasion. Now he is cementing his growing reputation as a publisher in his own right with a series of bite-size limited-edition monographs (like zines, but with the production value of books), which he plans to put out more or less annually. The 7-by-9.5-inch format is fixed; the agenda, on the other hand, is open-ended, an opportunity for Mr. Strettell to introduce new work, shine a light on older work and let his eye wander. Among the first seven titles are ''Back to Mystery City,'' Andreas Laszlo Konrath's photos of the Perus crew, a posse of Helsinki skateboarders; ''Color'd,'' Jim Mangan's scenic nudes; and Mr. Strettell's personal project, ''Soviet Beauty Queens From the Archive of Modern Conflict,'' anonymous images from various pageants and the Leningrad Beauty Institute at the height of perestroika. Dashwood Books, 33 Bond Street; dashwoodbooks.com. ALIX BROWNE

During tumultuous historical moments, it's useful to think about presidential candidates as being either reflectors or channelers. Reflectors -- a Pat Buchanan, say, or a Howard Dean -- satisfy the electorate's fury by reflecting it back. Channelers, like Ronald Reagan (or Barack Obama), harness that fury behind an agenda that feels constructive. The good news for Republicans fearing an intraparty meltdown: Reflectors never win. The bad news: There isn't a channeler in the bunch.

A profile of the American composer Nico Muhly last Sunday gave outdated information about his association with the movie ''Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.'' While he was with the production at one point, he has since left and therefore will not be scoring the film.

Taking a late-night trip down dark, bumpy roads to see the incandescent waters of Vieques's Mosquito Bay, which gets its eerie glow from microscopic organisms that light up the water, has long been a must for tourists. Most visitors opt for a boat ride out to the middle of the bay but the best way to tour the bay is to paddle into the glowing waters by kayak or canoe. And now it's the closest thing to being in the water -- Puerto Rico's Department of Natural and Environmental Resources has been cracking down on swimming in the bioluminescent bay after a tourist was bitten by a shark this summer. Vieques Adventure Company (viequesadventures.com) offers tours in see-through canoes for $50 a person. Abe's Snorkeling (abessnorkeling.com) offers two-hour kayak tours for $30 a person. Go on a cloudy or moonless night, when the bay is at its most brilliant.

MEYER--Doris Asiel, 96, died peacefully at home in Delray Beach, FL, on November 5. Born in New York City to Nelson I. Asiel and Ethel Rossin Asiel, she was predeceased by her husband, Blakeman Q. Meyer, and by her brother Robert Asiel. Mrs. Meyer was a graduate of the Knox School in Cooperstown, NY, and Finch College in New York City. During World War II, she served as a nurse's aide, treating hospitalized veterans. Continuing her efforts in public service in the 1950s, she was a regular volunteer for the Arthritis Foundation. In the 1960s, she worked for New York City Mayor John Lindsay and became his liaison with the New York State Federation of Republican Women. An avid golfer, she was a member of the Stanwich Club in Greenwich, CT, and the Little Club in Gulf Stream, FL. She is survived by her brother E. Nelson Asiel, son Robert Gimbel, daughter-in-law Despina Gimbel, granddaughter Alexandra Gimbel, grandsons David Gimbel (Amelia) and Mark Gimbel (Dede Welles) and great-grandchildren Lucas and Lila Gimbel. Funeral services private. Donations in her memory may be made to the Hospice of PBC, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL, 33407 or online at: www.hpbcf.org

Bearded men are as common in Brooklyn as out-of-work actors in Los Angeles. And some will fight for bragging rights at the N.Y.C. Beard and Mustache Competition, on Dec. 3. It's part of a beard-contest circuit that extends as far as Trondheim, Norway, host of the World Beard and Moustache Championships. Phil Olsen, captain of Beard Team USA, a real organization, has noticed a rise in hirsute competitors. ''Fewer men want to look like women,'' he says.

Considering that two New York City taxi medallions recently sold for $1 million each, an all-time high, some fear we are currently experiencing a medallion bubble. After all, low interest rates make it cheaper to buy a medallion with borrowed money, and prices have doubled in the past five years. At the going rate, the total value of all medallions is more than $10 billion -- more than the market capitalization of several large U.S. airlines. But not everyone sees them as overvalued assets. ''These are mini cash cows running around the city,'' says Andrew Murstein, president of Medallion Financial, a publicly traded company that finances medallion investors. ''It's something that at least for the next hundred years is a great investment.''
Dance Jack Anderson

In theory, an island like St. John should be unspoiled enough that you won't need to go looking for a spot that makes you feel that you've truly left the world behind. But with more development encroaching on the downtown area of Cruz Bay, you'd be smart to venture, even for just an afternoon, to Coral Bay. Located at the opposite end of the island from Cruz Bay, about 20 minutes away by car, Coral Bay is about as remote as it gets in the United States Virgin Islands. A road sign on the drive out that reads ''Not Cruz Bay'' says it all. The bay's deep and well-sheltered natural harbor, appropriately named Hurricane Hole, doesn't offer much in the way of a beach. But its mangroves are overlooked for exploring, whether in a kayak, by paddle board or with a snorkel and mask. After you've worked up an appetite, stop into Skinny Legs for a burger or Shipwreck Landing conch fritters and grilled mahi-mahi.

IT was only a matter of time. Plants have begun texting for help. Thanks to clever new digital devices, a dry philodendron, undernourished hibiscus, or sadly neglected wandering Jew can send its owner a text or Twitter message. Humans like to feel appreciated, so a begonia may also send a simple ''Thank-you'' text -- when it's happy, as gardeners like to say, meaning healthy and well-tended. Picture your Boston fern home alone placing Botanicalls. But why should potted plants be the only ones to reassure their humans? Another company has found a way for crops to send text messages in unison, letting their farmer know if she's doing a good enough job to deserve a robust harvest. What is the sound of one hand of bananas clapping? Probes monitoring the soil can send a range of prerecorded messages specific to each plant's needs. Plants texting humans may be new, but malcontent plants have always been chatting among themselves. When an elm tree is being attacked by insects, it does the chemical equivalent of broadcasting ''I'm hurt! You could be next!'' alerting others in its grove to whip up some dandy poisons.

WASSERMAN--Dr. Bernard.,91, of Brooklyn Heights, died November 11. Dearly beloved husband of the late Bernice, cherished father of Harvey and Kim and Andrew and Donna; loving grandfather of Jake and Sarah; beloved uncle, cousin and friend. Graduate of Brooklyn College and Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine, he served in the US Army during WWII and later was a professor at the University of Rhode Island before returning to Brooklyn to open his veterinary hospital. Creative and vivacious, he was an author and artist and enjoyed skiing, tennis, animals, nature and spending time with family and friends. We will miss him deeply. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Michael J. Fox Foundation appreciated. Services, Sunday, November 13, 10:30am, Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn.

KROLIK--Richard, died November 6th of natural causes. He was active in broadcasting, public relations and government. He was 93. After co-founding the Dartmouth College radio station and serving as an Air Corps Captain in the Southwest Pacific during WWII, he worked in New York for the Mutual Broadcasting System, THE MARCH OF TIME, and LIFE Magazine. He also worked on NBC's TODAY show before becoming Vice President of Time-Life Broadcasting. He came to Washington in 1972 as an assistant to the Chairman of the House Subcommittee on Communications. He served as Staff Director of the Ad Hoc Committee on Energy. As a free-lance writer, he contributed to WASHINGTON JOURNALISM REVIEW and TELEVISION QUARTERLY. He is survived by his daughter Cynthia Stuart (Jason) of New York, a son Jeffrey Krolik (Christine) of Hillsborough, CA and three grandsons.

Rolls-Royce found 2,700 buyers worldwide for its Phantom and Ghost models last year. And to hear company executives tell it, roughly 2,699 of them are perfectly content with their V-12 gasoline engines. But that hasn't stopped the 102EX, a 6,000-pound, all-electric version of the brand's Phantom sedan, from barnstorming around the globe. It brought its nearly silent stump speech to Manhattan on Monday. First shown in Geneva in March, the one-off car, also called the Phantom Experimental Electric, has already ferried Rolls owners and prospects in locales as varied as Beijing, Singapore, Pebble Beach, Dubai, Madrid and Abu Dhabi.

MOTTOLA--Rita, 86, passed away November 9, 2011 in her Manhattan home. Her many years as a secretary at AGMA and to various performing artists including Cesare Siepi, George London, and Glenn Close provided her ample opportunity to indulge her passion for opera and theater. She was also a voracious reader, dedicated fan of the NY Yankees, and a proud supporter of her cousin Rudy Giuliani. Rita was beloved by her large and extended family, and a dear and generous friend to many throughout her life. Her warmth, wisdom, curious mind, and enthusiasm for the arts will be remembered by all who were close to her. Family and friends are welcome to visit at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave on Monday November 14 from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave. at 10:00am on Tuesday, November 15.

As the forests surrounding the Great Smoky Mountains passed their autumnal peak foliage in early November 1861, a group of potters and farmers gathered at the Greene County, Tenn., home of Jacob and Henry Harmon. There the brothers, joined by Christopher Haun, Henry Fry and Jacob Hinshaw, finalized their plot to destroy the nearby Lick Creek railroad bridge on Nov. 8. This was no local conspiracy, however. More than 100 fellow East Tennessee Unionists plotted to simultaneously burn eight other railroad bridges as far away as northeast Alabama, effectively severing all rail and telegraph connection between Virginia and the heartland of the Confederacy.

No, "apology" is not the collective noun for enclaves. The accepted term is a complex of enclaves - although more imaginative suggestions are welcome. Nor do I feel the need to apologize for enclaves. Yes, these geopolitical anomalies - for the uninitiated, a chunk of one political or ethnic unit lying wholly within another - have caused their fair share of misery and grief. But fascination with a subject does not equal approval of all its phenomena; herpetologists need not apologize for snakebites.

Sunday's Times Book Review included the Children's Books section, which always precedes the holidays, and which I look forward to every year. Besides being the usual good read for lovers of children's books, it's an ideal shopping guide for the aunt, parent or friend who does all of her holiday shopping for the younger set at the bookstore. I was a book-obsessed child, and the flat packages that meant hours of vacation pleasure to me were what I most wanted to find under the tree. I give books for the simple reason that I love books, but unless a child has a favorite series (and doesn't yet possess them all), it's tough to book-shop for kids past the picture-book age and feel reasonably confident in your chances of success.

I'm sure you've noticed those TV ads for pharmaceutical products that include an incredibly long list of side effects and possible hazards recited by a cheerful voice as men and women are shown living the happy lives made possible by a drug that can inflict on them everything from bloating and joint pain to death. This combination of positive and negative communications is mandated by the government requirement that drug manufacturers must disclose all the risk factors attending the product they are hawking.

There are plenty of arresting moments in "Idols," an exhibition of photographs by Gilles Larrain of the denizens of Max's Kansas City in the 1970s. Mr. Larrain's searingly colorful portraits - the likes of Harvey Fierstein, Taylor Mead, Holly Woodlawn and the New York Dolls vamping in shrill makeup and assorted states of dishabille - were first published in the '70s. Since going on view earlier this month at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea, they've drawn a steady stream of visitors.

It can feel as though you've somehow gone back in time when you're driving up the looping curves of Route 17 in northern Vermont and take one last turn, toward the spine of the Green Mountains, to suddenly find what appears to be the movie set of a small 1960s ski resort brought painstakingly to life. There is a cluster of quaint yellow and blue rustic clapboard buildings. A rutted dirt parking lot. A single-chair lift rising into the clouds over narrow trails that seem to pitch and hurtle down the mountain.

America’s love affair with movie gangsters shows no signs of letting up. A. O. Scott looks back at one of the films that helped spark that passion, “The Public Enemy” from 1931. Directed by William Wellman, the film stars James Cagney as a prohibition-era Chicago mobster named Tom Powers. Tom and his cohorts begin as petty thieves, but they rise in the criminal underworld once alcohol is outlawed. Mr. Scott praises Cagney’s performance, along with that of his co-star and love interest Jean Harlow.

For the millions of Americans who suffer from mild to severe winter blues - a condition called seasonal affective disorder, or S.A.D. - bright-light therapy is the treatment of choice, with response rates comparable with those of antidepressants, reports today's Consumer column.

The "Sunday Night Football" game between the New England Patriots and the New York Jets was by far the No. 1 program in all ratings categories, giving NBC an easy victory over all for the night (the Patriots also had an easy win, 37-16). "Once Upon a Time" on ABC was the highest-rated scripted program and has been very steady the last three weeks, hovering between 11 and 12 million total viewers (with 11.3 million this week).

These are turbulent times in Occupy encampments around the country. City officials closed down camps in at least six cities over the weekend and early Monday, after three people died in encampments late last week. Salt Lake City police ordered the closing of the camp in Pioneer Park after a man was found dead in his tent in what the police said was possibly a drug overdose combined with carbon monoxide poisoning. Last week, a protester in Burlington, Vt., shot himself in an apparent suicide, and in Oakland, a 25-year-old protester was shot and killed on the outskirts of the encampment in Frank Ogawa Plaza. Evictions in Portland, Denver, St. Louis, Salt Lake City, Burlington and Oakland were largely peaceful, but more than 60 people were arrested nationwide. [Daily Kos, MSNBC, CNN]

Whenever people worry that the American electorate has become hopelessly divided, I like to point out that we're remarkably united on at least one issue: Everyone dislikes Congress. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that only 9 percent of Americans approve of the way lawmakers are handling their jobs. And more than four out of five Republicans, Democrats, and Independents actively disapprove. (President Obama's 46 percent approval rating looks like massive support by comparison.)

BLACK veils, usually reserved for religious ceremonies, goth brides and Daphne Guinness, are bringing some dramatic flair to street and cocktail dress. In Paris, at last month's round of fashion shows, the French designer Faustine Rome looked like a latter-day Marlene Dietrich from "Shanghai Express," in a veiled cloche, ruffled cape (in lieu of feathers) and studded bangles (today's pearls?). Another young woman wore an oversize black-cherry fascinator from the British milliner Piers Atkinson, whose quirky fruit headpieces have adorned Anna Dello Russo. Ms. Dello Russo also wore a veiled cap, a Stephen Jones design fresh off the Jil Sander runway. Come spring, the cap, shown in several colors, should be street-style fodder. For the holiday season, though, this veiled headband with a polka-dot bow from Maison Michel will make a sweet and mysterious accessory to wear with a black cocktail dress.

Performa lore is inextricably bound up with the Iranian artist Shirin Neshat. In 1998, RoseLee Goldberg, the visual-art performance biennial's founder, wondered what would happen if Ms. Neshat translated her work in video and photography into live art. One result, in 2001, was "Logic of the Birds." Ms. Neshat's first foray into performance, it led to the creation of Performa as a vehicle for pushing performance forward while educating people about its past.

CHRISSIE MILLER of Sophomore, a line of sportswear basics with a bit of an edge, and Lindsey Thornburg, known for her wool blanket cloaks, have gone into business together: their new boutique, named 143, will open Friday at 143 Ludlow Street, (212) 780-0900. "We had crushes on each other's lines," Ms. Thornburg said. On one side of the whitewashed and baby-blue shop are the Thornburg cloaks and bohemian layered-chiffon dresses, which run from $700 to $2,000; on the other side is Sophomore, designed with Madeleine von Froomer, with drawstring pants and floral dresses, $50 to $400.

As befits the pointy-headed elevation of all simple things, gourmet attention is now being paid to the humble gin and tonic. Specifically, to the tonic. Why would one bother? What's broke? Well, since the 1970s, the default Schweppes and Canada Dry tonics in the United States have been made with high-fructose corn syrup, which renders them blowsy and a bit toothless. If you are the type of imbiber who seeks out a specific gin (or vodka) on which to base your drink, doesn't the larger proportion of that drink - which in this case comprises at least twice the volume of the spirit - deserve equal scrutiny and care?

As I walked through the sliding doors at my local Veterans Affairs clinic last week, I couldn't help but cringe at the morose scene in front of me. Sitting in the small, overcrowded waiting area were the former fighters of our nation's wars, both past and present. Veterans from every conflict since Korea seemed to be represented. The Vietnam vets, with their worn out olive-drab field jackets, outnumbered the rest, but a few Korean, Desert Storm, Iraq and Afghanistan veterans were scattered throughout.

The Interior Department has named James A. Watson IV, a rear admiral in the Coast Guard who helped coordinate the response to BP's huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, to succeed Michael R. Bromwich as director of the department's Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement. For the brand loyalist there's an abundance of designer-specific e-commerce sites. Leave it to the minimalist Patrik Ervell to be ahead of the curve with an online destination that's one of the cleanest and easiest to shop. Organized into only a few basic categories, Ervell's perennial favorites (like this padded shirt, $370, and leather backpack, $670) are brilliantly presented on models in motion, so that shoppers can get all angles and details of the clothing they're considering. Should they be looking to branch out beyond the staples, there are runway offerings like this pleather flight suit, $1,200, too, that make the web site - like the collection - anything but monotonous.

With so many shows scheduled over the last five days in conjunction with the annual New York Comedy Festival, we decided to pose a challenge to select comics: Tell us your best clean joke. (The networks may have relaxed their standards but we at The New York Times are standing firm.) A mix of established performers and up-and-comers took us on: Jim Gaffigan, Michael Che, Rachel Feinstein, Leah Bonnema, Angelo Lozada and John O'Donnell. We posted their entries here and asked you to vote. Whose bit killed? Voting closes at the end of the day, so you still have a chance to weigh in.

La Tête Dans les Olives, a sliver of a food shop and restaurant in the 10th Arrondissement, is the work of Cédric Casanova, a slack-rope walker who spent 15 years performing in traveling circuses, most recently Cirque du Soleil. Casanova developed a passion for Sicily's fruity olives during summers he spent there as a child - his father is Sicilian - and wanted to share them with his hometown, Paris. The tiny épicerie offers oils and handpicked olives from his favorite growers, along with tapenades, sun-dried tomatoes and other seasonal delicacies. "The way people react to good olive oil is like what I see in the circus," Casanova says. "People smile. They love it." Go to interactive feature >>

A new study published on Monday shows patients are more likely to take their medicine when they do not have to help pay for the prescriptions. The study, which appears online in the New England Journal of Medicine, focused on patients with health insurance who had heart attacks.

Steven Levy of Wired magazine profiles Jeff Bezos as Amazon ships its first Kindle Fire tablets today. The piece sets up Amazon vs. Apple. "Apple is fundamentally a hardware company - 91 percent of its revenue comes from sales of its coveted machines, compared to just 6 percent from iTunes," he writes. "Amazon, on the other hand, is a content-focused company - almost half of its revenue comes from sales of media like books, music, TV shows, and movies - and the fire-sale-priced Fire is designed to be primarily a passport to the large amount of that content that's available digitally." [Wired]

In an innovative study, nest boxes installed at a California vineyard attracted hundreds of birds that picked the farmers' crops clean of pests in exchange for the free housing. The experiment is heartening news for conservationists amid reports of shrinking habitats and population declines for so many species.

COWEN--Dolores Cohen. was born September 4, 1928 in New York City to loving parents, Mary and Louis Cohen joining siblings Marvin and Ina. She is survived by Sandy, her beloved husband of 63 years, five loving children; Barbara, Joy, David, Alan and Stacey, 11 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. She quietly passed on November 11, 2011 after a 13 month struggle with an incurable disease. Funeral services will be held at 11:15am on Tuesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to the Kidney and Urology Foundation of America and Temple Sinai of Delray, Florida.

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The Board of Play For P.I.N.K. deeply mourns the loss of Evelyn Lauder, Founder and Chairman of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation. Evelyn embodied everything that is good in the world. We are proud of our 15 year partnership with BCRF and her memory will continue to inspire us. Laura Lassman, President

LAUDER--Evelyn H. It is with profound sadness that the Hunter College community mourns the loss of a great humanitarian and distinguished alumna whose generosity and keen interest in students and faculty extended to the labs and classrooms of her beloved alma maters, Hunter College and Hunter College High School. Evelyn was a visionary who worked passionately towards the goal of finding a cure for breast cancer. Hunter College was fortunate to be able to assist in that goal through the generosity of Evelyn's support to the College's breast cancer research lab. She contributed in so many other ways through her work on the Hunter College Visioning Board and the leadership committee of the High School endowment campaign. She received an honorary degree from the College in 2004 and the Distinguished Alumni Award from the High School in 2010. Her extraordinary life story of immigration, hard work and success will continue to serve as an inspiration to the many Hunter College students who follow in her footsteps. Our heartfelt condolences to our dear friend, Leonard, and to her family. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College Klara Silverstein Chair, Hunter College Foundation

An article last Monday about the presidential victory of Otto Pérez Molina, a former general during Guatemala's bloody civil war, misstated the country's debt load. It is about 30 percent of Guatemala's G.D.P., not 3 percent.

LAUDER--Evelyn. The Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn, with great sorrow, the loss of Evelyn H. Lauder, beloved wife of our Chairman Emeritus Leonard A. Lauder and mother of William and Gary. Evelyn was a dynamic and gracious woman and a visionary philanthropist. She had a marvelous aesthetic sense, evident in everything she did from her work with Estee Lauder, her style as hostess, cook, and gardener to her great talent as a photographer. She faced her illness with courage and a great joy for life. She was an inspiration to those around her. She was warm, helpful in times of need, and there for her friends, family and even many who hardly knew her. So too are we--the Whitney Museum family--here for Leonard and his family. Evelyn H. Lauder, a refugee of Nazi-occupied Europe who married into an illustrious family in the beauty business and became an ardent advocate for breast cancer awareness, raising millions for research, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75. The cause was nongenetic ovarian cancer, said Alexandra Trower, a spokeswoman for the Estée Lauder Companies. As the wife of Leonard A. Lauder, the chairman emeritus of the Estée Lauder Companies, and as the daughter-in-law of the company's formidable matriarch, Estée Lauder, Evelyn Lauder had to establish her own place in a family as complex as it was competitive. Mrs. Lauder frequently told the story of how, early in her marriage, she returned to the couple's apartment to find that Estée had rearranged the furniture more to her liking. When Evelyn and Leonard were dating -- it was only their second date -- Estée implored her to stay and be the hostess for a birthday party she was giving her son. ''So I stayed,'' Mrs. Lauder said in an interview in 2008. ''What could I do? She was like a steamroller.'' Yet it was clear that Estée was crazy about the young woman, and soon after Evelyn's marriage, in 1959, she joined the family cosmetics company, then a small enterprise, pitching in wherever she was needed. ''I was very strong,'' she said. ''Having had a childhood like the one I had, I was much more tough than a lot of people. I was one of the few people who spoke my mind to Estée.'' Mrs. Lauder learned she had breast cancer in 1989 and soon became a strong voice on behalf of women's health, though she was always reluctant to discuss her own condition. ''My situation doesn't really matter,'' she told a reporter in 1995. She was a creator of the Pink Ribbon campaign, a worldwide symbol of breast health, and in 1993 she founded the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, which has raised more than $350 million. In 2007 she received a diagnosis of ovarian cancer, which developed independently of her breast cancer, Ms. Trower said. Evelyn Hausner was born on Aug. 12, 1936, in Vienna, the only child of Ernest and Mimi Hausner. Her father, a dapper man who lived in Poland and Berlin before marrying the daughter of a Viennese lumber supplier, owned a lingerie shop. In 1938, with Hitler's annexation of Austria, the family left Vienna, taking a few belongings, including household silver, which Ernest Hausner used to obtain visas to Belgium. The family eventually reached England, where Evelyn's mother was immediately sent to an internment camp on the Isle of Man. ''The separation was very traumatic for me,'' Mrs. Lauder said. Her father placed her in a nursery until her mother could be released and he could raise money. In 1940, the family set sail for New York, where her father worked as a diamond cutter during the war. In 1947, he and his wife bought a dress shop in Manhattan called Lamay. Over time they expanded it to a chain of five shops. Mrs. Lauder grew up on West 86th Street and attended Public School 9. During her freshman year at Hunter College, she met Leonard Lauder on a blind date. Already graduated from college and training to be a naval officer, Mr. Lauder had grown up on West 76th Street, though in a sense it was a world apart. ''He was the first person who took me out to dinner in a restaurant,'' she recalled. They married four years later at the Plaza Hotel. Though always at home by 4 p.m. when her two children were little, Mrs. Lauder said she never considered being a stay-at-home mom, in spite of the family's growing wealth. ''I couldn't bear it,'' she said. ''I grew up with a working mother.'' Mrs. Lauder was also a public school teacher for several years. She held many roles at Estée Lauder, including creator of training programs and director of new products and marketing. In 1989, the year of her breast cancer diagnosis, she became the senior corporate vice president and head of fragrance development worldwide. Mrs. Lauder is survived by her husband; her sons, William and Gary; and five grandchildren. Though Mrs. Lauder, an avid photographer, had a home in Colorado and a penthouse on Fifth Avenue lined with modern art, she and her husband liked to retreat to a plain cabin in Putnam County, N.Y., where Mrs. Lauder might serve guests German food she had prepared. Asked once how she felt about working with her husband in the early days, she replied, ''Working with Leonard was a riot.'' Indeed, she joked that he had such a sense of business, without family favoritism, that getting an appointment with him was sometimes tough. ''It would take me much longer to get a date with him,'' she said, ''than someone who didn't have his name.'' Reprinted from Sunday's late editions.nThis is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

(Flix) THE 400 BLOWS (1959) The director François Truffaut, in his feature-film debut, a defining entry in French New Wave cinema, drew inspiration from his childhood for a story about a 12-year-old who escapes his dysfunctional family by turning to crime. ''Words cannot state simply how fine is Jean-Pierre Léaud,'' in the lead role, Bosley Crowther wrote in his review in The New York Times. ''Out of this brand-new youngster, M. Truffaut has elicited a performance that will live as a delightful, provoking and heartbreaking monument to a boy.'' He added, ''Here is a picture that encourages an exciting refreshment of faith in films.''

ULYSSES, Kan. -- Change can be unsettling in a small town. But not long ago in this quiet farming community, with its familiar skyline of grain elevators and church steeples, the owner of a new restaurant decided to acknowledge the community's diversity by adding some less traditional items to her menu. Cheeseburgers. French fries. Chicken-fried steak. ''American food,'' the restaurant owner, Luz Gonzalez, calls it. And she signaled her move by giving her Mexican restaurant a distinctly American name: ''The Down-Town Restaurant.''

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The employees of the Estee Lauder Companies deeply mourn the passing of Evelyn H. Lauder, Senior Corporate Vice President and Head of Fragrance Development Worldwide. She died peacefully of complications from non-genetic ovarian cancer on November 12th at the age of 75 at her home in New York City, surrounded by her family. Mrs. Lauder was a beloved friend and colleague to the entire employee family. She was a risk-taker and trailblazer and always led with style. One of her greatest joys in life and business was applying the many aspects of her creativity and invaluable insights to new products and brands. A schoolteacher by training, Mrs. Lauder joined the Estee Lauder Companies in its infancy in 1959. Ever the teacher, Mrs. Lauder created ground-breaking education training programs--practices the Estee Lauder Companies uses to this day to maintain its place as a leader in global prestige beauty. She helped her much-loved mother-in-law, Mrs. Estee Lauder, develop and launch the Company's first men's fragrance, Aramis. And she was the driving force behind the idea for the brand Clinique, coming up with the brand's name and becoming its first Training Director. Her passion for beauty and nature, as well as her work on Aramis, helped frame what would become one of her most important imprints on the Company. In 1989, Mrs. Lauder began a successful 22-year career in fragrances after discovering her innate talent for recognizing distinct fragrance notes. It was an interest she shared with Mrs. Estee Lauder and one that stemmed from Mrs. Lauder's lifelong passion for flowers and gardening. Her rare ability to visualize unique fragrance combinations led to some of the Company's most successful global fragrances, including the best-selling Beautiful and Pleasures. In 1989, she assumed the role of Senior Corporate Vice President and Head of Fragrance Development Worldwide, a position she held and cherished until her death. In 1992, Mrs. Lauder began her mission to bring global awareness to breast cancer when she launched the Company's Breast Cancer Awareness (BCA) Campaign and co-created the Pink Ribbon, now known as the worldwide symbol of breast health. Through its brands, employees and fundraising initiatives with its retail partners, the BCA Campaign has raised more than $50 million for The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded by Mrs. Lauder in 1993 to provide crucial funds to the world's top medical and scientific researchers. Mrs. Lauder loved the Estee Lauder Companies and she loved its people, whom she considered part of her extended family. Those who had the opportunity to meet and work with her were touched by her kindness, warmth and deep, personal interest in them, whether they were behind the department store counter or a senior executive. She made a point to visit our counters in every country she visited and was sincerely interested in people's lives. She was known for her quick humor and was valued for her advice on almost any subject: love, marriage, finding the perfect lipstickeven on how to make her famous brisket. Mrs. Lauder's caring and pioneering spirit, business talent, fiery charm, extraordinary philanthropic drive, and enthusiastic love of life will be sorely missed by us all. She had an enormous impact on each one of us. She was a treasured role model to every employee of the Estee Lauder Companies, and our thoughts are with the Lauder family during this difficult time. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Evelyn Lauder Founder's Fund: www.bcrfcure.org or 60 East 56th Street, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10022.

MAHONY--Robert C.,age 92, of Bronxville, NY, formerly of Riverdale, NY, died Saturday, November 12, 2011 in his home. Husband to Doris Sullivan and father to Barbara Weaver, Robert J. Mahony, Michael P. Mahony, Maureen Casper, and Mary Jo Flynn, he was most proud of the 42 children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren that he took direct responsibility for producing. An active parishioner of St Joseph's Catholic Church in Bronxville for over 30 years (formerly of St. Margaret's in Riverdale for some 60 years), he taught CCD and was a lector and daily communicant. He was a Eucharistic Minister for his parish, visiting the sick at their homes and at Lawrence Hospital where he volunteered for many years. He took great joy in volunteering at the Pregnancy Care Center in New Rochelle where he walked and played with the children under their care. Robert ran the J.G. Mahony Company, Inc., insurance brokerage firm up until 2010, a firm his father established, and was on the Board of Directors of Anchor Savings Bank, Dime Savings Bank, and The Schervier Nursing Care Center in the Bronx, NY. He is survived by his brother, Richard Mahony, and sister, Catherine Howett. Calling Hours at the Fred H. There was much controversy leading up to the Museum of Contemporary Art's annual fund-raising gala, which was held over the weekend in a tent in front of the museum in downtown Los Angeles. Despite all efforts to maintain secrecy, word had leaked that Marina Abramovic, who art-directed the event, was going to submit a cast of young men and women to acts reminiscent of some of the often excruciating performances that have made her one of the world's most well-known performance artists. Some would be required to lay dead still in the nude on a lazy susan or buried under a skeleton for hours on end; others would stick their heads out from underneath a table, maintaining a straight face throughout the course of the evening, while surrounding guests feasted on a three-course meal. The news prompted another veteran performance artist, Yvonne Rainer, to send an open letter to the museum director, Jeffrey Deitch, protesting abuse and exploitation in the name of museum fund-raising. While Rainer's letter may have spoiled some of the night's surprises (and reportedly added to Abramovic's pre-event jitters), for the gala's organizers it proved to be an unexpected public relations blessing, keeping much of the art world abuzz long before the first guests even hit the red carpet.

One of my favorite subgenres of novelty music is "the wrong and inappropriate cover song," as pioneered by the great William Shatner. (My other favorite subgenre? Jazz-singing rodents.) Of course there are a million awful cover songs out there, but only a few are truly, spectacularly Shatner-level awful. Rolling Stone recently took a poll of the 10 worst covers, and Miley Cyrus's cover of "Smells Like Teen Spirit" won first prize. I'll leave that one out, was kind of obvious. "Goudemalion," on view at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris, examines the work of the artist and image maker Jean-Paul Goude through the lens of the Pygmalion myth. Indeed Goude incarnates the sculptor of Ovid's "Metamorphoses," in love with the art carved out of his own hands. Goude, who calls himself "The French Correction," is known for his willful distortion of the human figure, in works like the Constructivist "maternity dress" he created for his longtime muse Grace Jones and for any number of his Ektachrome collages in which models like Toukie Smith, Bjork or his wife, Karen Park Goude, appear far greater than the sum of their body parts. Included in the exhibition is a 1972 episode of "The Mike Douglas Show" in which Goude attempted to deconstruct his method. Out come the perfect teeth (fake), up go the hemlines (exposing feet vaulted on 12-inch heels), out come the shoulder pads (revealing slim upper bodies), up go "new" bellybuttons (to shift the waistline). His is an artfully composed morphology, one without pretense or the sly retouching that portends that the faux is real.

The sun was about to set on the Indonesian island of Bali when Ben Ripple and Frederick Schilling, owners of the artisanal food company Big Tree Farms, led me through their new chocolate factory near Ubud. It was still under construction as we stepped into a titanic inner chamber with a high pitched roof, the last light of the day streaming dramatically through a long, narrow skylight at the peak, allowing the 30 or so builders to keep working. NABLUS, West Bank - Last Saturday, I arrived at the Nablus train station, a low, thick-walled stone structure, in time to board the 3:20 pm to Jerusalem. Some 20 passengers were waiting at the entrance, mostly young men and women, with a few people old enough to remember the days of train travel during the British Mandate over Palestine. The excitement was palpable: It was our chance to take a ride to Jerusalem, a city we are barred from visiting, bypassing the Israeli checkpoints along the way. As I entered the station, a porter in a dark blue uniform issued me a ticket on the Green Line. The journey would take 30 minutes, with stops planned at Hawwarah, Zatara, Uyun al Haramiya, Attarah and Kalandia - all existing checkpoints. I made my way to the waiting room. It was barren, except for low tables with brochures entitled "Palestine Connected" showing local train networks and their destinations. Gaza. Jaffa. Haifa. Beersheba.

You reach the house of Indu Prakash Vaidya, a 32-year-old housewife, by trekking down a two-foot-wide alley through an inch of stinking, wet mud, filled with plastic bags and kitchen scraps.Her 200-square-foot shanty, in Rajiv Gandhi Nagar, in the Dharavi neighborhood of Mumbai, has faulty electrical lines, no water supply and a non existent sewage system. Still, Ms. Vaidya's house is her most prized possession. "If I decide to sell it, it will fetch me more than Rs 10 lakh" rupees, or about $24,000, she estimates, based on the offers she has been getting.
Woe is us.

Confronted by a quarterly loss and new capital requirements, UniCredit, the largest Italian bank, said on Monday that it would raise $10.3 billion and eliminate 5,200 jobs in Italy in the next few years. The bank said that if its results were adjusted to exclude one-time items, its third-quarter loss would total 474 million euros. UniCredit had earnings of 334 million euros in the third quarter of 2010.

Many New York politicians returned to work on Monday with a fresh suntan from their time at a conference in Puerto Rico this weekend. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, showed up with something considerably less attractive: bruises on his face and a set of stitches under one of his eyebrows.

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The Board and Staff of 92nd Street Y mourn the passing of Evelyn Hausner Lauder. Mrs. Lauder is survived by her husband Leonard and her two sons Gary and William a long standing member of 92nd Street Y's board and five grandchildren. Through the generosity of Evelyn and Leonard, 92Y has held its annual "Update on Breast Cancer" lecture by Dr. Larry Norton for 19 years, thus offering the latest information to the public. Thousands have been helped, adding to the millions whose lives have been bettered by BCRF and the Evelyn Lauder Breast Center of MSKCC. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Lauder family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Thomas S. Kaplan, President Fredric Mack, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director Helaine Geismar Katz, Associate Executive Director

BCRF stands in tribute to her vision and will endure through the force of her commitment, which will live forever in our hearts. Hilary Mantel, winner of the 2009 Man Booker Prize for ''Wolf Hall,'' a historical novel about Henry VIII's adviser Thomas Cromwell, will follow it with a sequel, ''Bring Up the Bodies,'' her publisher said on Monday. The book is scheduled for release in fall 2012 by John Macrae Books, an imprint of Henry Holt and Company. ''Hilary Mantel is a brilliant literary portraitist whose work is full of complexity and nuance that is coupled with a distinctive voice and utterly irresistible prose,'' Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Holt, said in a statement. ''I share in the enthusiasm and anticipation of the many 'Wolf Hall' readers who eagerly await the return to Cromwell's life in the tangled web of Tudor England and Hilary's vast imagination.''

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the business strategy of John Paton, chief executive of the MediaNews Group, gave an incorrect definition of the financial acronym Ebitda. It is earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- not earnings before interest, taxes, ''debt'' and amortization.

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with sorrow the passing of Evelyn H. Lauder, who served with distinction as a member of MSKCC's Boards from 1990 until the time of her death. Mrs. Lauder spearheaded the fund drive to build and equip Memorial Sloan-Kettering's Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center, which opened in 1992 at 205 East 64th Street. This outpatient facility, which served as a model for breast cancer centers around the world, offered multidisciplinary care for breast cancer patients, who were able to see experts from surgeons to medical oncologists to psychiatrists and social workers all under one roof. In 2009, MSKCC opened the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center in a new home at 300 East 66th Street. This state-of-the-art center offers comprehensive breast cancer services in a patient-centered setting designed to accommodate evolving modalities in the diagnosis and treatment of the disease. The serenity and beauty of the treatment areas reflect Mrs. Lauder's commitment to building a home for patients and for their physicians and nurses, and her belief in the healing power of nature, natural light, and art. But its deeper beauty derives from what it enables and facilitates-the rapid translation of laboratory and clinical discoveries into meaningful advances for patients with cancer. Women with breast cancer and their families, as well as the members of our treatment and research communities, will be forever grateful for Mrs. Lauder's philanthropic support, wisdom, enthusiasm, and guidance. Her tireless dedication to the improvement of treatment for breast cancer will continue to serve as an inspiration. She will be profoundly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Leonard, her children and grandchildren, and the rest of her family. Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman, Boards of Overseers and Managers Craig B. Thompson, President Robert E. Wittes, Physician-in-Chief, Memorial Hospital Larry Norton, Deputy Physician-in-Chief, Breast Cancer Programs Medical Director, The Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center John R. Gunn, Executive Vice President

LAUDER--Evelyn. Toby and Itzhak Perlman and all the talented musicians at The Perlman Music Program express our deepest condolences for the loss of a great music enthusiast and loving friend, Evelyn Lauder. We offer our most heartfelt sympathies to her family.

LAUDER--Evelyn H. It is with profound sadness that the Hunter College community mourns the loss of a great humanitarian and distinguished alumna whose generosity and keen interest in students and faculty extended to the labs and classrooms of her beloved alma maters, Hunter College and Hunter College High School. Evelyn was a visionary who worked passionately towards the goal of finding a cure for breast cancer. Hunter College was fortunate to be able to assist in that goal through the generosity of Evelyn's support to the College's breast cancer research lab. She contributed in so many other ways through her work on the Hunter College Visioning Board and the leadership committee of the High School endowment campaign. She received an honorary degree from the College in 2004 and the Distinguished Alumni Award from the High School in 2010. Her extraordinary life story of immigration, hard work and success will continue to serve as an inspiration to the many Hunter College students who follow in her footsteps. Our heartfelt condolences to our dear friend, Leonard, and to her family. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College Klara Silverstein Chair, Hunter College Foundation

LAUDER--Evelyn. Our thoughts are with Leonard, William, Gary and Laura and the entire Lauder family during this difficult time. Evelyn was such a vibrant and wonderful woman and will be greatly missed by everyone she touched. With love and condolences, Marc and Sheri Feigen

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation grieves the passing of Evelyn Lauder, our visionary Founder and Chairman--and much-loved friend. Evelyn's passionate action and determination to improve the health of women and families led her to establish BCRF in 1993, and her single-minded dedication to finding a cure for breast cancer never wavered. She inspired us daily with her grace and elegance, and her leadership and friendship made each of us better and stronger. Her irrepressible sense of humor made her instantly approachable and loved by everyone who met her. She made us laugh! We cannot imagine a world without her, but her example propels us to carry on in her memory. Our hearts go out to her beloved husband, Leonard, her sons, William and Gary, of whom she was so very proud, and her entire family whom she loved so dearly. Myra Biblowit, President Jeanette S. Wagner, Vice President Deborah Krulewitch, Secretary Robert Bigler, Treasurer BCRF Board of Directors Larry Norton, MD, Scientific Director Executive Board of Scientific Advisors Clifford Hudis, MD, Scientific Advisory Committee Chair Scientific Advisory Committee Margaret Mastrianni, Deputy Director Advisory Board and Leaders Council

Following cheating scandals in several major American school districts and a rise in complaints of tampering with New York State's exams, Education Commissioner John B. King Jr. announced on Monday that he would name a veteran lawyer to analyze how the state handles reports of cheating. Hank Greenberg, a former assistant United States attorney and senior legal adviser to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo when he was attorney general, will review how the state's Education Department receives and investigates complaints of alleged test tampering.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a performance on Saturday by the pianist Richard Goode at Washington Irving High School in Manhattan misidentified the key of a Beethoven sonata that was on the program. The sonata -- Op. 31, No. 3 -- is in E-flat, not B-flat.

KLEIN--Renee. The Officers, Board of Governors, The Women's Group, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Renee Klein, and extend our sincerest condolences to her daughter Lisa Klein and family. Robert Anton, President

Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev, major stars of the ballet world and two of Russia's best-known classical artists, said on Monday that they were leaving the storied Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow for the Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg. While a blow to the Bolshoi, which recently reopened after a long renovation, their defection is a coup for the Mikhailovsky, a venerable but lesser-known house that has received a large infusion of money from Vladimir Kekhman, the owner of Russia's largest fruit company, who became its general director in 2007.

An article on Thursday about a test that detected meaningful brain activity in three people thought to be in a ''vegetative'' state erroneously attributed a distinction to a study published in The Lancet reporting the finding. While it is the first large study to demonstrate that clear signs of conscious awareness can be detected on an electroencephalogram machine using an innovative strategy, it is not the first study of any size to do so. (Single cases have been reported before, including one by researchers at New York University School of Medicine and a similar one by scientists at Weill Cornell Medical College.)

A museum review on Friday about the remodeled New-York Historical Society and the new exhibition ''Revolution! The Atlantic World Reborn,'' which looks at slavery among other issues, misstated the year Britain abolished slavery. It was 1833, not 1807. (That was the year Britain abolished the slave trade in its empire.)

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The employees of the Estee Lauder Companies deeply mourn the passing of Evelyn H. Lauder, Senior Corporate Vice President and Head of Fragrance Development Worldwide. She died peacefully of complications from non-genetic ovarian cancer on November 12th at the age of 75 at her home in New York City, surrounded by her family. Mrs. Lauder was a beloved friend and colleague to the entire employee family. She was a risk-taker and trailblazer and always led with style. One of her greatest joys in life and business was applying the many aspects of her creativity and invaluable insights to new products and brands. A schoolteacher by training, Mrs. Lauder joined the Estee Lauder Companies in its infancy in 1959. Ever the teacher, Mrs. Lauder created ground-breaking education training programs--practices the Estee Lauder Companies uses to this day to maintain its place as a leader in global prestige beauty. She helped her much-loved mother-in-law, Mrs. Estee Lauder, develop and launch the Company's first men's fragrance, Aramis. And she was the driving force behind the idea for the brand Clinique, coming up with the brand's name and becoming its first Training Director. Her passion for beauty and nature, as well as her work on Aramis, helped frame what would become one of her most important imprints on the Company. In 1989, Mrs. Lauder began a successful 22-year career in fragrances after discovering her innate talent for recognizing distinct fragrance notes. It was an interest she shared with Mrs. Estee Lauder and one that stemmed from Mrs. Lauder's lifelong passion for flowers and gardening. Her rare ability to visualize unique fragrance combinations led to some of the Company's most successful global fragrances, including the best-selling Beautiful and Pleasures. In 1989, she assumed the role of Senior Corporate Vice President and Head of Fragrance Development Worldwide, a position she held and cherished until her death. In 1992, Mrs. Lauder began her mission to bring global awareness to breast cancer when she launched the Company's Breast Cancer Awareness (BCA) Campaign and co-created the Pink Ribbon, now known as the worldwide symbol of breast health. Through its brands, employees and fundraising initiatives with its retail partners, the BCA Campaign has raised more than $50 million for The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded by Mrs. Lauder in 1993 to provide crucial funds to the world's top medical and scientific researchers. Mrs. Lauder loved the Estee Lauder Companies and she loved its people, whom she considered part of her extended family. Those who had the opportunity to meet and work with her were touched by her kindness, warmth and deep, personal interest in them, whether they were behind the department store counter or a senior executive. She made a point to visit our counters in every country she visited and was sincerely interested in people's lives. She was known for her quick humor and was valued for her advice on almost any subject: love, marriage, finding the perfect lipstickeven on how to make her famous brisket. Mrs. Lauder's caring and pioneering spirit, business talent, fiery charm, extraordinary philanthropic drive, and enthusiastic love of life will be sorely missed by us all. She had an enormous impact on each one of us. She was a treasured role model to every employee of the Estee Lauder Companies, and our thoughts are with the Lauder family during this difficult time. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Evelyn Lauder Founder's Fund: www.bcrfcure.org or 60 East 56th Street, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10022.

FRANKFURT - Josef Ackermann unexpectedly canceled plans to become chairman of Deutsche Bank when he retires as chief executive in May, possibly heralding his departure from the public stage after a decade as one of the most powerful and controversial figures in European banking. The announcement Monday came on the same day as reports that prosecutors in Munich had searched the executive offices of Deutsche Bank on suspicion that Mr. Ackermann and other current and former top executives had given false testimony in a long-running civil lawsuit. Deutsche Bank denied any wrongdoing. The timing of Mr. Ackermann's announcement appeared to be a coincidence.

LAUDER--Evelyn. The Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn, with great sorrow, the loss of Evelyn H. Lauder, beloved wife of our Chairman Emeritus Leonard A. Lauder and mother of William and Gary. Evelyn was a dynamic and gracious woman and a visionary philanthropist. She had a marvelous aesthetic sense, evident in everything she did from her work with Estee Lauder, her style as hostess, cook, and gardener to her great talent as a photographer. She faced her illness with courage and a great joy for life. She was an inspiration to those around her. She was warm, helpful in times of need, and there for her friends, family and even many who hardly knew her. So too are we--the Whitney Museum family--here for Leonard and his family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown, Director

Irene was a New York City teacher working with hearing impaired children and then became a guidance counselor until her retirement. She married the late Herbert K. Pillersdorf Esq. and then married fellow educator Rudy Lipkind. Irene is survived by two sons, Dr. Alan B. Pillersdorf, and his wife Rhona of Palm Beach Florida, and Gary B. Pillersdorf, an attorney in New York City and his wife Diane. She also is survived by six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street on Tuesday at 12:45pm, with Burial at Cedar Park Cemetery immediately thereafter. The family will sit at the home of Gary Pillersdorf through Thursday.

8 P.M. (TCM) AFI'S MASTER CLASS -- THE ART OF COLLABORATION Turner Classic Movies and the American Film Institute examine the 40-year friendship and working partnership between the director Steven Spielberg and the composer John Williams. The program begins with a look at ''The Sugarland Express'' (1974), Mr. Spielberg's first theatrical film, for which he hired Mr. Williams to write the music. It then moves on to blockbusters like ''Jaws'' (1975), above, which earned Mr. Williams the first of three Oscars he would win from scoring Mr. Spielberg's films; ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' (1977); ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial'' (1982), Mr. Williams's second Oscar; and ''Schindler's List'' (1993), his third. ''Saving Private Ryan'' (1998), starring Tom Hanks as a squad leader sent to find a soldier (Matt Damon) whose brothers have died in combat, and which Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, called ''soberly magnificent,'' follows at 9. Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Williams's work can be seen in the coming ''Adventures of Tintin'' and ''War Horse,'' both in theaters at Christmas, and in their 26th film together, ''Lincoln,'' slated for release in December 2012. 9:15 A.M. (Sundance) OF TIME AND THE CITY (2009) In his first documentary Terence Davies uses archival footage, musical excerpts and recollections to construct a poetic essay about the Liverpool, England, of his childhood. He revisits the pain and pleasure of growing up gay and Roman Catholic in postwar Britain. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''a deeply personal piece of art that never descends into the confessional or the therapeutic, and a work of social and literary criticism that never lectures or hectors, but rather, with melancholy, tenderness and wit, manages to sing.'' In ''Fermat's Room,'' Luis Piedrahita and Rodrigo Sopeña's thriller, at 12:15 p.m., four mathematicians are trapped inside a shrinking chamber and must solve a series of puzzles to survive.

The Trade column on Oct. 27, about the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement history related to collateralized debt obligations, referred incompletely to actions taken against individuals. The agency has sued four other people in addition to the two bankers mentioned in the column; it is not the case that it has brought civil actions against ''only two small-time bankers.'' The error was repeated in a caption.

Chimpanzees can live 50 to 60 years in captivity, so those that are retired have long histories, although the details can be spotty. On her Web site, The First 100, Lori Gruen, chairwoman of the philosophy department at Wesleyan University, has thumbnail biographies of the first 100 chimps used in research in the United States. She hopes to create a similar site for chimps now in research laboratories, called The Last 1,000. The chimps pictured here, some with long histories, others with uncertain futures, are at Chimp Haven and the New Iberia Research Center, both in Louisiana.

EPSTEIN ELEFANT--Ingrid. Beloved wife of Jack, cherished mother of Wendy and Ellen, and devoted grandmother to Jason, Sarah, Joshua, and Stephanie. Passed away at home, surrounded by her husband and daughters, on November 13, 2011. One of the hidden children of the Holocaust, she was active in educating younger generations. She enjoyed a satisfying career as a clinical social worker. Her family and friends will miss her dearly.

SUDER--Isaac, passed peacefully on November 12. Ike epitomized a person of compassion and moral integrity who lived a life of doing the right thing. He was a true renaissance man, having a deep knowledge of and passion for music, art, travel, politics, history, literature, business, sports, and the well-being of the State of Israel. Born in Brooklyn, NY on August 12, 1924, Ike moved to Manhattan at the start of the Great Depression. He graduated from New York University with both a B.S. and M.S. in Chemical Engineering. Ike served two tours of duty in the Pacific Theater during WW II with the Navy, the second as an officer upon graduating from the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point. Ike met Frances Gruss, the love of his life, on a blind date and the two wed on Veteran's Day 60 years ago this past Friday, November 11th. After a successful career as a partner at M. Golodetz & Co, an international commodity firm, Ike remained philanthropic in several charitable organizations, played tennis regularly, studied piano, and gave back-stage tours at the Metropolitan Opera, his second home. Isaac and Frances were the adoring parents to three devoted children: Michael of New Orleans, LA, Jonathan of Ft. Worth, Texas and Nicolle of New York City. Ike was also blessed with six grandchildren, Morgan, Jason, Roxanne, Margo, Ryan and Natalie. He is survived by his children and grandchildren. The family requests that donations be made to one of his and Fran's favorite charities - Boys Town Jerusalem Foundation, 1 Penn Plaza, Suite 6250, New York, NY 10019, Attn: Ronald Gray. Ike will be missed but never forgotten. Services will be on Tuesday, November 15 at 11:30am Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors 402 Park St. Hackensack, NJ.

TUCKER--William, 92, of Great Neck, NY, died November 12. Survived by Selma, his wife of 65 years, and a large loving family. Bill cared for those around him and strove to make the world a better place. Funeral at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, November 15 at 11:00.

An article on Wednesday about a second woman who publicly accused the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain of sexually harassing her misidentified a client of Mr. Cain's attorney, L. The Canadian author Margaret Atwood and the French theater director Patrice Chereau are among the six artists who will serve as mentors in dance, film, literature, music, theater and visual arts as part of a program sponsored by Rolex. -Under the Rolex Mentor and Protege Arts Initiative, established a decade ago, each mentor will select an emerging young talent for a year of creative dialogue and exchange. The cost-cutting at Goldman Sachs is now reaching the top ranks of the firm. An unusually high number of partner retirements have been announced internally at the Wall Street bank in recent weeks, according to people who were briefed on the matter but are not authorized to speak on the record. More than a dozen partners have announced plans to leave recently, a much higher number than in the same period in past years.

Nearly three years after Bernard L. Madoff's gigantic fraud imploded, federal authorities say they are cracking down on Ponzi schemes in greater numbers. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission brought 32 enforcement cases against suspected Ponzi schemes in its 2011 fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, a 45 percent increase from 2010 and a record high for the agency, according to data that will be released on Tuesday. In the same period, the Federal Bureau of Investigation opened more than 1,000 inquiries into possible Ponzi schemes, a roughly 150 percent increase from 2008, new figures show.

Her blood was cold, but her heart, her keepers said, was warm. Elizabeth, the Brooklyn Children's Museum's senior iguana, died on Thursday in her enclosure at the age of 19. She was a remarkably social animal, those who knew her said, equally at ease with mayors, music stars and developmentally disabled children. Her departure leaves a gap that the museum is presently too stricken to contemplate filling.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the growing Hispanic population in small rural towns throughout the Great Plains misstated, in some editions, the population for one of the towns, Ulysses, Kan. In the 2010 Census, the population was 6,161, not 6,933. And also because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly in some editions to the decline in the non-Hispanic white population in western Kansas. It declined in all counties but one (Ellis County) -- not in all counties.

LEE--Robert A.,passed away on November 10, 2011, at the age of 94, in Lakewood, Washington. He died peacefully in his sleep with family members present. Born April 25, 1917, in Spokane, Washington, Bob was the younger of two sons of Mathilde B. and Sigurd H. Lee. The family moved to Portland, Oregon when Bob was two. There he attended Benson Polytechnic High School, where he began a lifelong career in journalism, serving as editor of the school paper and as a stringer for the Portland Oregonian. He enrolled in Reed College in 1934, but on the advice of his editor at the Oregonian transferred to the University of Oregon, from which he graduated Phi Beta Kappa in 1938, majoring in English. In 1936, he met his future wife, Catherine Taylor, then a journalism student at University of Oregon. They married in 1941 and had three children. After graduation, Bob joined the Oregonian where he worked until 1960, first as a reporter and later as an editor. His stint at the Oregonian was interrupted by two years' service as a radio technician in the Navy during WWII. He was instrumental in founding the Portland Reporter, an independent daily paper, which was published from 1960 to 1964. In 1960 he joined the New York Times, and the family moved to Montclair, NJ. In 1962, the Times sent him to Los Angeles for the start-up of Western Edition, of which he became managing editor. The family returned east in 1964, where he worked for the Times until retiring in 1980, finishing his career as head of the make-up desk and associate news editor. Following retirement, Bob and Katy returned to Portland, where they enjoyed their life together until Katy's death in 2005 at the age of 85. During this period, the couple traveled extensively, to Europe, South America, Africa and Asia, as well making numerous trips to visit their children and grandchildren. Throughout his life, Bob was known for his kindness and compassion, his liberal politics, keen intelligence and wit. He was an avid golfer, an insightful student of history and politics, and lover of literature and the arts, regularly attending the theater, opera, and symphony both in New York and later in Portland. But most of all, he was devoted to his family and friends, and will be deeply missed by those whose lives he touched. He is survived by a daughter and son-in-law, Stephanie and Fred Ostmann of Tacoma, WA; two sons and daughters-in-law, Daniel T. and Nelma Lee, of Portland, OR, and Robert S. and Laura Lee, of Houston, TX; three grandchildren, Dr. Heather Ostmann currently of Jacksonville, FL, Lilah Helton, of Seattle, WA, and Natalie Lee of Houston, TX; and great-granddaughter Stephanie Ann Despain, of Jacksonville, FL. He was predeceased by his wife Katy and brother Norman K. Lee of Boise, Idaho. A memorial service will be held in Portland, OR, on December 3. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Oregon Food Bank P.O.Box 55370, Portland, OR 97238. ww.oregonfoodbank.org.

In a new interview with Esquire magazine, the theater director Julie Taymor accuses Bono and the Edge of U2 - her former collaborators on the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' - of maligning her as exhausted and overwrought as a bogus explanation for ousting her from the production in March and then overhauling the show as they saw fit. Edge, who wrote the music and lyrics for ''Spider-Man'' with Bono, had previously used those two adjectives to describe Ms. Taymor's state of mind last winter. Of those adjectives, Ms. Taymor told Esquire, ''I think that those were important to paint a picture of a director who you needed to release in order to make this big change. I had to be characterized that way in order for something to happen.'' After her firing, ''Spider-Man'' shut down for three weeks to insert new dialogue and scenes that Ms. Taymor's former colleagues had been secretly preparing and sharing with the producers during the winter.

POSNER--Alan Henry, 86, NYC, NY, beloved husband of Lillian (nee Palitz) Posner (predeceased), loving father of Marshall, Jeffery, Matthew and Claudia, grandfather of Bowen, Lily, Holly and PJ, and devoted companion of Margot Green, passed away November 12th, from lung cancer. Born in NYC July 3, 1925, graduated Horace Mann School and Yale University (1946), served in the Merchant Marine in WWII. He was a real estate investor in NYC, The president of board of 911 Park Avenue for 30 years, a trustee Knickerbocker Hospital, Board President the Hewitt School; Treasurer and Finance Committee member Yale Club; a director Interfaith Committee Jewish Community Relations Council; and a trustee of the Catholic Medical Center for over 22 years. Memorial Service, Wednesday November 16, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

No one could have imagined that five months later, Paterno would be ousted after 46 years amid a criminal investigation into a child sexual abuse scandal involving his former defensive coordinator, Jerry Sandusky.

MURKY ACCOUNTING By playing down its exposure to European sovereign debt, MF Global lost credibility in the market and eventually got hammered as fears over possible bond defaults rose. More than 1,000 MF Global employees have been laid off, customer accounts have been frozen, and federal investigators have been trying to sort through the mess. According to White Collar Watch, the collapse of MF Global shows how easy it is to obscure risky investments and the pitfalls that can occur when those problems surface. PETER J. HENNING

The American pipeline operator Kinder Morgan struck one of the biggest deals of the year nearly a month ago with its $21.1 billion purchase of a rival, the El Paso Corporation. What was just as notable was the financing backing the deal - a $13.3 billion loan package arranged by Barclays Capital, one of the largest financing efforts that the bank had made on its own. It was the second time this year that the British investment bank took the initial financing of a megadeal upon its shoulders. In August, Barclays lent $8.3 billion to Hewlett-Packard to help pay for its $11.7 billion purchase of the British software company Autonomy.

On a typical night in the emergency room, a patient shows up short of breath, suffering from emphysema or heart failure or maybe both, as well as diabetes and high blood pressure. Doctors and nurses administer inhalers to ease his breathing and diuretics to take off excess fluid, and admit him to the hospital. Over the next few days, interns and residents furiously adjust his medications and fix his diet. He is discharged with a stack of prescriptions. A week or two later, chances are good he'll be right back in the emergency room.

"The muscles in Villegas's arms are like a bas-relief when he grips the golf club," Karen Crouse noted last year in The Times. "His tight shirts set off his boxer's biceps." Indeed, Villegas cuts quite the swath: he belly-flops onto the green to size up a putt, like a stalking lioness. He has posed nude for ESPN The Magazine. It's hard to keep up with Lawrence Weschler. The celebrated author of over a dozen books of literary nonfiction is, in this age of self-branding, defiantly unbrandable. An artist who draws money and tries to spend his drawings; the eccentric proprietor of Los Angeles's Museum of Jurassic Technology; the aftermath of the Yugoslav wars: this is Weschler's idea of a beat. (Fittingly, a journal he founded some years back was called "Omnivore.") He has devoted years of inquiry into political movements and the curious nature of artistic expression, most famously in his 1982 biography of the artist Robert Irwin, "Seeing Is Forgetting the Name of the Thing One Sees." His newest book, "Uncanny Valley: Adventures in the Narrative" (Counterpoint Press), collects pieces, previously published in Artforum, The New Yorker, Wired and elsewhere, about such disparate subjects as digital animators and human-rights monitors, but which are connected by the kind of distinct, inimitable narrative thread only Weschler can weave. On the eve of a discussion of the book at the Open Society Institute in New York, The Moment spoke to Weschler about Richard Avedon, war films and why he was so embarrassed to discover a drawing of him by David Hockney, pictured above, in the home of a Chicago art collector.

Serious shoppers can use their smartphone's camera for more than just snapping photos of the things they want to buy. With a barcode scanner app installed, the phone's camera can be used to scan an item's bar code (also known as the Universal Product Code). Once scanned, most apps present a list of places and prices the scanned item can be found, which makes comparison-shopping even easier on the go. RedLaser and PriceGrabber are two apps that offer iOS and Android versions, as does Pic2Shop, which also works on Windows Phone. Search your phone's app store for others.

Next up for the Big City Book Club is "Breakfast at Tiffany's," Truman Capote's classic 1958 novella of bittersweet Manhattan self-invention. In anticipation of our conversation, I've pulled some articles from The New York Times's archives that cover the complications of adapting the book for Hollywood (pdf) at a time, well in advance of "Pretty Woman,'' when depictions of prostitution weren't necessarily welcome onscreen, including Janet Maslin's review of "Fifth Avenue, 5 A.M.," Sam Wasson's recent book about the making of the film.

Most small-business owners never seek venture capital, writes Pamela Ryckman in an article we've just published, but for those who do, it can feel like a deal with the devil. Venture-backed companies are expected to grow quickly, and their boards can impose rigorous controls, audits and metrics. A founder who takes venture capital gets the opportunity to grow but also risks losing control of the company. One way entrepreneurs mitigate the tension in the relationship is to work with venture capitalists who may have more patience during the company-building process -- because they have been through it themselves.

In 1919, the Italian tourism industry, like much of the country, had been devastated by war. Foreign visitors to Italy numbered 180,000, down from 700,000 a decade earlier. To combat the problem, the government created a promotional agency, ENIT, which in the process of selling Italy abroad made some enduringly beautiful images, often under the visual spell of Futurism or Art Deco. The ads are newly collected in "Manifesti Posters: Traveling Around Italy Through Advertising 1895-1960" (Silvana Editoriale, $75).

Sixteen big masonry urns, from 1,000 to 1,500 pounds each, had been standing on the parapets of Atria West 86 - the former Franklin Towers Apartment Hotel at 333 West 86th Street - since 1927; through freeze and thaw, countless storms and the incessant stiff winds off the nearby Hudson River. ISTANBUL - I suspect that many Istanbul residents, even those caught in the tailgate eternity of the daily commute to work, don't spend much time worrying about the broad-leafed knapweed. Like the small meadow saffron, it is one of the 2,000 species of flora that thrive in the greater metropolitan area - that's 150 varieties more than exist in all of Britain, a landmass 50 times the size. Famous as the juncture between Asia and Europe, Istanbul is also the meeting point of the climate systems of the Black Sea and the Mediterranean, which means that a diverse plant life complements its rich history.

The Uttar Pradesh cabinet led by Chief Minster Mayawati on Tuesday approved the division of the state into four regions: Purvanchal (eastern region), Bundelkhand, Avadh Pradesh (central region) and Paschim Pradesh (western region). Ms. Mayawati announced that a resolution will be tabled in the winter session of the state Assembly, then forwarded to the central government for approval (The Hindu). This decision comes ahead of the state elections scheduled for early next year. An editorial in The Indian Express, Wednesday titled "Four State Solution," argues that if the division comes through, "four states would mean four capitals, with attention lavished on each. There will, hopefully, be a rejuvenation of the fabled old towns strewn across the current Uttar Pradesh," the author says.
