For an article being published in next month's issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine, researchers at the University of Sydney in Australia reviewed dozens of recent studies of stretching, hoping to determine whether the practice prevents people from getting sore after they exercise. The authors found 12 studies completed in the past 25 years that looked directly at that issue. Most were small and short-term. But each produced essentially the same result, the review authors write, showing that "stretching does not produce important reductions in muscle soreness in the days following exercise."

1:30 P.M. (HBO Signature) BOBBY FISCHER AGAINST THE WORLD (2011) Liz Garbus (''The Farm: Angola, USA'') profiles Fischer (1943-2008), the prickly individualist from Brooklyn who became a chess grandmaster and in 1972 turned his match with Boris Spassky (left above, with Fischer), his Soviet counterpart, into a global media event. She also documents Fischer's inner turmoil, which in later years prompted him to live in exile in Japan and Iceland and to give voice to a worldview rife with conspiracy theories and anti-Semitism, despite his Jewish background. ''What happened?,'' A. O. Scott asked in The New York Times. The film, he wrote, ''does not traffic in easy explanations or medical diagnoses, but it leaves the strong impression of a continuity between the oddness Fischer displayed in early interviews and the mania so jarringly evident toward the end. And it also tactfully but strongly posits a connection between the genius he brought to an infinitely complex game and the madness that defined his relationship to just about everything else.'' And yet, Mr. Scott added, ''if he had been spared fame, the world would have been denied a share of sublimity, and the kingdom of chess would never have found its wayward, dazzling, tragic prince.'' 11:45 A.M. (Comedy Central) RUN FATBOY RUN (2008) A huffing and puffing security guard (Simon Pegg, above) enters the same marathon as the rich American boyfriend (Hank Azaria) of his former fiancée (Thandie Newton), whom he left on their wedding day. He wants to prove to her and to their son that he can see a plan through. This kind of movie could be dismissed as ''a goofy lark,'' Matt Zoller Seitz said in The Times. ''But it's also a rare comedy that believes in its own message, and that could inspire the depressed and the demoralized to grit their teeth and keep running.''

McGEE--Margaret. Family and friends mourn the loss of our dear Peggy. She died peacefully at home on November 14th after a short battle with pancreatic cancer. Her daughter Dyllan and dear friend Blair were at her side. Peggy instilled in each of us the importance of being real. She cared deeply about the people in her life and let them know it through quiet and generous deeds. Leaving her apartment each day wearing a baseball cap and pants (never dresses) she touched the lives of many, including her doormen and shopkeepers in the neighborhood who were among her close friends. Despite her love of fancy sheets and linens, Peggy found joy in simple things. Coca-Cola, M&M's, Cheetos, a crossword puzzle and a good movie made her happy. A proud mother and grandmother, she was a stickler for proper grammar and manners. Young people were drawn to her because she was truly interested in them and never judgmental. She was an excellent listener and her wry sense of humor made every family gathering more fun. Peggy was as real and genuine as any person can be. She is survived by her daughter Dyllan, her son-in-law Mark Weigel, and her grandsons Max and Henry who are infused with her love. She is also survived by her brother and sister Harry and Sally Sweatt, her nieces and nephews, her beloved Alma, and all of her surrogate children she cared for so deeply. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Monday, November 21st at Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York City. In lieu of flowers, Peggy has asked that donations in her memory be made to the Meserve Kunhardt Foundation and the Mt. Kisco Child Care Center.

The union representing hundreds of school support workers who lost their jobs last month plans to sue New York City on Wednesday, claiming the layoffs were unnecessary and discriminatory because of their disproportionate impact on schools that serve poor students. The lawsuit is possibly the last weapon available to the union, District Council 37, in its effort to reverse the layoffs. Some 672 school aides, parent coordinators and other employees who were among the city's lowest paid lost their jobs on Oct. 7 in a move that union leaders have described as political payback for their refusal to let the city tap a health care fund run by labor groups to close its budget gap last spring.

LAUDER--Evelyn. The Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn, with great sorrow, the loss of Evelyn H. Lauder, beloved wife of our Chairman Emeritus Leonard A. Lauder and mother of William and Gary. Evelyn was a dynamic and gracious woman and a visionary philanthropist. She had a marvelous aesthetic sense, evident in everything she did from her work with Estee Lauder, her style as hostess, cook, and gardener to her great talent as a photographer. She faced her illness with courage and a great joy for life. She was an inspiration to those around her. She was warm, helpful in times of need, and there for her friends, family and even many who hardly knew her. So too are we--the Whitney Museum family--here for Leonard and his family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown, Director

THE NEW YORK TIMES has named Pete Wells, its Dining editor for the last five years and a veteran of Food & Wine and Details magazines, as its new chief restaurant critic, the newspaper announced Tuesday. Replacing Mr. Wells will be Susan Edgerley, the former metropolitan editor who was most recently the newspaper's top editor for career development. There has been a vacancy in the restaurant critic's chair since October, when Sam Sifton became national editor.

Before the final week of the 2010 regular season, I noted that Drew Brees and Tom Brady had thrown at least one touchdown pass in each of their team's first 15 games. Brady threw a pair of touchdown passes against Miami in the season finale last season, and has thrown at least one touchdown pass in every game this year, giving him 25 consecutive games with a touchdown pass. But Brees also kept his streak alive in Week 17 last season. In fact, after throwing for two touchdowns against the Falcons on Sunday, Brees has now thrown a touchdown pass in 37 consecutive regular-season games. Over a five-year period from 1956 to 1960, Johnny Unitas threw a touchdown pass in 47 consecutive games in which he played, a record that has yet to be broken. Unitas missed two games with injury during the streak -- and Brees missed one game during his streak when the Saints had already clinched the N.F.C's top seed and he had set a league record -- but missed games are not counted by the N.F.L. for purposes of such touchdown streaks.

BUTNER--Lawrence, born April 17, 1931 in Brooklyn, NY. Died November 14, 2011 after a lengthy illness. Loving husband of Eleanor (Schwartz) Butner for 57 years. Devoted father of David Butner, Robin (Butner) Weidy and Gary Weidy. Loving grandfather of Brian Weidy, Dora Butner and Sara Butner. Cherished brother of Sylvia (Butner) Katzmann, John Katzmann, Sydney Schwartz, Jeffrey and Miriam Zuckerman, and Barbara and Philip Pakula. Served as a Sergeant in the Marine Corps during the Korean War. Received his BBA from City College of New York and his JD from Brooklyn Law School with a license to practice law in the state of New York. After working for many years at Albert Frank Guenther Law, Inc., a major financial services advertising agency, he started his own agency, Lawrence Butner Advertising, Inc., in April 1979. Larry became a guru in direct marketing building his company into a leading boutique firm with blue chip clientele for over 20 years. Funeral service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY on Wednesday November 16th at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to "SK Lectureship Researchship Fund" at NYU Langone, Development office 1 Park Ave, 17th Fl, New York, NY 10016, would be appreciated.

POSNER--Alan Henry, 86, NYC, NY, beloved husband of Lillian (nee Palitz) Posner (predeceased), loving father of Marshall, Jeffery, Matthew and Claudia, grandfather of Bowen, Lily, Holly and PJ, and devoted companion of Margot Green, passed away November 12th, from lung cancer. Born in NYC July 3, 1925, graduated Horace Mann School and Yale University (1946), served in the Merchant Marine in WWII. He was a real estate investor in NYC, The president of board of 911 Park Avenue for 30 years, a trustee Knickerbocker Hospital, Board President the Hewitt School; Treasurer and Finance Committee member Yale Club; a director Interfaith Committee Jewish Community Relations Council; and a trustee of the Catholic Medical Center for over 22 years. Memorial Service, Wednesday November 16, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

On Tuesday, the day after one of the bleakest episodes in the history of the National Basketball Association -- when the players rejected the league's contract offer, disbanded their union and moved the season a step closer to being abandoned -- the Nets held a rally to promote their ''Brooklyn Experience'' outside Borough Hall. This was for a team still located in New Jersey and that will play in Downtown Brooklyn next year in an arena that is now half-built, in a league that may not operate for the foreseeable future.

An article on Monday about Newsweek magazine's ending its long tradition of dispatching reporters to cover presidential candidates for a year misidentified the buyer of the magazine. Sidney Harmon -- not the Daily Beast Web site -- bought it for $1 and debt assumption. (The magazine and the web site later merged.)

Broadway producers are planning a fall 2012 opening for ''Leap of Faith,'' a musical starring four-time Tony Award nominee Raul Esparza (''Company'') that was adapted from the 1992 Steve Martin film about an evangelical con man who is offered a chance at redemption. Thomas Viertel, one of the lead producers, said on Tuesday that closed-door developmental readings of the musical last week drew strong feedback from an invited audience, including potential investors, leading the producers to deem the show ready for Broadway. A 2010 production of ''Leap of Faith'' in Los Angeles drew mixed reviews from critics. Since then, Alan Menken and Glenn Slater, the show's composer and lyricist, wrote five new songs and the book underwent a ''substantial rewrite,'' including the loss of one character and the combination of some others, Mr. Viertel said. ''Our creative team has done great work in clarifying the story, making it more fun, and creating surprises in how the story is told,'' Mr. Viertel said, adding that the show is also 25 minutes shorter than it was in Los Angeles. He said the Broadway capitalization would be between $10 million and $15 million. No theater or casting was ready to be announced on Tuesday, though Mr. Esparza would be certain to star. The female lead, a single mother who becomes involved with the preacher, was played in Los Angeles by Brooke Shields, who is no longer involved; the role was played in the readings last week by Jessica Phillips, who is now featured as Marion in the Broadway musical ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert.''

Tim Tebow was 2 of 8 passing for 69 yards on Sunday. He has completed less than 50 percent of his passes in each of his games this year. He's averaging just 131.5 passing yards per game in his four starts, not counting an average of 24 yards lost because of sacks in each game. No one would argue that Tebow wasn't horrific against the Lions and just as ugly for the first 55 minutes against the Dolphins. But he's actually been a much more effective quarterback the past two weeks. What do I mean by effective?

A long rope of sweet yeast dough is tightly wrapped in a spiral around a wooden form, something like a rolling pin. It is then baked, slowly turning, often in a hearth. But unless you happen to be from a Transylvanian village, do not try this at home. Anna Kozma, who hails from Romania, said this special-occasion cake (called kurtoskalacs, or chimney cake) was just a provincial treat until after the fall of Communism, when entrepreneurs began opening shops in Romania, Hungary and elsewhere in Europe. Now, at her Chimney Cake store and cafe in Long Island City, Queens, Ms. Kozma is using a special oven to turn out what look like giant empty cannoli, tweaking the sugared surfaces with coconut, almonds and walnuts. They are best eaten fresh, by breaking off pieces. The hollow cakes are not meant to be filled, she said, but next summer, she plans to make smaller ones to stuff with ice cream, then freeze and slice for sandwiches.

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation grieves the passing of Evelyn Lauder, our visionary Founder and Chairman--and much-loved friend. Evelyn's passionate action and determination to improve the health of women and families led her to establish BCRF in 1993, and her single-minded dedication to finding a cure for breast cancer never wavered. She inspired us daily with her grace and elegance, and her leadership and friendship made each of us better and stronger. Her irrepressible sense of humor made her instantly approachable and loved by everyone who met her. She made us laugh! We cannot imagine a world without her, but her example propels us to carry on in her memory. Our hearts go out to her beloved husband, Leonard, her sons, William and Gary, of whom she was so very proud, and her entire family whom she loved so dearly. Myra Biblowit, President Jeanette S. Wagner, Vice President Deborah Krulewitch, Secretary Robert Bigler, Treasurer BCRF Board of Directors Larry Norton, MD, Scientific Director Executive Board of Scientific Advisors Clifford Hudis, MD, Scientific Advisory Committee Chair Scientific Advisory Committee Margaret Mastrianni, Deputy Director Advisory Board and Leaders Council

While Herman Cain's foreign policy stumbles have raised questions about his command of the facts, he says he would consult with military officials and other expert advisers to guide him through the thicket of world affairs. The last time the remote Australian city of Darwin played a significant role in American military planning was during the early days of World War II, when Gen. Douglas MacArthur used the port as the base for his campaign to reclaim the Pacific from the Japanese. So it was with considerable symbolism that President Obama arrived on Wednesday in Canberra, Australia's capital, for a trip that will include an announcement that the United States plans to use Darwin as a new center of operations in Asia as it seeks to reassert itself in the region and grapple with China's rise.

LAUDER--Evelyn. The Board and staff of the Elton John AIDS Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend Mrs. Evelyn Lauder. Together with her husband Leonard, Evelyn was a devoted benefactor and patron of the Foundation's work for many years. In fact, Evelyn and Leonard were honored with the Elton John AIDS Foundation's Enduring Vision Award for their dedicated support and service to our mission in November of 2009. Evelyn also founded and chaired the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, established the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and helped to develop the Pink Ribbon, which serves as the global symbol for breast health. GLASS--Robert. Robert Glass, 70, a longtime member of the newsroom staff of The New York Times, died on Aug. 26 at the Villa Marie Claire Hospice in Saddle River, NJ. Bob, as he preferred to be called, worked at The Times for 40 years, joining the paper in 1966. Long a member of the paper's photography lab, Bob was also a freelance photographer for the paper as well as for New York sports teams that included the Jets, the Rangers and the Cosmos. An astute student of American history, he was a longtime member of a society of Civil War historians. He also loved to fish and friends say that his favorite place to be was on a bonefish flat in Islamorada in the Florida Keys. Besides his love of history and fishing, he cherished his friends inside and outside the office; they, in turn, cherished their friendships with him. A memorial gathering for Bob will be held Friday, November 18 at 6pm at the Landmark Tavern, Eleventh Avenue and West 46th Street, Manhattan.

ALLAN--Marshall G.,successful real estate investor, dies at 51. Marshall G. Allan, a founder of real estate investment firm Somerset Partners LLC, died on November 11, 2011 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan surrounded by his family. The cause of death was complications from acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Through Somerset Partners, Mr. Allan played a key role in the acquisition, development and disposition of significant commercial properties and apartment complexes throughout the United States. Some of the landmark office buildings that Somerset Partners purchased include 1801 K Street in Washington, D.C. and 85 Tenth Avenue and 450 Park Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Allan spearheaded the firm's work on redeveloping 1801 K Street, a project that won many honors, including the Best Real Estate Deal award from the Washington Business Journal. Marshall Geoffrey Allan was born on July 9, 1960 and grew up in Short Hills, NJ. He graduated from Boston College. Prior to founding Somerset Partners, he worked at Eichner Properties and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. A onetime resident of the Hotel Chelsea, Mr. Allan married the love of his life, Karen LaGatta, and maintained residences in Manhattan and Dutchess County, NY. Mr. Allan and his wife enjoyed horseback riding, travelling, entertaining and collecting art. Mr. Allan served on the Board of Trustees of The Institute of Classical Architecture & Classical America and the Thomas Moran Trust. Mr. Allan is survived by his wife, Karen LaGatta; his mother, Arline Allan of Manhattan; his uncle, Richard Aronson of Bethlehem, PA; and his beloved dachshunds, Mitzi and Ollie. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in memory of Marshall G. Allan to the Bone Marrow Transplant Research Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

PRUSSIA--Leland Spencer. November 13, 2011. Leland S. Prussia was Chairman of the Board of BankAmerica Corporation and Bank of America, NT&SA from 1981 to 1987. He served as the bank's Chief Financial Officer from 1974 to 1979 and 1984 to 1986; from 1979 to 1981 he was Chief Executive Officer of the World Banking Division. He was also a director of Hughes Aircraft, Hughes Electronics, Nippon Credit Trust Company and the Crowley Maritime Corporation. Born in San Jose, California, he graduated from Stanford University and served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War, returning to Stanford to earn his M.A. in economics in 1956. A lifelong Democrat, he worked hard on behalf of many causes that he believed in. He was the first chairman of the California board of directors of The Nature Conservancy and a governor of its national organization; a director of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget in Washington, D.C.; a trustee of the Neighborhood Housing Services of America Foundation; a director of the Santa Fe Institute; and a director of the Saint Francis Foundation of the St. Francis Memorial Hospital of San Francisco. For 54 years he was married to the late Vivian Blom Prussia, whom he loved dearly, and he is survived by his three children and four grandchildren. Donations may be made to The Nature Conservancy, 201 Mission Street #

The National Theater of Britain's production of ''One Man, Two Guvnors,'' directed by Nicholas Hytner, is coming to Broadway in the spring. James Corden, who is reprising his role as the hapless Francis Henshall, has appeared on Broadway before in ''The History Boys'' and in a BBC television sitcom, ''Gavin and Stacey.'' The comedy, written by Richard Bean, is based on Carlo Goldoni's play ''Servant of Two Masters.'' Michael Billington in The Guardian called it ''one of the funniest productions in the National's history.'' The show, produced by Bob Boyett in collaboration with the National, is scheduled to open at the Music Box Theater on April 18.

The celebrated Chinese artist and dissident Ai Weiwei on Tuesday posted the equivalent of $1.3 million with Chinese tax authorities in an effort to contest accusations of tax fraud that he says are politically motivated. An outspoken critic of the Chinese government, Mr. Ai was detained without charge this year for nearly three months. After he was released, the authorities said his company, Fake Culture Ltd., which is registered in the name of his wife, Lu Qing, owed $2.4 million in back taxes and fines and gave him until Wednesday to pay. By putting up roughly half now as a guarantee, Mr. Ai can request an administrative review of the accusations. If he loses, he would have to pay the balance or could sue the tax offices.

2:13 p.m. | Updated Edson Buddle, Clint Dempsey and Jozy Altidore scored first-half goals as a surprisingly offense-minded United States national team beat Slovenia, 3-2, in a friendly in Ljubljana on Tuesday afternoon. The Americans, who had scored only two goals in a 1-4-1 start under their new coach Jurgen Klinsmann, came out in a more attacking, 4-4-2 formation against Slovenia. Buddle and Altidore started up front, with Dempsey tucked behind, and they took the game to Slovenia from the opening minute, when Fabian Johnson nearly scored on a rocketed shot from the top of the penalty area. Buddle opened the scoring in the ninth minute, pinging a 25-yard shot in off the left post after Altidore and Dempsey forced a turnover.

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The employees of the Estee Lauder Companies deeply mourn the passing of Evelyn H. Lauder, Senior Corporate Vice President and Head of Fragrance Development Worldwide. She died peacefully of complications from non-genetic ovarian cancer on November 12th at the age of 75 at her home in New York City, surrounded by her family. Mrs. Lauder was a beloved friend and colleague to the entire employee family. She was a risk-taker and trailblazer and always led with style. One of her greatest joys in life and business was applying the many aspects of her creativity and invaluable insights to new products and brands. A schoolteacher by training, Mrs. Lauder joined the Estee Lauder Companies in its infancy in 1959. Ever the teacher, Mrs. Lauder created ground-breaking education training programs--practices the Estee Lauder Companies uses to this day to maintain its place as a leader in global prestige beauty. She helped her much-loved mother-in-law, Mrs. Estee Lauder, develop and launch the Company's first men's fragrance, Aramis. And she was the driving force behind the idea for the brand Clinique, coming up with the brand's name and becoming its first Training Director. Her passion for beauty and nature, as well as her work on Aramis, helped frame what would become one of her most important imprints on the Company. In 1989, Mrs. Lauder began a successful 22-year career in fragrances after discovering her innate talent for recognizing distinct fragrance notes. It was an interest she shared with Mrs. Estee Lauder and one that stemmed from Mrs. Lauder's lifelong passion for flowers and gardening. Her rare ability to visualize unique fragrance combinations led to some of the Company's most successful global fragrances, including the best-selling Beautiful and Pleasures. In 1989, she assumed the role of Senior Corporate Vice President and Head of Fragrance Development Worldwide, a position she held and cherished until her death. In 1992, Mrs. Lauder began her mission to bring global awareness to breast cancer when she launched the Company's Breast Cancer Awareness (BCA) Campaign and co-created the Pink Ribbon, now known as the worldwide symbol of breast health. Through its brands, employees and fundraising initiatives with its retail partners, the BCA Campaign has raised more than $50 million for The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded by Mrs. Lauder in 1993 to provide crucial funds to the world's top medical and scientific researchers. Mrs. Lauder loved the Estee Lauder Companies and she loved its people, whom she considered part of her extended family. Those who had the opportunity to meet and work with her were touched by her kindness, warmth and deep, personal interest in them, whether they were behind the department store counter or a senior executive. She made a point to visit our counters in every country she visited and was sincerely interested in people's lives. She was known for her quick humor and was valued for her advice on almost any subject: love, marriage, finding the perfect lipstickeven on how to make her famous brisket. Mrs. Lauder's caring and pioneering spirit, business talent, fiery charm, extraordinary philanthropic drive, and enthusiastic love of life will be sorely missed by us all. She had an enormous impact on each one of us. She was a treasured role model to every employee of the Estee Lauder Companies, and our thoughts are with the Lauder family during this difficult time. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Evelyn Lauder Founder's Fund: www.bcrfcure.org or 60 East 56th Street, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10022.

LONDON - UBS has chosen Sergio P. Ermotti, who has run the Swiss bank on an interim basis since September, to become its permanent chief executive. Axel A. Weber, a former chief of the German central bank, will take over as chairman next year, a year earlier than planned, UBS said on Tuesday.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about additional suspected victims who have come forward since the arrest of the former Penn State defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky on sexual abuse charges misidentified the source of a quotation by Sandusky. The comment -- ''I enjoy being around children. I enjoy their enthusiasm. I just have a good time with them.'' -- was from a 1987 NBC News interview with Sandusky in which he joked that he started the Second Mile foundation, a charity for needy children, because he was a ''frustrated playground director.'' It was not from a telephone interview he gave Bob Costas on Monday night during NBC's ''Rock Center.'' (NBC included the 1987 quotation in a press release issued before the Costas interview, in which Sandusky said: ''I enjoy young people. I love to be around them. But, no, I'm not sexually attracted to young boys.'')

After spending much of the last decade directing films in the Harry Potter series, David Yates is ready to embark on a new film franchise: ''Dr. Who,'' Daily Variety reported. This British television series, which ran from 1963 to 1989 before beginning a second broadcast life in 2005, is one of the BBC's most popular exports. ''We're looking at writers now,'' Mr. Yates said. ''We're going to spend two to three years to get it right. It needs quite a radical transformation to take it into the bigger arena.'' The director, who is working with Jane Tranter, the head of BBC Worldwide Productions in Los Angeles, said he planned to ''start from scratch,'' rather than adapt an existing story line.

LAUDER--Evelyn H. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the passing of Evelyn Lauder, a visionary philanthropist and humanitarian. As founder and chairman of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Mrs. Lauder spearheaded the growth of what is today the largest national organization dedicated exclusively to funding exceptional research relating to the causes, treatment, and prevention of breast cancer. Since its establishment in 1993, BCRF has provided breast cancer researchers around the world with crucial funds for their studies. Here at Rockefeller, BCRF has long supported breast cancer research in the laboratories of Paul Nurse and Titia de Lange. Evelyn Lauder also embraced a number of other programs at Rockefeller University, including the Women & Science initiative. In 2003, the University honored her with the Brooke Astor Award for Outstanding Contributions to the Advancement of Science. The award recognized Mrs. Lauder for her work as leader of BCRF, as well as for her many other philanthropic achievements, including the creation, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, of the first comprehensive breast and diagnostic center. Through her leadership, compassion, and generosity, Evelyn Lauder brought breast cancer to the forefront of public awareness and played an outstanding role in the global fight against the disease. We celebrate a life extraordinarily well lived, and we extend our deepest condolences to Leonard and the entire Lauder family. Russell Carson, Chairman Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Paul Nurse, President Emeritus Titia de Lange, Leon Hess Professor Women & Science Committee Members

An article on Saturday about the wide discretion colleges have in policing campus crimes overstated the action taken by two colleges to settle complaints stemming from the suicides of two freshman women who had accused athletes of sexual assault. (Dominican College did pay New York State a $20,000 settlement for underreporting campus crimes.)

BROOKS--Charles Benjamin "Ben" Jr. Beloved husband of Joan Jolliffe Brooks passed away peacefully in their home in Cresskill, New Jersey on November 15, 2011. Ben was born in 1924 in Haverstraw, New York to C. Benjamin Brooks, Sr. and Ann Gommersall Brooks. He was elder brother to the late Paul Wallace Brooks. He is survived by his loving wife of 60 years, Joan Jolliffe Brooks, his three daughters, Mary Brooks Puckett of Edgewater, New Jersey and East Hampton, New York, Ann (Thomas) Brooks Martin of Corvallis, Montana, Joan (Alex) Brooks Emerson of Chattanooga, Tennessee and grandchildren, James Clay Crumbliss, Jr. And Brooke Crumbliss McCants. Ben received his BA in 1948 from Hamilton College in Clinton, New York and his MBA with Distinction from the Wharton School of Business in 1949. He served as a Lieutenant in the Army Air Forces from 1943 to 1946. Ben retired in 1989 as President of Clairol, Inc. and a VP of Bristol Myers Squibb Co. in New York, New York. Ben served as a Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Wharton Club of New York City, Treasurer and Member of the Board of Trustees of the Dwight Englewood School and the Treasurer and Member of the Board of Trustees of the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood, NJ. Ben served two terms as President of the Knickerbocker Country Club of Tenafly, NJ. At the time of his passing, Ben was a long time member of the University Club of New York, New York, The Knickerbocker Country Club of Tenafly, The Pine Tree Golf Club in Boynton Beach, Florida, and The Little Club in Gulfstream, Florida. Of all of the awards Ben received, it was the Cardinal Cushing Humanitarian award in 1988 that was closest to his heart. Visitation will be held at The Barrett Funeral Home in Tenafly on Thursday, November 17, 2011 from 4pm to 8pm. The Funeral Service will be held at The First Presbyterian Church of Englewood on Friday at 10:00am. Memorial donations may be sent to The Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York City 10018. For directions visit: www.barrettfuneralhome.net.

Falcons Coach Mike Smith was criticized for his adventuresome fourth-down decision in overtime against the Saints. After initially deciding to punt from his 29 on fourth-and-inches, he had Michael Turner run up the middle. He was stuffed, and the Saints won soon after with a field goal. Brian Burke of Advanced NFL Stats said Smith had played the percentages correctly based on Win Probability: ''The go-for-it option is worth, on net, a 0.47 W.P. That's better than the 0.42 W.P. of the punt option, at least according to league-average percentages. I'm certain the fact that Drew Brees and the rest of the Saints offense is not league-average helped sway Mike Smith's mental calculus.''

Dance organizations in New York City are entrepreneurial and innovative, despite having to scramble for money and rely on part-time, contract and volunteer labor, according to a 30-page report by Dance/NYC, the city's dance advocacy group, which will be released this week. The group drew on information about 127 nonprofit dance makers and organizations, culled from the statewide Cultural Data Project, which offers detailed data on finances, programs and employment in arts and culture. The report highlighted a strong start-up culture of dance. The smallest groups, with budgets of $25,000 to $99,000, had low numbers of full-time and part-time staff and relied on significant in-kind resources but still managed a high level of new creations. Nineteen percent of all premieres and 22 percent of all commissions came from companies with budgets in that range. Companies with budgets of more than $5 million were responsible for 15 percent of all premieres and 31.3 percent of all commissions.

Until September of 2010, Pam Boucher's life was small. Living in Brunswick, Me., a rural town of 21,000, she was dependent upon others to move. At the time, she used crutches or a walker to get around and seizures prevented her from driving. She'd get rides to medical appointments from a social service agency. Trips to buy groceries, or visit her husband in a nursing home, required the help of her adult sons or scheduling a social service staff member. A trip to the local Wal-Mart would cost $28 in taxi fees. Socializing outside her apartment was pretty much impossible. "I was very limited," she says.

"The New York dining scene is crazy. I mean, you can eat practically anything you want at any given hour," says James Lelonde, the chef and co-owner of San Francisco's acclaimed pop-up cafe SloMoSF. "New York chefs visit San Francisco to showcase their cooking all the time but not vice versa. So we're trying to offer something a little different."For three days, starting tomorrow, Lelonde and his SloMoSF partner Ryoji Kajikawa will team with Kelly Geary of Brooklyn's Sweet Deliverance to host a series of weekend dinners featuring their unique culinary spin. Equipped with diverse backgrounds, each chef brings something different to the table: Kajikawa's skills are rooted in traditional Japanese techniques; Lelonde is heavily influenced by fresh Californian cuisine, favoring unusual twists on classics; Geary is passionate about cooking with what's seasonal and local. Just imagine the possibilities when you combine the skill sets of these three spirited epicureans.

More than any other American designers, Charles and Ray Eames helped define the postwar Modernist aesthetic. Their furniture filled houses, offices and airport terminals. Their films, like "Powers of Ten," (video) made us think about big questions and small in new ways. Their "information overload" approach produced multiscreen installations, like "Glimpses of the USA," for the National Exhibition in Moscow in 1959 and their I.B.M. Pavilion at the 1964 World's Fair in New York, which foreshadowed the way information is presented on the Internet. And their work was presented with an artistry that made it look effortless. Of course, it wasn't.

Most foreigners who come to the south of France think of Marseille as an exit or entry point. It's convenient, only an hour's drive from Avignon and the hill towns of the Vaucluse and so many other lovely places in Provence. In Marseille's small airport, you buy a 1 euro cup of machine coffee and you get on a plane headed for Paris or home, your mind filled with one version of France: idyllic little towns with churches and castles, lush green valleys, fruit trees in serried ranks, Provençal linens, village markets, antiques, lace, espadrilles, vineyards, lavender, handcrafted pâtés, local wines, artisanal goat cheese.

"End of the Rainbow," a hit London drama-with-music about Judy Garland's final months, will play in New York this spring at the Belasco Theater, one of the last Broadway houses to announce its booking for the coming theater season. The show's producers announced on Thursday that its star, the British actress Tracie Bennett, who received critical praise for the West End production, will be joined on Broadway by Michael Cumpsty (the 2008 revival of "Sunday in the Park With George") as her gay pianist, Anthony; Tom Pelphrey (a daytime Emmy Award winner on "Guiding Light") as her young fiancé, Mickey; and Jay Russell in various other roles. Written by Peter Quilter and directed by Terry Johnson (a Tony Award winner in 2010 for "La Cage aux Folles"), "End of the Rainbow" will begin preview performances on March 19; the show will open on April 2 instead of the previously announced April 3.

When the conservation writer Jonathan Waterman decided to investigate the health of the Colorado River, he took it to extremes. In the spring of 2008, he packed up his supplies and set out on a 1,450-mile source-to-sea journey down the Colorado River.

In June, Oren Etzioni, the brains behind the airline price predictor site Farecast, brought forth Decide.com, a Web site that predicted the future prices of laptops, cameras and televisions. With a Wait or Buy signal, it gave you the probability that prices would change or that a new model was coming. There was one flaw with it. You need this information in the store as much as at home or in the office on your PC. The company promised a mobile app and it is now in the Apple App store.

In this week's podcast, we ask how you convert a popular 1,200-page travel guide into an interactive iPad app. As the latest edition of "1,000 Places to See Before You Die" arrives in stores this week, its author,  Patricia Schultz - along with David Link and Joe McCambley of the Wonderfactory digital design studio - discuss how they created the book's companion app.

Using a technology that sounds more NASA than Napa, TastingRoom.com "reformats" wines from their original retail packaging into 50- and 100-milliliter, single-serving bottles. Technicians re-pour some 1,000 varieties of wine inside an oxygen- and particle-free Plexiglas clean room, which is 40 feet long and protected from contamination by a pair of airlocks, similar to the entry and exit vestibules on a spacecraft. Tiny bottles mean consumers can sample high-quality individual wines without committing to buy a traditional 750-milliliter bottle of each one.

He says Citigroup is a good place to start. Read more »

Tim Tebow is breaking the game probability model. How can a quarterback lead his team to victory while going 2 for 8, for 69 total passing yards? It's widely accepted that passing efficiency is the main driver of team success, but what if an astounding 8.6 yards per attempt comes on only two completions?

Expect to be confronted with the unexpected at an open-air exhibition in Prague with the appropriate title of "Confrontations." Jaroslav Andel, the artistic director at DOX Center for Contemporary Art created the show, which takes inspiration from an older Czech art form: the pairing of contrasting images. The exhibition runs Nov. 18 to 26 on the plaza between the National and Nova Scena theaters.

We recently did a post on "the future of reading" about how books and reading habits are changing because of technology. What kinds of things do you read in an average day, and how do you read them? For instance, do you read novels you find at bookstores or libraries, or do you buy and read them on an e-reader? Do you read news or follow current events about a hobby or interest? If so, do you do so mostly on your computer or phone, or in print? Do you often follow links on social networks like Facebook or Twitter? How would you characterize the kinds of things you read that way?

The government published rules outlining the liability that nuclear equipment suppliers to India's government-operated power plants would face in the case of an accident. The rules are unlikely to completely satisfy concerns of the U.S. government, which signed a landmark civilian nuclear agreement with India in 2006, and American vendors like General Electric, which have lobbied for India to exempt suppliers from liability. The new rules place a 15 billion rupee ($300 million) cap and effectively limit liability to the first five years of operation. SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. The boards and staff of NARAL Pro-Choice New York and the National Institute for Reproductive Health profoundly mourn the loss of Irwin Schneiderman, lifelong champion of reproductive rights for all women. Irwin served on the organizations' boards for decades, and was a stalwart friend and ally in the battle for abortion rights and reproductive freedom. His commitment, leadership, warmth and courage will be deeply missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family and all those who were touched by his extraordinary legacy.

The Deal Professor column on the DealBook page on Wednesday, about financing decisions made by technology entrepreneurs, misstated the percentage of shares owned by the co-founders of the real estate site Zillow after its initial public offering. It was approximately 41 percent, not 75 percent.

Readers of The New York Times who thought they knew better than network executives just which shows would succeed and which would fail submitted their fantasy lineups by Oct. 1, predicting which shows would be canceled first in our TV Ratings Game. And who can argue with them? In the Dream Lineup contest, a first-tier cluster of 37 participants averaged a score of 3.7 when they forecast which of the 26 new network shows would succeed this fall, based on the first couple of months of ratings in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

BYRDIE BELL, model and actress. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW A MaxMara coat and pants. The pants have a zip in the back and are like fancy-lady sweat pants. A threadbare T-shirt I bought on eBay. Christian Louboutin heels. A YSL ring.
Smartphones can't eliminate all the pain of holiday shopping, but depending on what's on your list, they can make the job easier. Here are a few steps to a more pain-free shopping expedition.

A critically acclaimed one-man play about institutional abuse of children that created waves in Ireland when it was first produced in 2003 will be coming to New York. ''James X,'' written and performed by Gerard Mannix Flynn, will begin performances on Dec. 6 and open on Dec. 9 at 45 Bleecker Theater. The play presents the story of a man waiting to present testimony to a tribunal investigating the sexual and physical abuse of children. It will be directed by Gabriel Byrne, the actor, and produced by Mr. Byrne, the actor Liam Neeson and Culture Project, a New York-based performance organization whose work focuses on human rights issues.

The pizza, it turns out, is political. When Herman Cain declared his bid for the White House, Godfather's Pizza, the fast-food chain he once led, was known for its uncontroversial, utterly serviceable slice, available at more than 600 restaurants in more than 40 states.

Jeff Zimmerman, a Brooklyn artist who works in glass, spent more than six months creating the all-encompassing installation of bronze-and-glass vines currently on display at R Gallery in TriBeCa. ''The whole back of the gallery is a forest of vines you can walk through,'' said Zesty Meyers, an owner of the gallery. ''It's like being in an underworld.''
Jets (5-4) at Broncos (4-5), 8:30 p.m. Eastern Thursday Matchup to Watch: Tim Tebow vs. Jets' defense

What's old is new: 20th Century Fox said on Wednesday that it would use a modern twist on one of Hollywood's hoariest marketing tactics - the sneak preview - to help sell its coming comedic drama ''We Bought a Zoo.'' Read More on Media Decoder This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
ENGELBERG--Gertrude. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. "David J. Nathan Parnas"

The offer - for lollipops infected with chickenpox virus - appeared on Facebook last month and quickly circulated among parents who oppose vaccinating their children against diseases. ''I have PayPal and plenty of spit and suckers,'' the message read. ''It works too because that's how we got it! Our round was FedEx'd from Arizona. We've spread cooties to Cookeville, Knoxville and Louisiana!''

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. The Center for Reproductive Rights mourns the loss of Irwin Schneiderman, our longtime friend and husband of Board member Roberta Schneiderman. He was a passionate and tireless champion of women's reproductive rights. We will miss him greatly.
Q. What happens when you send someone e-mail in a font that his or her computer lacks? I have a font I like for my e-mail newsletter, but do my recipients need to have it as well?

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. The Board of Trustees of the Central Park Conservancy mourns the loss of Irwin Schneiderman, longtime supporter and friend of the Central Park Conservancy. Irwin served on the Conservancy Board since 2003 and chaired its Finance Committee since 2006. He was also active in the Executive, Audit and Operations Committees. His passion for the Park was unparalleled and his commitment to our success helped steer a course for the Conservancy that will sustain our organization's record of success for years to come. Our hearts go out to his wife, Roberta, also a dear friend of the Conservancy, and the entire Schneiderman family. We shared many fond memories with Irwin and will think of him often. He will be sorely missed. Thomas L. Kempner, Jr. Chairman, Board of Trustees Central Park Conservancy Douglas Blonsky, President Central Park Conservancy and Central Park Administrator

WEBDALE--Kenneth. The staff of Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourn the passing of Kenneth M. Webdale, President and CEO of R-C Healthcare Management, who died on November 13 from a sudden illness. Ken was a hospital reimbursement consultant to GNYHA for 20 years and a beloved figure. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends.

Writing on her blog, the British soul singer Adele joked with fans that she was practicing a mime show after undergoing surgery in Massachusetts to stanch the bleeding on a benign polyp on her vocal cords. ''I'm doing really well, on the mend, super happy, relaxed and very positive with it all,'' Adele wrote. ''The operation was a success and I'm just chilling out now until I get the all clear from my doctors.''

An article on Wednesday about a sports medicine operation known as hip impingement or bone shaving surgery misstated the surname of a patient in DeKalb, Ill., who said the operation relieved her hip pain. She is Melissa Stephens, not Domb.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Regis Philbin, who is retiring from the ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' show on Friday, misstated the year he became a host of ''The Morning Show'' in New York and misidentified his first co-host. It was in 1983, not in 1982, and the co-host was Cyndy Garvey not Ann Abernathy. (Ms. Abernathy followed Ms. Garvey as co-host.)

BLACK veils, usually reserved for religious ceremonies, goth brides and Daphne Guinness, are bringing some dramatic flair to street and cocktail dress. In Paris, at last month's round of fashion shows, the French designer Faustine Rome (above left) looked like a latter-day Marlene Dietrich from ''Shanghai Express,'' in a veiled cloche, ruffled cape (in lieu of feathers) and studded bangles (today's pearls?). Another young woman (top) wore an oversize black-cherry fascinator from the British milliner Piers Atkinson, whose quirky fruit headpieces have adorned Anna Dello Russo. Ms. Dello Russo (right, with Giovanna Battaglia) also wore a veiled cap, a Stephen Jones design fresh off the Jil Sander runway. Come spring, the cap, shown in several colors, should be street-style fodder. For the holidays, though, this veiled headband with a polka-dot bow from Maison Michel will make a sweet and mysterious accessory to wear with a black cocktail dress. Maison Michel headband, $270 at Kirna Zabête, 96 Greene Street, (212) 941-9656; kirnazabete.com.

This week, The New York Times introduces The Collection, a fashion app exclusively for the iPad that brings together in one spot all the fashion coverage offered by Thursday and Sunday Styles, T Magazine, The Moment and the International Herald Tribune. The Collection is a visual playground where you are encouraged to explore the latest in fashion news, from reviews by Cathy Horyn to Bill Cunningham's On the Street videos. You can also click on more than 150 designer galleries from the current season. The app is organized into five sections, with the option to view ''All'' or filter content according to a specific category: News, Trends, Street and Runway. The Collection is free to download from the iTunes store through Dec. 31.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Nov. 8 about a drive along a proposed Formula One racecourse in Weehawken and West New York, N.J., referred incorrectly to the need for lodging near the race circuit. The Park Avenue Hotel is no longer an option, having been demolished. The article also misstated part of the name of a road on the course and referred incorrectly at one point to another part of the course. A downhill stretch of the course is on Anthony M. DeFino Way, not ''Delfino,'' and the end of the course is at Pershing Road, not ''Street.''

A report in the Observatory column on Nov. 8 about research into the unusual vocal cords of lions and tigers described incorrectly the National Center for Voice and Speech, where some of the researchers were based. The center operates at the University of Utah and is a collaboration between that institution and the University of Iowa; it is not a University of Iowa program.
Q. What will Microsoft's ''end of support'' for Windows XP actually mean for users?

MARCUS--Irving Charles, 71, of Short Hills died at his residence on Monday, November 14, 2011. He was a man who always gave of himself without expecting anything in return. He was vibrant and passionate in all his endeavors- drawing cartoons, collecting contemporary art, playing tennis, and loving the company of his family and friends. Mr. Marcus is survived by his beloved wife Harriet (nee: Zimmerman), two daughters, Sarah Marcus Barton and Miriam Marcus Karas, his sister, Toby Scriba, and five grandchildren, William, Josie and Russell Barton and Jonathan and Alice Karas. Mr. Marcus was born and raised in Newark and lived most of his adult life in Short Hills. He was a member of the 1958 graduating class of Weequahic High School. He graduated from Williams College in 1962 and Harvard Law School in 1965. He was a senior partner at the law firm of Lasser, Hochman, LLC, of Roseland for over 40 years. Funeral services will be held 1:00pm at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, NJ 07078, on Thursday, November 17, 2011. Burial will follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Iselin. Memorial contributions can be made to Taub Institute at Columbia University Medical Center or Summer Search. Info. call: Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road in Livingston (800) 938-6372.

8 P.M. (ABC) REGIS PHILBIN: THE MORNING MAESTRO WITH KATIE COURIC On Friday Mr. Philbin (above with Ms. Couric) will end his long reign as a morning television host. In this special edition of ''20/20'' he talks with Ms. Couric about his career and his farewell, which he says ''will be from my heart, and I will really mean it.'' He vows not to cry. On Nov. 2 Ms. Couric presented Mr. Philbin, 80, with the Living Landmark Award from the New York Landmarks Conservancy, given to New Yorkers who have made extraordinary contributions to the city. 6 A.M. (HBO2) A PRESIDENT TO REMEMBER: IN THE COMPANY OF JOHN F. KENNEDY (2008) Robert Drew combines footage from four of his documentaries from the early 1960s (''Primary,'' ''Adventures on the New Frontier,'' ''Crisis: Behind a Presidential Commitment'' and ''Faces of November'') to create an overview of Kennedy's life, from his campaign as a young senator to his assassination in 1963. Using critical moments captured by Mr. Drew and his associates, Albert Maysles, D. A. Pennebaker, Richard Leacock, Hope Ryden and James Lipscomb, the film follows Kennedy as a fledgling candidate meeting with union workers and observes his wife, Jacqueline, delivering a stump speech. Other elements include election strategy discussions; dealings with the Soviet Union during the Cuban missile crisis; and Kennedy's work with his brother and attorney general, Robert F. Kennedy, during a showdown over integration with Gov. George Wallace of Alabama. The documentary, narrated by Alec Baldwin, ends with scenes of a grieving nation.

COWEN--Henry Charles, born New York City on May 17, 1920. He died in his sleep at his home in Commack, NY on November 12, 2011. Revered in the direct marketing industry and adored by his large family: his wife Diane Scott; his son David and Margaret Cowen, his daughter Jackie and Lou Toback, stepsons Joseph and MaryJo Scott, Will and Angie Scott; his grandchildren Shana and John Helsel, Leza and Lou Mendella, Darren and Amy Toback, Aaron Cowen, Will and Lauren Scott, Joseph and Caleb Scott; great grandchildren Lexi, Benny, and Angelo Mendella, Jacob and Emilly Helsel, Lena Toback and a player to be named. Service will be family only. Love and affection and fond memories are enough yet, if desired, donations to a favorite charity are fine.

8:26 p.m. | Updated Looking to extend its reach as a hub for entertainment and social networking, Google introduced a set of music features on Wednesday, including a download store to compete with iTunes. The service, Google Music, will sell individual tracks and full albums, letting customers store the songs on servers, on so-called cloud accounts. And through an integration with Google's nascent social network, Google+, the company will also let customers share music by offering friends one free listen to any bought track.

Nearly three weeks after $600 million in customer money went missing from MF Global, the search for the cash has been hampered by the bankrupt brokerage firm's sloppy record-keeping, an increasingly worrisome situation that has left regulators frustrated and customers in the lurch. The round-the-clock effort has consumed an alphabet soup of federal regulators and criminal investigators, with lawyers sleeping at open desks and each agency commandeering a different conference room at the firm's offices. But as authorities comb through some 38,000 customer accounts, they are growing more suspicious about what went wrong at MF Global, the commodities powerhouse once run by Jon S. Corzine, the former Democratic governor of New Jersey.

McGEE--Margaret. Family and friends mourn the loss of our dear Peggy. She died peacefully at home on November 14th after a short battle with pancreatic cancer. Her daughter Dyllan and dear friend Blair were at her side. Peggy instilled in each of us the importance of being real. She cared deeply about the people in her life and let them know it through quiet and generous deeds. Leaving her apartment each day wearing a baseball cap and pants (never dresses) she touched the lives of many, including her doormen and shopkeepers in the neighborhood who were among her close friends. Despite her love of fancy sheets and linens, Peggy found joy in simple things. Coca-Cola, M&M's, Cheetos, a crossword puzzle and a good movie made her happy. A proud mother and grandmother, she was a stickler for proper grammar and manners. Young people were drawn to her because she was truly interested in them and never judgmental. She was an excellent listener and her wry sense of humor made every family gathering more fun. Peggy was as real and genuine as any person can be. She is survived by her daughter Dyllan, her son-in-law Mark Weigel, and her grandsons Max and Henry who are infused with her love. She is also survived by her brother and sister Harry and Sally Sweatt, her nieces and nephews, her beloved Alma, and all of her surrogate children she cared for so deeply. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Monday, November 21st at Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York City. In lieu of flowers, Peggy has asked that donations in her memory be made to the Meserve Kunhardt Foundation and the Mt. Kisco Child Care Center.

Some ''South Park'' fans wondered if the end was near for the animated series earlier this year when Trey Parker and Matt Stone turned in an episode that centered on the cynicism and unhappiness of the main characters, complete with the playing of the Fleetwood Mac song ''Landslide.'' A metaphor, maybe? Maybe not. On Wednesday Comedy Central, the channel that has shown 15 seasons of ''South Park,'' said it had signed up Mr. Parker and Mr. Stone to write, direct and edit the series through 2016, thus reaching a 20th season. Their prior contract ran only through 2013. There had been at least a bit of anxiety at Comedy Central about whether the pair would extend it further, given their success this year with the Broadway musical ''The Book of Mormon.''
COBRIN--Benjamin. In our hearts forever. We love and miss you. Jill, Ed, Erica and David

A former trader at Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities is expected to plead guilty on Monday to conspiring to defraud firm customers beginning in the early 1970s, two decades earlier than Mr. Madoff claims to have started his Ponzi scheme. David L. Kugel, who joined the Madoff firm as a trader in 1970, is scheduled to enter his guilty plea in Federal District Court in Manhattan, according to a letter sent to Judge Laura Taylor Swain by federal prosecutors on Wednesday.

KRIEGER--Allyson M.,Senior Editorial Director at SiriusXM Radio, 40, died November 13 at home in New York City. She was the wife of Bryan Campbell, and the daughter of Joan Polzin, of Brookfield, CT, and the late Dr. Paul Krieger. She is survived by her grandmother, Ruth Krieger; her brother, Daniel Krieger; and her stepsister, Christy Doyle. A Memorial Service will be held on November 20 at 10am at Astor Center, 399 Lafayette St. (at East 4th St.) New York, NY 10003. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Ms. Krieger's memory at www.chosa.org and www.bideawee.org.

The rules posted - and now enforced - at Zuccotti Park seem straightforward enough. No camping. No sleeping bags. No lying down. No bikes or skateboards or in-line skates. No engaging in ''any other activities prohibited by law or statute.'' The rules are silent, though, on a few topics of interest to the Occupy Wall Street protesters. Chief among them is sleeping - as opposed to lying down. But sleeping is nevertheless forbidden in the park, at least overnight, according to the city, which provides backup security when necessary for the owner of the park, Brookfield Office Properties.
I don't really have much of a choice. I don't have the means to move out. HOLLIS ROMANELLI,

WILLNER--Albert. New York Medical College is saddened by the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Albert Willner, M.D. A 1943 graduate who served the Alumni Association for more than 40 years, and a trustee since 1996, Dr. Willner was one of the university's most ardent supporters. He and his late wife, Blanche, were longtime benefactors of the College and other civic and philanthropic organizations. Their generosity contributed to the advancement of science and medicine, to the quality of student life and to the beauty and functionality of campus buildings. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Karl P. Adler, M.D. Chief Executive Officer Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D. Provost and Dean, School of Medicine

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about commercial buildings with bicycle rooms described incorrectly a 2009 New York City law that requires commercial office buildings to allow cyclists to bring bicycles into their offices. Buildings with freight elevators must provide access for bicycles if tenants ask for it, but the buildings are not required to provide storage for bicycles.

LAUDER--Evelyn. The Board and staff of the Elton John AIDS Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend Mrs. Evelyn Lauder. Together with her husband Leonard, Evelyn was a devoted benefactor and patron of the Foundation's work for many years. In fact, Evelyn and Leonard were honored with the Elton John AIDS Foundation's Enduring Vision Award for their dedicated support and service to our mission in November of 2009. Evelyn also founded and chaired the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, established the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and helped to develop the Pink Ribbon, which serves as the global symbol for breast health. We extend our deepest condolences to Leonard and to their entire family. Evelyn leaves behind an extraordinary legacy of humanitarian philanthropy that is both humbling and awe inspiring and that will never be forgotten. Sir Elton John, Founder David Furnish, Chairman Scott Campbell, Executive Director

Because of a production error, a map on Saturday with an article about gas drilling on Pennsylvania's prized hunting grounds was distorted, causing its proportions to be skewed and creating several errors, including incorrect locations for Philadelphia and State Game Land 59. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/national.

ISABEL MARANT designed this limited-edition T-shirt for the Gap (Product) Red campaign. Heather-gray with bright splotches, the tee, a boyish V-neck like those in Ms. Marant's Étoile line, is available online Thursday and in stores Nov. 25, in time for World AIDS Day, with half the proceeds going to the Global Fund to fight AIDS in Africa. Gap (Product) Red T-shirt by Isabel Marant, $24.95 at gap.com.

IMBER--Doris "Dotty," 83, peacefully on November 15. Beloved wife of the late Manus "Sonny," devoted mother of the late Hilarie (Michael) and Philip, loving grandmother of Danielle and Matthew. Also, survived by dear companion Ed, and many loving nieces, nephews and longtime friends. Family will receive friends on Thursday and Saturday after 7pm and on Sunday after noon at the home of Michael Gold.

WILLNER--Albert, M.D.,was born to immigrant parents on May 20, 1918. He spent his life fulfilling their dreams, helping others, and putting his mind to building a better future for all. Dedicated to his work and family, he also lent his strength and vision to The Weizmann Institute of Science, serving as the President of The American Committee. He dedicated himself to NYU's Medical School and The Steinhardt School, and NY College, where he served on the Board of Trustees. His daughter, Dr. Jane Bloomgarden, his son-in-law, Dr. David Bloomgarden, and their sons, Dr. Noah and his wife Jennifer, Zachary and Joshua Bloomgarden, will miss him deeply, cherish their memories of him and his beloved wife Blanche, and continue to find inspiration in the life he lived so well. His son and daughter-in-law, Drs. Joseph and Judith Willner, his grandchildren, Daniel, Dr. Rachel Thompson, and Dr. Jon Willner, and his four great-grandchildren also survive him and were fortunate to have him in their lives. Services will be held Friday, November 18 at noon. Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

''Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Cabin Fever,'' the sixth book in Jeff Kinney's blockbuster series of illustrated chapter books for young readers, was published on Tuesday, with a jaw-dropping six million copies in its first print run. In the new book Greg Henley, the protagonist and antihero, is trapped inside with his dysfunctional family during a major snowstorm, which will surely drive him mad but will thrill legions of eager readers.

At the headquarters of Atria Senior Living, a nationwide operator of retirement and assisted-living homes, it must have seemed like a no-brainer. Sixteen big masonry urns, from 1,000 to 1,500 pounds each, had been standing on the parapets of Atria West 86 - the former Franklin Towers Apartment Hotel at 333 West 86th Street - since 1927; through freeze and thaw, countless storms and the incessant stiff winds off the nearby Hudson River. Heaven only knew what held them fast to their precarious ledges, but heaven help anyone in the path of a falling half-ton urn. ''The engineering firm we contracted with inspected the urns and recommended they be removed, due to serious structural issues,'' said Amy Schuster, Atria's director of public relations. ''As these urns continued to deteriorate, they could have caused severe injury or death had we not taken action.''

In the premiere video of an online series that had its debut on Wednesday, the composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim discussed a bit of history he was forced to forsake when writing the lyrics for ''West Side Story.'' ''I wanted to be the first person to use a four-letter word in a musical,'' Mr. Sondheim said in the first episode of ''Legends of Broadway,'' produced by Sony Masterworks. ''I thought, shock people, that's great.''

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. The Board of Trustees and staff of New York Public Radio mourn the loss of our passionate, beloved trustee, friend, and former chair Irwin Schneiderman. For more than 20 years, Irv led, inspired, and challenged us. He played a significant role in every step of our evolution. As chair of the Board from 1993 to 1996, he led the development of the strategy to buy WNYC-AM and WNYC-FM from the city. We will miss his common sense and his uncommon acuity, his courtly charm and his bracing candor, his warmth and wit, and his unrelenting dedication to New York Public Radio and the people who work here. We celebrate Irv's distinguished legal career and his profoundly influential patronage of the arts, especially of music, in New York City. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Roberta, his son Eric, his extended family, and his many, many friends. Herb Scannell, Chair Laura Walker, President/CEO New York Public Radio

LAUDER--Evelyn. The Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn, with great sorrow, the loss of Evelyn H. Lauder, beloved wife of our Chairman Emeritus Leonard A. Lauder and mother of William and Gary. Evelyn was a dynamic and gracious woman and a visionary philanthropist. She had a marvelous aesthetic sense, evident in everything she did from her work with Estee Lauder, her style as hostess, cook, and gardener to her great talent as a photographer. She faced her illness with courage and a great joy for life. She was an inspiration to those around her. She was warm, helpful in times of need, and there for her friends, family and even many who hardly knew her. So too are we--the Whitney Museum family--here for Leonard and his family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown, Director

LAUDER--Evelyn H. Our deepest thoughts are with Leonard, and the Lauder family. Evelyn was a truly great lady; a wonderful wife, mother, and grandmother, and through her dedicated leadership efforts for BCRF, she will remain an inspiration to us all. It was an honor, privilege, and joy to call her friend. Emily Landau & Candia Fisher

READY TO GO PUBLIC Angie's List, the Web site started by Angie Hicks, below, that compiles reviews of local services like home repair and catering, priced shares for its initial public offering at $13 on Wednesday, at the top end of its expected range. At that price, the company, which is selling 8.79 million shares, is set to raise $114.3 million. Its underwriters, led by Bank of America Merrill Lynch, have the option to sell an additional 1.3 million shares. EVELYN M. RUSLI

A new advertisement by Rick Perry takes a sharper tone than his previous ads, taking aim at President Obama's comment last weekend that American businesses had been ''a little bit lazy'' in taking for granted that new investment would want to come to the United States. The ad, playing on Iowa broadcast and cable channels and national cable, may be an effort to shift attention from Mr. Perry's recent stumbles by attacking the White House -- one issue that unites the major Republican presidential candidates. According to a person close to the Perry campaign, the ad is also a part of the Texas governor's nearly $1 million new national ad buy.

Jim Gaffigan, whose lack of sympathy with slow-moving pedestrians in Times Square -- so they use walkers? they're still in his way -- made enough of you laugh to make him the winner of The New York Times Comedy Challenge. Mr. Gaffigan was one of six comedians participating in the New York Comedy Festival last week selected by The Times to tell his best clean joke. He won in a landslide, with 32 percent of the vote, a tally bolstered by his 795,000 Twitter followers. Mr. Gaffigan, like many participants, exhorted his followers to support him in the online vote. ''Vote for @CheThinks,'' Mr. Gaffigan tweeted during the voting period, facetiously encouraging his minions to vote for Michael Che, a 28-year-old comedian from the Lower East Side. ''I would but I already voted for myself.''

The latest software for the Nano, Apple's midsize music player, changed the home screen interface from a square of four small icons that you flick through across multiple screens, to a sliding row of larger icons that move across the screen as you swipe them with your finger. But you can change back to the smaller icons grouped on the screen if you prefer the old layout. To ditch the big icons and revert to the smaller ones, tap the Settings icon on the Nano's home screen. On the Settings menu, tap General and then on Home Screen. Tap the button next to Small Icons to On. J. D. BIERSDORFER

11:08 p.m. | UpdatedJesmyn Ward won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for ''Salvage the Bones,'' a haunting tale of the struggles of a 15-year-old pregnant girl as a hurricane bears down on her fictional Gulf Coast town of Bois Sauvage, Miss. Accepting the award with a trembling voice, Ms. Ward said she had begun writing stories to honor her younger brother after his death, to do something with her life that would have meaning.

STANGER--Dr. Melvin ("Mel"), 76, of Brooklyn, New York, died at his home on November 16 of brain cancer. Born and raised on the Lower East Side, he was the youngest son of Joseph and Tillie Stanger. Deeply beloved by his wife Sheila, children Richard Salmen (Angela), Lisa (Gregory Colodner), Michael (Sandi), and Ilana (Jordan Stanger-Ross), and grandchildren Sophia, Arielle, Noah, Eva, Abigail, Caine, and Tillie. A graduate of NYU and the University of Bologna Medical School, he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army in Vietnam. He was, until recently, a Psychiatrist and Psychoanalyst in Brooklyn and Manhattan, an Associate Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at NYU, and a faculty member of the Psychoanalytic Institute where he was a training and supervising analyst. He loved his profession and was devoted to his practice. Fluent in Italian and Yiddish, he enjoyed watching sports, debating politics, and travelling. He was passionate about food and wine, especially when shared with friends and family. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to American Friends of Magen David Adom, Hebrew Free Burial Society (New York) and Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation.
A report in the Off the Menu column on Wednesday about the opening of the restaurant Amali in Manhattan misstated its phone number. It is (212) 339-8363.

The Internet, we hear all the time, ''levels the playing field'' for music. With the global and instantaneous reach of digital distribution, and social media's ability to quickly amplify any trend, you might expect that the top rungs of Billboard's sales charts would frequently be filled with unknown acts that have broken through with a catchy song. But that kind of success does not happen often. Almost all the top-selling artists are on major labels or big independents, which have the marketing budgets and influence with retailers and radio stations to push an act to No. 1.

DURING that tense moment between the now-traditional serving of chicken potpie and the announcement of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winners for 2011 on Monday night, while the designers of the 10 nominated labels sat anxiously in their seats, Diane Von Furstenberg walked over to the table where Joseph Altuzarra was sitting and pinched the designer on his cheek. She held that pinch for a good 30 seconds and asked him a question, speaking in French. ''She asked me if I went to pee,'' he said.

CHRISSIE MILLER of Sophomore, a line of sportswear basics with a bit of an edge, and Lindsey Thornburg, known for her wool blanket cloaks, have gone into business together: their new boutique, named 143, will open Friday at 143 Ludlow Street, (212) 780-0900. ''We had crushes on each other's lines,'' Ms. Thornburg said. On one side of the whitewashed and baby-blue shop are the Thornburg cloaks and bohemian layered-chiffon dresses, which run from $700 to $2,000; on the other side is Sophomore, designed with Madeleine von Froomer, with drawstring pants and floral dresses, $50 to $400. ''Our clothes are in the same world,'' Ms. Miller explained, ''at different price points.'' Shoppers will also find vintage pieces (think Stevie Nicks) from the cultish dealers Sisters of the Black Moon and Crystal Visions; House of Lavande jewelry; and skin care items from Amanda Lacey and Mitchell and Peach. Art and rock 'n' roll books will also be for sale, as will art, with works by Richard Kern, Dan Colen and Cass Bird.

When the architects of the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul flinched from the most effective solution - breaking up the banks so that none would be too big to drag down the financial system - they forced regulators of the derivatives market into a cumbersome and potentially dangerous workaround. Those regulators are feverishly making lots of important, arcane rulings that are being followed only by insiders. They are replacing an opaque system prone to failures with a new, huge Rube Goldberg-like system that may reduce global financial risk. Or it may not. Nobody knows, not least the regulators themselves.

An art review on Friday about the Tom Sachs show ''Work,'' at Sperone Westwater on the Lower East Side, misidentified the gallery floors where some works are situated. A series of resin-coated vessels based on Sèveres porcelain is on the second floor, not on the third. Tables and chairs made from cut-up and reassembled Ikea furniture are on the third floor, not on the fourth. (As the review correctly noted elsewhere, the show is on three floors of the gallery.)
LEE--Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Lee, associated with The New York Times from May 25, 1960 until retiring on June 1, 1980.

ALLAN--Marshall G.,successful real estate investor, dies at 51. Marshall G. Allan, a founder of real estate investment firm Somerset Partners LLC, died on November 11, 2011 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan surrounded by his family. The cause of death was complications from acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Through Somerset Partners, Mr. Allan played a key role in the acquisition, development and disposition of significant commercial properties and apartment complexes throughout the United States. Some of the landmark office buildings that Somerset Partners purchased include 1801 K Street in Washington, D.C. and 85 Tenth Avenue and 450 Park Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Allan spearheaded the firm's work on redeveloping 1801 K Street, a project that won many honors, including the Best Real Estate Deal award from the Washington Business Journal. Marshall Geoffrey Allan was born on July 9, 1960 and grew up in Short Hills, NJ. He graduated from Boston College. Prior to founding Somerset Partners, he worked at Eichner Properties and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. A onetime resident of the Hotel Chelsea, Mr. Allan married the love of his life, Karen LaGatta, and maintained residences in Manhattan and Dutchess County, NY. Mr. Allan and his wife enjoyed horseback riding, travelling, entertaining and collecting art. Mr. Allan served on the Board of Trustees of The Institute of Classical Architecture & Classical America and the Thomas Moran Trust. Mr. Allan is survived by his wife, Karen LaGatta; his mother, Arline Allan of Manhattan; his uncle, Richard Aronson of Bethlehem, PA; and his beloved dachshunds, Mitzi and Ollie. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in memory of Marshall G. Allan to the Bone Marrow Transplant Research Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

McKEON--John Thomas, was born to Diana Brady McKeon and Donald S. McKeon on September 6, 1955. He passed away on November 15, 2011, surrounded by his family. Loving husband to Cynthia Deviney McKeon and devoted father to four daughters: Meredith, Shannon, Kaitlyn, and Molly. Loving brother to his six siblings, their spouses, partner and fiance: Robert and Clare McKeon; Karen McKeon and Jim Bickford; Donald and Rebecca McKeon, Joseph and Caroline McKeon, George and Barbara McKeon, Matthew McKeon and Joseph Griffiths. John worked for the New York State Division of Corrections and Division of Parole for 33 years. He will live on in the hearts of all who knew and loved him. Visitation from 2-4 and 7-9pm on Saturday November 19, 2011 and Sunday from 2-6pm at Quigley Bros Funeral Home, 337 Hudson St. Cornwall-On-Hudson, NY 12520. Mass of Christian Burial will be 10am Monday November 21, 2011 at St. Thomas of Canterbury Church, 340 Hudson St., Cornwall-On-Hudson, NY. Burial to follow in Gate of Heaven Cemetery-Hawthorne NY.

Here are some of the problems with listening to music in your car (which is otherwise awesome): 1. Commercial radio is just awful. A limited number of songs played in endless repetition is bad enough - to then have to hear asinine ads for weight-loss and debt-reduction services on top of that makes you wish you had never been born. Zeke Emanuel, perhaps the least-known brother in the power trio that includes Rahm and Ari, has written a memoir of his childhood and adolescence as a member of the Emanuel family, his publisher said on Wednesday. ''Growing up Emanuel,'' to be published by Random House, will reveal stories of Mr. Emanuel's parents, Benjamin and Marsha Emanuel, and describe ''the free-wheeling, competitive, civic-minded, and over-achieving environment that his parents fostered,'' his publisher said in a statement. ''Emanuel casts new details on well-known episodes of his and his brothers' early lives and reveals never before told stories of their growing up in Chicago.'' No publication date was announced.
