Administrivial Non-Standard Puzzle Alert! The puzzle for tomorrow, Sunday, Nov. 20, has some unusual features. In the print version of this crossword, some squares (containing slashes) in the Across and Down answers do not actually cross. Write both parts of the answers in those squares. Then use the central Across answer to interpret them properly to spell an appropriate final word. In the online version of this puzzle, the slashes are replaced by circles, and the program will accept either one of the answers that goes in that square, but not both (because of electronic restrictions). Although this Across Lite version does work, it is recommended that solvers download and print out the PDF version of this puzzle. As a second-best alternative, print out this Across Lite version and solve on paper. Don't worry. Just give it a try; it will make much more sense as you go.

The winter travel edition of T sets out on a quest for adventure, starting in Utah's Canyonlands, where the model Heidi Mount takes a hike through her childhood stomping grounds. Next it's off to Ecuador for a look at how an ambitious new lodge hopes to save the cloud forest by opening it to tourism; then father and son Max and Alex Vadukul make a pilgrimage to the divine chaos of Kolkata, to meet the city's leading cultural figures. We also meet Bali's own Willy Wonkas and their new bamboo chocolate factory; the shadowy mistress of Ukraine's fashion set; and a former circus performer who now preaches the gospel of olive oil in Paris. Along the way, T touches down in the skiing utopia of Vermont's Mad River Glen; in the eternal French melting pot of Marseilles; and in Florida, for a tour of what's buzzing in the Sunshine State.

It's not often that pieces from a designer's collection end up in a gallery before they make it into stores, but such is the case for the designer Dries Van Noten. An exhibition that opened in Vienna yesterday, and that will later travel to Hong Kong, Tokyo and Paris, features a selection from Van Noten's spring 2012 collection alongside photographs by the London-born artist James Reeve that inspired them. Among the pieces are Reeve's photo of buildings in La Rouviere, a housing complex in Marseille, and the shirt that Van Noten applied it to. "I liked the mystery, the lights at night, the moment of wonder, where you're questioning what's happening on the other side of the windows," says Van Noten of the image. Reeve, too, considers the picture quite voyeuristic. "It's like 1,000 small colorful television screens all lined up in rows on the hillside," he says. "I have often seen people peering into the windows, trying to discover what kind of activity is going on inside." Other pieces on view with their corresponding photographs include Van Noten's bridge shift and "Circus, Circus" top. "I'm used to seeing my work as two-dimensional," Reeve says. "It was inspiring to see Dries translate it into dynamic forms -- the way the ruffle skirts seem to almost play with the lights as they move, the colored crystals that he sewed into the windows of La Rouviere. I thought that was a really beautiful idea."

Bones are life's records. The forces of a lifetime - diet, accidents, age - are inscribed upon them. Forensics experts use bones to interpret these stories, or so-called osteobiographies, which can identify a person's identity and cause of death.

In a sea of bespoke everything, from suits to shoes, it is surprising that bespoke glasses are hard to come by. Cutler and Gross just introduced what it says is the first bespoke frame service in the world, at its chic flagship store in Knightsbridge, London. Frames fanciers can make a selection from more than 4,000 styles, dating from 1969 to present, in the store’s top-floor mirrored atelier. Frames can be made in the exact color to match a suit or dress, or even feature vintage lace. If the “perfect” frames are hard to find, you can design your own shape. All of the glasses are handmade in Italy and take a minimum of six weeks to make, so order now for the holidays. The kicker? Your name, or your beloved’s if you so choose, laser-inscribed on to the inside temple. Madonna, Kate Moss and Claudia Schiffer are fans.Bespoke service starts at $950. 16 Knightsbridge Green, London; 011-44-207-581-2250; cutlerandgross.com.

As the sexual-abuse case at Penn State continues to unfold, much of the unfolding means looking back. Above all, there are the law-enforcement and institutional investigations into what happened over the last dozen-plus years. Then there's the journalistic impulse to cast a now-darker eye over past events, both small and innocent as well as large and iniquitous. In that first category, some of those lesser moments were themselves journalistic ones. There's Jack McCallum's 1999 Sports Illustrated profile of Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach accused of molesting several young boys, which McCallum returned to last week on SI.com. LOS ANGELES -- Back in the day, 1968 to be exact, a Dodge Coronet was stripped down, offered with a Hemi, renamed the Super Bee and rolled out as part of the Scat Pack, Dodge's exclusive coterie of high-performance cars. In 1971, the Charger inherited the Super Bee name. In either configuration, the Bee distinction was a hit with muscle-car enthusiasts, who could enlist the limited-edition cars as commuters or as fierce drag-strip competitors.

During his final appearance on "Live With Regis and Kelly" Friday morning, Regis Philbin managed to stay in character, Bill Carter writes from the studio on the Upper West Side, which was filled with celebrities and friends of Mr. Philbin's. Even as his producer, Michael Gelman, and his co-host, Kelly Ripa, fought back tears, Mr. Philbin looked for laughs. After Robert A. Iger, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, announced that ABC was installing a plaque in Mr. Philbin's honor on the facade of the studio building, Mr. Philbin said with mock complaint: "I got a plaque." And then: "How about a star in front of the place too." Read more at ArtsBeat »

With the opening two months ago of the National September 11 Memorial, the black-white-and-blue "9/11 Memorial" trademark has turned up just about everywhere in Lower Manhattan, even on subway signs that have never before been branded with the logo of a private corporation.

How much time should a high school student devote to sex education? In four years of school, a student in a district on a semester schedule might take a total of 48 classes, with more than half going to core subjects and some smaller number of electives: language, music, art, theater  (more in a school that offers more than six classroom periods daily). Starting in January, New York City public high school students will spend at least one of those semesters in a mandatory sex education class (as will middle schoolers). The sex ed can take place in (or take the place of) existing health education classes or be added to the curriculum, and what is taught and how is left to the discretion of the schools.

It is Day 3 at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne Golf Club in Australia, with the United States team holding a 7-5 lead over the International team. Today's action will feature two sessions -- five morning foursomes and five fourball matches in the afternoon. Steve Stricker and Nick Watney of the United States team and K.T. Kim and Y.E. Yang of the International team will sit out the morning's matches, but must play in the afternoon session. Below are the pairings for the morning session. Notably, Tiger Woods is in match against Adam Scott and former caddie Steve Williams for the second time in the event. (The captains, Fred Couples and Greg Norman, will announce the pairings for the afternoon session later today.)

The Food and Drug Administration announced Friday that it was revoking its approval of the drug Avastin for breast cancer after concluding that it "has not been shown to be safe and effective for that use." Avastin, made by the pharmaceutical company Roche, will remain an approved treatment for certain types of colon, lung, kidney and brain cancer, the F.D.A. commissioner, Margaret A. Hamburg, announced. Some women who say the drug has been keeping them alive had pleaded desperately for the approval to be retained. Read the article by Andrew Pollack.

Moving to protect a lucrative monopoly against impending competition, Amgen has reached an agreement that will preserve its status as the main supplier of anemia drugs to one of the nation's two large kidney dialysis chains. The dialysis chain, DaVita, agreed that Amgen's drug, Epogen, will account for at least 90 percent of its purchases of that type of anemia drug through the end of 2018. DaVita will get discounts and rebates on the drug, Amgen said in a regulatory filing Friday morning. Read the article by Andrew Pollack.

It was a misty May morning near Moab, Utah, and I was marveling at a rock: Fisher Towers, to be exact, an enormous hunk of rosy sandstone eroded over the centuries to resemble the fortress of a hermetic medieval wizard who happened to settle in southern Utah. I had pitched a tent in a campground ($12 a night) in the valley below with an outdoorsy friend. We slept next to the Colorado River. There was an outhouse, a Dumpster and a fire pit.

TEL AVIV - On Sept. 5th, nine military cadets of the Israel Defense Force officer training school, all Orthodox Jews, walked out of an official event marking operation Cast Lead. A group of soldier-singers had taken the stage, but when a woman started her solo, the nine cadets stormed out. Four of them refused to come back to the hall, despite being warned that they were breaching an order, and two days later were expelled from the school.

8:55 a.m. | Updated The business of politics is good business for TV, CBS's chief executive, Leslie Moonves, said Thursday during a question-and-answer session at a Hollywood Radio and Television Society luncheon at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, The Los Angeles Times reported. With its range of TV and radio stations, CBS could collect as much as $250 million of the estimated $2.4 billion that is expected to be generated by political campaigns across the country, The Times wrote. Such sums have only grown larger because of a 2010 Supreme Court ruling allowing unlimited campaign spending by corporations and unions.

Like pretty much everyone in Ecuador, Roque Sevilla drives fast. I hurtle with him from the capital of Quito down two and a half hours of gut-stirring switchbacks, losing elevation with every turn. The sugar-cane and cattle farmsteads tumbling past on either side dwindle steadily, while the surrounding forests gain in age and power.

MOSCOW - "Propaganda of homosexuality": the wording sounds almost quaint in English, like a panicky phrase out of the 1970s backlash to the early gay liberation movement in the United States. But in Russia, the phrase is current: This week lawmakers have been talking of banning "propaganda of homosexuality" - whatever the phrase may mean.

Father and son Max and Alex Vadukul traveled to Kolkata this summer, to photograph the city's thinkers, writers and artist. "The misunderstood city welcomed our curiosity. On a warm, sunny Saturday morning this month, about a hundred men and women gathered on Church Street in the heart of Bangalore. Dressed in white T-shirts, plastic gloves and masks that concealed their identity, they held brooms, mops and small buckets of paint. The group set out to clean the major roads of Bangalore, wielding placards that read "Kaam chalu, mooh bandh" (speak less, work more).

The writer Salman Rushdie emerged victorious in a spat with Facebook over his identity, in which the social network company required him to use his legal given first name, Ahmed. The conflict has given more attention to the whole question of identity online. Should people be allowed to be anonymous, or obscure their identities, online? Or should they be required to identify themselves? Something in between?

COWEN--Henry Charles, born New York City on May 17, 1920. He died in his sleep at his home in Commack, NY on November 12, 2011. Revered in the direct marketing industry and adored by his large family: his wife Diane Scott; his son David and Margaret Cowen, his daughter Jackie and Lou Toback, stepsons Joseph and MaryJo Scott, Will and Angie Scott; his grandchildren Shana and John Helsel, Leza and Lou Mendella, Darren and Amy Toback, Aaron Cowen, Will and Lauren Scott, Joseph and Caleb Scott; great grandchildren Lexi, Benny, and Angelo Mendella, Jacob and Emilly Helsel, Lena Toback and a player to be named. Service will be family only. Love and affection and fond memories are enough yet, if desired, donations to a favorite charity are fine.

Les Daniels, one of the earliest historians of comic books -- from the launching (off the doomed planet Krypton) of Superman in 1938 through the countercultural comix movement of the '60s -- and an author of horror novels, died on Nov. 5 at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 68. The cause was a heart attack, said Diane Manning, his sister and only immediate survivor.

An article in some copies on Wednesday about a plan by the New York State Board of Regents to require the state to provide illegal immigrants with the same types of scholarships and tuition assistance offered to other students gave an incorrect estimate for the number of illegal immigrants attending public schools statewide. It is 120,000 -- not 345,000, which is the estimated number of children statewide whose parents are illegal immigrants.

OGULNICK--Ruth H.,99. Beloved grandmother of Sandra, Howard, Sharyl and Lori, Loving great-grandmother of Lauren, Mitch, Juliette, Matthew, Dillon, Erika and Alec. Adored wife of the late Eli. Cherished mother of the late Marion and Judy. Services Sunday, 10am, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ, 201843-9090. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to "Everybody Wins!" for the benefit of the Ruth H. Ogulnick Literacy Champions Fund, Attn: Celia Arnold, 50 Broad Street, Suite 1720, New York, NY 10004.

After five years in TriBeCa, the annual Romanian Film Festival in New York is moving uptown. In a sign of expanding interest in the innovative cinema coming out of the Eastern European country, this year's edition, which is scheduled to begin on Nov. 30 and conclude on Dec. 6, will be held at Lincoln Center, where the Film Society of Lincoln Center has signed on as a partner. The festival is also broadening in its scope. In addition to New York or American premieres of several new Romanian films, including ''Morgen,'' the country's entry for the best foreign-language film Academy Award, the event will feature retrospectives devoted to the work of two leading figures: the director, writer and actor Liviu Ciulei, whose career began in the early years of harsh Communist rule and who died last month at the age of 88; and Radu Muntean, one of the most prolific exponents of the so-called Romanian New Wave of the last decade.

An article on Wednesday about the Salvation Army's experiment with accepting donations by mobile payments misstated the year the organization was established. It was 1865 -- not 1852, which is the year its founder, William Booth, started preaching.

While House Republican and Democratic leaders are finding it difficult to agree on spending cuts, they are coming together next month for Capitol Hill's first-ever Facebook Hackathon. The goal is to find new ways to use the social network to make information about the legislative process more transparent and to help members of the public more easily engage with lawmakers. Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the Republican leader, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer, a Democrat from Maryland and his party's whip, are co-hosting the event, scheduled for Dec. 7 at the Capitol, which will include Facebook engineers, independent software developers, advocates for the open data movement and members of Congress.

Though no clamor for a comeback had been heard, ''The Munsters'' may be returning to television. NBC has ordered a pilot of a new version of the 1960s sitcom in a re-conceived format: an hourlong drama. Specifically, NBC said Wednesday night that the new version would be a ''visually spectacular one-hour drama.''

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. J Street mourns the loss of our founding supporter Irwin Schneiderman. We send heartfelt condolences to his family and salute his commitment to Israel and the cause of Middle East peace.

An article on Thursday about the arrest of a man suspected of shooting at the White House misidentified, at one point, the police agency that arrested him in Pennsylvania. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, it was the Pennsylvania State Police, not federal authorities. (The state police were acting on information from Secret Service agents.) And a map with the article mislabeled, in some editions, the state in the upper left corner of the contiguous United States that is considered solidly Democratic. It is Washington, not Oregon. (Though the outcome of some races may be in doubt, one thing is for certain: Oregon will always be solidly under Washington.)

SHAKE-UP Zynga, which is headed for an initial public offering in the next few months, is reorganizing its upper ranks. Owen Van Natta, below, the company's chief business officer, has resigned but will remain a board member, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday. Brad Feld, a director of the Foundry Group, a venture capital firm, has stepped down from the board. Sunil Paul, a partner at Spring Ventures and the former chief executive of FreeLoader, will succeed Mr. Feld. EVELYN M. RUSLI

An article on Nov. 6 about political uncertainty in Greece as George Papandreou, then the prime minister, struggled to form a unity government amid financial turmoil misstated, in some copies, the size of the next installment of foreign aid the country is hoping to secure. It is $11 billion, not $11 million.

Several years ago, Paul Painter, a professor of polymer science at Pennsylvania State University, saw a news report about the deaths of hundreds of ducks that landed on a tailings pond near an oil sands mine in the Canadian province of Alberta. The ducks had become coated with residual petroleum floating on the pond, which was filled with wastewater from the process used to extract oil from the strip-mined sands. ''It wasn't that I'm a rabid environmentalist,'' Dr. Painter said recently. ''It just occurred to me that we were working with something that might prove useful.''

The Tony Award-winning actors Bernadette Peters and Martin Short will meet with a team of theater producers this month to discuss a possible Broadway revival of ''I Do! I Do!,'' the 1966 Tom Jones-Harvey Schmidt musical about the trials and tribulations of a married couple over a 50-year period, according to theater executives familiar with the discussions. The meeting is not a developmental reading or industry workshop for potential investors - steps that would indicate a revival is likely - but rather a preliminary meeting to talk about the script and bat around ideas for the characters, Agnes and Michael Snow. The executives spoke on condition of anonymity because the producers considering the project had not authorized its disclosure.

Mississippi voters just approved a new law requiring voters to show photo identification at the polls. But that law will not go into effect immediately, thanks to the Voting Rights Act. Instead Mississippi will get in line behind Texas and South Carolina as the Department of Justice examines each state's voter ID laws, in a process known as ''preclearance.'' The Justice Department will allow each law to go into effect only if the state can show its law will not have a racially discriminatory purpose or effect. Such proof may be hard to come by: a recent study by The Associated Press found that African-American voters in South Carolina would be much harder hit by that state's ID law than white voters because they often don't have the right kind of identification. But this important preclearance procedure may not be around much longer. Before the next election season rolls around, the Supreme Court could well strike down this provision of the law as an unconstitutional infringement on states' rights, leaving minority voters essentially unprotected from efforts to diminish their voting power. Congress needs to act before then to protect voting rights everywhere.

LONDON - The British government agreed on Thursday to sell Northern Rock, the lender it nationalized more than three years ago, to Virgin Money, which is controlled by Richard Branson, in a deal that represents a loss for Britain's taxpayers. The government is to receive 747 million ($1.18 billion) in cash, and the total proceeds could reach as much as 1.03 billion if certain conditions are met. That compares with the 1.4 billion the government injected into the retail bank in 2010 after it split Northern Rock into two.

The Vital Statistics column on Tuesday, about trends in sexual activity among young people, misstated the proportion of unmarried teenagers in a 2002 study who reported having had intercourse at least once. In that study, 45.5 percent of girls and 45.7 percent of boys had had sex by age 19 -- not 51.1 percent of girls and 60.4 percent of boys. (The higher figures are from a 1988 report.)

WILLNER--Dr. Albert. The leadership, staff, and entire community of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our esteemed President Emeritus Dr. Albert Willner. Al was an indefatigable advocate for the Weizmann Institute whose sincere warmth and visionary leadership inspired supporters across the country. He served as a member of the Board of Directors and the Weizmann Institute International Board. In addition, Al was Chairman of the American Committee Palm Beach Region. His meaningful gifts to the Weizmann Institute along with his late wife Blanche include the Willner Family Center for Vascular Biology and scholarships for high school students and graduate students. He and his family also established the Willner Family Leadership Institute, a major philanthropic initiative at the Institute. The Willner residences on campus are named in their honor. Al's vision, compassion, and insight will be missed enormously by the Weizmann Institute family. We extend our deepest heartfelt condolences to son Dr. Joseph Willner and his wife Dr. Judith Willner, and daughter Dr. Jane Bloomgarden and her husband Dr. David Bloomgarden, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. & C.E.O. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

The New York sculptor Tom Otterness may be known for his whimsical and warm sculptures of animals and cartoon-like characters, but in San Francisco, a lurid act from his past has come back to haunt him. Earlier this year the sculptor was commissioned to do two projects for the city worth more than $1.4 million. One was to install 59 bronze sculptures in the Moscone Station of the proposed Central Subway project, for which he was to be paid $750,000; the other was to create a sculpture for the new San Francisco General Hospital, for $700,000.
POPOLOW--Lois, 74. Survived by her loving husband Robert, children, Barbara and Douglas, and five grandchildren. Donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

Survived by Rhoda Gordon and daughters. Devoted father to Kenneth, Jeffrey and Andrew (Karen). Adored grandfather to Katie Mae. Loving brother to Martin and Joel (Barbara). Wonderful uncle and cousin to many. You will be missed.

Updated, 9:25 p.m.|The former state attorney general hired last month by City Comptroller John C. Liu's campaign to conduct an internal review of its fund-raising practices resigned on Thursday, a day after a federal inquiry focused on Mr. Liu led to criminal charges against one of his fund-raisers. Mr. Liu, first on Monday through the campaign's lawyer and then on Wednesday through the criminal defense lawyer he hired to represent him in the federal investigation, had requested that the former attorney general, Robert Abrams, suspend his inquiry, according to Mr. Abrams's resignation letter. A copy of the letter, dated Thursday, was made available to The New York Times.

FELTHEIMER--Myron, 94, Our beloved husband, father, grandfather died peacefully at home in Roslyn, NY on November 9. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Marcia, his children Jon (Laurie), Jill (Ed Fisher) and Benn (Amy) and seven grandchildren. A man of extraordinary decency, selflessness and humor, he inspired all who knew him. Born in Brooklyn, March 5, 1917, his first career as a theater manager was interrupted by WWII. After his service (305 signal corp.), he began a career in financial services. He worked for First Investors Corporation for 45 years, touching the lives of countless people. He retired in 2000 as Executive Vice-President. He was our anchor, a model of how to live. We aspire to be more like Myron.

COLONIE, N.Y. - Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was received as a hero on Thursday at a meeting of the state's Democratic Party, with elected officials crediting him for several critical victories in local government elections last week, and the governor highlighting those elections as a referendum on his first 10 months in office. But Mr. Cuomo's appearance before his party's leadership also had signs of continuing tension between the popular governor and the liberal wing of the Democratic Party. After he departed, some party members sought unsuccessfully to pass resolutions that would have rebuked parts of Mr. Cuomo's handling of economic and environmental issues.

A report in the Gadgetwise column on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about MOG, a subscription online music service, misidentified the group that sings ''No Parking on the Dance Floor.'' It is Midnight Star, not Atlantic Starr.

My column on Tuesday about the general reaction to the Penn State sexual abuse scandal incorrectly described the nationality of the gang members that kidnapped Ilan Halimi. There were people from several countries in the gang. They were not just Moroccans.

GABRIEL--K. Georg, 83, died peacefully at home in Washington, D.C. Beloved husband of 50 years to Meg Gabriel; father of Robert Paul Gabriel (Megan Roberts Gabriel) and Margaret Wendy Gabriel (Alex Totino); grandfather of Margaret, Will, and Honor Gabriel; brother of Martin Gabriel of Halberstadt, Germany; and Peter Gabriel of Ashfield, MA. Georg received his MBA from the Harvard Business School and a PhD from Harvard University. From 1967 to 1988, he held senior management positions at the World Bank, including Controller; Director of Programming and Budgeting; and VP Finance-International Finance Corporation. Georg managed the World Bank Pension Fund from 1972-1988. Georg also served on the Investment Committee of the Eugene and Agnes Meyer Foundation and on the boards of several mutual and investment funds. From 1988-2005, Georg was a Senior Advisor at Strategic Investment Partners, a Washington DC-based asset-management firm. Georg was a long-time member of the Metropolitan Club of Washington, D.C. Georg's graciousness, selflessness, humility, and class are among his many fine qualities that will be missed by so many whose lives he touched. Private burial will be held at St. John's Church, Lafayette Square, Washington, D.C. Memorial Service to follow next spring.

MANCHESTER, N.H. -- Has the usually gregarious Herman Cain become camera-shy and taciturn, at least when it comes to meeting with newspaper editorial boards? It might seem that way. On Thursday, Mr. Cain, back in this early voting state for the first time since early October, was scheduled to meet with The Union Leader of New Hampshire for a one-hour question-and-answer session that would be videotaped for the paper's Web site. But Thursday morning, before a stop at a local diner, the Cain campaign objected to the videotaping, then sought to reduce the interview to 20 minutes. From there, a series of misunderstandings seem to follow. According to the campaign, the paper, disappointed about the changes, decided not to follow through. But according to the paper, it was the Cain campaign that canceled.
SOCOLOV--Al. Stalwart. Just. Forever in our hearts. Trustees of the St. Mark's Historic Landmark Fund

Stung by a surprise burst into Parliament by protesters, Kuwait's ruler ordered tighter security in the building on Thursday and vowed that his oil-rich country, which has so far dodged the Arab Spring upheavals that have shaken the region, would not tolerate ''preplanned sabotage.'' The decree by Kuwait's emir, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Jaber al-Sabah, came hours after dozens of protesters, including some lawmakers, muscled their way into the Parliament building on Wednesday night, demanding the prime minister's resignation.

BERGER--Bertha, 99, passed away on November 7. Predeceased by her husband Harry, survived by her daughters Marilyn Levy, Potomac MD, Sondra Somin Huntington, NY, and son Ira Berger, Palm Harbor, FL. Bertha lived in Brooklyn prior to her retirement to Deerfield Beach and St. Petersburg. She was office manager at Cyfrati Diamonds in Manhattan. She will be greatly missed.

An article on Monday about Google's secret engineering lab erroneously attributed a distinction to Sebastian Thrun, a leader at the lab. Though Mr. Thrun developed a driverless car, he was not the first to do so. Others, including the German engineer Ernst Dickmanns, have done pioneering work in developing the robotic automobile.

When Sergio P. Ermotti entered the chandelier-drenched ballroom at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan for his first investor day at UBS as chief executive, he started choking on a piece of food, prompting a few attendees to joke that he may have bitten off more than he can chew in taking the top spot at the beleaguered Swiss bank. As he took to the stage, a more composed Mr. Ermotti outlined the much-anticipated turnaround strategy for the firm, which in recent months has weathered the European debt crisis, global market turmoil and a trading scandal that prompted the resignation of his predecessor and dented employee morale.

Harry Rosenblum spent a recent afternoon rolling out dough to make egg noodles at the Brooklyn Kitchen, a food emporium he owns in Williamsburg. His wooden rolling pin bathed in flour and egg, Mr. Rosenblum carefully wiped it clean and gently slid it into a cloth casing.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. We mourn with profound sadness the passing of Irv Schneiderman, beloved past President, Co-Chairman, Chairman and Board Member of New York City Opera. Through his visionary leadership and unwavering championship of the Company, Irv gave generously of his time, insights, and resources for nearly three decades. Together with his adored wife Roberta, Irv ranks among City Opera's most historically generous and thoughtful donors. He was much loved by all who were fortunate enough to know and work with him. We are comforted that Irv's legacy will endure through the impact of his altruism and his love of music, and we will miss him forever. We send our deepest condolences to Roberta, their son Eric, the entire Schneiderman family and Irv's many friends and colleagues. George Steel, General Manager and Artistic Director, and Charles R. Wall, Chairman, on behalf of New York City Opera and its Board of Directors.

GELLER--Monroe. Died peacefully on November 17, in his 95th year. He was the son of Andrew Geller, a pioneer of women's fashion footwear since the early 1920s, who founded the iconic family business bearing his name, in a factory on Lorimer Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. That edifice was a such a fixture in the neighborhood that it was memorialized in a New York Times article entitled "The Ladies of Lorimer Street". The younger Mr. Geller entered his father's business in 1936 and helped shape it in to one of the leading manufacturers of the classic high-heel "pump" after WW II. The company also manufactured women's handbags and had a flagship retail store in NYC on West 57th street which attracted multitudes of passers-by with it's innovative window displays. Under Mr. Geller's leadership, the company became among the first domestic manufacturers to market women's footwear under licenses from noted clothing designers Calvin Klein and Geoffrey Beene. In addition to the original Andrew Geller logo, Mr. Geller expanded the family business to include over six brands, multiple factories and over a dozen Andrew Geller retail stores in various parts of the country. Every major fashion department and specialty store carried the brand. When the industry gravitated overseas, Mr. Geller and his family made the company a leader in establishing manufacturing bases in Italy, Spain and Taiwan. Mr. Geller sold the family business to Russ Togs, a publicly traded clothing manufacturer, in 1968, but subsequently took the company private until it was again sold in a leveraged buyout in 1985. As an avid collector of modern art, Mr. Geller was a major contributor to the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis University and a generous supporter of the Anti-Defamation League and World Jewish Congress. Mr. Geller's wife of 60 years, Edith, predeceased him. He is survived by his loving children, Jane, Elizabeth and Thomas, eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.
ALPERN--Jerome, 95, on November 16, 2011. Survived by his dear wife of 70 years, Libbie (Roginsky), son David, daughter-in-law Sylvia. Loved all the music of life.

HERMAN--Joan. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Joan Herman. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Richard G. Hunegs, President Mervyn Manning, Secretary

PEARLMAN--Gilbert Dale, 82 passed away November 9th in Beverly Hills, CA after a long illness but never having lost fondness for his wife, a good book, and a dry martini. Born December 12, 1928 in Iowa, Gil had a diverse career from being co-founder of the Theater Department of the HB Acting Studios, to working with Walt Disney and Stanley Kubrick, to owning his own AD Agency, being a producer of the 1972 Motion Picture "Tomorrow," and writing alongside his brother in-law Gene Wilder the televisions film series "Murder In A Small Town." Gil is survived by his most beloved wife of 60 years Corinne, two sons Steven Pearlman of Merced, California and Jordan Walker-Pearlman of New York City and Los Angeles, a granddaughter Devorah, and two generations of nieces and nephews.

A vivid purple and pink sunset dissolved into night while bright lamps blazed inside a vast tent as the Boston Symphony Orchestra began playing Beethoven's ''Leonore'' Overture No. 3 before 5,000 people. The date was Aug. 5, 1937, and it was the orchestra's first concert at an estate known as Tanglewood. Next July 6, 75 years later, the Boston Symphony will reproduce the program (which included Beethoven's symphonies No. 5 and 6) during the latest version of the Tanglewood Music Festival, the orchestra said on Thursday. The festival runs from June 22 to Sept. 2. In announcing the program for its anniversary season the orchestra said it would also reproduce an all-Wagner program from that 1937 summer and introduce eight new commissions. Composers of the new works include Andre Previn, John Harbison, Gunther Schuller and Michael Gandolfi.. A gala concert to celebrate the 80th birthday of the conductor and film score composer John Williams will include appearances by Leonard Slatkin, Yo-Yo Ma and Jessye Norman. The orchestra said it would provide a free digital stream of past performances each day of the concert at www.bso.org. Full programming will be available at www.tanglewood.org.

BUTLER--Benjamin, was dedicated to social justice and community change. Mr. Butler who died of a heart attack on Wednesday, November 9, was the CEO of Community Development Associates, Inc. (CDA), a national consulting practice dedicated to improving the quality of life for children and families. SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. Brooklyn College mourns the passing of Irwin Schneiderman '43, reported in The New York Times on November 17, who has served on the board of trustees for the Brooklyn College Foundation since 1983. A noted philanthropist and attorney who specialized in advising troubled corporations, Mr. Schneiderman was president of the board of trustees from 1990 to 1992. Born in Brooklyn on May 28, 1923, he served in the Navy shortly after graduating from college. Thanks to the G.I. Bill, after the war he attended the Harvard Law School, where he eventually established the Irwin Schneiderman Scholarship Fund specifically for pre-law Brooklyn College graduates. In 1993, Brooklyn College awarded him an honorary doctorate of humane letters at its commencement exercises. Mr. Schneiderman is remembered by his fellow trustees and the entire Brooklyn College community.

Is the Washington Research Group the Wall Street version of Joe Btfsplk, the ''L'il Abner'' comic-strip character who walked around with a dark cloud over his head and brought misfortune to everyone around him? Consider this: The government policy analysis group has had nine owners in its 37-year history. They include Drexel Burnham Lambert, the 1980s investment bank that collapsed amid scandal; the Stanford Financial Group, the firm run by the indicted financier R. Allen Stanford; and most recently, MF Global, the brokerage firm now in bankruptcy.

It may be the new, new thing in fraud. John A. Mattera, 50, a Florida-based investment manager, was arrested Thursday on charges of running an $11 million, two-year fraud that falsely promised investors access to coveted shares of Groupon, Facebook and other private companies.

MF Global improperly diverted customers' cash for its own use in the days before its bankruptcy, an act that regulators believe may help explain why $600 million of customer funds remains missing, people briefed on the investigation say. Investigators have now zeroed in on hundreds of millions of dollars in suspect borrowing at the commodities and derivatives brokerage firm, which at the time of its collapse was run by Jon S. Corzine, the former Democratic governor of New Jersey. At least some of that money was used to cover trading losses at MF Global, regulators suspect, meaning the money may no longer be simply missing. It may be gone.

An article on Saturday about public subsidies for renewable energy projects described incorrectly the earnings that the utility company NRG projected by 2015 from its solar projects. The company told investors that it expected the projects to generate $354 million annually in Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization; it did not project ''more than $300 million a year in profits.'' (While Ebitda is one common method of viewing profitability, ''profits'' is more typically used to describe pretax income, which the company said would be $49 million a year.)

FELS--Margaret, died November 12th following a heart attack. A brilliant and accomplished physicist at Princeton University, Meg was central to shaping the field of energy efficiency program evaluation. She was a generous, gifted teacher and a mentor to women going into science, and a coach, guide, and friend to far more in other areas of her life. She built community with everything she did. Wife of Bill Slack and widow of Stephen Fels, Meg was the radiant light of a family that includes her children Katya and Nicholas and their spouses, her two brothers and their spouses, and her nieces, nephews and cousins. She loved and was loved deeply and fiercely. Her life came to orbit joyously around grandchildren Desdemona and Stephen, to whom she was a playful, curious, kind and devoted friend as she would have been to grandson Jacob, born just last week. She was this also to her family and a legion of people she inspired through a decade-plus battle with metastatic breast cancer that, while she won, she never let define her existence. She sang in Princeton Pro Musica, loved opera, gardening, science, the beach, and living each day to its fullest. Gifts in celebration of Meg can be made to the Breast Cancer Resource Center, www.bcrcnj.org

LOVE--Howard McClintic Howard M. Love, known to his friends as "Pete", an extraordinary business man and civic leader, died at his home in Pittsburgh, PA on Wednesday, November 16 of Parkinson's disease. He was 81 years old. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy and then went on to graduate with a BA from Colgate University in 1952. He received his MBA from Harvard University. Mr. Love served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force where he was awarded the Commendation Medal. He was president and chief executive officer of National Steel Corporation. He was the beloved husband of Jane (Vaughn) Love; father of Marion Love Couzens, George Hutchinson Love II, Howard McClintic Love, Jr., Jane Love McGraw and Victoria Love Salnikoff. Funeral services will be held at 11:00am at Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh on Tuesday, November 22. Memorial contributions can be made to the Love Family Foundation Chair for Parkinson's Disease Research. Please contact Jim Olsen, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Forbes Tower, Suite 8084, 3600 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213. 412-647-7781.

The developer Bruce C. Ratner unveiled the design Thursday for what would be the world's tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 32-story residential building in Brooklyn at the corner of Flatbush Avenue and Dean Street in the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project. The 350-unit building would use varying rectangular shapes, colors and glass to break up the mass of the structure, which would sit snugly up against the Barclays Center, the arena for the Nets that is to open in September. Mr. Ratner, chief executive of Forest City Ratner, said that prefabrication, or modular construction, could save construction time and cut costs by as much as 25 percent. Fourteen other residential buildings would be built at Atlantic Yards using the approach. The second tower would be even taller, 50 stories.

FEDER--Dr. David O. Inventor, Trailblazer, Activist and acclaimed all-around battery Guru D.O. Feder, BS, 1946, MS., 1948, and PH.D., 1959, Columbia University. Was employed at Bell Laboratories, from 1954 through the early 1980's, when he formed his own company, Electrochemical Energy Storage Systems, Inc. While at Bell Laboratories, Dr. Feder's responsibilities included, electron tube materials and processing; selection and evaluating materials for use in the first orbital communication satellite "TELSTAR".; developed applications of the Nickel-Cadmium and the Lead Acid stand-by Battery system. He became the head of the Battery Development Department, which channeled his life activities in that field. He and his development team developed a long life stand-by battery "The Round Cell" known in the industry as the "Bell Cell" In the 1980s he became an advocate for battery standards and was appointed as the task force leader to coordinate the activities of three groups that produced the IEEE standards documents covering the manufacturing, testing, acceptance and measurement equipment for batteries. He was a WWII veteran, a member of the Electrochemical Society; Intellec: Sigma Xi; Tau Beta Pi; Phi Lambda Upsilon. He was the authored and co-author of many papers still guiding the industry and in 2004 he was inducted into the Battcon Hall of Fame. He will be greatly missed by the many colleagues, friends in his personnel life and in the field of lead acid batteries, in which he is universally respected. Dave was an avid skier, runner, and boater. A devoted husband and father. He leaves his wife Denise of 59 years; Four children Peter, Stephen Sonia and Danielle and 10 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Peconic Baykeeper, 10 Old Country Road, Quogue, NY 11959.

Rhode Island lawmakers, meeting in a special session on Thursday, passed a pension overhaul bill meant to rein in benefit costs that were growing so fast they threatened to overwhelm the state. Both houses passed identical versions of the bill by wide margins after defeating floor amendments that would have shielded public workers from some of its provisions.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. The partners, associates and staff of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP are profoundly saddened by the passing of Irwin Schneiderman, our esteemed former partner and friend of 63 years. Irv was a preeminent corporate attorney and trusted advisor to many of the firm's clients. During his many years with the firm, Irv set the standard that brought the firm's corporate practice to prominence. The bar has lost a true gentleman and leader. We are proud to have been his partners, friends and colleagues. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Roberta, and his son, Eric.

LAUDER--Evelyn. The Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn, with great sorrow, the loss of Evelyn H. Lauder, beloved wife of our Chairman Emeritus Leonard A. Lauder and mother of William and Gary. Evelyn was a dynamic and gracious woman and a visionary philanthropist. She had a marvelous aesthetic sense, evident in everything she did from her work with Estee Lauder, her style as hostess, cook, and gardener to her great talent as a photographer. She faced her illness with courage and a great joy for life. She was an inspiration to those around her. She was warm, helpful in times of need, and there for her friends, family and even many who hardly knew her. So too are we--the Whitney Museum family--here for Leonard and his family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown, Director

My Sunday column argues that the Occupy movement's success isn't about encampments at bits of real estate around the country, but about putting the issue of income inequality on the national agenda. The moral high ground it occupies is the issues, and that's why it doesn't matter if protesters lose control of parks here or there.

You know those moments in certain operas that you wish would last forever? As you read this, the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson is extending one of the most exquisite - from Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" - to the length of 12 hours. He is doing this in "Bliss," an effort perhaps best characterized as a work of endurance/appropriation/performance art that was commissioned by Performa 11. It is playing until midnight Saturday at the Abrons ArtCenter at 466 Grand Street on the Lower East Side. If Mozart, opera or performance art interest you, consider dropping by. It is also free.

Administrivial Non-Standard Puzzle Alert! The Sunday, Nov. 20, puzzle has some unusual features. In the print version of this crossword, some squares (containing slashes) in the Across and Down answers do not actually cross. Write both parts of the answers in those squares. Then use the central Across answer to interpret them properly to spell an appropriate final word. In the online version of this puzzle, the slashes are replaced by circles, and the program will accept either one of the answers that goes in that square, but not both (because of electronic restrictions). Although this Across Lite version does work, it is recommended that solvers download and print out the PDF version of this puzzle. As a second-best alternative, print out this Across Lite version and solve on paper. Don't worry. Just give it a try; it will make much more sense as you go.

If you have read "Independent People," the great novel by Halldor Laxness, Iceland's only recipient of the Nobel Prize for Literature, you might experience déjà vu while watching and listening to Guy Maddin's magical film-and-live performance "Tales from the Gimli Hospital: Reframed." The novel chronicles the incredibly difficult lives of early-20th-century Icelandic sheepherders in excruciating detail, and the narrative is leavened by weirdly fantastic and darkly comical episodes. The movie similarly looks back on the experience of Icelandic immigrants to Canada in the late 19th century.

There are days when it seems - both in and out of the food world - that Everything Is Going Wrong. That makes it easy enough to complain, and I'm not alone in doing so routinely. Nothing tastes the way it used to. Even pricey restaurants have lost their glow. Quality is shot. People die from eating melons. The dominance of hyper-processed, industrialized food (and, more to the point, food-like products) is spreading globally, and we're all gaining weight faster than ever, while wrecking the planet.

Summers are tidal but beaches remain. I'd taken an apartment for the summer in Coney Island to write but found myself staying on after Labor Day - because I hadn't made any progress, my novel didn't have an ending, or a middle, or even a continuable beginning ("Summers are tidal but beaches remain") - and because I'd become something of an island myself.

To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them - as well as to further their understanding of President Obama's recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans - Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of "Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,'' published in February.

Baby Bachchan: Bollywood's First Baby arrived on Nov. 16. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, wife of actor Abhishek Bachchan and daughter-in-law of iconic superstar Amitabh Bachchan (Time magazine once referred to them as "Bollywood's Father, Son and Holy Babe") delivered a baby girl. At 9.52 a.m. on Wednesday Abhishek broke the news on Twitter and immediately, the social networking site went into overdrive with other celebrities (Shah Rukh Khan, Karan Johar, Javed Akhtar) congratulating the family and discussing her cute-quotient (director Ram Gopal Varma tweeted "I just hope that she has more Aishwarya than Abhishek"). Within the hour, Baby B was trending on Twitter. The electronic media, however, was unusually restrained. In early November, the Broadcast Editors' Association had circulated an internal memo dictating conduct for coverage of the birth (guidelines included that the story would not be treated as breaking news and no cameras or broadcast vans would be sent to the hospital). Television channels stuck to the code and both Bachchans - Amitabh and Abhishek - thanked the media (on Twitter again) for respecting the family's privacy. Bachchan senior also assured the media that time would be allotted to them, for both print and television, but said that the immediate priority was to get some sleep.

This is a part of the continuing negotiations between the Nationalist Socialist Council of Nagaland and the Ministry of Home Affairs on its demand for a "sovereign" Nagaland. "While state boundaries would not change, the proposed councils for Naga-dominated areas outside Nagaland would exercise effective control there," reports the Nagaland Post.

Do you have a chunk of credit-card debt that you keep bouncing from card to card to take advantage of an attractive balance transfer offer? Or have you opened new credit card accounts just so that you can collect extra miles or some other enticing bonus? If so, you might be curious about how all of this factors into your credit score. In a few words: it's probably not helping, but not for the reason you may think.

The long bloody reign of ''Dexter'' on Showtime will continue for at least two more seasons. Showtime announced on Friday that it had ordered a seventh and eighth season of the dark comic drama about a serial killer, largely because the show continues to be among the most popular that the pay cable channel has ever produced. Ratings for the current sixth season have been up for five weeks in a row, Showtime reported, and with all the possible ways to see the show factored in -- premiere telecast, DVR playback, repeat plays on the channel and on-demand plays -- it is averaging more than five million viewers per episode, the best for any season of ''Dexter.'' Showtime previously announced that it had signed up the series's star, Michael C. Hall, above, for two more seasons. Each additional season will produce 12 episodes, the channel said. The eight-season run is unusual for cable shows. ''The Sopranos'' ran for six seasons (over eight years) as did ''Sex and the City''; both are widely considered to be among cable's most successful series. Unless, of course, you count ''South Park'' on Comedy Central. That series just concluded a deal that will keep it on the air for 20 seasons.

Joseph F. Skowron had everything going for him. A Yale-educated doctor, Mr. Skowron gave up a budding career as an orthopedic surgeon for the riches of Wall Street. He became a star hedge fund manager, using his medical knowledge to earn millions of dollars trading health care stocks. He lived with his wife and four young children in a $7 million mansion in the wealthy Connecticut suburb of New Canaan, where he could be seen driving through town in his Aston Martin.

Island Def Jam has postponed the release of Rick Ross's next album until next year because his recent health problems have delayed production, Billboard reported. Mr. Ross, above, a 6-foot, 300-pound rapper who writes about drug dealing and the gritty side of Miami life had planned to release his latest recording, ''God Forgive, I Don't,'' on Dec. 13, but an Island Def Jam executive said the record would not hit stores until the first or second quarter of 2012. Mr. Ross suffered at least two seizures on airplanes in mid-October. He has not said publicly what caused the seizures, nor has he released medical details about what happened to him. Appearing on a television talk show recently, he said that his poor sleeping habits had contributed to his health problems and that he had been advised by doctors to get more sleep. He had been getting by with only a couple of hours of rest every night, he said.

''He's a winner.'' For many fans, that is the trump card in any discussion about N.F.L. quarterbacks, the kill shot that negates contrary arguments based on statistics, scouting reports or other empirical evidence. ''So what if he generated only 225 yards of offense, scored just 10 points, and needs the entire playbook turned inside out to achieve even minimal success. He's a winner. Case closed.''

Goldman Sachs has appointed 261 new managing directors, according to a list obtained by DealBook. It is the smallest class since 259 were named managing director in 2008, reflecting a broad cost-cutting effort at the firm. Managing director is a title handed out across Wall Street, and it typically comes with higher pay. At Goldman, the base salary for a managing director is $500,000. This doesn't include bonus, which can run into the millions.

Premieres of works by Lisa Kron, Idris Goodwin, Mona Mansour, Courtney Baron, Greg Kotis and Lucas Hnath will be offered at next spring's Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., one of the most prestigious showcases for original theater in the country. ''This constellation of amazing playwrights includes a mix of men and women, experiences that range from the suburban Midwest to the Middle East, veterans of Broadway and writers who'll see their work produced on this scale for the first time,'' said Amy Wegener, literary director of the Actors Theater, which sponsors the festival. ''The Veri**on Play,'' by Ms. Kron and directed by Nicholas Martin, is a mix of screwball comedy and horror that begins with a call to customer service about a cellphone bill. Ms. Mansour's play ''The Hour of Feeling,'' directed by Mark Wing-Davey, takes place in 1967 as borders in the Middle East are about to change. And Mr. Kotis's ''Michael von Siebenburg Melts Through the Floorboards,'' features a 500-year-old Austrian bachelor living in an American city. The festival, which begins on Feb. 26, is expected to attract more than 40,000 people during its six-week run. Supported by the Humana Foundation, the National Endowment for the Arts and the Harold and Mimi Steinberg Charitable Trust, the festival will be celebrating its 36th year in 2012.

The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about some commercial real estate loans that lost more than 100 percent of their value, referred imprecisely to a package of securities that the American International Group offered to buy back earlier this year from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. While they were mortgage-backed securities, they involved residential real estate, not commercial.

A news analysis article on Wednesday about the Obama administration's effort to reassert the American role in the Pacific region referred incorrectly to a diplomatic agreement signed by China and Southeast Asian nations in July. It was a set of guidelines for implementing a ''declaration on conduct'' concerning the resolution of disputes in the South China Sea; it was not the declaration itself, which was signed in November 2002.

Gary D. Cohn, the president of Goldman Sachs, is expected to be interviewed by the government in its insider-trading case against Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of the bank. Mr. Cohn's name emerged late Friday during a hearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan before Judge Jed S. Rakoff. Federal prosecutors and Mr. Gupta's lawyers debated the timing of depositions that are set to be taken in a parallel civil case being brought against Mr. Gupta by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Last winter, when a storm descended on Stamford, Conn., residents received a recorded phone message from the city's director of public health and safety. The voice was authoritative and effusive, with a bit of a carnival barker mixed in. It was unmistakably Bobby Valentine. Valentine, who lives in Stamford and operates a restaurant and sports academy there, dived enthusiastically into public service, as he does with all of his pursuits. He is a man of many interests, but baseball manager suits him best. The Boston Red Sox seem to know this, and they have made him the latest candidate in their ongoing search to replace Terry Francona, even asking other baseball people about him during the just-concluded general manager meetings in Milwaukee.

An art review on Friday about an exhibition of work by Richard Pousette-Dart at the Luhring Augustine gallery in Chelsea, organized by the artist's daughter and the painter Christopher Wool, misidentified the college at which Mr. Wool studied with Mr. Pousette-Dart and misstated the time period. It was at Sarah Lawrence in the 1970s, not Bard in the early 1980s. The review also misspelled the daughter's given name. She is Joanna Pousette-Dart, not Johanna.

An article on Friday about the renewed interest in transmission of electricity using direct current incompletely described the flow of DC power. In a DC system, electric current flows from a battery or power station to a home or an appliance, and continues flowing in a circuit back to the original source; it does not stop in the home or appliance.

Carl Pope, who has led the Sierra Club for much of the last two decades, is planning to leave the organization next year as it struggles to redefine its mission in a tough economy, the organization said Friday. The move reflects a broader debate among many of the nation's environmental groups, which are finding it a challenge to raise money, motivate activists and build public support for core concerns like climate change in the face of high unemployment and hostility from Republicans in Congress and on the presidential campaign trail.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE DILEMMA (2011) Vince Vaughn stars as Ronny, and Kevin James is Nick, best buddies enthralled by beautiful women (Jennifer Connelly and Winona Ryder, above with Mr. James) and business partners who are designing an engine that combines fuel efficiency with muscle-car brawn and noise. But what is Ronny to do when, in the midst of planning the perfect proposal for his girlfriend, he spies Nick's seemingly devoted wife in a lip lock with another man (Channing Tatum)? ''Promotional clips released last year caused some umbrage because they contained homophobic jokes, and those lame gags -- about the somehow nonsexually-specific 'gayness' of electric cars -- are still in the movie, along with the usual exaggerated reassurances that the two main characters, who love each other dearly and whose love is tested by difficult circumstances, are Not Gay,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But 'The Dilemma,' written by Allan Loeb and directed by Ron Howard -- hardly a name associated with frat-boy yukfests -- is not entirely what it appears to be. It is less a macho comedy than what you might call a bromantic melodrama, an unabashed weepie with enough beer, sports, fistfights and cars to reassure the snuffling he-men in the audience that their tears are Not ... well, you know.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Bob Faw reports on happiness, and whether people's contentment should be a measurement of a country's standard of living. The Rev. James Martin, the author of ''Between Heaven and Mirth,'' talks about why joy, humor and laughter are essential elements of faith.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. The partners, associates and staff of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP are profoundly saddened by the passing of Irwin Schneiderman, our esteemed former partner and friend of 63 years. Irv was a preeminent corporate attorney and trusted advisor to many of the firm's clients. During his many years with the firm, Irv set the standard that brought the firm's corporate practice to prominence. The bar has lost a true gentleman and leader. We are proud to have been his partners, friends and colleagues. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Roberta, and his son, Eric.

A young New York entrepreneur has one word in response to complaints about high A.T.M. fees: Advertising. Free ATMs NYC, brought to you by Clinton Townsend, 25, offers free withdrawals to all users. The catch? While you wait for your cash to be dispensed, a 15-inch screen on the machine plays an advertisement. Then, when you get your receipt, it will have a coupon for a discount, perhaps at a restaurant nearby.

A film review on Friday about ''The Greater Good,'' a documentary that looks at what some people say is a link between autism and childhood immunization, referred incorrectly to its depiction of the effects of diseases, including polio, that can be prevented by vaccines. The film does in fact show children in iron lungs.

LaFOSSE--Patrick J.M.,82, passed away peacefully in Paris, France, on November 12th. He is survived by Florence LaFosse, his beloved wife, and by his sons Laurent, Ulrich and Julian, and grandchildren, Andre and Elise. Patrick worked in financial services becoming a partner at age 32 at Halle and Stieglitz, and eventually joining Banque Privee Edmond De Rothchild, in Geneva where he became Vice President and a member of the Executive Committee. He will be greatly missed by his family, his friends, and his associates.

The fourth movie in the Twilight Saga series earned $30.25 million from its midnight screenings, doing better than the previous three movies in the lucrative vampire franchise and boding well for its prospects this weekend. Producers have predicted that the new film, ''The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1,'' which opened on Friday, will bring in more than $140 million at United States and Canadian box offices before the weekend is finished. Based on Stephenie Meyer's ''Twilight'' novels, the films tell the story of a romance between Bella Swan, a teenage girl played by Kristen Stewart, above with Robert Pattinson, and her vampire lover, Edward Cullen, played by Mr. Pattinson. (A werewolf named Jacob Black, played by Taylor Lautner, also vies for Bella's affection.) The film tells how Edward carries the day and marries Bella. ''The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn -- Part 1'' did slightly better during its midnight opening than the previous movie in the series, ''The Twilight Saga: Eclipse,'' which grossed $30.1 million when it came out in June 2010. Still, the latest Twilight movie came nowhere near touching the final installment of the Harry Potter saga -- ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2'' -- which set a record for a midnight opening in July, earning $43.5 million. That movie went on to set a three-day weekend record with $169.2 million in the United States and Canada.

So why did Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, ''sell'' his home to his wife for the paltry sum of $1? The timing of the transfer, on July 21, has raised the issue of what Mr. Paterno was trying to accomplish. Last week, he was ousted as head football coach after 45 years amid questions about his response to allegations of sexual assault against one of his coaches.

The ''white albs'' are vestments or long clerical robes; they are not cassocks, which are generally black.

The Emmy Award-winning actor Jim Parsons (''The Big Bang Theory'') is in talks to return to Broadway this spring to play Elwood P. Dowd in the Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy ''Harvey,'' about a man who claims to be friends with a 6-foot-tall rabbit no one else can see. Two theater executives close to the discussions, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to disclose the possible deal, said Mr. Parsons, above, was in negotiations with Roundabout Theater Company. Representatives for Mr. Parsons and for Roundabout declined to comment. The two executives said the production hinged on the schedule of Mr. Parsons, who stars as the socially awkward theoretical physicist Sheldon Cooper in ''The Big Bang Theory'' on CBS, for which he won the Emmy for best actor in a comedy in 2010 and again in September. Mr. Parsons made his Broadway debut last spring, to critical accolades, in the Tony Award-winning revival of ''The Normal Heart,'' playing the young gay activist Tommy Boatwright. ''Harvey,'' by Mary Chase, opened on Broadway in 1944 and ran for more than four years; the play was made into a movie in 1950 starring Jimmy Stewart as Elwood and Josephine Hull as his exasperated sister Veta, a performance that earned her an Academy Award for best supporting actress. The play has been revived once on Broadway, in 1970, starring Stewart and Helen Hayes (in her final Broadway production) as Veta.

With the opening two months ago of the National September 11 Memorial, the black-white-and-blue ''9/11 Memorial'' trademark has turned up just about everywhere in Lower Manhattan, even on subway signs that have never before been branded with the logo of a private corporation. A symbol for such an important institution deserves scrutiny, beginning with the identity of the typeface, which is key to its appearance.

An art review on Nov. 11 about ''Cecil Beaton: The New York Years,'' at the Museum of the City of New York, misstated the number of Oscars Mr. Beaton won for costume and set designs. It was three, not two. (He won one for his work on ''Gigi'' and two for ''My Fair Lady.'')

In just a few days, we will once again endure the annual spectacle of the president of the United States  pardoning a turkey that would otherwise have been fated for the Thanksgiving table. This event is typically covered in the media as a light-hearted bit of fluff - and fluff is what it might well be, if there were not actual humans on death row awaiting similar intervention. In the current American context, however, the turkey pardon is a distasteful parody of the strange power vested in politicians to decide the earthly fates of death-row prisoners. There is in it an implicit acknowledgment that the killing of these prisoners is a practice that bears real, non-jocular comparison to the ritual slaughter of birds for feasts.

It was a gooey, cheesy weekend at the multiplex as the movie series that teenage girls love and many adults love to hate -- "The Twilight Saga" -- returned with a sonic boom. "Breaking Dawn -- Part I," the fourth and the worst-reviewed film in the franchise, as judged by RottenTomatoes.com, was an enormous No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $139.5 million. Yipit, which aggregates and filters daily deals from companies like Groupon and Living Social, is an example of the high-tech start-up that is altering the employment picture in New York. Alan Feuer, of the New York Times, reports that high-tech employment in New York is shooting up by 30 percent in the last five years, at a time when overall private-sector employment has decreased. New York recently surpassed Boston in the amount of venture capital invested in Internet start-ups, and lags behind only San Francisco.

New York remains envious of the wealth and success of Silicon Valley. It has tried to duplicate it and failed. But it is trying again, reports Gina Bellafante, the Big City columnist at the New York Times. Positioning New York for 21st-century global supremacy has been a preoccupation of the Bloomberg administration, she write, and one central to the mayor's vision of greatly expanding the technology sector by ratcheting up elite science education.

Status has long been based on appearance, accomplishment and notoriety, but social media reach is becoming a new criterion, reports Beth Landman in the New York Times. Klout is trying to measure it by rating social media influence on a scale of 1 to 100, as a means of determining V.I.P. status.

DES MOINES - Six Republican presidential candidates on Saturday night diverged from their usual campaign conversations about the economy, foreign policy and President Obama to offer a glimpse into how hardships and faith have shaped their lives.

New York's museums have moved beyond the audio wand, reports Joshua Brustein, the App City columnist at The New York Times. He reports that the American Museum of Natural History is opening a new exhibit, Beyond Planet Earth, this weekend, with an ambitious mobile application that conjures up three-dimensional images of solar systems and spacecraft on visitors' phones. The Guggenheim recently introduced its first mobile application, for its retrospective on the Italian-born artist Maurizio Cattelan.

As retailers battle to draw customers into their stores on Black Friday, online merchants are plotting a cunning ambush, reports Stephanie Clifford of the New York Times. She reports that the merchants are offering an arsenal of mobile-only deals intended to pick off shoppers as they wait in line.

As retailers battle to draw customers into their stores on Black Friday, online merchants are plotting a cunning ambush, reports Stephanie Clifford of the New York Times. She says the merchants are offering an arsenal of mobile-only deals intended to pick off shoppers as they wait in line.

Dr. Dre is the pitchman for the hot new sound in headphones. To the surprise of almost everyone, except him and his partners, Beats have redefined the lowly headphone, as well as how much people are willing to pay for a pair of them. Andrew Martin of the New York Times reports that whether Beats are worth the money is open to debate. Reviews are mixed, but many people love them.

Alessandro (Alex) Stratta, who developed quite a reputation in Las Vegas, will open his first New York restaurant next week. He will be executive chef and co-owner of Bigoli, with serious but fairly simple Italian food.

Their camp was evicted. Their property was removed. Many had not slept. But as dawn began to break over Lower Manhattan on Tuesday morning, just hours after the Occupy Wall Street protesters had been driven from Zuccotti Park in an overnight police operation, a hush fell over the huddled masses reconvened in Foley Square.

As part of the Metropolitan section's special Digital City issue, we're asking readers to share their Sunday Routines with us. Throughout the day, let us know what you're up to on Twitter using the hashtag #SundayRoutine, on Facebook and in the comments below. (More information about the project is here.) Below are some highlights from what we've received so far.

To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them - as well as to further their understanding of President Obama's recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans - Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, spent this past week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of "Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,'' published in February.

The annual Feriarte Art and Antiques Fair will bring together over 100 Spanish and international antiques dealers and gallery owners from Nov. 19 to 27 at the Feria de Madrid (Avenida del Partenón; www.ifema.es. Participants will offer an impressive array of furniture, paintings, sculptures, timepieces, lamps, jewelry and Asian and tribal art. Nearly 50 experts oversee the entries to guarantee their quality and authenticity.
The America’s Cup champion skipper Jimmy Spithill of Oracle swept the French Energy Team in two races to win the match racing portion of the America’s Cup World Series on San Diego Bay.

Next Media, a Hong Kong-based company with gossipy newspapers in Hong Kong and in Taiwan, has gained an appreciative following for its news cartoons: short animated segments, often humorous and sometimes racy, that provide a visual narrative for major stories.

"What's Your Foreign Degree Worth?" the Economic Times asks in its Sunday Magazine. "For decades, the foreign degree has been a great Indian middle-class dream," the article says, and the crisis in India's higher education system is only pushing more students overseas. But foreign education options are expensive, sometimes fraudulent and don't always guarantee a good job overseas or at home. "The days when Indian employers used to be fascinated with a foreign degree are gone," one human resources company executive says.
The shakeup in the top 10 continued, as Oregon lost to U.S.C. on a missed field goal and Oklahoma lost to Baylor on a last-second touchdown.
Tiger Woods secured the clinching point Sunday to ensure that the Presidents Cup will be coming home to the United States.

MONTEE BALL The Wisconsin running back rushed 38 times for 224 yards and 2 touchdowns and caught a touchdown pass as the 15th-ranked Badgers (9-2, 5-2 Big Ten) scored 21 straight points in the second half to rally at Illinois, 28-17. "We started off pretty slow," said Ball, who has 30 touchdowns to extend his Big Ten season record.

As a preview of Sunday's M.L.S. Cup final between the Los Angeles Galaxy and the Houston Dynamo, John Godfrey took a look at David Beckham's impact - good and bad - on the league since arriving five years ago. But he had plenty from Beckham left over in his notebook when he was done writing.

Here are five places that let guests relive Thanksgiving the way the original settlers did. Just don’t count on forks and knives.
November is showtime for a certain segment of the re-enactor set, a month in which they try to gently correct that stereotypical image of the first Thanksgiving.
Before they set foot on the Mayflower, the Pilgrims journeyed from English farmlands to the urban streets of Leiden, in the Netherlands.
Muffie Potter Aston balances life as a mother with a demanding schedule of charity work.
Max Hastings’s survey of World War II concentrates on the experience of those who took part.
In these personal essays, John Casey shares his love of sports and the outdoors.
Sabina Murray’s stories delve into the lives of explorers, reimagining the pivotal moments that secured their place in history.
Each of the stories in Don DeLillo’s collection addresses a different kind of unease.
Mushrooms have much to offer, Eugenia Bone tells us.
Leeds Radio is a joyful jumble of old electronic parts that attracts musicians, hi-fi aficionados and ham radio buffs.
Walking in the footsteps of America’s first settlers, from English farmlands to the urban streets of the Netherlands.
Frogs can sing, penguins can’t and other lessons that Bret McKenzie, of the musical-comedy duo Flight of the Conchords, learned while writing music for the Muppets.
Elaine Paige, the first lady of British musical comedy, is back on Broadway in the revival of “Follies.”
Sue Grafton is nearing the end of her alphabet crime series — only four more books and, yes, we’re counting.
A Williamsburg electronics shop, one of the oldest in the country, carries hundreds of thousands of analog electronic parts, all manufactured before 1968.
Thanks to a new downtown scene, there’s now a Santa Barbara for every budget.
Over the past few years, the city has made room for a new downtown scene humming with cool shops and laid-back wine bars.
Twenty minirecipes designed to stimulate both your overindulged appetite and your tryptophanned-out brain.
The picture book “A Very Young Dancer” influenced a generation of girls in 1976. But its protagonist’s later life wasn’t all slippers and stages.
In Amwell Township, Pa., the dividing line is between those who are getting rich and those who are paying the price.
The playwright J. T. Rogers has found a home writing about geopolitical conflicts.

The Weeknd — singer, songwriter, producer and Drake collaborator — performed at the Guelph Concert Theater in Ontario. His Twitter messages say his third album is coming.

GRADY--Henry W. Died in New York City, November 16, 2011 in his 86th year. Graduate of Thayer Academy and Harvard College, he also served in World War II. An investment adviser at U.S. Trust (1955-1985) and chairman of Colonial Consulting Corp. (1985-1995), he was a retired director of Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corp. (U.S.A.). In addition to a long association with several charitable organizations in the city, he was a co-founder of the Bonnie Cashin Foundation. At his request there will be no funeral or memorial service. Those who wish may make gifts in his memory to Bat Conservation International, P.O. Box 162603, Austin, TX 78716, or a charity of their choice.

I was intrigued (make that wildly excited) when I heard there was a fancy hotel in Switzerland where I'd be forced to eat meat, frites, cheese and chocolate and drink red wine and Champagne in order to lose weight. Was this a publicity ploy or a miracle? Whatever the case, the timing was exquisite. I'd had just about all the juice cleanses, freaky fasts and detox diets I could stomach, and was ready to bite off something I could actually chew. So, armed with an appetite and a copy of Gabrielle Hamilton's ''Blood, Bones & Butter,'' I set off for the sleepy city of Lausanne, which has stunning views of Lake Geneva and the Swiss Alps and one of Europe's grandest grande dame hotels - the Beau-Rivage Palace.
