POMEROY--Burdette (Bill), 89, died November 13, 2011 at Lawrence Hospital Bronxville, NY, where he was born July 4, 1922. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Julia Richmond Pomeroy and their children: Stacy Pomeroy Draper, Reynolds Pomeroy II (Bettie), James B. Pomeroy (Kathryn), and Nancy Pomeroy Foster and his grandchildren, Kathryn N. Draper, Marshall D. Pomeroy, Merrill C. Pomeroy, Kinley W. Pomeroy, Amelia Berry Pomeroy, Julia R. Foster, and Christopher P. Foster, Jr. He is also survived by Jean Lyon, his daughter by a former marriage, and several nieces, nephews and cousins. He was the son of Reynolds Pomeroy and Amelia B. Pomeroy and stepson of Daisy Holt Pomeroy. He was predeceased by his brother, John R. Pomeroy. Mr. Pomeroy attended Brantwood Hall in Bronxville, Riverdale Country Day School and the University of Arizona, Tuscon. After WWII he went to work with his father at Reynolds Pomeroy Co., insurance brokers in Manhattan, becoming President in 1966 and continuing his career for over half a century. He had a lifelong passion for automobiles, especially classics, and was a frequent winner of trophies at antique car shows. A Memorial Service will be held at The Reformed Church, Bronxville on Friday, December 9th at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, please consider a memorial donation to a charity of your choice.

Like pretty much everyone in Ecuador, Roque Sevilla drives fast. I hurtle with him from the capital of Quito down two and a half hours of gut-stirring switchbacks, losing elevation with every turn. The sugar-cane and cattle farmsteads tumbling past on either side dwindle steadily, while the surrounding forests gain in age and power. Sevilla talks the whole way. Slender, mustached and hugely energetic, he recites the names of tree species, describes different hummingbirds and tells stories about the foundations of Ecuador's conservation movement. ''I have been in Europe, Africa, Asia and North America,'' he says, ''but Ecuador - and I don't say this only because it is my home - is truly special.''

Room service used to be the stepchild of hotel dining: the menus were an afterthought, and guests often ordered in as a last resort. But many independent and chain hotels have been rethinking room service, making it more desirable. For starters, guests can increasingly find healthy choices for in-room dining. Kimpton hotels recently rolled out a Travel Healthy menu, on which all choices are under 500 calories. The Pierre in New York City is set to unveil a menu featuring lower-calorie dishes (above), and the Waldorf-Astoria has selections catering to diets like gluten-free and low sodium. Room service is also becoming more like restaurant dining. The Windsor Court in New Orleans gives guests the option of having meals served in courses, as do several Four Seasons properties.

RAYNOLDS--John Fiske John Fiske Raynolds, a U.S. Navy frogman and underwater demolition team officer in the Korean War, served as CEO of Outward Bound USA during the 1980s, the organization's most significant period of growth. He died at his home in Vero Beach, Florida on November 11, 2011. He was 82. As a diver in the Navy, Mr. Raynolds served on the first team to jump from helicopters into the ocean, an operation that led to the genesis of the U.S. Navy S.E.A.L.S. Mr. Raynolds graduated from Williams College and continued to a career in car dealerships in California, then returned to government service, spending four years with the U.S. Intelligence Service in Ghana, West Africa. His following careers included investment banking with Butcher & Sherrerd in Philadelphia before becoming President and CEO of the Outward Bound USA, a position he held from 1981 until 1991. During his ten years as CEO, Outward Bound's enrollment increased from 7,000 to over 30,000 students per year. A lifelong mountaineer, Mr. Raynolds was a member of the American Alpine Club and the Explorers Club. The Wall Street Journal was intrigued by his unusual combination of corporate and not-for-profit careers and did a feature article on him, entitled "The Stew Pot Theory of Career Building", and CNN produced a 30-minute special on him in their program "Pinnacle", which aired internationally. John F. Raynolds III was born in Minneapolis, MN on September 25, 1929 to John Fiske Raynolds II and Valeria Blunt Raynolds. He was the 2009 recipient of the Bicentennial Medal from Williams College for distinguished achievement in experiential education. Mr. Raynolds is survived by his wife Eileen Blaker Raynolds; three children from his previous marriage, William S. Raynolds, Virginia Raynolds Stark, and Helen Winton Griffith; two stepchildren, Kelley McCabe Ruff and Linda Weiss; and six grandchildren. Memorials preferred to Outward Bound USA, 100 Mystery PT RD, Garrison, NY 10524 c/o Raynolds Memorial Fund.

SOGI--Francis Yoshito, age 88, in Kona, Hawaii, November 3, 2011. He was an international lawyer admitted to practice both in New York and Japan and a partner at Kelley, Drye & Warren. He founded the Sogi Foundation in 1980. He served as Chairman of the Board of the Japanese American National Museum and Emeritus Trustee. Emperor Akihito of Japan awarded Mr. Sogi the Order of the Sacred Treasure. In 2004, Mr. Sogi published his memoirs, "Riding The Kona Wind". He is survived by his wife, Sarah M. Sogi, his son, James Sogi.
MARKS--Joannee (Nee Hauptman), 87, died November 12, 2011 in Riverdale, NY. She is survived by her son Bruce Marks and grandchildren Justin and Andrew.

On a recent Saturday night in Boulder, Col., a warehouse in an industrial park on the city's southeast side was humming with live music, food trucks and people who'd dropped by on bicycles for a martini. Which may seem customary in the People's Republic of Boulder - except that the warehouse isn't a new cocktail bar exactly but rather Boulder Distillery, one of the many small spirit producers that are multiplying all over the state. Steve and Terri Viezbicke started this one in 2008 with 303 Vodka, made from Steve's Polish grandfather's recipe, then branched out into potato whiskey (the first of its kind). Because Colorado law allows distilleries to sell what they make right from their plant, the tasting room - a bar in a corner of the distilling floor strung with lights and lined with potato sacks - slings pickletinis and bloody Marys and sells bottles of its spirits all weekend long.

A picture caption last Sunday with a brief article about four of the most popular drinks in the Caribbean this season reversed the labels on two of them. The drink on the far left is the Lemon Crash and the one at the far right is Love City.

FOR the first years of their marriage, Jennifer Betit Yen and Peyton Worley were bicoastal. They had met in law school at Boston University. But Ms. Betit Yen soon fell into acting. After she got a role in an independent film, she seized the opportunity, left her job and moved to Los Angeles. Mr. Worley remained at his law firm in Boston. For almost three years he flew back and forth, spending half the month in each city. The traveling became tiresome, but he was able to transfer to the firm's office in New York, a city that would work for both of them.

To the Sports Editor: For all of the fault attributed to Joe Paterno and the leadership at Penn State for failing to stop Jerry Sandusky, the former defensive coordinator who is charged with sexual abuse of boys over 15 years, a question is not being asked. Why are the police and the Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare that interviewed Sandusky in 1998 not coming under the same criticism? They interviewed Sandusky, and he stated then that he was wrong to shower with boys. Do we need more admission of guilt? Joseph Moore Jr. Pittsburgh To the Sports Editor: Lost in all the reaction to the indictment of Jerry Sandusky and its aftermath is the collective amnesia of America of all the good that Penn State students do. As we all know by now, the students were not responsible for the scandal; they are without blame. Penn State is so much more than football and its coaches. Students and alumni are on track to raise more than $500,000 for the victims of abuse. Jed Kirsch Plainview, N.Y. To the Sports Editor: Even if it turns out that Joe Paterno complied with Pennsylvania's child abuse reporting laws, his moral conscience and compass failed him severely. Losing his job as head coach, ending his career in public disgrace and tarnishing his family name are all just punishments that will forever weigh heavily on his heart. But Paterno's suffering will always pale compared with that of the abuse victims. ALAN GUTTMAN Washington To the Sports Editor: Penn State will be judged less for the heinous acts that a trusted coach may have committed, but more for the silence spanning more than 10 years that allowed the crimes to continue. One hopes that the students of Penn State are not further harmed by lasting tarnish. PAM HOLLAND Chevy Chase, Md.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. All of us at City Opera who worked so closely with Irv during his 14-year chairmanship took constant strength from his enthusiasm, transforming financial support, positive presence, and stabilizing advice. He cared profoundly, we cared profoundly for him, and we wish we could live it again. Much love to our dear Roberta and his son Eric. Paul Kellogg and Irv's Devoted City Opera Friends

AMERICAN GRAFFITI The windowless cinder block warehouses of Miami's Wynwood neighborhood have long served as blank canvases for local graffiti writers. But in recent years, a group of street artists has turned the formerly industrial area into a grass-roots answer to the annual Art Basel Miami Beach fair. After starting with five murals in 2006, they formed an organization, Primary Flight, to sponsor more of them. Five pieces became 35 the following year, 85 the next. ''The idea was, Let's take the street art out of the gallery and put it back into its natural environment,'' explains Books Bischof, the group's founder. With some 200 murals now wallpapering Wynwood (including Adrian Sonni's, above), these few square miles have become one of the largest open-air street-art installations in the world. In a reversal of the usual progression, the graffiti has led to commercial development. With the gallery giant Jeffrey Deitch, Tony Goldman - one of the driving forces behind SoHo - created Wynwood Walls (NW Second Avenue, between 25th and 26th Streets), a more tightly curated and manicured exhibition of murals. This fall Wynwood adds a much-anticipated performance space, the Light Box at Goldman Warehouse (404 NW 26th Street), and, during Art Basel, a pop-up store next to the Wynwood Walls grounds where a book of the murals photographed by Martha Cooper will be sold. For visitors who want to see all of the neighborhood's murals in two hours, the guides at Roam Rides offer graffiti tours by jewel-tone Vespa.

COWEN--Henry C. born New York City on May 17, 1920. He died in his sleep at his home in Commack, NY on November 12, 2011. Revered in the direct marketing industry and adored by his large family: his wife, Diane Scott; his son David and Margaret Cowen, his daughter Jackie and Lew Toback, his stepsons Joseph and MaryJo Scott, Will and Angie Scott; his grandchildren Shana and John Helsel, Leza and Lou Mendella, Darren and Amy Toback, Aaron Cowen, Will and Lauren Scott, Joseph and Caleb Scott; his great-grandchildren Lexi, Benny and Angelo Mendella, Jacob and Emily Helsel, Lena Toback and a player to be named. Service will be family only. Love and affection and fond memories are enough yet, if desired, donations in his memory to a favorite charity are fine.

Police use of pepper spray on a dozen protesters at University of California, Davis, on Friday sparked calls for the resignation of the university's chancellor and the start of an investigation into the incident. Videos of the Davis incident uploaded to YouTube show police officers dousing the protesters -- mostly students, according to local reports -- with orange pepper spray, after repeatedly asking them to disperse from the main quad on campus. The protesters were seated with their arms linked on a sidewalk.

The artist and filmmaker Meredith Danluck and the director of photography Jake Burghart met while working on ''Garbage Island,'' a documentary about the North Pacific Gyre for Vice magazine's Web site. The couple, now married, recently wrapped up ''North of South, West of East,'' an 85-minute, four-channel film that had them shuttling between Detroit and Marfa, Tex., for much of the past year. The film follows four characters through the well-traveled territory of car culture and the American dream, and succeeds in pioneering a new genre: ''It's like an action-comedy-art film,'' Burghart says.

New York is in tip-top color, and the clothes reflect the autumn foliage. The fashion statements are varied, but sleeveless fur jackets are the hit of the season. On Central Park South, a view of fall at its peak is framed by two five-foot-tall stained-glass parrots. Gardeners are planting tulip bulbs for an entirely different color scheme this spring.

McCARTER--Michael G. The Board of Directors of the Group of North American Insurance Enterprises (GNAIE) expresses its condolences to the family of Michael G. McCarter who passed away last Monday. For many years, Mike was a lone voice in the insurance industry to recognize the importance of the American presence in the development of International Accounting Standards. To accomplish this goal, he helped forge our trade association. His contributions are beyond measure. They include service as Chairman of the GNAIE Research Committee responsible for the early documents and papers that still act as a foundation of GNAIE policies and principles. We will miss his humor, spark, and brilliant contributions. Our hearts go out to his family and friends but hope he will always be remembered for the joyfulness he brought to our lives.

PRUSSIA--Leland Spencer. November 13, 2011. Leland S. Prussia was Chairman of the Board of BankAmerica Corporation and Bank of America, NT&SA from 1981 to 1987. He served as the bank's Chief Financial Officer from 1974 to 1979 and 1984 to 1986; from 1979 to 1981 he was Chief Executive Officer of the World Banking Division. He was also a director of Hughes Aircraft, Hughes Electronics, Nippon Credit Trust Company and the Crowley Maritime Corporation. Born in San Jose, California, he graduated from Stanford University and served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War, returning to Stanford to earn his M.A. in economics in 1956. A lifelong Democrat, he worked hard on behalf of many causes that he believed in. He was the first chairman of the California board of directors of The Nature Conservancy and a governor of its national organization; a director of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget in Washington, D.C.; a trustee of the Neighborhood Housing Services of America Foundation; a director of the Santa Fe Institute; and a director of the Saint Francis Foundation of the St. Francis Memorial Hospital of San Francisco. For 54 years he was married to the late Vivian Blom Prussia, whom he loved dearly, and he is survived by his three children and four grandchildren. Donations may be made to The Nature Conservancy, 201 Mission Street #

Like most creatures on earth, humans come equipped with a circadian clock, a roughly 24-hour internal timer that keeps our sleep patterns in sync with our planet. At least until genetics, age and our personal habits get in the way. Even though the average adult needs eight hours of sleep per night, there are ''shortsleepers,'' who need far less, and morning people, who, research shows, often come from families of other morning people. Then there's the rest of us, who rely on alarm clocks. For those who fantasize about greeting the dawn, there is hope. Sleep experts say that with a little discipline (well, actually, a lot of discipline), most people can reset their circadian clocks. But it's not as simple as forcing yourself to go to bed earlier (you can't make a wide-awake brain sleep). It requires inducing a sort of jet lag without leaving your time zone. And sticking it out until your body clock resets itself. And then not resetting it again.

GILLERMAN--Gerald. The Honorable Gerald Gillerman, 86, of Cambridge, MA, passed away November 15, 2011. He is survived by his wife Dorothy Hughes Gillerman, his sister Jeanette Bello, four children and six grandchildren. During WWII, Gerald served in the 22nd Infantry in France, where he received the Purple Heart. He practiced law for many years in Boston and in 1990 was appointed to the Massachusetts Court of Appeals by Michael Dukakis, where he served for 12 years. A service in his memory will be held on Friday, December 2nd, 2:00pm, at the Storey Chapel at Mt. Auburn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

COLLECTIVE BARGAINING As most anyone in Palm Beach will tell you, many of the pastel city's fortunes were managed by Bernie Madoff, and it's tempting to think that this is why its upscale consignment shops are teeming with loot. New York decorators haven't picked over the more than 40 antiques stores on West Palm's South Dixie Highway, known as Antique Row, where midcentury modern is almost as common as vintage rattan. The 8,000-square-foot Objects20c and its loft upstairs (3611 South Dixie Highway; 561-659-0403) offer everything from Eames chairs to Stickley mission furniture. Faustina Pace Antiques (3633 South Dixie Highway; 561-804-6682) mixes Swedish and French industrial pieces, while Cashmere Buffalo (3709 South Dixie Highway; 561-659-5441) has mod, Asian and African antiques. Coco House & Co. (3625 South Dixie Highway; 561-305-3157; cocohouseandcompany.com) specializes in whimsical English bamboo furniture, which holds up well in the Florida sun. A popular pit stop for decorators, Rhythm Cafe (3800 A. South Dixie Highway; 561-833-3406) is a campy former 1950s drugstore that serves an excellent Earl Grey ice cream. Serious collectors will want to stay at Hotel Biba (320 Belvedere Road; 561-832-0094), a cheerful, kitsch-filled motor lodge from the 1940s with easy access to Antique Row. For the definitive Palm Beach experience, check in at the very grand and recently restored Breakers Palm Beach (One South County Road; 888-273-2537), where courtyard boutiques carry Loeffler Randall, Repetto and K. Jacques shoes alongside the requisite Tory Burch and Lilly Pulitzer prints.

To the Sports Editor: Go ahead and cancel the N.B.A. season . No one will miss a sport that has reduced itself to hulking men pushing and shoving under the basket or the predictability of swinging the ball around and posting up, blah, blah, blah.

LEWISOHN--Joan Snyder, 65, on Monday, November 14. Adored wife of Richard, cherished stepmom of Brandon Lewisohn and Heather Barton, and beloved Granny Buns/GiGi of Anna, Graham, Spencer and Sarah. Sister of Sheldon Snyder and more than just an aunt to David, Amy, Scott and Susie of Chicago and their children.

To accompany her spring collection's sporty graphic dresses and jumpers, the designer Stella McCartney teamed up with the International Trade Center's Ethical Fashion Program on a line of Kenyan-made accessories. ''I have actually never been to Kenya,'' says McCartney, who has done similar collaborations with Oceana and the Natural Resources Defense Council. ''But the project helps to use the widely available and affordable materials there.'' The tote bags ($330) and strappy sandals ($300) in python-patterned screen prints are made of recycled cotton safari tents and sewn by seamstresses in Nairobi. Go to saks.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CONNOR--Marjorie, 82 years old, left us to be with her beloved husband Sidney on November 16, 2011. Cherished mother of Bradley, Nancy and Joseph, daughter-in-law Sharon, son-in-law Doug and loving grandmother of Liora, Danielle, David and Michelle. Her many friends and family mourn her loss.

GUTERMAN--Stanley, passed away and is survived by wife of 66 years, Jacqueline, daughters Andrea (Jim) and Roslyn (Casey), brother Ben (Shulamith), grandchildren Woody, Winn, Myriah and great-grandchildren. He will be in our hearts forever.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

Most foreigners who come to the south of France think of Marseille as an exit or entry point. It's convenient, only an hour's drive from Avignon and the hill towns of the Vaucluse and so many other lovely places in Provence. In Marseille's small airport, you buy a 1 euro cup of machine coffee and you get on a plane headed for Paris or home, your mind filled with one version of France: idyllic little towns with churches and castles, lush green valleys, fruit trees in serried ranks, Provencal linens, village markets, antiques, lace, espadrilles, vineyards, lavender, handcrafted pates, local wines, artisanal goat cheese. But I like to leave the airport behind and drive another 20 minutes. As I come round a bend in the highway, a very different France pops up in front of me. After the rest of Provence, Marseille's cityscape is a giant reality check - an affront to the storybook country. Yes, the usual orange-tiled roofs spill down a hill to the city center, but vast housing projects are scattered throughout the north side of town, and huge, serious ships sit in Marseille's modern port, a dozen or so cranes and forklifts towering over it, lifting and turning, testimony to construction and economic activity. Unlike the rest of the country, for Marseille, it's all about the water; the land has very little to do with the life of the place.

IS that guy with a laptop at the local coffee shop cooking up a business plan or just checking his Gmail? Tech start-ups are hard to count, but according to public records, more than 400 New York City start-ups have raised money from investors in the past two years. Where do the startups go? The center of gravity remains Union Square, with companies spreading south and north along Broadway from there.

The Pomo Indians, who once inhabited the land, were long gone the day in 1962 when Al Boeke flew in a small plane over the pristine beaches, steep bluffs, wind-swept woods and sheep-grazed meadows along the Pacific Coast in Sonoma County, Calif., about 150 miles north of San Francisco. What Mr. Boeke saw, in his mind's eye, was a residential community that would blend in with that 10-mile stretch, with its jagged rocks, redwoods, pines and Monterey cypresses.

BUTNER--Lawrence, born April 17, 1931 in Brooklyn, NY. Died November 14, 2011 after a lengthy illness. Loving husband of Eleanor (Schwartz) Butner for 57 years. Devoted father of David Butner, Robin (Butner) Weidy and Gary Weidy. Loving grandfather of Brian Weidy, Dora Butner and Sara Butner. Cherished brother of Sylvia (Butner) Katzmann, John Katzmann, Sydney Schwartz, Jeffrey and Miriam Zuckerman, and Barbara and Philip Pakula. Served as a Sergeant in the Marine Corps during the Korean War. Received his BBA from City College of New York and his JD from Brooklyn Law School with a license to practice law in the state of New York. After working for many years at Albert Frank Guenther Law, Inc., a major financial services advertising agency, he started his own agency, Lawrence Butner Advertising, Inc., in April 1979. Larry became a guru in direct marketing building his company into a leading boutique firm with blue chip clientele for over 20 years. Funeral service was held on Wednesday, November 16th. In lieu of flowers, donations to "SK Lectureship Researchship Fund" at NYU Langone, Development office 1 Park Ave, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10016, would be appreciated.

Mardy Fish had dropped all that weight and kept it off. He had shored up his forehand and his endurance, finally committed himself to consistency and no-regrets exploration of the full range of his tennis talent. Yet in the early stages of this season, with his body refusing to cooperate with the master plan, Fish began to despair. At age 29, which is advanced for a 21st-century tennis professional, Fish knew the moment to make a major move was now, but despite all the training and ambition, he was mysteriously low on energy.

Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). It's hard to fathom how poorly the talented Eagles secondary has played at times this season. The low point came against Arizona last week when it allowed the Cardinals' backup quarterback, John Skelton, to throw for 315 yards and 3 touchdowns.

Before she was made empress, how Catherine the Great suffered! In his gripping new biography, ''Catherine the Great'' (Random House, $35), Robert K. Massie reveals a young woman lorded over by a tempestuous monarch, a meddling mother and a man-child husband who raised hunting dogs in her sleeping chambers. (She couldn't even get a tooth pulled without insult; the palace surgeon tore out a piece of her jaw in the process.) The ''Bento'' in John Berger's ''Bento's Sketchbook''(Pantheon, $29) refers to the philosopher Baruch Spinoza, Berger's starting point - along with a plum tree - in this uplifting rumination on how we see the world.

TOBIAS--Anne Strong, 89, died on November 13, 2011 at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, New York. She was born on March 23, 1922, the only daughter of Walter Ansel Strong, owner and publisher of the Chicago Daily News, and Josephine Haviland (Webster) Strong. She was raised in Winnetka, Illinois, and attended North Shore Country Day School. She then attended Smith College and later studied at the Art Institute of Chicago. She married her high school classmate Peter Wolkonsky on December 31, 1946 in Chicago. They were later divorced. Following World War II, Anne worked for the United Nations. On June 27, 1957 she married Jaromir Tobias at her family's summer home on the Rock River in Oregon, Illinois. In 1958, Anne founded a magazine titled Young Americans and served as its editor and publisher. She lived in New York City for many years, and in 1962 bought a farm in Rhinebeck, New York, where she operated a trout hatchery. Anne had a lifelong love of music, art, and literature, enjoyed tracing astrological influences on famous personalities, and was a devoted bird watcher. She was predeceased by her brothers, Walter Ansel, Jonathan Webster, Robert Kitchell, and David Seymour Strong. She had no children of her own, but is survived by many nieces and nephews with whom she maintained close ties. A memorial service will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Rhinebeck Chamber Music Society, P.O. Box 465, Rhinebeck, NY 12572.
Theater Ben Brantley

THE photograph shows the panorama of a messy bedroom. A box of Honey Nut Cheerios is on the floor, near a pack of cigarettes. The closet doors are all open, as if someone were trying to show the size of the place to a prospective tenant and had not had time to clean up first. But there, on the bed, face down, is a man's body. His hands are bound behind his back. He is so perfectly laid out that it looks like a photo from a haunted house tour, but the crime scene is very real, and so is the corpse.

Long dismissed as dirty little secrets, Rembrandt's erotic etchings have been known to collectors for centuries but rarely seen by the public. In 2001 the British Museum exhibited several of the prints. Now, the World Erotic Art Museum (weam.com) in Miami Beach is showing the entire collection together -- 20 etchings -- for the first time. Rembrandt depicts sexual encounters in a suggestive but unambiguous way in works like ''The Ledikant'' (1646), which portrays a couple making love. Above, a detail of ''Woman With the Arrow (Venus and Cupid?),'' 1661.

BOGART--Dina, beloved wife of Milton, after a long courageous battle with cancer, passed away on November 10. Her love of arts, crafts, fashion, travel and fine dining was an inspiration to her husband and the family and friends that knew her.

SUSSMAN--Lila, of Englewood, NJ and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Peacefully after a courageous battle. She was 77 years old. Devoted wife for 54 years to Richard Sussman. Loving mother of Rachel, Nina, and David Sussman. Mother-in-law to Gary Hobbib and beloved Grandmother to Isabelle. She will be deeply missed by her family and many more. A lifetime patron of the arts and benefactor to other notable causes. A beautiful woman both inside and out, Lila had a passion for life and lived each day to its fullest. Donations in her name can be made to: CURE PSP, 30 E. Padonia Rd., Suite 201, Timonium, MD 21093

The Sunday Routine column in some editions last Sunday about Rafael Viñoly, the architect who designed Jazz at Lincoln Center, using information from a publicist, misstated the month that one of his projects, the first ''green'' police station for the New York Police Department, on Staten Island, is scheduled to open. It is July, not January.

In your book, ''The End of Normal,'' you write about a girlfriend setting you up on a blind date with your future husband, Mark Madoff, whom she described as ''one of the wealthiest men in New York.'' Was that appealing? No. I never wanted to be some sort of socialite, and I don't think that's what Mark wanted. He always told me that one of the reasons he liked me so much from the beginning is because I wore a Timex. When I read about the December 2010 suicide of your husband, I remember being disturbed by the image of him hanging himself with the family dog's leash. Does this still haunt you? It haunts me every time I have to walk the dog and every night when I try and go to bed. What haunts me most is that he tried it with a vacuum-cleaner cord first, and it didn't work, and he tried again. The determination of it is gruesome.

SMITH--Sylvia Butensky, of Ardsley, NY, formerly of Upper Nyack, NY died on November 4 at the age of 88 years. A Registered Dietitian and Former Director of Food Services at the Rockland County Infirmary, in Pomona NY. Predeceased by Dr. David J. Smith, her husband of 64 years. Survived by her three daughters, Judith (Brian) Dobbs of London, England, Lois (Charles) Goldsmith of Croton-on-Hudson, NY and Diane of New York, NY and grandchildren David and Charlotte Dobbs and Michael and Jonathon Goldsmith. Contributions in her name can be made to a local Meals on Wheels.

Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery.

EUNICE LEE, the designer behind the Unis men's wear line, which opened its first Los Angeles outpost this week, often looks to her customers and male friends for feedback. ''I'm a woman designing a men's wear brand,'' Ms. Lee said. ''I can't wear the clothes, so I'll ask 10 different guys how something feels on instead.'' Giving men exactly what they want is exactly why Unis has earned a loyal following since it's opening in 2000. The label is known for deceptively simple shirting, outerwear, pants and knits, as Ms. Lee's obsessive tweaks and improvements elevate everything above similar brands and their mass market counterparts. ''It will be interesting to see what happens at the L.A. store when we discover a whole new set of customers that I can respond to,'' she said. ''L.A. definitely has its own style. I'm hoping to just slide right in and offer guys here something sophisticated.'' And it's fair to assume that she's open to suggestions. Unis L.A., 138 South La Brea Avenue. STEVE DOOL

HAMMER--Dorothy Kapstein, passed away on November 17 at home in Greenwich Village in the company of her sons Matthew and Ethan Kapstein. Dotty was the loving sister of Rhoda Gilinsky, grandmother of Anne, Laura, Nina, and Felicity Kapstein, and aunt of Beth Gilinsky Spero and Joshua Gilinsky. Born on August 18, 1923, Dotty was a fashion pioneer first as reporter at Tobe Associates and later as senior editor at Seventeen Magazine. Her company, Bamboula, promoted and developed contemporary African crafts and she served as consultant to the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of African Art. Dotty was also co-creator of Shibui Blues, a Japanese-inspired clothing line. She was a devoted Democrat, a tireless traveler and a creative cook, a friend to many here and abroad. Her beloved second husband, Arthur Hammer, died in September 1994. A private memorial will be held at her home early in the new year. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Dotty's memory to Doctors without Borders or the New York Coalition for the Homeless.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week. We knew this was coming. In a deciduous forest in autumn, leaves are going to fall. Yet the stark nudity of the trees on Tuesday morning is still a shock. They seem to have hemorrhaged leaves; in the space of a week, most have fallen.

Nothing causes New Orleanians to wake up in night sweats like the prospect of their beloved city turning into a Houston or an Atlanta or some other well-adjusted city. Of course, there is little to be gained by becoming a quaint still life, either, and it is this tension - between adopting from the outside and holding on to what makes New Orleans what it is - that has governed the past six years of recovery. While the city itself is still trying to find the balance, a wave of new cocktail bars, gastropubs and hotels are striking it in their own way. Housed in a former firehouse on a dimly lit corner in the Uptown neighborhood, Cure (4905 Freret Street; 504-302-2357) is TriBeCa on the Mississippi. Ambitious in its mixology and earnestly hip in its presentation, the bar serves Jamaican meat pies and baked crabcakes alongside a cocktail menu heavy on house-made bitters. Cure is among the first of the city's new craft cocktail bars, and its peers are plenty, including the retro-styled Bouligny Tavern (3641 Magazine Street; 504-891-1810), which has clever drinks like the Sage Julep and refined bar food. The more adventurous can head to the barely marked Twelve Mile Limit (500 South Telemachus Street; 504-488-8114) in Mid-City, owned by a bartender formerly of Coquette, one of the city's upscale bistros. Inside it looks like a proper dive - jukebox, pool table, well-worn sofa - but one that makes inventive cocktails, barbecue-inspired cuisine and superb doberge cake. The French Quarter is generally avoided by the young and cool, but then came Sylvain (625 Chartres Street; 504-265-8123), where locals go for comfortable cuisine done smartly, like porchetta po' boys. There's music, too, a short stroll downriver at Three Muses (536 Frenchmen Street; 504-298-8746), where you can order a Spaghetti Western - Bourbon, orange-infused Campari and rosemary syrup - and listen to a tattooed lady sing Bessie Smith standards.

THEIR camp was evicted. Their property was removed. Many had not slept. But as dawn began to break over Lower Manhattan on Tuesday morning, just hours after the Occupy Wall Street protesters had been driven from Zuccotti Park in an overnight police operation, a hush fell over the huddled masses reconvened in Foley Square. ''Hey!'' a man shouted, raising his smartphone aloft. ''We're trending on Twitter!''

New York would never be mistaken for the Motor City, but on Tuesday, Smith Electric Vehicles announced that it intended to assemble electric trucks in the South Bronx, adding 100 jobs to the region. A package of more than $6 million in state and city incentives sweetened the deal. Smith, based in Kansas City, Mo., manufactures battery-powered box trucks suitable for urban deliveries and has already found customers in New York, including the Duane Reade pharmacy chain and Down East Seafood. Coca-Cola and Frito-Lay have also bought trucks.
THE BIG PROFILE By Dave Itzkoff

We're turning the Sunday Routine column over to you, our readers. On Sunday, Nov. 20, using Twitter, Facebook and the Web, let us know what you're up to, right now and throughout the day -- whether sleeping in, exploring the city or going to work. We'll offer highlights online during the day and publish the results on Nov. 27, online and on this page. ON TWITTER Tweet using the hashtag #SundayRoutine and tell us what you're doing at the moment you're writing. We will collect your tweets to create a group portrait of our readers' day off.

''Founders stay too long, and they chase out the next generation of leaders,'' says Kevin Rollins, who served three years as chief executive of Dell before he was replaced by the company's founder, Michael S. Dell. Techdom turns out many wonderfully rational products with cool precision.

WALLACH--Louis, on November 18, 2011. Beloved husband of Carrie, devoted father of Joan, Lynne and Gary and father in law of Mark Altman and Donna Wallach. Adored grandfather of Alexander, Harry, Evan, Sam, Kate and Benjamin. Dear brother of Selma Leiman and the late William and Maury Wallach. COLA BUZZ Pensacola is the first stop on what some disparagingly call ''the Redneck Riviera.'' But a few miles inland from Jimmy Buffett's new Margaritaville resort is a booming downtown district where Old Florida mingles with the whole-hog hipster set. About 120 new businesses have sprouted here in the past five years, and next year will bring a $52 million stadium complex.

HOLLAND--Bert. Died November 15. Clinical psychologist and computer programmer in social science research at New York University. Born April 8, 1927 in New York. Bert attended Hessian Hills School, Croton-on-Hudson, NY, and Stuyvesant High School. Before service at Great Lakes Naval Training Center, he attended Franklin and Marshall College. Further education at Roosevelt University, The New School for Social Research, and graduate study in psychology at NYU. In 1954 Bert married Nora Bell (nee Potashnick) who died in 1991 of Alzheimer's, through which Bert cared for her with greatest devotion. Recently, Bert lived in Peabody, MA, near his close friend Davida Rosenblum. Active in leftist causes as a teenager, Bert always supported a broad range of social and political issues and enjoyed vigorous discussion. Survived by son Joel Holland, of Croton and New York City, stepdaughter Jordy Bell of Croton, two step-grandsons and three step-great-grandchildren. Donations to Amnesty International in his name welcome.

BOAT TO TABLE Florida's Gulf Coast should be a smorgasbord for seafood lovers, but nearly two years after the BP oil spill - and despite a chorus of positive food-safety reports - sales of Gulf seafood remain down by as much as 20 percent. A few chefs are even reluctant to say their fish is locally caught. Here's where to find some of the Gulf's best, if lately underappreciated, shellfish.

AS if two 25-carat black opals weren't enough, these showstoppers by the New York jeweler Kimberly McDonald also contain white and gray diamonds, rubies and natural Burmese sapphires that were hand-carved in the 1920s. ''These are bar none, my all-time favorite earrings,'' Ms. McDonald said. ''Opal is the only material that seems to possess an internal light. And, of course, no two are the same. The sapphires are unusual and exquisite.'' Available at Bergdorf Goodman, for $142,670. SANDRA BALLENTINE

FELTHEIMER--Myron, 94, Our beloved husband, father, grandfather died peacefully at home in Roslyn, NY on November 9. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Marcia, his children Jon (Laurie), Jill (Ed Fisher) and Benn (Amy) and seven grandchildren. A man of extraordinary decency, selflessness and humor, he inspired all who knew him. Born in Brooklyn, March 5, 1917, his first career as a theater manager was interrupted by WWII. After his service (305 signal corp.), he began a career in financial services. He worked for First Investors Corporation for 45 years, touching the lives of countless people. He retired in 2000 as Executive Vice-President. He was our anchor, a model of how to live. We aspire to be more like Myron.

It was our managing editor, George Gene Gustines, who suggested we do a T made of Legos for our winter travel issue. ''I'm a huge fan of Legos and spent hours building houses and superheroes out of them as a kid,'' he said. ''Of all my childhood toys, I probably miss them the most.'' Representatives at Lego led us to Sachiko Akinaga. As an expert Lego sculptor, Akinaga has enviably turned child's play into a profession. From animal musicians to jumbo parfaits, Akinaga has created intricate worlds of whimsy. Here, she shares some of her brick-building insights with The Moment.

A report on Oct. 16 about the marriage of Jeanne Cathcart and Brian Gari misstated part of the title of a book written by the bridegroom's mother, Janet Cantor Gari. It is ''Stop the World, I Want to Tell Someone Off,'' not ''Stomp the World, I Want to Tell Someone Off.''

I'd taken an apartment for the summer in Coney Island to write but found myself staying on after Labor Day. After writing my quota for the day and having no money to spend on whatever people spend money on (movies? bars? apartments in vitrine buildings with dedicated bicycle storage, where each unit comes complete with a spare office set aside for each couple's eventual parturition?), I'd taken to walking at night. Some nights there was a moon; other nights there was no moon; always there was Lower New York Bay, called, by the geographically oblivious, the Ocean. On nights with no moon it was so dark out there the weather and wake seemed one. The dark thwack of sneakers on planks. The soft boards whose knots are black gum. That night there was a scud of red up ahead, where the boardwalk swerves like a D.U.I. at Ocean Parkway. I went toward that blinking light -- it was a truck, backed up to the beach. A slow, short old man stood with a shovel on the sand three steps down. His nose was inverted, in a sense; it resembled a thumbprint like one a cop would take but not in ink, in concrete. He was digging down and then, weak with the weight of each load, shoveling the sand into large bags and then flinging the bags into the back of his truck.

The face of single parenthood in the United States has long been defined by the image of a woman, often struggling with challenges like divorce, desertion, poverty and the scarcity of good child care if she is employed. Indeed, according to census figures compiled this year, of the 11.8 million single parents living with children under age 18 in the United States, 10 million, or 85 percent, were mothers. But the number of families headed by single fathers has been growing faster than the number headed by mothers only or by married couples, according to the Census Bureau. The ranks of single fathers in the nation totaled 1.7 million, or 15 percent, of single parents, according to data collected this year. That number has grown steadily since 1970, when there were about 400,000 single fathers.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Irwin. We mourn with profound sadness the passing of Irv Schneiderman, beloved past President, Co-Chairman, Chairman and Board Member of New York City Opera. Through his visionary leadership and unwavering championship of the Company, Irv gave generously of his time, insights, and resources for nearly three decades. Together with his adored wife Roberta, Irv ranks among City Opera's most historically generous and thoughtful donors. He was much loved by all who were fortunate enough to know and work with him. We are comforted that Irv's legacy will endure through the impact of his altruism and his love of music, and we will miss him forever. We send our deepest condolences to Roberta, their son Eric, the entire Schneiderman family and Irv's many friends and colleagues. George Steel, General Manager and Artistic Director, and Charles R. Wall, Chairman, on behalf of New York City Opera and its Board of Directors.

RINDLER--Philip A.,peacefully died at age 82 on November 11th. Born in Ridgewood, NY to Rose and Sidney where he ran Waxgiser & Rindler, Inc. until he retired in 1996. Survived by Rhoda Gordon and daughters. Devoted father to Kenneth, Jeffrey and Andrew (Karen). Adored grandfather to Katie Mae. Loving brother to Martin and Joel (Barbara). Wonderful uncle and cousin to many. You will be missed.

ON a typical night in the emergency room, a patient shows up short of breath, suffering from emphysema or heart failure or maybe both, as well as diabetes and high blood pressure. Doctors and nurses administer inhalers to ease his breathing and diuretics to take off excess fluid, and admit him to the hospital. Over the next few days, interns and residents furiously adjust his medications and fix his diet. He is discharged with a stack of prescriptions. A week or two later, chances are good he'll be right back in the emergency room. A 2009 study in The New England Journal of Medicine showed that among Medicare patients, 20 percent were re-admitted to the hospital within 30 days of being discharged. We call these chronically ill patients frequent fliers.

An article last Sunday about collectors of discarded bottles and cans misstated the time frame during which bottle and can deposits became a fact of life in New York City. It was almost 30 years ago, not almost 20. (The state law was put into effect in 1983.)

THOMAS TAIT was in New York last week for London Showrooms, a presentation of British talent. Actually, Mr. Tait is Canadian, educated in Montreal. In 2010, he completed the master's program at Central Saint Martins in London, whereupon he joined that race known as the Young Designer. He is 24. His spring collection was a favorite of mine. The lines were fairly simple, but he added color (baby pink and green) and turned a screen-printed silk jersey into micro-pleated trousers or panels for dresses. He used a traditional technique in a fresh way. Mr. Tait's clothes are sold at Louis Boston and Blake in Chicago. We spoke over a drink at the Standard Hotel.

With 85 tournament victories worldwide, 10 major championship trophies and a place in the L.P.G.A. and the World Golf Halls of Fame, Annika Sorenstam earned a restful retirement when she left competitive golf. She is instead involved in more ventures than ever, with a golf academy, a charitable foundation, a clothing line, a wine label, a fragrance and an international golf course design business. Sorenstam and her husband/manager, Mike McGee, have two young children. Annika Academy, a golf instructional app for smartphones and tablets, became available last week. And last month, the United States Golf Association announced that she would receive its highest honor, the Bob Jones Award, in 2012.

An article last Sunday about the impressive rookie season of Cincinnati Bengals quarterback Andy Dalton misstated, in some editions, the year one of his predecessors, Carson Palmer, was drafted by the team. It was 2003, not 2004.

The cover article on Oct. 30 about gothic sites that inspired the early gothic writers erroneously attributed a distinction to ''A Mystery of the Campagna,'' a novella by Anne Crawford, a Victorian author. It was not the first vampire story in English. (At least one short story, ''The Vampyre,'' by John Polidori, also written in English, and published in 1819, predated it by 68 years.) The article also misstated the relationship between an evil monk in Ann Radcliffe's novel ''The Italian'' and a girl he was hired to kill. He was her uncle, not her father. (He believed he was her father but later learned the real connection.)
MATHES--Irma, 86, beloved mother of Roberta died November 17. Funeral services today 1:30pm at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Route 4 in Paramus, NJ.

Just in time for Italy's 150th anniversary (and a major financial crisis), a flurry of new books present the country as frustrating, inscrutable and magnificent. ''Rome'' by Robert Hughes (Knopf, $35) A fascinating personal history of the Italian capital, ''Rome'' begins with an exegesis on the founding myth of Romulus and Remus and ends with a rant about how the city has lost its ''Dolce Vita''-era glory. Hughes says Rome has been ''gutted by the huge and ruthless takeover of its imagination by mass tourism.'' Its television is ''crap,'' its civic experience ''brutally compromised by automobile and driver.'' The city that wasn't built in a day (try 2,500 years) refuses to be understood in the space of ''a decade or a guided bus ride.''

A four-bedroom apartment in the Superior Ink building at 400 West 12th Street that sold for $15.5 million was the most expensive sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com. And with each square foot of gilded space costing $4,234, it is one of the priciest non-penthouse purchases of the year, brokers said. The apartment will be used as a pied-a-terre, a term that usually conjures up an image of a snug, cozy space where the owner can regroup after a night at the theater or spend a weekend taking in some of the pleasures of the city. This buyer, the head of a private investment firm, will have a sprawling 3,661 square feet in which to put up his feet or park his shopping bags.

STANGER--Dr. Melvin. The measure of a man is his impact on the lives of those he touched. By that standard, Dr. Stanger was at the pinnacle of his profession. I am one of those fortunate to have been helped by him and I owe him enormous gratitude. Judy Fields

Mardy Fish had dropped all that weight and kept it off. He had shored up his forehand and his endurance, finally committed himself to consistency and no-regrets exploration of the full range of his tennis talent. Yet in the early stages of this season, with his body refusing to cooperate with the master plan, Fish began to despair. At age 29, which is advanced for a 21st-century tennis professional, Fish knew the moment to make a major move was now, but despite all the training and ambition, he was mysteriously low on energy.
Television Kathryn Shattuck

Every time we put together a travel issue, we look over the pictures that have been taken for the various stories and appoint a single image as the ''jigsaw puzzle.'' We usually can spot it on sight: an insanely detailed, entirely magnificent, wickedly diverse in its minutiae, panoramic view of an exotic place; something that could still render some surprises when shattered into a thousand bits. For this issue, the choice of one was not so easy. There were the streets of Kolkata (Page 130) by Max Vadukul, with their crowds, bright taxis, quirky signage and painted shutters. There was Vava Ribeiro's Ecuadorean cloud forest (Page 136) with its lush diverse growths and vibrant denizens. From Moab, Utah (Page 122), Cass Bird turned in humorous and epic shots of Heidi Mount among mountains of rocks. (How many shades of pink and red can one find in sandstone?) Our favorite jigsaw photographs, though, came from François Deladerrière. They are of Marseille (Page 142), and they accompany Amy Wilentz's terrific essayistic tour of France's second-largest city. What we found so wonderful about them is that they forced us to look more closely, and with real delight, at a cityscape we knew well. Like great travel writing, they made us want to discover the secrets, all the twists and turns, of a familiar place.

STERN--Jonathan J.,born February 24, 1942, in the Bronx, died November 9, 2011, in Boca Raton, FL. He was the loving and devoted husband of Sandi, proud father to Jennifer, Daniel, and Brian, and loyal brother to Julie. He was admired by many for his integrity, leadership, generosity, humor, and philanthropy, qualities which he embodied in both his personal and professional relationships. Services were held November 13, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Manhattan.

The sun was about to set on the Indonesian island of Bali when Ben Ripple and Frederick Schilling, owners of the artisanal food company Big Tree Farms, led me through their new chocolate factory near Ubud. It was still under construction as we stepped into a titanic inner chamber with a high pitched roof, the last light of the day streaming dramatically through a long, narrow skylight at the peak, allowing the 30 or so builders to keep working. Several of them cheerfully called down to us from their tinkertoy-like scaffolding as we picked our way through the piles of construction materials. ''We're building the Big Tree cathedral,'' Ripple said. And they're doing it almost entirely out of bamboo. Not only will the three-story, 23,500-square-foot structure be the world's largest commercial building made out of bamboo, but it also might just be the most Wonkaesque. From the outside, the factory resembles a giant Balinese handicraft - like an apartment-building-size basket or a giant crocheted toy barn. The facade and some interior walls are woven from bamboo strips, and the roof is made of dried alang-alang grass. Ripple said the walls had to be coated with food-grade sealant in order to meet building codes for a commercial food-processing plant. ''And we have about 10,000 fire extinguishers stashed away,'' he said with a laugh.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from Nov. 11 to 17. 1. PATERNO TRANSFERRED OWNERSHIP OF HOME TO WIFE FOR $1 The transaction came less than four months before a sexual abuse scandal engulfed his Penn State football program and the university.
DAVISON--James, on November 10th. We will remember you with love always. Susan, Elizabeth, & Ben Affuso

ONCE you get a load of these new hand-stained brogues from Cole Haan, you will never think of a wingtip in the same way again. For its winter collection, the iconic American brand worked hard at blending its comfortable technology (Nike Air cushioning, even in heels) with cutting-edge design. This includes everything from sexy stilettos in its Maria Sharapova collection to these iridescent oxfords for women. At first glance they seem totally traditional except for an odd sheen. But shine a light on them, and you're suddenly wearing twinkle toes. Maliya Wingtip, $268 at Cole Haan SoHo, 128 Prince Street. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

LAUDER--Evelyn. The entire Aspen Institute family mourns the loss of a truly remarkable woman. Together with her husband, Leonard, she provided invaluable philanthropic support of many key initiatives at the Aspen Institute but her generosity of spirit will be her biggest legacy. To her family, we extend deepest condolences.

Heeere's Yvonne! Setting artists and audience members in a maze of 350 refrigerator boxes, Yvonne Meier's dance-installation piece ''The Shining'' returns Dec. 13 to 23 at New York Live Arts in all of its maddening glory. It was first performed in 1993 at Performance Space 122, above -- and, yes, that is Ms. Meier leaping among the Beckett-like boxes. ''The Shining'' earned her a Bessie Award in 1993 (newyorklivearts.org).

For ''Send in the Clouds,'' (Page 136), the writer Anthony Doerr spent five days at the Mashpi Rainforest Biodiversity Reserve in Ecuador, where an eco-resort is scheduled to open in January. He slept in an outbuilding with local biologists. ''It's not for high-maintenance people,'' says Doerr of the muddy but magical location, in an untouched region a few hours from Quito. But Doerr, the author of a column on science books for the Boston Globe, said he was in heaven. ''When I was little, I was one of those nerdy kids who picked up bugs all the time.'' Doerr, the author most recently of ''Memory Wall,'' is at work on a book about the impact of radio during World War II. Alex Vadukul

David Beckham has always possessed a flair for the dramatic, so why should it be any different now? He announced his arrival on the soccer scene in Manchester United's 1996 season opener, launching an audacious shot from the center stripe that soared into the net. Two years later, an impetuous red card in the 1998 World Cup cost his team dearly and turned Beckham into a pariah throughout England. Three years after that, his stoppage-time goal in a World Cup qualifier against Greece rescued his country -- and restored his reputation.
Pop Nate Chinen

SOME people come to East Fork of the San Gabriel River, about 80 miles from Los Angeles, to trade the snarl of the freeway for the sound of a running stream. Others get down to business -- bringing shovels, buckets and pans to prospect for gold. Some of the searchers are from the Los Angeles area; others are tourists. ''It's all about chasing the gold,'' says John Estrada, a frequent visitor who has a collection of small gold pebbles and flakes at home that he plans to give to his children. He is following a dream that has captivated people since the 19th century. And with gold around $1,700 an ounce, more people are catching the fever in the 21st. J. EMILIO FLORES
What do corporate clients wish associates were taught in law school? A better understanding of modern litigation practice, which is about gathering facts and knowing how to settle a case.

REISMAN--Dr. Arnold, passed away on November 1, 2011 at the age of 84. He is survived by his loving, beloved wife of 62 years and best friend, Hilda, his children and their spouses, Richard (Susan), Robert (Lisette), David (Emma), and Daniel (Gabriella), and his 11 beautiful grandchildren, Elizabeth, Lillian, Jacob, Eli, Rachel, Simone, Joseph, Isaac, Jackson, Raquel, and Ethan. Dr. Reisman received his BS in chemistry from CCNY (1949), his MA in chemistry from Brooklyn College (1953), and his PhD in physical inorganic chemistry from The Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute (1958). From 1958 until 1982, he served as project manager and then senior manager at IBM's T.J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, NY, the leader in the evolving field of microelectronic technologies. Upon taking early retirement from IBM, Dr. Reisman, in 1982, became a full professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at North Carolina State University, and served as a vice president of the Microelectronics Center of North Carolina. In his scientific work, Dr. Reisman, an internationally renowned physical chemist, pioneered studies of materials, processes and thin film technologies used in microelectronic devices. He authored over 170 technical papers, books, and book chapters, holding over 50 patents, for which he received numerous awards. He oversaw inventions in technologies now used in everyday electronics, such as plasma screen TVs, flash drives, and ink jet printers. Dr. Reisman found his greatest joy, though, in his personal life, as a singularly devoted and loved family man, opera buff, painter, amateur tennis player, mandolinist, photographer, and repairman of all things great and small. He will be dearly missed. The family is asking that donations be made in Dr. Reisman's memory to The National Parkinson's Foundation, Gift Processing Center, P.O. Box 5018, Hagerstown, Maryland 21741-5018 or online at www.parkinson.org.

''Nature really is a beast to duplicate,'' says the Maslin designer Pip Amey, whose new beach towels feature cheetah and zebra prints that took her a year to draw. Named after Australia's first nude beach, the towels were inspired by '70s hedonism and replicate life-size hides big enough to hold a small orgy of sunbathers. Amey says she chose zebra and cheetah because ''they're like the Grace Jones and Keith Richards of the animal kingdom.'' Go to maslinandco.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

''GOUDEMALION,'' on view through March 18, 2012, at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris, examines the work of the artist and image-maker Jean-Paul Goude through the lens of the Pygmalion myth. Like the sculptor in Ovid's ''Metamorphoses,'' Mr. Goude tends to fall in love with his own creations. He is best known for his willful distortions of the human figure, from the Constructivist ''maternity dress'' he made for his longtime muse Grace Jones to any number of his Ektachrome collages in which the likes of Bjork or his wife, Karen Park, appear far greater than the sum of their body parts. Included in the exhibition is a clip from a 1972 ''Mike Douglas Show'' episode, in which the artist tries to deconstruct his method to the clueless host. Mr. Goude's is an artfully composed morphology, one without pretense or the sly retouching that pretends the faux is real. At 109, rue de Rivioli. SARAH MOROZ

Dulcie Gray, a stalwart of British stage, screen, radio and television who won enthusiastic reviews when she made her Broadway debut at age 80 with her husband and frequent acting partner, Michael Denison, died on Tuesday at Denville Hall, a home for elderly actors in Middlesex, England. She was 95. The cause was pneumonia, a spokeswoman for the home said.

The magazine's blog, The 6th Floor, has been compiling lists of ''My Three Favorite ...'' from staff members and contributors. Here are some recent selections. For the full posts, as well as more Three Favorite lists, visit 6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com.

For travelers who hop from Web site to Web site to compare hotel rates or find the best value, there's a new online tool aiming to be a one-stop shop. Room 77 has introduced a platform (room77.com) that aggregates hotel rates from a variety of travel sites like Hotels.com, Expedia, Priceline and Orbitz, and serves up search results in one place. Those results, displayed in list, grid or map view, can be further filtered by user preference, for example showing only hotels that offer free Wi-Fi or breakfast. Moreover, users can select what kind of view they want -- city, water, pool -- or which amenities. The Web site also lists fees for add-ons like valet parking or roll-away beds. In grid view, users can see rates by room category to better compare options. Like Room 77's mobile app, users can also look inside select rooms.

''We accept that Africa is a place that comes with risks,'' says the Ethos Water creator Peter Thum, but ''seeing a little kid with a gun is very jarring.'' So Thum (right) and John Zapolski (left) founded Fonderie 47, a company aimed at reducing Africa's estimated 20 million assault weapons by turning the metal into jewelry. Working with the Mines Advisory Group, the company has helped remove more than 5,000 AK-47s from Congo. Designed with the jeweler Philip Crangi, each steel-and-gold signet ring (price on request; e-mail contact@fonderie47.com) finances the demolition of 75 more guns and is etched with the serial number of the weapon it once was.
8:20 p.m., NBC MATCHUP to watch
FANDEL--John. September 9, 1925 to November 15, 2011, poet, artist and professor of English at Manhattan College.

REUSCHE--Robert F.,83, of Lake Forest, IL, passed away on November 15, 2011. Beloved husband of Mary Reusche for 61 years; loving father of Emily Reusche Selbe, Anne (David) Reusche, and Alec (Tracy) Reusche; devoted grandfather to Bob Selbe, Melissa, Ted and Tom Reusche, and Kiel and Lily Marzahl; dear uncle; cherished brother-in-law; and devoted friend and colleague to many. Bob graduated from Ohio State in 1949 and received his MBA from the University of Chicago in 1955. He retired as vice chairman of the Northern Trust Company in 1990 after a 39-year career in the trust department, including 18 years at its helm. Bob was a senior advisor at the Chicago Community Trust; founder of the Lake County Community Foundation; founding board member of the Health Foundation of Northern Lake County; life trustee and chairman of the Ravinia Festival; chairman of PADS of Lake County; trustee of the West Virginia chapter of The Nature Conservancy; board director of St. Ignatius College Prep; board director of the Lumen Christi Institute of Catholic Thought at the University of Chicago; board president of the Policeman's Annuity and Benefit Fund of the City of Chicago; and life member of the Commercial Club. An avid supporter of his alma mater, Bob served Ohio State in numerous leadership capacities including board member of the University Foundation; member of the College of Arts and Sciences Advisory Board; and founding member of the Humanities Dean's Advisory Committee. As part of his legacy at Ohio State, Bob established lacrosse as a competitive sport in 1949 and in recent years provided counsel and support to the team. Donations may be made to the Robert F. Reusche Memorial Fund at the Lake County Community Foundation, 114 South Genesee Street, Suite 505, Waukegan, IL 60085.

Chargers (4-5) at Bears (6-3) Sunday, 4:15 p.m. Line: Bears by 3.5 . Lovie Smith does not get the credit he deserves. His coaching staff is filled with temperamental geniuses who have impulse control issues. The offense is loaded with divas: when Roy Williams comes across as normal, you know you are dealing with some Timothy Leary-level team chemistry. On paper, Smith's blitzed-up take on the stodgy Cover-2 defense, built around the talents of 30-something linebackers, looks about as dangerous as a Toyota Celica with mag wheels. This is a team that strives to beat opponents with punt returns, for heaven's sake. Yet Smith has coaxed winning records out of this collection of disparate parts and quarrelsome personalities four times in the last six years, and he currently has a team that was universally overlooked in the preseason in the thick of the wild-card race. Norv Turner has also mixed playoff runs with .500 seasons during his Chargers tenure, but he has done so under much more favorable conditions: his division is much softer, he has an indisputable franchise quarterback and he does not have to hold the reins on assistants like Mike Martz. Turner needs everything to break right to win, and this year nothing has. The Chargers' offensive line has been torn apart by injuries, with Marcus McNeill (neck) and Louis Vasquez (foot) unlikely to play Sunday and the All-Pro Kris Dielman (concussion) out for the year. Philip Rivers' mysterious slump is not so mysterious when his blockers are Brandyn Dombrowski and Scott Mruczkowski and his receivers include castoffs like Patrick Crayton. Turner cannot win when his quarterback is throwing interceptions, whereas Smith is only now learning what it is like to win otherwise: that is as clear a contrast as you need between these two teams. Pick: Bears.

GABRIEL--K. Georg, 83, died peacefully at home in Washington, D.C. Beloved husband of 50 years to Meg Gabriel; father of Robert Paul Gabriel (Megan Roberts Gabriel) and Margaret Wendy Gabriel (Alex Totino); grandfather of Margaret, Will, and Honor Gabriel; brother of Martin Gabriel of Halberstadt, Germany; and Peter Gabriel of Ashfield, MA. Georg received his MBA from the Harvard Business School and a PhD from Harvard University. From 1967 to 1988, he held senior management positions at the World Bank, including Controller; Director of Programming and Budgeting; and VP Finance-International Finance Corporation. Georg managed the World Bank Pension Fund from 1972-1988. Georg also served on the Investment Committee of the Eugene and Agnes Meyer Foundation and on the boards of several mutual and investment funds. From 1988-2005, Georg was a Senior Advisor at Strategic Investment Partners, a Washington DC-based asset-management firm. Georg was a long-time member of the Metropolitan Club of Washington, D.C. Georg's graciousness, selflessness, humility, and class are among his many fine qualities that will be missed by so many whose lives he touched. Private burial will be held at St. John's Church, Lafayette Square, Washington, D.C. Memorial Service to follow next spring.
DICKMAN--Andy, suddenly on November 12, 2011. Son of Florence (Goldman) Dickman of Dedham, MA and the late Seymour Dickman. Brother of Claudia Greenfield and Amy Kramer. Services were held.

It was a misty May morning near Moab, Utah, and I was marveling at a rock: Fisher Towers, to be exact, an enormous hunk of rosy sandstone eroded over the centuries to resemble the fortress of a hermetic medieval wizard who happened to settle in southern Utah. I had pitched a tent in a campground ($12 a night) in the valley below with an outdoorsy friend. We slept next to the Colorado River. There was an outhouse, a Dumpster and a fire pit. What had led me to this holiday? Perhaps it was Edward Abbey's ''Desert Solitaire: A Season in the Wilderness,'' his 1968 account of being a park ranger in nearby Arches National Park, which chronicles the seasons he spent patrolling vast expanses of rock and shrub and having passive-aggressive dealings with various critters. Perhaps it was the idea of turning ''luxury'' on its head: I would wear only Tevas (purchased on Moab's main street) and worn-out clothes with wicking; the chic local boutique would sell rocks; there would be no shower. Yet what wind and rain had conspired to create over the centuries - crazily beautiful friezes, surreal statuary, squint-and-you-could-be-in-the-Valley-of-the-Gods enormities, and arches galore - would make for a holiday of unreal privilege and glamour. For $12 a night.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel finds a cut-rate flight to Miami and a bargain hotel, and then takes on a tough challenge: finding ways to party all night on the cheap.

In 1919, the Italian tourism industry, like much of the country, had been devastated by war. Foreign visitors to Italy numbered 180,000, down from 700,000 a decade earlier. To combat the problem, the government created a promotional agency, ENIT, which in the process of selling Italy abroad made some enduringly beautiful images, often under the visual spell of Futurism or Art Deco. The ads are newly collected in ''Manifesti Posters: Traveling Around Italy Through Advertising 1895-1960'' (Silvana Editoriale, $75). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
The Principals The interior designers David Rockwell and Alexandra Champalimaud and the chef Wolfgang Puck teamed up to reinvent a classic from the 1940s.

WHEN Murray Moss of the SoHo design mecca Moss decided to re-cover this pair of vintage Eames Lounge Chairs in Hella Jongerius's eye-popping Repeat Dot fabric from Maharam, he took a ''Mad Men'' era design icon and catapulted it into the 21st century. The chairs, the first in a planned series of collaborations between Moss and the forward-thinking textile company, were made by Herman Miller with a veneer of Brazilian rosewood, the material that was originally specified, but which was discontinued in 1992 when it was listed as endangered. They are $16,000 each, $30,000 for the pair. But then, fabulous doesn't come cheap; mossonline.com. PILAR VILADAS

SUSSMAN--Lila. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the passing of their member, Mrs. Lila Sussman and offer their deepest sympathy to her husband, Richard and the entire Sussman and Wilsker Families. Alpine Country Club John Margaritis, President

THERE are days when it seems -- both in and out of the food world -- that Everything Is Going Wrong. That makes it easy enough to complain, and I'm not alone in doing so routinely. Nothing tastes the way it used to. Even pricey restaurants have lost their glow. Quality is shot. People die from eating melons. The dominance of hyper-processed, industrialized food (and, more to the point, food-like products) is spreading globally, and we're all gaining weight faster than ever, while wrecking the planet. Nevertheless, it's nearly as easy to find signs of hope -- lots of them -- as well as people and organizations who've been prodding American food back on a natural, sustainable, beautiful track.

The Practical Traveler column last Sunday, about deals being offered for Caribbean vacations this season, misstated the length of time a hotel in Jamaica spent on a recent refurbishment. The Strawberry Hill Hotel and Spa reopened last month after a refurbishment that took six weeks, not six months.

Of all the third-world metropolises, few are as maligned as Kolkata. To many, it is synonymous with bleakness, instinctually associated with slums, delirious traffic, Mother Teresa's Home for the Dying and weary rickshaw pullers. But it is also part of India's cultural bedrock, having produced some of its greatest writers, thinkers, artists and filmmakers. In June I traveled to the city with my father, Max Vadukul, to interview and photograph a cast of notable residents, from the artist Suhasini Kejriwal to the godfather of Indian cinema, Mrinal Sen.

Next up for the Big City Book Club is ''Breakfast at Tiffany's,'' Truman Capote's classic 1958 novella of bittersweet Manhattan self-invention, a story very different in tone from the 1961 Blake Edwards film it inspired. Join Ginia Bellafante, the Big City columnist, for a live online discussion of the book on the City Room blog on Tuesday, Nov. 29, from 1 to 4 p.m.

A review on Nov. 6 about ''Becoming Dickens: The Invention of a Novelist,'' by Robert Douglas-Fairhurst, and ''Charles Dickens,'' by Claire Tomalin, recounted an anecdote in Tomalin's book in which Dostoyevsky told of meeting Dickens. While others have also written of such a meeting and of a letter in which Dostoyevsky was said to have described it, some scholars have questioned the authenticity of the letter and whether the meeting ever occurred.

LOS ANGELES -- GE Energy announced Wednesday evening that its 240-volt wall-mounted WattStation electric vehicle charging unit would be official equipment for the coming Coda E.V. In its press release, GE called Coda ''a leading E.V. manufacturer.'' That's ironic, considering that Coda, a California start-up, has not sold a single vehicle. But the tie-up is one more sign that Coda, after a series of launch delays, may finally be ready to make its entrance into the emerging electric car market.

ALLAN--Marshall G. The board, staff, chapter leaders, instructors, students, and members of the Institute of Classical Architecture & Art mourn the death of trustee Marshall Allan, whose senses of curiosity and compassion for the communities he helped build and the interests he held closest live on in the hearts of those working alongside him. A love of design excellence and related historical inquiry ranked among them and all of us gained as a steadfast result. Peter Pennoyer, Chairman Paul Gunther, President

HADLEY--Peter Starr, 83, passed away Tuesday, November 15th, 2011 in Wallingford, CT. Born in Manhattan in 1928, Peter was a 1949 graduate of Harvard University and was awarded an MBA from Columbia University. He was a Korean War veteran, honorably discharged from the Army. Until October, Peter resided in Greenwich, CT. for 29 years. He was also a long-time resident of Inlet, NY in the Adirondack State Park. He was employed by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for 37 years, serving as Treasurer before being promoted to Senior Vice-President of Corporate Investments. Peter was an avid hiker who traversed large portions of the Appalachian Trail. He climbed all 47 of the White Mountains as well as many in his beloved Adirondacks. Peter was predeceased by his first wife, Patra Dawson Hadley and his step-grandson, Julian A. Ulloa. He is survived by his wife, Nancy E. Hadley; daughter Patra Starr Hadley of Glenview, IL; son Clifton Starr Hadley (Susan) of Flanders, NJ; step-son Alexander Ulloa (Donna) of Marlborough, CT; granddaughter Allison M. Hadley and step-grandson Michael A. Ulloa; sister Caroline Starr Wood of Croton-on-Hudson, NY and brother Charles Starr Hadley (Sally) of Cape Elizabeth, Maine; brother-in-law Richard Boner and sister-in-law Susan Pryor of Austin, TX, as well as several nieces and nephews. A celebration of Mr. Hadley's life will be held on Saturday, December 3rd at 1pm at the Hartog Center at Ashlar Village, Ashlar Village Rd., Wallingford, CT 06492 (www.ashlarvillage.org). Memorial contributions may be made to the Dingletown Community Church c/o Hyde Clarke, P.O. Box 951, Greenwich, CT., 06836-0951, or to the Inlet Volunteer Emergency Services, P.O. Box 300, Inlet, NY., 13360. www.wallingfordfh.com

Finding a seashell on the beach hardly seems like a life-changing event, but it was exactly that for this globe-trotting jewelry designer who divides her time among New York, India and Mexico. Six years ago, Beltrán plucked an Anadara shell from the sand while working as an assistant on a Bruce Weber shoot in Virginia Beach. She cast it in gold, made it into a bracelet and, voilà, Dezso, her line of sea- and sand-inspired jewels, was born. She spent three years in Jaipur learning about stones and honing her craft, and became addicted to India's vivid colors and rich culture. ''It's a crazily beautiful, exotic country,'' Beltrán says. ''I love the textiles, the architecture, the incredible artisans. It's like Candy Land for creative people.'' Go to dezsosara.com.

It can feel as though you've somehow gone back in time when you're driving up the looping curves of Route 17 in northern Vermont and take one last turn, toward the spine of the Green Mountains, to suddenly find what appears to be the movie set of a small 1960s ski resort brought painstakingly to life. There is a cluster of quaint yellow and blue rustic clapboard buildings. A rutted dirt parking lot. A single-chair lift rising into the clouds over narrow trails that seem to pitch and hurtle down the mountain. Here at Mad River Glen, you won't find high-powered quad chairlifts or gondolas. You'll find hardly any snow making or grooming. And you won't find snowboards at all - they aren't allowed. What you will find is a cult of simplicity and rugged outdoorsmanship, and a form-follows-function aesthetic in which some of the best skiers in the country are often kitted out in a kind of duct-tape-and-deerskin-gloves reverse chic. They pray at the altar of natural snow and are impatient with the kind of spoon-feeding that many ski resorts serve up these days, in which the bumps are literally smoothed out for their customers. ''The skiing is so different from the places where everything is just like a big superhighway because it's been plowed or groomed,'' says Elliot Wiener, an attorney from Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., who's been coming here for years. ''You get to Mad River Glen and it's like driving the back roads. What would you rather do - drive the interstate or drive the back roads?''

THE north end of the Valencia Street corridor of San Francisco still has its fair share of grit: you'll find the Mission Police Station and the odd shouting inebriated denizen on the same block as camera-phone-wielding French tourists and high-end home-design stores. But the strip is slowly being colonized by shops carrying funky, eco-friendly clothing lines; small-production cheeses; urban beekeeping supplies; and, of course, custom bikes. Indeed, in this bike-friendly neighborhood, it's smart to step lively and look before you cross to avoid being run over by the continuous parade of helmetless cyclists whizzing by. BONNIE TSUI
