Like most creatures on earth, humans come equipped with a circadian clock, a roughly 24-hour internal timer that keeps our sleep patterns in sync with our planet. At least until genetics, age and our personal habits get in the way. Even though the average adult needs eight hours of sleep per night, there are ''shortsleepers,'' who need far less, and morning people, who, research shows, often come from families of other morning people. Then there's the rest of us, who rely on alarm clocks. For those who fantasize about greeting the dawn, there is hope. Sleep experts say that with a little discipline (well, actually, a lot of discipline), most people can reset their circadian clocks. But it's not as simple as forcing yourself to go to bed earlier (you can't make a wide-awake brain sleep). It requires inducing a sort of jet lag without leaving your time zone. And sticking it out until your body clock resets itself. And then not resetting it again.

La Tête Dans Les Olives, a sliver of a food shop and restaurant in the 10th Arrondissement, is the work of Cédric Casanova, a slack-rope walker who spent 15 years performing in traveling circuses, most recently Cirque du Soleil. Casanova developed a passion for Sicily's fruity olives during summers he spent there as a child -- his father is Sicilian -- and wanted to share them with his hometown, Paris. The tiny épicerie offers oils and handpicked olives from his favorite growers, along with tapenades, sun-dried tomatoes and other seasonal delicacies. ''The way people react to good olive oil is like what I see in the circus,'' Casanova says. ''People smile. They love it.''

In ''The Boy Who Became Judy Garland,'' on the cover of Metropolitan last week, Dan Barry profiled Tommy Femia, 52, who had a tough time coming out as gay when he was a teenager but is now cheered by his family during his drag performances. Readers wrote to NYTimes.com to applaud his story, his parents and his act; below is a sampling of their responses. They also discussed Ginia Bellafante's Big City column criticizing tax breaks for the film and television industries at a time when schools are experiencing spending cuts. Our world would be a better place if all families shared this kind of love and support and acceptance of diversity. What a beautiful story. I wish the Femia family many more years of success and happiness.Maxim

Until recently, Wynwood's food scene consisted mostly of a few beloved food trucks that descend on the neighborhood during the monthly art walk. Then came Joey's 1 (2506 NW Second Avenue; 305-438-0488; joeyswynwood.com), run by Tony Goldman's son, which turns out fresh wood-fired pizzas like the Dolce e Piccante, with figs, gorgonzola, honey and hot pepper. Next door, a Shepard Fairey mural wraps the interior of the even newer WynwoodKitchenandBar 3 (2550NWSecond Avenue; 305-722-8959; wynwoodkitchenandbar.com), another Goldman family production, where tapas-style Latin dishes are served alongside cocktails created by artists whose work is featured at the Wynwood Walls. (The Kenny Scharf: Plymouth gin, grapefruit juice, Cointreau, lime and basil.) A rustic craft beer bar, Wood Tavern (2531 NW Second Avenue), is opening across the street this fall. And down the block is Panther Coffee 2 (2390 NW Second Avenue; 305-677-3952; panthercoffee.com), a specialty coffee roaster started by a couple from -- where else? -- Portland, Ore., that has a loyal following across the city and a graphic store front by one of the Wynwood muralists.

Over the 26 years they've spent growing up in the Marais, the identical twins Alex and Victor Carril have earned a reputation for street brawling - with each other - in their picturesque Paris neighborhood. When the director Pascal-Alex Vincent caught wind (as all locals eventually do) of these "hot twins who fight," he cast them in his short film "Bébé Requin," which competed at Cannes in 2005, and later as the leads in "Donne-Moi la Main," a movie inspired by their bellicose proclivities. As villains in this month's "Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows," the twins will undoubtedly earn even wider recognition. But until then they keep busy making hip-hop music videos and working on their fashion line, Is Not Dead. And they both hold court nightly in the cafes near their family home on the Place du Marché Sainte-Catherine.

On Nov. 13, the celebrated Modernist designer Eva Zeisel turned 105. As if this weren't impressive enough, Zeisel marked the occasion by publishing a memoir about the 16 months she spent in a Soviet prison in the 1930s, during which time she tried to commit suicide by cutting her wrists with a copper wire pulled from a toilet. "For many years Eva did not want to make her prison experiences public, in part because she was afraid that the K.G.B. would come after her in the U.S.," said her daughter, Jean Richards.

She was a designer learning the ropes at Levi's and Ralph Lauren. He was a photographer and drummer playing the Brooklyn music scene. They met after a concert, fell in love and started making clothes. Les Aperizes is Laurence Nguyen and Brian Tamborello's debut spring collection. And like their story, the couple's style is wildly romantic: preciously made petal-collar silk dresses, blouses detailed with hand-embroidered French knots and fluidly tailored trousers (all priced between $240 and $1,350). "Before ever sketching, we like to talk about a woman as if we're writing a character and imagine what she wears throughout different times in her life," says Nguyen, who sees herself as the line's dreamer and Tamborello as its down-to-earth craftsman. Regarding the latter, the cut is slouchy sexy and thoughtfully undone. Tamborello says: "We ask ourselves, 'Can we picture our clothes on every character? Will they age beautifully with her?' " Stores like Barneys New York and Ikram in Chicago sure think so.

Few holiday traditions are more Italian than making presepi -- the cribs that sit in Christmas nativity scenes. It's said that, all the way back in 1223, St. Francis of Assisi himself created the world's first nativity scene. Now, nearly 800 years later, many worry that the craft of creating and displaying handmade presepi is languishing.

The annual concert at Carnegie Hall to benefit music education programs for the poor will have a Rolling Stones theme this spring, the event's organizer, Michael Dorf, announced. Rosanne Cash, Steve Earle, the Carolina Chocolate Drops and others have signed on to perform all 21 tracks from the Rolling Stones classic collection "Hot Rocks 1964-1971," on the 40th anniversary of its release. The concert will take place March 13 and the proceeds will go to support nonprofit organizations that provide music classes to impoverished youths, among them the Church Street School of Music, Young Audiences, Music Unites and the Pinwheel Project. Mr. Dorf, who owns the City Winery, has raised about $600,000 for charity with similar concerts over the last seven years, asking contemporary musicians to pay tribute to the music of older artists. Past shows have focused on the songs of Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen and the Who, among others. This year, at least 21 solo artists and groups will be on the bill to interpret songs by the Stones, including the Mountain Goats, Rich Robinson of the Black Crowes and Glen Hansard.

JOHANNESBURG -- I am sitting in front of the entrance to my new two-story flat in upmarket Sandton in northern Johannesburg, admiring the colorful bed of flowers planted at my doorstep. Two women in their sixties walk around the block several times, and each time they pass I notice their increasingly sweaty brows, evidence of an impressive effort to stay fit. They look like they might be training for a race, complete with sport shoes and sweat bands on their wrists.

On Nov. 21, 1964, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was opened, connecting Staten Island and Brooklyn. It surpassed San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge as the world's largest suspension bridge, with a 4,260-foot-center span between two 693-foot towers. The bridge is so large that its design called for the towers to be angled slightly away from each other to compensate for the curvature of the Earth.A large ceremony was held for the opening of the upper deck of the two-deck bridge, attracting dignitaries like Mayor Robert Wagner, Gov. Nelson Rockefeller and Robert Moses, known as the "master builder" of mid-20th century New York City. The ironworkers who built the bridge, however, boycotted the ceremony when Moses did not invite them to participate.

BODDICKER--Arthur F.,of Garden City and Saltaire, NY on November 6, 2011 at the age of 89. Husband of the late Mary. Father of Christine Roach (Michael). Grandfather of Alison, Jennifer, Edward and Eliza. Brother of Lawrence (Phyllis). Flew 40 missions as a ball turret gunner with the 13th Air Force in the SW Pacific. Graduate of St. John's University. Retired as a Vice President of Manufacturers Hanover Banks after 48 years of service. KEY PERFORMANCE Punting against the Eagles at home hasn't always been pretty for the Giants, but Steve Weatherford was one of the few Giants who turned in a consistent effort Sunday. Weatherford, a former Jet, punted nine times for an average of 51.4 yards and had four punts downed inside the Eagles' 20-yard line.

It was a gooey, cheesy weekend at the multiplex as the movie series that teenage girls love and many adults love to hate -- ''The Twilight Saga'' -- returned with a sonic boom. ''Breaking Dawn -- Part I,'' the fourth and the worst-reviewed film in the franchise, as judged by RottenTomatoes.com, was an enormous No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $139.5 million. ''Breaking Dawn -- Part I,'' directed by the Oscar-winning Bill Condon, cost Summit Entertainment an estimated $110 million to make. Summit said that 80 percent of the audience was female; 60 percent of ticket buyers were over 21. The strong opening-weekend total demonstrated that young fans were sticking with the franchise as they age. It was also good news for Hollywood, which has been experiencing a box office slump of late and is urgently seeking momentum as it rolls out a parade of major films over the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays.

Black Friday 2011 offers tips and strategies; TGI Black Friday lets users shop online-only sales from their cellphone, and Shopkick's location function serves customers as they enter stores. SHELLY FREIERMAN

KHEEL--Marti. Scholar/activist, a gentle soul, a person of determination, courage, conviction and humor, died November 19th in Greenwich, CT of acute myeloid leukemia. She was 63 years old. Founder of Feminists for Animal Rights, author of Nature Ethics: An Ecofeminist Perspective and such landmark articles as The Liberation of Nature: A Circular Affair, From Heroic to Holistic Ethics: The Ecofeminist Challenge, and From Healing Herbs to Deadly Drugs: Western Medicine's War Against the Natural World, Marti wove a unique life, blending her activism on behalf of animals and the environment with her scholarship as a leading voice in ecofeminist ethics. Forever learning, Marti held a B.A. in history from the University of Wisconsin, an M.A. in sociology from McGill University, and a Ph.D. in religious studies from the Graduate Theological Union. Most recently she was a visiting scholar in the Department of Environmental Science, Policy, and Management at the University of California, Berkeley. Beloved by her sisters Ellen, Connie, Jane and Kate, brother Bob, brother-in-law Arnie, nieces and nephews AJ, Beryl, Dan, David, Dunya, Rick, Douglas, Sarah, Rachel, Rivka and Eliyahu, dear friends and colleagues from Berkeley to New York, to every corner of the planet, Marti loved every creature, loved language, loved laughter (and would tell you planets don't have corners). Marti was pre-deceased by her mother Ann Sunstein Kheel and her father Theodore Kheel of New York. Memorial plans in New York and Berkeley will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to any of these charities that she supported: Feminists for Animal Rights; Animal People; Food Empowerment Project; EMF-Safety Network; Stopsmartmeters.org; or International Fund for Africa.

An article last Sunday about collectors of discarded bottles and cans misstated the time frame during which bottle and can deposits became a fact of life in New York City. It was almost 30 years ago, not almost 20. (The state law was put into effect in 1983.)

KUH--Richard H. The firm of Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh, LLP mourns the passing of our distinguished founding partner, a highly respected member of the Bar and leader of our firm. After a long and effective career in public service, including a period as Manhattan District Attorney, Dick joined our firm and led our litigation department for over 25 years. Among the many clients he represented on highly complicated commercial litigation were major U.S. corporations, including Sony Music and the Mirage. He played a crucial role in the well-known von Bulow case and in the Estate of Dorris Duke. Always a true gentleman, Dick was nevertheless a vigorous and effective advocate for, and trusted advisor and friend of all his clients. For those of us in the firm who had the privilege of working with him on a daily basis, he was a wise and helpful partner who always applied the highest standards of our profession to his own work and expected his colleagues to follow suit. Among his many interests were, writing, reading, traveling, skiing, politics and most of all his family to whom he was a proud and devoted husband and father. He was respected by both friends and adversaries, as well as by judges, prosecutors and other members of the defense bar. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Joyce, his children Michael and Jody and their families, and his brother Joseph. Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh, LLP

BADY--Donald, President Emeritus and a Director of 870 UN Plaza. 860/870 UN Plaza mourns the passing of Donald Bady on November 18, 2011. The author of Colt Automatic Pistols 1896-1955 and a devoted and caring neighbor. His benevolence touched the lives of many and will continue to inspire us for years to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Bady's family.

GARELIK--Sanford (Sandy) D.,passed away on November 19, 2011, 93 years. Devoted husband of 57 years to his wonderful wife Catherine, who predeceased him 4 years ago. Beloved father and mentor to his son Neal and grandchildren Sarah, Nate and Liam and Rian. Beloved son of Yetta and Nathan, brother of Morty, Bernard and Clarence. Devoted uncle, cousin and family member. Lifelong Bronx native who was involved in all aspects of New York's civic affairs. Growing up, he worked in the family dairy business, before going to college at University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, where he graduated in 1938. Member of renowned class of 1940 from New York City's Police Academy. Also graduate of FBI Academy. Served in US Army Air Force intelligence overseas in various theaters during World War II. With the New York City Police Department, rose through the ranks from patrolman to Chief Inspector (Chief of Department), in the process becoming the first Jewish Chief Inspector and the then youngest Captain and Chief of the NYPD. Recipient of NYPD's Combat Cross and Medal of Valor. With U.S. State Department in early 1950's overseeing Latin American security, where he provided guidance on law enforcement and security to numerous Latin American countries. Elected as President of the New York City Council from 1970 through 1974. Served as Chief of New York City's Transit Police Department and Director of Security for the MTA from 1975 through 1980. From 1980 to 1994, established and served as Executive Director of the Garment Center Economic Security Council, which served as the pioneer for today's business improvement districts. Head of security for Fashion Center Business Improvement District from 1994 to 2004. In these posts, he was instrumental in the revitalization of Manhattan's garment center and surrounding neighborhoods. A true revolutionary during his six decades in law enforcement who pioneered numerous innovations and reforms that helped to create the modern police, law enforcement and intelligence practices. Served as a professor at, inter alia, West Point Military Academy and John Jay College. He was devoted to making his city and country a better place. Throughout his career, his mantra was to help and better the lives of all who came into contact with him. During all of his years of public duty, he always devoted himself to his wife, son and family. After retiring from public service, Sandy helped his son establish Excel Security, a fully integrated national security firm. A consummate gentleman and statesman, he was admired for his integrity, leadership, honor and accessibility. An extraordinary man, with grace, charisma and kindness. He is dearly missed by his family and friends. A memorial will be held on Monday, November 21, 2011 at 12noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan. Memorial donations preferred to the Sanford D. Garelik Memorial Fund at the NYPD's Captains Endowment Association, 233 Broadway, Suite 1801, New York, NY 10279.

KATZ--Simon. We are saddened today with loss of a great person Simon Katz . Mr. Katz was my idol, mentor, teacher and friend. Our heart goes out to his family Janice his lovely wife, his children Philip and Nancy, Howard and Patti, David and Judy, Joanna and Jeff as well all of his grandchildren and extended family. Simon Katz lived his life as a true mensch. He will truly be missed. Barry and Corinne Kirshenbaum

KUH--Richard H.,90, November 17, 2011. Survived by wife, Joyce, daughter, Jody, son, Michael, daughter-in-law, Katrina, grandchildren Theo and Hannah. Donations in lieu of flowers, Vera Institute of Justice, Harvard Law School, Grace Church School in Manhattan. Service on Tuesday, November 22 at 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel

ENGELBERG--Gertrude B. Herlands. Guetchen, matriarch of our family, adored sister of Charlie A"H and Els, loving aunt to her nieces and nephews. Her devoted children, Barbara and Myron, Jimmy A"H and Joyce, Jonny and Rachel and their families have continued to sing the beautiful melody that she composed; a harmonious blending of family, love and tradition. Min Hashamayim Tenuchamu. The Bendheim, Guedalia, Eisenberg, Sussman, Zussman and Levine Families

DAVIDSON--Alva, President of Olga Tritt, Inc. November 16 in Southbury, Connecticut. She was 97 and lived almost all of her life in Manhattan. In 1935, working in the Palm Beach Branch of the jewelry store founded by her mother, she met the love of her life, Harold P. Davidson. They were married for 64 years until his death. Survived by her children Lynn and John Davidson, and granddaughters, Jessica and Rachel Stults. She was a classy woman of style and determination. Alva specified that no services be held.

How do you sell something people can get free? That is a central question in the music industry today, particularly when it comes to music videos, which are abundantly available on YouTube, Vevo and other sites. But record companies sell videos on iTunes for $2 that fans can watch free elsewhere, and a handful of companies have specialized in archival footage, betting that collectors and connoisseurs will pay a dollar or two for a high-quality download.

During a very brief annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday, Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, said: ''We are in an era where the range of smart devices is continuing to expand. That is a fantastic thing for Microsoft.'' So far, so good. The explosion of smart devices, particularly phones and tablets, is notable. Almost all of them are devices running Apple's iOS and Google's Android software, though. Microsoft has its own mobile operating system in Windows Mobile, of course, and should get a boost next year from Windows 8 for phones and tablets. A seemingly careless statement to a French Web site by an executive at Nokia, Microsoft's close partner in phones, indicates that Nokia will have a Windows 8 tablet in June.

NASHUA, N.H. - Mitt Romney collected the backing of the freshman Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire on Sunday, a coveted endorsement from a conservative Republican and rising star in state politics, amid growing signs that leaders from the party's right wing are making peace with the possibility of Mr. Romney as their nominee. The endorsement from Ms. Ayotte, Mr. Romney's most prominent from a sitting elected official in New Hampshire, fueled a sense of momentum for his campaign in the state, a crucial primary battleground that he lost by a relatively narrow margin in 2008.

A Manhattan man who became fascinated by the American-born Muslim militant Anwar al-Awlaki was arrested on charges of plotting to build and detonate bombs in New York, city officials announced on Sunday night. At a hastily called City Hall news conference, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, who appeared alongside Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., said the man, Jose Pimentel, 27, had begun in August to plot a bomb attack. But it was the death of Mr. Awlaki, who was killed in a drone strike in Yemen in September, that refocused his efforts, Mr. Kelly said.

BERGER--Gladys Raab, age 82. Passed away following a sudden illness on November 19th. Beloved wife of Sidney Berger, adored by children Lisa and Michel Amzallag, Richard Berger and Katalin Gyorgyey, and Evan and Tiffany Berger. Cherished by grandchildren Daniel and Arielle Amzallag, and Zachary, Harry and Theresa Berger. She filled our lives with love and laughter, a light in our hearts that will never go out. She was unique and extraordinary, and gave strength and breadth to so many. Funeral services on Monday, November 21st at 12:30pm, Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St, Stamford CT.

I have piles of loyalty cards from my local coffee shop sprinkled around my house. Each one is half-empty, just a few stamps away from a free cup of coffee. The problem is, I keep losing the cards and have to start over. Square, the mobile-payments start-up, announced Tuesday that it is offering a solution to this problem with a customer loyalty feature it is adding to its mobile app.

NEVILLE--Thomas J. Jr.,63, a longtime resident of New York City, passed away suddenly on Friday, November 18, 2011. Born on June 15, 1948 in Medford, MA, Tom was the son of the late Thomas J. and Gertrude M. (Hahesy) Neville and the beloved husband of 25 years to Isabelle Bedard. He Graduated from Holy Cross in 1970 and earned a PhD from Princeton University in 1981. Prior to his retirement, Tom worked for Warner Amex Cable, was a Vice President of Viacom and ended his career as a director of BSkyB of London, England. Besides his wife Isabelle, Tom is survived by his son, Thomas G. Neville. Tom also leaves his twin brother Tim (Susan), his sister Mary (Peter) Hood and Rita (Bob) LaVigne. He also leaves his sister-in-law Catherine (Robert) Bayne along with numerous nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville Tuesday morning, November 22, 2011 between the hours of 11:00am to 12:30pm Mass of Christian burial at St Joseph's Church immediately following at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Tom's memory to a charity of your choice.

HOLLAND--Bert. Died November 15. Clinical psychologist and computer programmer in social science research at New York University. Born April 8, 1927 in New York. Bert attended Hessian Hills School, Croton-on-Hudson, NY, and Stuyvesant High School. Before service at Great Lakes Naval Training Center, he attended Franklin and Marshall College. Further education at Roosevelt University, The New School for Social Research, and graduate study in psychology at NYU. In 1954 Bert married Nora Bell (nee Potashnick) who died in 1991 of Alzheimer's, through which Bert cared for her with greatest devotion. Recently, Bert lived in Peabody, MA, near his close friend Davida Rosenblum. Active in leftist causes as a teenager, Bert always supported a broad range of social and political issues and enjoyed vigorous discussion. Survived by son Joel Holland, of Croton and New York City, stepdaughter Jordy Bell of Croton, two step-grandsons and three step-great-grandchildren. Donations to Amnesty International in his name welcome.

WYER--Joan Best, passed away surrounded by flowers in her home in Locust, NJ, in the early morning November 19, 2011, after a long illness. She was in her 90th year. For her beauty, her engaging personality, her numerous stories and sharp wit, she was admired by all. Joan was an accomplished horsewoman and an avid tennis, croquet and bridge player. She enjoyed membership in the Seabright Lawn Tennis & Cricket Club, Rumson Country Club, Rumson Garden Club, Seabright Beach Club and The Jupiter Island and Jupiter Island Garden Clubs in Florida. She is survived by her husband James I. Wyer, her daughter, Joan (Bitsy) C. Tatnall, two stepchildren, three grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. A service in her memory will be held at a time and place to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of Central Jersey and Planned Parenthood.

FLORES--Karen Weissman, 54, passed away on Saturday, November 19, 2011, with her loving family and friends by her side. Karen fought a courageous battle against metastatic breast cancer for over two years, leaving no stone unturned in her valiant will to live. Karen will be sorely missed by cherished husband Carlos, adored and adoring boys Daniel and Ross, devoted mother Helene, father in law Carlos, siblings Eileen Hoffman (Andy), Michael Weissman (Donna), nieces and nephews, Emily, Kate, Sarah and David and numerous relatives and friends, including Doris Block, who was by her side throughout her treatments, and her family Ira, Adam and Erica. Karen was predeceased by her father Morton Weissman. Karen was a teacher to many, not only in her job as Hebrew School teacher at Sinai Free Synagogue, but in her role as wife, mother, sister and friend, always making time to nurture and care for others and to share her home and her heart. Funeral services will take place on Monday, November 21 at 10:00am at Sinai Free Synagogue in Mount Vernon.

RUSSELL--Alan C. The staff of Russell Marketing Research, Inc., are deeply saddened by the passing of one of the company's Partners, Alan C. Russell. He was the founder of our company and a mentor to many of us. We will miss him. Our sympathies to his sons and their families.

8 P.M. (TCM) BATTLE OF THE BLONDES Turner Classic Movies devotes the month to 18 shades of bombshells, including Betty Grable, Jayne Mansfield, Marilyn Monroe, Lana Turner, Jean Harlow and Grace Kelly. The tribute picks up with ''My Sister Eileen'' (1955), in which Ohio siblings -- one pretty (Janet Leigh), one witty (Betty Garrett) -- plot to take New York City by storm, and ''Houdini'' (1953), at 10, with Leigh married to that magician and escape artist, played by her husband at the time, Tony Curtis. The evening continues at midnight with a Brigitte Bardot double bill: Roger Vadim's ''... And God Created Woman'' (1956), about an 18-year-old orphan in St. Tropez with an unbridled sexual appetite who loves one brother but marries another (Jean-Louis Trintignant, above with Bardot), and, at 1:45 a.m., Louis Malle's ''A Very Private Affair'' (1962), about an 18-year-old living on Lake Geneva who falls in love with her mother's former lover (Marcello Mastroianni). The night ends with Billy Wilder's ''A Foreign Affair'' (1948), at 3:45, starring Jean Arthur as a prim congresswoman and Marlene Dietrich as a nightclub singer who spar for the affections of an American officer (John Lund) in post-World War II Berlin. 8 P.M. (AMC) THERE WILL BE BLOOD (2007) Daniel Day-Lewis won the best-actor Oscar for his role as a California oil prospector who becomes morally bankrupt as his fortune grows. Paul Thomas Anderson directed and wrote the film, which was inspired by Upton Sinclair's 1927 novel, ''Oil!'' Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that Mr. Day-Lewis gave ''a thrilling performance, among the greatest I've seen, purposefully alienating and brilliantly located at the juncture between cinematic realism and theatrical spectacle.''

The Sunday Routine column in some editions last Sunday about Rafael Viñoly, the architect who designed Jazz at Lincoln Center, using information from a publicist, misstated the month that one of his projects, the first ''green'' police station for the New York Police Department, on Staten Island, is scheduled to open. It is July, not January.

An article last Sunday about the impressive rookie season of Cincinnati Bengals quarterback Andy Dalton misstated, in some editions, the year one of his predecessors, Carson Palmer, was drafted by the team. It was 2003, not 2004.

GRADY--Henry W. Died in New York City, November 16, 2011 in his 86th year. Graduate of Thayer Academy and Harvard College, he also served in World War II. An investment adviser at U.S. Trust (1955-1985) and chairman of Colonial Consulting Corp. (1985-1995), he was a retired director of Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corp. (U.S.A.). In addition to a long association with several charitable organizations in the city, he was a co-founder of the Bonnie Cashin Foundation. At his request there will be no funeral or memorial service. Those who wish may make gifts in his memory to Bat Conservation International, P.O. Box 162603, Austin, TX 78716, or a charity of their choice.

Janeane Garofalo, well-known for her comedic roles in television and film, will have a chance to show her dramatic chops on the stage for the first time in January, when she is set to appear in the New Group's production of ''Russian Transport,'' the company announced. Directed by Scott Elliott and written by Erika Sheffer, the play focuses on a Russian family living in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, and struggling to assimilate to American life. Ms. Garofalo will portray Diana, a wife and mother of two. In a telephone interview, she said she was ''as surprised as anyone'' about the casting. But it wasn't any kind of comedy-to-drama genre barrier that caught her off guard. ''I don't speak Russian,'' she said. ''The character is a Russian immigrant who speaks Russian so I double-checked that that was the part I was supposed to do.'' Nonetheless, Ms. Garofalo was drawn to the production by the strength of the script and was convinced by Mr. Elliott that she could play the part. ''I could probably fake my way through using broken English with a Russian accent, but he has this way of convincing you that you can do anything,'' she said. ''It's an exciting challenge, but at the same time I am terrified about seeming like the biggest fraud in the world.''

Transatlantic Holdings is in advanced talks to sell itself to a consortium led by the Alleghany Corporation, people briefed on the matter said Sunday night. Under the terms of the proposed deal, worth about $3.4 billion, Alleghany would pay $59 to $60 a share, one of these people said. The company is working with Joseph Brandon, a respected former chief executive of General Re, and Dan Jester, a former Treasury Department official and onetime Goldman Sachs executive.

Matthew Stafford threw five touchdown passes, the last a 7-yarder with less than three minutes left, to rally the Lions over the Panthers, 49-35. It was the third time that Detroit has won a game after trailing by at least 17 points. Kevin Smith caught Stafford's first scoring pass and also ran for two scores in the fourth quarter. Defensive end Chris Clemons had three of the Seahawks' five sacks and recovered two fumbles by Sam Bradford in a 24-7 win over the Rams.

LOEB--Fred, 97, died at home in Fort Lee, New Jersey, on November 18, 2011. Whether it was working in his beloved artificial flower business or playing tennis, he did everything with a fierce passion. He lived a long and full life and was the patriarch of a family that extended from the US to Brazil, England and India. A true American success story, he fled Nazi Germany in 1938, spent four years in the Army during World War II and then revolutionized the artificial flower business with his long-time partner and best friend Henry Weitz in the 1970's when they created Magicsilk. Husband of the late Hannah Herzberg Loeb, he is survived by his son Michael, his grandson Jonathan, his sister Ruth, 98, of Rio de Janeiro, and his beloved long-time companion Irma Escoto.

The Atlantic owes its name and legacy to the 154-year-old monthly magazine founded by New England literary greats likeRalph Waldo Emerson. But in October, the company marked a very modern milestone: digital advertising revenue exceeded print advertising revenue for the first time. For any magazine publisher to take in the bulk of its advertising revenue from online sources is incredibly rare. Publishing industry executives said they were not aware of any examples of a brand as prominent as the Atlantic doing so.

Could people talk about books with the same timely intensity that they do the latest episode of ''Mad Men'' or ''Top Chef''? The novelist Mark Z. The red pant had a good, long run as fashion's best-loved bottom, but it's about time a new color came into favor. The top contender: green, and more specifically pale, mellow, minty green, introduced in the resort collections as a prelude to spring's more pastel-centric palette (only a few months away). This green's dustier renditions - as seen on the spring runway at Theyskens' Theory - act similar to a khaki or olive green and can be worn as easily. "We treat it like a neutral," says Acne's Jonny Johansson, who did suede leggings in the softest jade hue. "It's like our gray." From the Row, a pair of silk pants in the prettiest sea foam need nothing more than a bit of shine - jacket or jewels - to make them evening-appropriate. "The mint would look great paired with any metallic, silver or gold," say the designers Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen about their elegant, Deco-esque pant. Now, that's refreshing.

A new study by Harvard researchers may provide another reason to skip the canned pumpkin and cranberry sauce this Thanksgiving. People who ate one serving of canned food daily over the course of five days, the study found, had significantly elevated levels -- more than a tenfold increase -- of bisphenol-A, or BPA, a substance that lines most food and drink cans.

It was the 10th of May when a letter marked "On Her Majesty's Service" dropped through our letter box. I wasn't home, because, in one of life's rare strokes of serendipity, I was presiding over the selection committee for London's Newgen at the British Fashion Council, the panel that X-rays young designers for runway-worthiness. My husband thought he ought to call, anyway. "Listen to this," he began, and as soon as I heard the words "Dear madam, the prime minister has asked me to inform you . . ." Jonathan Anderson's paisley-print pantsuit melted before me into a psychedelic fudge, ". . . that Her Majesty may be graciously pleased to approve that you be appointed a Member of the British Empire (M.B.E.) in the 2011 Birthday Honors List."

I support a one-man team. All you need to know about Arsenal, which has won five Premier League matches in a row, and has dragged itself all the way from 19th after three matches up to seventh, level on points with Chelsea and Liverpool above them, is defined by the winning goal Robin van Persie scored in Saturday's match at Norwich. Aaron Ramsey won the ball in midfield and was tripped, ending up on his stomach. Alex Song, who had an otherwise desultory, wasteful match, hurdled the prone Ramsey and advanced rapidly. He had Gervinho, streaking alone on the left, and van Persie, between two defenders on the right. He twitched, almost passing the ball to Gervinho, the lively Ivoirian who had already missed three sitters in the match, then changed his tune, rotated his body to pick out van Persie, who touched once, ran into space, and on his second touch lifted the ball over John Ruddy with his right foot, his weaker one, and just inside the near post.

In honor of Art Basel Miami, which opens next weekend, Christian Dior asked the Berlin artist Anselm Reyle to design a collection of colorful accessories. Of his collaboration with the Avenue Montaigne couture house, Reyle notes: "As an artist, I have a fascination with dubious taste, so collaborating with Dior, a symbol of 'good' taste was exciting." He didn't turn the house on its head so much as on its side. The neon stitching on Dior's quilted cannage bag has been tilted to reflect the artist's fiddling with tradition. The limited-edition flats, totes and jewelry will be available in Christian Dior boutiques come January. They might be camo, but don't expect to blend in.

The South African Parliament on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a new secrecy law that critics say is intended to shield a corrupt elite from press scrutiny, Alan Cowell reports. Despite last-minute objections from some of the leading figures of the anti-apartheid struggle, including Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, Nelson Mandela and the writer Nadine Gordimer, the bill was backed by the governing African National Congress and passed overwhelmingly. Supporters say the new law is needed to replace apartheid-era secrecy legislation. Opponents have said they will challenge it at the Constitutional Court once President Jacob Zuma signs it into law, as he is widely expected to. They are calling today Black Tuesday, evoking memories of a similarly titled press crackdown in the 1970s under white rule; on Twitter the hashtag #blacktuesday is trending in South Africa. Read more »

The so-called unveiling of holiday window displays has become something of a competitive tradition for Manhattan department stores. Last night, Saks heralded its windows with a performance by the American Ballet Theater. But tutus and fancy footwork proved no match, ultimately, for Lady Gaga and her hair. Gaga's "boudoir," designed by her stylist Nicola Formichetti for Barneys, presents a chaise, a vanity desk and a rather terrifying mannequin of the songstress herself, all made entirely out of hair - both human hair and the kind of artificial follicles used in wigs. Meanwhile, at Bergdorf Goodman, David Hoey unpacked a boatload of exquisite ephemera - as usual - along with leather monkeys, a plush mountain goat, a Baccarat chandelier and, every once in a while, an article of clothing.

Facebook has decided to create its own smartphone - code name Buffy, as in the vampire slayer - enlisting the Taiwanese company HTC to build it with the social network "integrated at the core of its being," according to report in AllThingsD, part of Dow Jones. (Neither Facebook nor HTC would confirm the report.) The phone will not make it to market for 12 to 18 months and is expected to use a modified version of the Android operating system created and released by Google, the Web site reported. While some online commentators questioned the wisdom of Facebook entering the hardware business from scratch, the AllThingsD account described the decision as about independence: "Google and Apple run the two major smartphone operating systems, giving Facebook little say over its mobile destiny."

LONDON - Is anything in art more overrated than distance? Distance, we're told, is what must come between a momentous event and any work of art created around that event, or else the art may be short on reflection and digestion. The long view, a step back, space to unknot our emotions - all are necessary for art. This point of view was thrown around with abandon on the 10th anniversary of 9/11: "too soon" was a phrase much overused to explain the absence still of any great art about that day. Yet if reflection and digestion have their place, there's a problem with distance and it's distance.

Though Juan Gatti's many accomplishments in photography, fashion and graphic design have established him as an artist with a wide range, he is probably best known for designing influential posters for Pedro Almodóvar's films. Starting with a poster for "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown" in 1988, Mr. Gatti has collaborated with the filmmaker many times, leaving his mark on the visual aesthetics of many of the director's films. Indeed, posters for films including "Talk to Her," "Broken Embraces" and this year's "The Skin I Live In" line the walls of "Contraluz," the first exhibition that traverses the length of Mr. Gatti's career -- although the actual focus of the show lies elsewhere.

On Nov. 22, 1963, President John F. Kennedy was fatally shot while riding in an open-top car through Dealey Plaza in Dallas. Two bullets struck the president, the first in his back and throat and the second in the back of his head. Gov. John Connally of Texas, another passenger, was also shot, though he survived. Jacqueline Kennedy and Nellie Connally, the men's wives, were also in the car but were not injured.The New York Times reported on the assassination: "Mr. Kennedy apparently was hit by the first of what witnesses believed were three shots. He was driven at high speed to Dallas's Parkland Hospital. There, in an emergency operating room, with only physicians and nurses in attendance, he died without regaining consciousness."

GRADY--Henry W. Died in New York City, November 16, 2011 in his 86th year. Graduate of Thayer Academy and Harvard College, he also served in World War II. An investment adviser at U.S. Trust (1955-1985) and chairman of Colonial Consulting Corp. (1985-1995), he was a retired director of Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corp. (U.S.A.). In addition to a long association with several charitable organizations in the city, he was a co-founder of the Bonnie Cashin Foundation. At his request there will be no funeral or memorial service. Those who wish may make gifts in his memory to Bat Conservation International, P.O. Box 162603, Austin, TX 78716, or a charity of their choice.

6:10 A.M. (HBO Signature) TWO FOR THE ROAD (1967) A successful architect (Albert Finney) and his wife (Audrey Hepburn, above, with Mr. Finney) travel through the South of France in their Mercedes-Benz 230 SL roadster while reminiscing about the various Continental excursions during their rocky, 12-year relationship. Stanley Donen directed this bittersweet British comedy, considered experimental at the time with its nonlinear juxtaposition of scenes past and present. Frederic Raphael wrote the Oscar-nominated screenplay, and Henry Mancini composed the theme song, which he said was his favorite, with lyrics by Leslie Bricusse. ''What the film has to say about the state of matrimony and the restlessness of modern husbands and wives is more in the jumble of details and the eccentricity of the montage than it is in the exposition of a rational development,'' Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. ''The method'' -- which Mr. Crowther called just a lot of dazzle -- ''is the message, as it were.'' 8 P.M. (CNN) CNN NATIONAL SECURITY DEBATE Wolf Blitzer moderates this Republican presidential debate, broadcast from DAR Constitution Hall in Washington. Mr. Blitzer and members from the debate's sponsors, the Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institute, will pose questions to the candidates on national security, foreign policy and the economy.

The likely failure of the special Congressional deficit committee to reach an agreement will come as no surprise to most Americans, with recent polls showing broad majorities lacking confidence in the committee's ability to reach a deal. In a McClatchy-Marist poll, 85 percent of registered voters said they were not confident that Congressional Democrats and Republicans on the committee would be able to come to an agreement on how to significantly reduce the federal budget deficit. Similarly, nearly 8 in 10 Americans in a CNN/ORC poll called an agreement unlikely.

TRYNIN--Nathan (Nick) K. Died November 18, 2011 at his home on Shelter Island, NY, where he lived with his beloved partner and wife of 33 years, Judith Sutton. He was 81. Nick grew up in New York City son of Ada Wilentz Trynin and Theodore N. Trynin. He was very attached to his high school, Poly Prep, where he was captain of the baseball team, and served 19 years on its Board of Trustees. He graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School. Nick went on to serve his country in the Judge Advocate General's Department of the Air Force and then later became Assistant US Attorney for the Eastern District of NY, serving under the Honorable Leonard P. Moore. The majority of his professional life was spent at Amerada Hess Corporation as a senior executive. Nick was an appreciator of all cultures through his extensive international travels. His life was filled with family, many meaningful long term friendships, and hobbies which included sailing and golf. A creature of habit and a repeater of a good joke, Nick favored filet of sole, chocolate ice cream and a gin martini, best enjoyed out at the end of his Shelter Island dock with his friend Marvin. This coming Thanksgiving will be the first time in 27 years that Nick will not host his favorite event of the year, his Thanksgiving Harvard Club Dinner for family and friends, which he organized with his wife, Judy and his dear sister, Kate. He was predeceased by his other NYC "club" of 50 years, Gino on Lexington Ave. Nick is survived by his wife Judith Sutton, his sister Kate Kestnbaum, his daughter Jennifer S. Trynin and son-in-law, Mike Denneen, his son Thomas C. Trynin and daughter-in-law, Robin Trynin, and his two adored grandchildren, Gracie Denneen and Sadie Trynin. Services will be held on Wednesday, November 23 at 10:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to his favorite Shelter Island charities.

Ted was one of a kind and he will be greatly missed.

SHAPIRO--Lynn Mayson, 54, a dancer, choreographer, and writer, died November 19, at Beth Israel Hospital, succumbing to complications from breast cancer. For more than 30 years, she was a resident of Soho, her base as a performer and as a choreographer, and where, in 1999, she began her work as a writer. Ms. Shapiro was born in Washington D.C., and raised in Cambridge, MA. She attended Smith College and graduated from NYU with a Bachelor's Degree in Fine Arts. She choreographed for her own company, The Lynn Shapiro Dance Company, and won several awards for her work, among them fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, The Jerome Foundation, and The New York Foundation for the Arts. In recent years, Ms. Shapiro concentrated on writing. Her poem, Sloan Kettering, won The Pushcart Prize in 2008. Other poems have appeared in the publications, Rattle and Mudfish. A piece excerpted from her memoir entitled, Savage Love at Beth Israel, was published in the literary journal, Fifth Wednesday, and was nominated by board of editors for a Pushcart Prize. Ms. Shapiro is survived by her husband, the cellist Erik Friedlander, with whom she often collaborated; by their daughter, Ava Shepherd Friedlander; and by her parents, David and Jane Shapiro of Cambridge, MA.

On Jessica Haley's 28th birthday in June, she posted a wish on the fund-raising Web site IndieGoGo. Ms. Haley and her husband, Sean, of Melbourne, Fla., wanted a baby, but their insurance did not cover fertility treatment. To their astonishment, donations started pouring in. Word of the couple's plight spread on Twitter and Facebook, and a ''Help the Haleys Have a Baby'' campaign raised $8,050 -- including $423 from a total stranger.

The National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, which oversees the Grammy awards, is adding another 25 recordings to its Grammy Hall of Fame, which honors works at least 25 years old that ''exhibit qualitative or historical significance.'' The works to be inducted in 2012 are an unusually diverse lot, ranging from Cole Porter's ''Anything Goes,'' a single from 1934, and the Rolling Stones' ''Exile on Main Street,'' an album from 1972, to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr's historic ''I Have a Dream'' speech, taken from a spoken-word album issued in 1963, and the influential ''Anthology of American Folk Music,'' from 1952. The selections are particularly heavy in recognizing old blues songs that, though minimized as ''race records'' when originally released in 78-rpm versions, went on to influence later generations of popular musicians. The songs in that category include such blues standards as Bukka White's ''Fixin' to Die'' and Big Bill Broonzy's ''Key to the Highway,'' both released on the Okeh label in the early 1940s, as well as Leroy Carr's ''How Long, How Long'' and Furry Lewis's ''Kassie Jones,'' both from 1928. ''The Message,'' a seminal rap recording Grandmaster Flash & the Furious Five from 1982, was also included.

An obituary on Saturday about the former Manhattan district attorney Richard H. Kuh misstated the circumstances under which Malcolm Wilson, who nominated Mr. Kuh in 1974, became governor of New York. Mr. Wilson succeeded Nelson A. Rockefeller when Mr. Rockefeller resigned in December 1973 to become chairman of the Commission on Critical Choices for Americans; he did not become governor in August 1974 when President Gerald R. Ford appointed Mr. Rockefeller vice president.

SEGAL--Ellis R.,84, died on November 20, 2011 in Philadelphia. For the last twenty years, Ellis was co-owner of Dion-Segal Associates, a real estate development company, and previously co-owned and operated Dee's Appliances, one of the largest appliance chains in the Philadelphia metropolitan area. Ellis served in the United States Navy during World War II. He also served on the Board of Directors of Ben Gurion University, the Maltz Jupiter Theater, and was actively involved in the National Liberty Museum. However, the true pride and joy of Ellis' life was his family. He is survived by his beloved wife of 61 years, Sylvia Dion Segal, his daughters Adele Cohen (James Dipollito), Robin Viola (Greg) and Karen Segal (David Green), and his grandchildren Matthew, Rachel, Amelia, Alexander and Rebecca. Relatives and friends are invited to services Wednesday, November 23, 2011 at 10:30am at Joseph Levine and Sons Memorial Chapel, 4737 Street Road, Trevose, PA. Interment Roosevelt Memorial Park. Henry R. Kravis, the private equity titan, was born in Tulsa, Okla., the son of an oilman. With his latest deal, Mr. Kravis appears to be going back to the well. His private equity firm, KKR & Company, is near an agreement to buy most of the Samson Investment Company, a privately held Tulsa oil and gas company, for more than $7 billion, according to two people with knowledge of the deal who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it.

A law firm that had become a lightning rod in the controversy over mortgage-foreclosure practices has shut down, costing 89 employees their jobs. The Steven J. Baum P.C. law firm, which has offices in Amherst, N.Y., and Westbury, N.Y., has filed papers with government agencies notifying them that it plans to close. It made the filings under a federal law requiring employers to provide notice before mass layoffs.

WYER--Joan Best, passed away surrounded by flowers in her home in Locust, NJ, in the early morning November 19, 2011, after a long illness. She was in her 90th year. For her beauty, her engaging personality, her numerous stories and sharp wit, she was admired by all. Joan was an accomplished horsewoman and an avid tennis, croquet and bridge player. She enjoyed membership in the Seabright Lawn Tennis & Cricket Club, Rumson Country Club, Rumson Garden Club, Seabright Beach Club and The Jupiter Island and Jupiter Island Garden Clubs in Florida. She is survived by her husband James I. Wyer, her daughter, Joan (Bitsy) C. Tatnall, two stepchildren, three grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. A service in her memory will be held at a time and place to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of Central Jersey and Planned Parenthood.

LinkedIn had a bonanza of an initial public offering in May, when its stock price doubled and many of its employees became paper millionaires. Six months later, some of those insiders are cashing in - and the company's stock price slumped.

THE FACTS Ear infections can be one of the most persistent ailments of childhood, striking frequently and leaving children in agony. Many doctors prescribe antibiotics, but in many cases the drugs cause complications. One preventive measure that may hold promise is chewing gum that contains xylitol, a natural form of sugar.

An article on Friday about Energy Secretary Steven Chu's testimony to Congress about Solyndra, a failed solar panel maker, misstated then year that Dr. Chu assumed his cabinet post. It was January 2009, not 2008.

MARGOLIS--Barbara. The Camp Greylock directors and alumni mourn the passing of Bobbie Margolis. She was a beloved member of the Greylock family who passed away peacefully in her home in New York City on Friday. Bobbie with her late husband Bert Margolis owned and operated Greylock for many years until the early 1990's. Bobbie's terrific wit, caring, and zest for life added to the happiness of hundreds of staff and children each summer. Her charismatic style brought people together. She will be remembered and greatly missed.

CABOT--Francis H. The Board of Directors and staff of Wave Hill mourn the passing of Frank Cabot, a devoted and unwavering champion beginning with the creation of Wave Hill as a public institution nearly a half-century ago. A luminary among horticulturists, he provided vision, vitality, and leadership in our pivotal early years as Wave Hill transitioned from the Perkins family's private Bronx estate to a world-renowned public garden. He established Wave Hill's Friends of Horticulture to encourage support for Wave Hill's future and to promote its international reputation. We will miss his quick wit, astute advice, and instinctive perfection. Our heartfelt condolences extend to his family, especially his loving wife, our dear friend and longtime Board colleague Anne Perkins Cabot. Cathy Marks Weinroth, Chair Claudia Bonn, President Scott Canning, Director of Horticulture

An article on Monday about the men's basketball team at Chaminade University in Honolulu, which annually hosts the Maui Invitational tournament, misidentified the Roman Catholic order that runs the university. It is Marianist, not Marist.
An article on Sunday about the emphasis on theoretical over practical learning in law schools misidentified a first-year course about common law crimes. It is Criminal Law, not Criminal Procedure.

CASTRO--Joanne Hearst, died November 15, 2011, in her sleep at her home near Seville, Spain. She was 70. A granddaughter of William Randolph Hearst, Castro was a resident of Tulsa, OK, and Santiago, Chile. She also maintained homes in Barbados, Miami and near Seville, Spain. Castro was born in California on December 17, 1940, to John Randolph Hearst and Fanne Wade. She studied at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Albany, NY, and at Briarcliffe College. Castro was an avid horse owner and breeder, and also raised Cavalier King Charles Spaniels. She is survived by her husband, Jose Castro Rivera; children, Christian Tarafa, Stefan Lawrence and Andrea Veronica Lawrence, from former marriages; and eight grandchildren. Other survivors include her brother William R. Hearst II, and sister Deborah Hearst. Castro is predeceased by her son John Hearst Herndon and her brother John R. "Bunky" Hearst, Jr. Final services are pending.

SANDS--John Keating, of Glen Cove, NY died at home on November 19, 2011. Born March 1, 1922, the son of William F. Sands and Edith Keating Sands of Washington, DC, he attended Landon School and graduated from Portsmouth Abbey School, the University of North Carolina, and New York University Graduate School of Finance. He served in the US Navy during World War II and the Korean Conflict and began his professional career at McKinsey & Company. He was later employed by Dillon, Read & Co, W.C. Langley & Company, and Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. He served as a director of New York Capital Resources, Auerbach Pollak & Richardson, Laidlaw Equities, and Saugatuck Capital among others. Survivors include Elizabeth Petty, Catherine Sands, John Sands, Jr., and Margaret Witham, their spouses, nine grandchildren and his former wife Patricia Pulling Sands. He was predeceased by his three brothers, James, William F. and Robert J. Sands. Funeral Mass: 11am Saturday, November 26 at St. Hyacinth Church, 319 Cedar Swamp Road, Glen Head, NY 11545. In lieu of flowers, gifts to: Portsmouth Abbey School, 285 Corys Lane, Portsmouth, RI 02871.

The Personal Health column on Nov. 1, about osteoporosis, misstated the upper figure for the range of bone density measurements that defines osteopenia, a condition that may precede osteoporosis. Osteopenia is defined as a ''T-score'' between minus 1.0 and minus 2.5 -- not between minus 0.1 and minus 2.5.

Beginning next fall the Juilliard School and the Signature Theater company will collaborate on a new program for Juilliard's drama students, to be based at the new rehearsal and performance space being built for Signature on West 42nd Street. The partnership coincides with the creation of a new master's degree in theater that Juilliard will offer as of next year and is meant to give drama students there a transition to a working actor's career through readings and workshops in a professional setting. The link between the programs is James Houghton, who is both the founding artistic director of Signature and the director of the drama division at Juilliard. ''This has been in the works for several years,'' Mr. Houghton said in a telephone interview, adding that as it became clear that Signature was going to be able to achieve its goal of building ''the largest new theater arts complex in New York City since Lincoln Center,'' more and more ''it felt like these two things were meant to be together.''

It was supposed to be a special learning opportunity for the sixth graders at Public School 101 School in the Gardens in Forest Hills, Queens. A popular second-grade teacher was invited to their social studies class to give a lecture about Israel, as part of a unit on the Middle East. But at home that evening, Elli Surico, 10, started talking about how great Israel is and asking why the Arabs wanted to kill the Jews, alarming her mother, Dana Milstein. It turns out that Elli and her family are both Arab and Jewish, of Moroccan descent, and Ms. Milstein found her daughter's words deeply disturbing.

CABOT--Francis H. The directors and staff of the Garden Conservancy mourn the loss of our distinguished founder. In 1989, Frank created the Garden Conservancy, a national organization dedicated to saving exceptional American gardens. He personally gathered support and respect for the fledgling organization, traveling tirelessly to spread the word, and was responsible for the Conservancy's early success and leadership in the field. His passion for gardens also led to the creation of two significant personal gardens: Stonecrop in Cold Spring, New York, and Quatre Vents in Charlevoix County, Quebec. The garden in Canada was the subject of his award-winning book, The Greater Perfection, and was described as "the most aesthetically satisfying and horticulturally exciting landscape experience in North America." Frank was honored by horticultural groups around the world, and was a sought-after speaker and advisor to many more. We will all miss Frank's vision, dedication, and generosity; he was an inspiration. We send our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Anne, to Colin, Currie, and Marianne and all his family and friends. Benjamin F. Lenhardt, Jr., Chairman Courtnay S. Daniels, Vice-Chairman Antonia F. Adezio, President Morris Cheston, Jr., Vice-President Howard G. Seitz, Secretary/Treasurer

MENDELL--Lesley S.,born February 5, 1917 to Esther and Louis and passed away November 19th after a long illness. He is survived by his beloved wife Rosalind, children Laura and Henry, and grandchildren Dara Hazeghi and Madeleine Mendell. Lesley attended City College of New York. He and Rosalind married the day after Pearl Harbor. During World War II, he served in the intelligence station at Vint Hill, Virginia, where he worked on cryptography, and after the war finished all but his thesis for the PHD at the New School for Social Research, when he became fully occupied with his fabric business. He had a wholesale fabric business in New York and four fabric stores in the Washington D.C. area, where his former employees still remember him for his kindness and generosity. Funeral services will be at Weinstein Chapel on Tuesday, November 22nd at 11:30 with subsequent interment at Beth-El Cemetery in Paramus, NJ.

ROCK--Mildred, 93, died on Monday, November 21st. She was the wife of the late Morris D. Rock and loving mother of Randy (Marcy Wolf). Also survived by adoring grandchildren, Michael and Andrew. A private burial will be held.

An article on Friday about the sale of The San Diego Union-Tribune to Doug Manchester, a local developer, misstated the holdings of his company, the Manchester Financial Group, because of outdated information on its Web site. While the company owned the Manchester Grand Hyatt San Diego and the San Diego Marriott Hotel and Marina at one point, it has since sold both.

The opening of ''The Twenty-Seventh Man,'' the first play by the novelist Nathan Englander, originally scheduled to run at the Public Theater next spring, has been pushed back until November 2012, the theater announced Monday. In its place, the Public will be reviving ''Gatz,'' the popular Elevator Repair Service theatrical adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''The Great Gatsby,'' for seven weeks between March and May. Mr. Englander, 41, is the author of two widely-praised works: ''The Ministry of Special Cases,'' a novel, and ''For the Relief of Unbearable Urges,'' a collection of short stories that includes ''The Twenty-Seventh Man.'' The Public's statement attributed the postponement of the play to an ''artist scheduling conflict,'' which Mr. Englander said applied both to him and others involved in the project.

PELLEGRINO--Joseph Peter of Boston and Osterville, Massachusetts and Mill Reef, Antigua, West Indies died Saturday, November 19th, after a long illness. Raised in Andover, Massachusetts, Mr. Pellegrino graduated from Phillips Andover Academy and Harvard College. After college, Mr. Pellegrino served in the United States Marine Corps, rising to the rank of Captain before his honorable discharge in 1968. After his military service, he joined his family's business, the Prince Company of Lowell, Massachusetts. He became President and Chief Executive Officer in 1973 and remained in that capacity until the company's sale to The Borden Company in 1987. The funeral is private. In lieu of flowers, gifts in memory of Joseph P. Pellegrino may be directed to the MGH Cancer Center in support of Dr. Matthew Smith and the Kaufman Chair. Checks may be made out to Massachusetts General Hospital c/o Development Office, 165 Cambridge Street, Suite 600, Boston, MA 02114.

Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, who have not toured since 2009, will be going out on the road beginning in mid-2012 on what Mr. Springsteen's Web site describes as a global tour, with some dates in Europe already announced and performances in North America and other locations confirmed. The shows will be the first for the band since Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist who for decades served as Mr. Springsteen's onstage foil, died of complications of a stroke in June. Mr. Springsteen's site said the tour would begin in May, in continental Europe, and move to Britain a month later. The shows that the Springsteen band will play include a festival on the Isle of Wight on June 24. No information was provided about when the American leg of the tour will begin and what cities will be included. But Mr. Springsteen did say that a new album is ''almost done (but still untitled)'' and is likely to be released next year.

The scheduled opening next year of the National September 11 Memorial Museum has been delayed because of a $156 million dispute between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the foundation responsible for running the museum, according to people familiar with the discussions. The Port Authority, which is responsible for the construction, has stopped approving new contracts, slowing work on the underground museum, which was to open on Sept. 11. The organizations have been arguing over the money for nearly 18 months, and tensions rose recently as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has sought to exert more control over construction projects in the city. Last month Mr. Cuomo nominated one of his deputies, Patrick Foye, to run the Port Authority and asked the agency to take over the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, a joint city and state enterprise that has been working on the redevelopment of the World Trade Center site. The National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center Foundation, whose chairman is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has maintained that poor management and delays by the Port Authority between 2006 and 2008 cost it more than $100 million. The delay in approving construction contracts was reported by The Wall Street Journal on Monday. Michael Frazier, the foundation's communications director, said Monday, ''We are working with the leadership of the Port Authority to come to an immediate resolution that allows this historic project to move forward.'' Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said, ''We're working cooperatively with New York City and the memorial foundation'' and that ''work is continuing.''

CAIRO -- The cabinet offered its resignation on Monday to Egypt's transitional military rulers as security forces carried out an increasingly lethal crackdown on three days of violent street protests, reviving the uncertainty about Egypt's future that marked the earliest days of the Arab Spring. Egypt's military had been seen as the linchpin of the political transition after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

Earlier this fall, Steve Ferdman celebrated getting a job offer from Credit Suisse in the usual Wall Street fashion. Over expensive oysters and dark rum cocktails at a trendy Manhattan restaurant with his parents, he toasted landing the full-time position after working six months as a consultant without benefits. A week later, Mr. Ferdman, 28, sat alone at the same place and ordered a gin and tonic to lament getting laid off by the bank, for the second time since 2008. When he told the bartender about his misfortune, his next round was on the house.

India's two key stock indexes plunged more than 2 percent on Wednesday, weighed down by a slumping rupee and a global economic downturn that shows no sign of abating, Mint reports. The Sensex dropped 2.27 percent Wednesday, and is down 10.6 percent in the last 10 trading sessions, the paper reports. The broader Nifty dropped 2.2 percent. The rupee's slide continued, which raises the price of crucial imports and further imperils the government's hopes of robust growth this year.

A lawsuit filed by 44 survivors and the families of 4 people who were killed when a stage collapsed in August at the Indiana State Fair has named the country band Sugarland in the suit, along with producers and other organizers of the concert, The Associated Press reported. Sugarland, the country music duo of Jennifer Nettles and Kristian Bush, was minutes away from performing at the fairgrounds in Indianapolis on the evening of Aug. 13 when a gust of wind that exceeded 60 miles per hour caused the stage to collapse. The accident, which occurred hours after a severe thunderstorm watch was issued, resulted in the deaths of seven people and injuries to dozens more, and video of the frightening scene spread rapidly across the Internet.

While the two-hour season finale of "Dancing with the Stars" on ABC was the highest rated program of the night on Tuesday, it was unable to reach the bars set by previous season-ending episodes of that show. When J.R. Martinez won the title, 19.4 million total viewers tuned in, down from 24 million last year, with a 23 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. It was the lowest rated fall finale ever for "Dancing" in the 18-to-49 category.

MINNEAPOLIS - Merce Cunningham, John Cage and Robert Rauschenberg are seated in a row and talking about their artistic partnership, delighted to be together. This is in a 1987 filmed interview that's playing on perpetual loop in the current "Cunningham/Rauschenberg" exhibition at the Walker Art Center here. "There was a carte blanche trust," says Rauschenberg about their radically modernist collaborations between 1952 and 1977, in which music, dance, and design were brought together only in performance or at dress rehearsal. "Independence was to be respected."

Please meet last week's cover photographer, Olivia Bee. She's 17, and it's a challenge to describe her without using the word "wunderkind." She started taking photos at 11, quickly established a devoted cult following and has since exhibited her work all around the world. Olivia has an exceptional way of capturing the sweet side of being a teenager. Her photos are romantic and innocent-seeming, even when the kids in the pictures are doing not-so-innocent things. So of course we thought she'd be perfect to shoot our cover story about sex-positive sex education. The concept was to illustrate teenage lust without actually showing anything. No faces and nothing explicit, just gestures.

They say that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Apply this wisdom to gift giving and one can offer up even the most practical thing -- a cooking app or caramels or a bottle of the best sunscreen -- and call it a present. We love this lemon soap on a rope because it's simple and useful, but to give it as a gift we know it must be packaged properly, with a citron suit from Stella McCartney, a clutch from Marc Jacobs and wooden bracelets that look beautifully fresh and clean. We love Adidas sandals. The original three-stripe slip-ons feel so right again, especially when given with an Eres bikini in a small-batch tote by the Los Angeles designer Jesse Kamm. This holiday season nothing is too obvious, everyday or inexpensive to please even the most discerning friend or relative. It's all about the company these gifts keep, their context, the complete package. The whole is greater than the sum. Just think about it a bit - about what she might need and what he uses every day. Build on that and we promise it'll add up.

YAFRAN, Libya - In a country where creativity was stifled to ensure the pre-eminence of one man, art can be the best revenge. Inside the gutted shell of a building that once housed a Qaddafi-regime intelligence unit, the paint of a new mural of a tree whose roots are feeding on the blood of fallen rebel fighters is drying on the wall. The house was half-destroyed in fighting between Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces and the rebels who brought him down - and that's exactly the way the artist Belgassem Grada hopes it will stay.

In 2001, I was standing on a street, watching a plane hit a tower and watching bodies, the bodies of people who were jumping out of windows, watching them fall through the sky and down. I ran that day, away from the fiery towers and dust. And in the days that followed, I ran away from the rubble, away from New York City - all the way to another state, where I would meet a man who was in the military, who would become my husband.

"The very nicest thing Hollywood can possibly think of to say to a writer," Raymond Chandler wrote, "is that he is too good to be only a writer." Chandler may have been only a writer himself, but he was a singularly influential one, whose body of work includes the classic detective novels "The Big Sleep" and "Farewell, My Lovely" and contributions to the screenplays for "Double Indemnity" (written with Billy Wilder) and "Strangers on a Train." Now a sale of books and papers from Chandler's personal collection offers a unique look at his legacy and literary influence, not to mention his uneasy relationship with that "showman's paradise," as he called it, known as Hollywood.

The Tribune Company, which is trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, agreed to pay its former chief executive, Randy Michaels, $675,000 in a settlement stemming from his abrupt resignation from the company last year, The Chicago Tribune reported. The company will also cover $50,000 in Mr. Michaels's legal fees. Mr. Michaels resigned under pressure, following reporting in The New York Times that detailed numerous instances of outlandish, often sexual behavior by Mr. Michaels and other top executives. The Tribune reported that he had demanded $900,000, the pro-rated portion of his 2010 management bonus, arguing that he "was effectively 'terminated without cause,' which would trigger the payment under terms of the bonus plan." The payment needs to be approved by a bankruptcy court judge.In Tuesday night's Republican presidential debate on CNN, which was devoted to national security issues, The Caucus live blog took note of the higher profile of Representative Ron Paul, the libertarian from Texas, who often can be hard to spot at these seemingly weekly encounters. As Trip Gabriel wrote for The Caucus, Mr. Paul's campaign "had claimed after the last debate hosted by CBS News that he got only 90 seconds of air time," but Tuesday night he played a more central role, serving as a dramatic foil to his rivals. He clashed with Newt Gingrich over the the Patriot Act, and Rick Santorum over profiling of travelers, including Muslims.

This fall's new sitcoms have left me, (A) not laughing much, and (B) feeling as if I've seen this stuff before. As I explain in this article I think we've reached a sort of End of Comedy moment, where TV sitcoms are recycling the same topics and setups. But instead of moping about this, let's have some fun with it. We'd like to see your best scenes that combine elements from two different sitcoms, current or past. Have the "Odd Couple" guys baby-sit the "Modern Family" youngsters. Put Archie Bunker on a plane next to Corporal Klinger. Whatever. Write some dialogue, throw in a pratfall or two if you like, and post it here. We'll report back on any of the submissions that make us laugh. Hey, maybe you'll even get a 13-episode network order.

Authorities are still investigating the cause of the fire.Already facing stiff criticism from the opposition, Congress party leader and federal Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee on Tuesday turned to Left party leaders to prevent the looming standoff in Parliament over rising prices. Left leaders had issued a notice for an adjournment motion on high prices in the Parliament yesterday, which had stalled parliamentary proceedings. During the meeting, Mr. Mukherjee is believed to have warned the leaders about the consequences for the government in the event of a vote following the adjournment motion, The Hindu reports. A discussion on prices is likely to be held on Wednesday, the federal parliamentary affairs minister said yesterday.

In August, ESPN announced a new way to measure quarterbacks: Total QBR. As you would expect, many writers weighed in with their thoughts. Few football fans have faith in the traditional passer rating system; even fewer understand how it works. That's one of the reasons ESPN spent several years devising a system that would not only represent a step forward from the traditional passer rating but would also be easier for fans to understand. Total QBR grades quarterbacks in some innovative ways: Statistics for rushing, sacks and fumbles for quarterbacks are included.

CABOT--Francis H. The Board and Staff of The New York Botanical Garden wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to the family of our esteemed colleague Francis H. Cabot. An internationally renowned gardener, designer, garden historian, and plantsman and founder of The Garden Conservancy, Mr. Cabot served as Chairman of the Botanical Garden's Board in the 1970s. In 2004, he was appointed a Distinguished Counsellor to the Board. His friendship and counsel will be much missed.Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman Thomas J. Hubbard and Wilson Nolen, Chairmen Emeriti Gregory Long, The William C. Steere Sr. President

An Economic Memo article on Saturday about the roots of a Republican pledge to curb taxes misstated the length of a government shutdown in 1990 stemming from partisan disagreement over budget issues. It was three days, not three weeks. (A later shutdown straddling 1995 and 1996 lasted three weeks.)

Information is the lifeblood of capital markets. In the movie ''Wall Street,'' Gordon Gekko demanded confidential information from a young would-be Master of the Universe, Bud Fox, played by Charlie Sheen. The value of stocks is based on information, which is why securities laws are intended to ensure that all investors have at least minimum amounts of information. Private, closed markets like SharesPost and SecondMarket aid in the cause of market transparency, providing platforms to trade shares of companies that have yet to go public. At the same time, the limited amount of information available to investors in these markets raises some questions. Regulators, which have been looking at these markets, may be right to be concerned.

CABOT--Francis H. The Board of Directors and staff of Wave Hill mourn the passing of Frank Cabot, a devoted and unwavering champion beginning with the creation of Wave Hill as a public institution nearly a half-century ago. A luminary among horticulturists, he provided vision, vitality, and leadership in our pivotal early years as Wave Hill transitioned from the Perkins family's private Bronx estate to a world-renowned public garden. He established Wave Hill's Friends of Horticulture to encourage support for Wave Hill's future and to promote its international reputation. We will miss his quick wit, astute advice, and instinctive perfection. Our heartfelt condolences extend to his family, especially his loving wife, our dear friend and longtime Board colleague Anne Perkins Cabot. Cathy Marks Weinroth, Chair Claudia Bonn, President Scott Canning, Director of Horticulture
