Another major publisher has pushed back against making its e-books available to library users. Penguin Book Group said it would ''delay the availability'' of new e-books to libraries because of security concerns. ''Penguin's aim is to always connect writers and readers, and with that goal in mind, we remain committed to working closely with our business partners and the library community to forge a distribution model that is secure and viable,'' Erica Glass, a spokeswoman for Penguin, said in a statement issued Monday. ''In the meantime, we want to assure you that physical editions of our new titles will continue to be available in libraries everywhere.''

WASHINGTON -- The Republican presidential candidates highlighted their party's lack of a single national security vision a decade after the Sept. 11 attacks, differing on Tuesday night over the pace of withdrawal from Afghanistan, aid to Pakistan and, in an exchange that could resonate dangerously for Newt Gingrich, what to do with illegal immigrants in the United States. Wading into treacherous territory in Republican primary politics just as he is climbing in polls, Mr. Gingrich said during a nationally televised debate that he would support allowing some illegal immigrants -- those who had been in the country for decades, had paid taxes and had raised families here -- to remain in the country. Mr. Gingrich, a former speaker of the House, warned that the party could not claim a family-friendly mantle if it was to ''adopt an immigration policy which destroys families that have been here a quarter-century.''

Also survived by sisters Maureen Burke and Kathleen Gormaley, brother, Thomas Gormaley, and many nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held at McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, 9620 Third Ave. (97th Street), Brooklyn, NY 11209 on Friday, November 25, 2011 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass will take place on Saturday, November 26, 2011 at 9:30am, at Our Lady of the Angels R.C. Church, 7320 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11209 (74th Street). Burial will be private.

The Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson has won the inaugural Malcolm Award at Performa 11, the visual art performance biennial. Mr. Kjartansson (above, at the 2009 Venice Biennale) received the award from Lou Reed at a crowded party on Monday at the Bowery Hotel, where the Performa grand finale took place. The award, which comes with a $10,000 prize, is named for Malcolm McLaren, the artist, provocateur and sloganeer who died last year, leaving a legacy that included organizing the punk-rock band the Sex Pistols. The award is to be presented at each biennial to an artist 40 or younger who has ''demonstrated the most innovative and thought-provoking performance during the three-week biennial,'' according to a news release from Performa. Mr. Kjartansson won for his 12-hour work ''Bliss,'' performed without a break at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side from noon until midnight on Saturday. Commissioned by Performa 11, the piece involved repeated performances of the denouement of Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro.''

Mitt Romney's campaign began broadcasting its first television ad in New Hampshire on Tuesday - the same day that President Obama visited the state to talk about his plan to turn around the economy. THE SCRIPT The words, ''On October 16, 2008 Barack Obama Visited New Hampshire,'' flash across the screen before spliced video of Mr. Obama's campaign in 2008 begins: ''Thank you. Thank you New Hampshire. How is everybody doing today? I am confident that we can steer ourselves out of this crisis. Who's been in charge of the economy? We need a rescue plan for the middle class. We need to provide relief for homeowners. It's going take a new direction. If we keep talking about the economy, we're going to lose.'' As Mr. Obama speaks, the words, ''He failed,'' flash across the screen, before the ad switches to Mr. Romney, who says: ''I'm going to do something to government. I call it the smaller, simpler, smarter approach to government. Getting rid of programs, turning programs back to states and, finally, making government itself more efficient. I'm going to get rid of ObamaCare. It's killing jobs. And it's keeping our kids from having the bright prospects they deserve. We have a moral responsibility not to spend more than we take in. I'll make sure that America is a job-creating machine like it has been in the past. It's high time to bring those principles of fiscal responsibility to Washington, D.C. I'm Mitt Romney and I approve this message.''

TOKYO - The Tokyo Stock Exchange, Japan's largest, on Tuesday announced a $1.1 billion merger deal with the Osaka Securities Exchange that would create the world's third-largest exchange, as measured by the value of listed stock The deal, which would unify the two exchanges by January 2013, is a bid to keep up with stiff competition among global market operators and to put Japanese equities back on the world map.

Julian H. Robertson Jr., the hedge fund manager, is expected to be named chairman of Forstmann Little, succeeding Theodore J. Forstmann, the co-founder of the private equity firm and prominent financier who died Sunday. Forstmann Little, which has largely wound down its operations, still has three investments in its portfolio: IMG, the sports, fashion and media company; 24 Hour Fitness, a health club chain; and ENK International, a fashion-industry trade-show business.

Because of an editing error, a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Tuesday about a financial dispute that is delaying a project at the World Trade Center site misidentified the subject of the delay at one point. The film producer Paula Wagner (the ''Mission Impossible'' films) is teaming with the veteran Broadway producer Roy Furman (''Seminar,'' ''The Book of Mormon'') to develop a revival of ''The Heiress,'' the 1947 play about the plain young Catherine who turns the tables on her wealthy cruel father, Dr. Sloper.

FORSTMANN--Theodore J. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the passing of our colleague Ted Forstmann, an outstanding philanthropist, humanitarian and business executive. Working closely with the IRC, Ted responded early on to the humanitarian crisis unfolding in the former Yugoslavia, marshalling support in 1992 that saved countless lives and eased the suffering of thousands. In 1993 he collaborated with the IRC to establish the Children's Medical Project in Zagreb that treated injured and critically ill children of all ethnic backgrounds. We were honored to have him as a member of our board from 1993 to 2004 and as an IRC Overseer from 2004 to 2009. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board Glenda Burkhart and Scott Pelley, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers George Rupp, President

6 P.M. (ABC Family) CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY (2005) Tim Burton's sugar rush, based on Roald Dahl's book (with, above from left, David Kelly, Freddie Highmore, Johnny Depp, Deep Roy, Jordan Fry and Adam Godley), stars Mr. Depp as an oddly sinister candymaker and Mr. Highmore as a boy who wants nothing more than to swim in chocolate. Well, who wouldn't? Despite burdening Wonka with a psychological back story and forcing a redemptive father-son reconciliation onto Dahl's tale -- ''worse than lazy; it is a betrayal of a book that the filmmakers seem otherwise to have not only understood, but also honored,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times -- ''the sumptuous, eerie look and mood of the movie make it possible to ignore this dispiriting and superfluous adherence to convention.'' He added: ''There is simply too much pleasure to be found in Wonka's world to get too hung up about his relationship with his dad. The real lesson of 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' is -- or should be -- that pleasure and curiosity are their own rewards.'' ''Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory,'' Mel Stuart's 1971 adaptation with Gene Wilder in the title role, Peter Ostrum as Charlie, and songs by Anthony Newley and Leslie Bricusse, follows at 8:30. 7:15 A.M. (Cinemax) FANTASTIC MR. FOX (2009) George Clooney, Meryl Streep, Jason Schwartzman and Bill Murray lend their voices to this animated tale from Wes Anderson, adapted with Noah Baumbach from the ''anti-fable'' by Roald Dahl about a fox that rallies his animal friends against three evil farmers. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott said the movie was in some ways Mr. Anderson's ''most fully realized and satisfying film,'' adding that, ''once you adjust to its stop-and-start rhythms and its scruffy looks, you can appreciate its wit, its beauty and the sly gravity of its emotional undercurrents.'' Is it a movie for children? Mr. Scott wonders. ''It is precisely the movie that a child smitten with Roald Dahl's fiction and fascinated by the enigmas of the adult world would dream of making: something to amaze and terrify the grown-ups and win the envy and adulation of his peers.''

Hedge funds, the golden children of finance, are having a very rough year. For one, they are not making money the way they used to. Returns for a number of funds, including those of star managers like John A. Paulson, have fallen by as much as half this year. And that poor performance comes just as these investment partnerships are coming under increased regulatory scrutiny.

An Associated Press report in the National Briefing column on Nov. 11 about a suicide at the Occupy Wall Street encampment in Burlington, Vt., misstated the military background of the man who shot himself. He served two weeks in an Army boot camp and was then discharged; he was not a veteran.

GARRETT--Paul Mitcham, architect, 71, born in Dumas, Arkansas on July 9, 1940, died suddenly behind the wheel of his beloved Lotus Elan on November 20, 2011. He was the cherished husband of Janie Cook Garrett for 48 years, father to Elizabeth and Juliet, and adored granddaddy to Josef, Greta, Lydia and Mia. He will be dearly missed.

A picture caption last Wednesday with an article about a fire that destroyed the Pavilion, a dance club on Fire Island that its owner wanted to transform with his other properties, including the Blue Whale, into a ''gay utopia,'' misidentified the venue of an event on Memorial Day weekend 2010. It was the Blue Whale, not the Pavilion. And another picture caption reversed the identifications, in some editions, for the two damaged buildings shown. The Pavilion was at the right and the LaFountaine Building at the left.

A Spare Times entry in some editions on Friday about an exhibition of the Dignity Memorial Vietnam Wall, at Pier 86 in Manhattan outside the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum, misstated the history of its display in New York City. It was shown on Staten Island in 2003; this was not its first appearance in the city.

When Pamela and Alan Rice were thinking of opening a beer store in the East 80s, some of their friends -- whose short memories did not register that the neighborhood, Yorkville, was once home to numerous German and Eastern European beer halls -- tried to discourage them. ''They said that the Upper East Side is too upscale for beer, and people drink wine,'' Ms. Rice said. The Rices, both career-changers, went ahead anyway, with happy results. Since opening two weeks ago, their shop and bar, City Swiggers, has been a magnet for beer-lovers, many of them locals. ''We have people coming in with strollers,'' he said.

SANDS--John Keating, of Glen Cove, NY died at home on November 19, 2011. Born March 1, 1922, the son of William F. Sands and Edith Keating Sands of Washington, DC, he attended Landon School and graduated from Portsmouth Abbey School, the University of North Carolina, and New York University Graduate School of Finance. He served in the US Navy during World War II and the Korean Conflict and began his professional career at McKinsey & Company. He was later employed by Dillon, Read & Co, W.C. Langley & Company, and Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. He served as a director of New York Capital Resources, Auerbach Pollak & Richardson, Laidlaw Equities, and Saugatuck Capital among others. Survivors include Elizabeth Petty, Catherine Sands, John Sands, Jr., and Margaret Witham, their spouses, nine grandchildren and his former wife Patricia Pulling Sands. He was predeceased by his three brothers, James, William F. and Robert J. Sands. Funeral Mass: 11am Saturday, November 26 at St. Hyacinth Church, 319 Cedar Swamp Road, Glen Head, NY 11545. In lieu of flowers, gifts to: Portsmouth Abbey School, 285 Corys Lane, Portsmouth, RI 02871.

The annual concert at Carnegie Hall to benefit music education programs for the poor will have a Rolling Stones theme this spring, the event's organizer, Michael Dorf, announced. Rosanne Cash, Steve Earle, the Carolina Chocolate Drops and others have signed on to perform all 21 tracks from the Rolling Stones classic collection ''Hot Rocks 1964-1971,'' on the 40th anniversary of its release. The concert will take place March 13 and the proceeds will go to support nonprofit organizations that provide music classes to impoverished youths, among them the Church Street School of Music, Young Audiences, Music Unites and the Pinwheel Project. Mr. Dorf, who owns the City Winery, has raised about $600,000 for charity with similar concerts over the last seven years, asking contemporary musicians to pay tribute to the music of older artists. Past shows have focused on the songs of Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen and the Who, among others. This year, at least 21 solo artists and groups will be on the bill to interpret songs by the Stones, including the Mountain Goats, Rich Robinson of the Black Crowes and Glen Hansard. An earlier version of this post misstated Michael Dorf's affiliation with the Knitting Factory. While he founded it and ran it for many years, he no longer owns it or runs it.

An article on Saturday about investors' accelerating withdrawal from European sovereign debt misstated the title and experience of Peter R. Fisher, who commented on the trend's detrimental effect on the fiscal health of Europe. He is the head of fixed income at the asset manager BlackRock, not a vice chairman, and he was a senior Treasury official in the administration of President George W. Bush, not of President Bill Clinton.

A Congressional panel has asked Jon S. Corzine to testify about the downfall of MF Global, and the hundreds of millions of dollars in customer money that went missing in the brokerage firm's final days. The hearing, scheduled for Dec. 15, will be a role reversal for Mr. Corzine, who spent five years on Capitol Hill as a Democratic senator from New Jersey. As a Congressional witness, Mr. Corzine is expected to come under fire for presiding over MF Global as it caused the futures industry's first major breach of customer money. A spokesman for Mr. Corzine declined to comment on Tuesday.

A film review on Friday about the documentary ''Eames: The Architect and the Painter'' misidentified the California city in which Charles Eames and his wife Ray ran a design studio. It is Venice, not Santa Monica. The review also misidentified the television show on which the couple appeared with Arlene Francis (their appearance is shown in the documentary). While Ms. Francis was the host, the show was called ''Home'' -- not ''The Arlene Francis Show,'' a later show.

Under a broad tarp, on a sidewalk along Harlem's Lenox Avenue, two rows of people found momentary shelter from the rain and cold. On one side were some of the neighborhood's neediest residents, receiving free Thanksgiving turkeys. On the other side, distributing the turkeys, were locked-out N.B.A. players. The scene was familiar. The players, through their union, pass out thousands of turkeys each year. But under current circumstances, the juxtaposition seemed awkward.

The painter Lucian Freud, who died in July at the age of 88, spent many of his Saturday mornings with an intimate group of friends at Clarke's restaurant in London, only steps from his home. Those Saturdays will be recalled in ''Breakfast With Lucian,'' a memoir by Geordie Greig, the editor of The London Evening Standard, his publisher said on Monday. Mr. Greig was a regular at the breakfasts, where the conversations veered from poetry and art to Kate Moss and Jerry Hall, he said in his book proposal. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, part of Macmillan, will publish the book in October 2012.

BESSIRE--Henry E. Born in Louisville, KY in 1935. Died November 18, 2011. Henrylived a wonderful and full life with family and friends. He transformed non-profit management by professionalizing institutional development at Lincoln Center in the 60s and his alma mater Princeton ('57) in the 70s, and was managing director at Brakeley, Inc., specializing in cultural institutions and higher education. He and Louise, his wife of 52 years, loved to travel, collect contemporary art and spend time with family in New York City and Marthas Vineyard. Services, 11am Saturday, November 26, St. Ignatius of Antioch, 552 WEA. Contributions to Vineyard Conservation Society.

An article on Saturday about a new Census Bureau count that put the number of people with incomes less than 50 percent above the poverty line -- a group known as the ''near poor'' -- far higher than previously thought described the health care for a quarter of that group incorrectly. They are uninsured; it is not the case that they have health insurance.

If Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo keeps his vow to veto a partisan redistricting plan, he will be in good company. Governors Alfred E. Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt both rejected legislative reapportionment plans that they regarded to be gerrymandering. Mr. Cuomo has demanded that the boundaries be drawn by an independent commission. He has said he would reject boundaries now being drafted by the Legislative Task Force on Demographic Research and Reapportionment - in effect, by the Democratic majority in the Assembly and the Republican majority in the Senate.

HERRICK--Anson Boulton, Jr. of Southold, NY, died November 19, 2011. Honorably discharged veteran of the Coast Guard. Husband of Mary Crandall Herrick, father of Daniel, Christopher, Deborah, Leah and eight grandchildren; brother of John Davis, William Lawrence and the late Gilbert Burdett, son of Ruth B. Herrick and the late Anson B. Herrick. Memorial service on December 2 at 11am, St. Peters Lutheran Church, 71305 Main Rd. Greenport, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to East End Maritime Museum, 3rd St, Greenport, NY 11944 would be appreciated.

FORSTMANN--Theodore. The Board of Governors, Members and Staff of Deepdale Golf Club deeply regret the untimely passing of our esteemed Member and friend, Theodore J. Forstmann. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President

EHINGER--Joan Weisz, a longtime resident of Summit, NJ passed away unexpectedly on November 17th at Winchester Gardens in Maplewood, NJ. She was 88. Visitation will be held on Friday, November 25th at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home in Summit, NJ from 2-and 7-9pm. A memorial service to celebrate her life will take place at 11am Saturday, November 26th at Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, immediately followed by a reception in Calvary's parish house. Joan was born on May 7, 1923 in Columbus, OH. Joan married Robert Ehinger and raised four children. She lived in Palo Alto, Whittier and Fullerton, CA, and Summit, NJ. She lived most of her life in Summit where she enjoyed a variety of activities including painting, the piano, gardening, duplicate bridge and extensive volunteer work. She is survived by her husband of sixty-three years, Robert, her daughters Elizabeth (Tom White), and Ruth Ellen (Rick Alexander), her sons, Robert Jr. (Sarah Kingsbury) and Tony (Marianne Hyzak), two brothers and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Interweave, P.O. Box 1516, Summit, NJ 07901 or Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ 07901.

New York City police officers shot and killed fewer people last year than at any other time since the Police Department began keeping track in 1971, according to a department report released Tuesday. Eight people were shot and killed by the police in 2010, down 33 percent from 2009; 16 others were shot and wounded, down 20 percent. The department's 2010 firearms-discharge report noted that the number of episodes in which officers fired their weapons also reached a new low, 92, down from 106. The number of such episodes has been steadily declining since 2006.

Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal may have never played one another with less on the line. Aside from being the first time in 26 meetings that neither Federer nor Nadal was ranked No.1, the round-robin format of the ATP World Tour Finals in London meant that either man could lose this match and still go on to win the tournament.

MARGOLIS--Barbara. The Camp Greylock directors and alumni mourn the passing of Bobbie Margolis. She was a beloved member of the Greylock family who passed away peacefully in her home in New York City on Friday. Bobbie with her late husband Bert Margolis owned and operated Greylock for many years until the early 1990's. Bobbie's terrific wit, caring, and zest for life added to the happiness of hundreds of staff and children each summer. Her charismatic style brought people together. She will be remembered and greatly missed.

DEADLINE EXTENDED A London judge ruled on Tuesday that Kweku M. Adoboli, below, a former UBS trader charged with fraud, could have an additional four weeks to look at evidence and get legal advice before entering a plea in a case that grew out of a $2.3 billion trading loss at the Swiss bank. Mr. Adoboli, 31, who was charged in September with playing a role in the huge loss that shook UBS, was remanded in custody until Dec. 20. He appeared at Southwark Crown Court in London on Tuesday, his fourth court appearance since he was arrested, and he spoke only to confirm his name. JULIA WERDIGIER

Schackman--Daniel, 47, beloved son of Dulcie and Walter Schackman, caring brother of Paul and Bruce and Ed Sikov, died suddenly on Sunday, November 20 of a heart attack. He was an Assistant Professor in the Department of Communication and Media at SUNY New Paltz. Services are private.

TRYNIN--Nathan (Nick) K. Died November 18, 2011 at his home on Shelter Island, NY, where he lived with his beloved partner and wife of 33 years, Judith Sutton. He was 81. Nick grew up in New York City son of Ada Wilentz Trynin and Theodore N. Trynin. He was very attached to his high school, Poly Prep, where he was captain of the baseball team, and served 19 years on its Board of Trustees. He graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School. Nick went on to serve his country in the Judge Advocate General's Department of the Air Force and then later became Assistant US Attorney for the Eastern District of NY, serving under the Honorable Leonard P. Moore. The majority of his professional life was spent at Amerada Hess Corporation as a senior executive. Nick was an appreciator of all cultures through his extensive international travels. His life was filled with family, many meaningful long term friendships, and hobbies which included sailing and golf. A creature of habit and a repeater of a good joke, Nick favored filet of sole, chocolate ice cream and a gin martini, best enjoyed out at the end of his Shelter Island dock with his friend Marvin. This coming Thanksgiving will be the first time in 27 years that Nick will not host his favorite event of the year, his Thanksgiving Harvard Club Dinner for family and friends, which he organized with his wife, Judy and his dear sister, Kate. He was predeceased by his other NYC "club" of 50 years, Gino on Lexington Ave. Nick is survived by his wife Judith Sutton, his sister Kate Kestnbaum, his daughter Jennifer S. Trynin and son-in-law, Mike Denneen, his son Thomas C. Trynin and daughter-in-law, Robin Trynin, and his two adored grandchildren, Gracie Denneen and Sadie Trynin. Services will be held on Wednesday, November 23 at 10:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to his favorite Shelter Island charities.

Beeps and blinking lights are the constant chatter of a hospital intensive care unit, but at the I.C.U.'s in North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y., the conversation has some unusual contributors.  Two L.E.D. displays adorn the wall across from each nurses' station.  They show the hand hygiene rate achieved:  last Friday in the surgical I.C.U., the weekly rate was 85 percent and the current shift had a rate of 91 percent.  "Great Shift!!" the sign said.   At the medical I.C.U. next door, the weekly rate was 81 percent, and the current shift 82 percent.

With the other networks taking a holiday from their regular prime-time schedules, ABC emerged as No. 1 in all ratings categories on Wednesday thanks to its usual comedy lineup. A new episode of "Modern Family" led the way, with 12.6 million total viewers, followed by "The Middle," at 9.1 million, according to Nielsen estimates. Elsewhere, a special Wednesday live results episode of "The X Factor" drew 8.5 million total viewers and put Fox in second place for the night in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic. CBS was in third place with a slate of repeats and a recap episode of "Survivor: South Pacific."

Michael Grandage, director of the Donmar Warehouse theater and known to New York audiences this season for his Metropolitan Opera production of Mozart's "Don Giovanni," is striking out on his own. Mr. Grandage is leaving the Donmar in London at the end of the year, and in an interview with that city's Evening Standard said he would form his own commercial company, without a home base. After 15 years running established companies, "It seems entirely appropriate to think about what I can take from those years, form a company that's buildingless and go out and make work," he told the newspaper. "It feels right at 49." The Evening Standard said that he and his executive producer at the Donmar, James Bierman, have formed Michael Grandage Productions. Mr. Grandage said he also hoped to make an independent movie.

The National Gallery in London says it is cracking down on ticket-scalping for a major exhibition of the works of Leonardo da Vinci, which opened on Nov. 9. BBC News reports that the gallery will enforce warnings that resold tickets "will be cancelled without refund and admission will be refused to the bearer," and is asking resale Web sites to halt the practice. The museum declined to say how it would identify scalped tickets, according to the BBC. The show has drawn large crowds, and on Thursday, the U.K. eBay site listed the starting bid for a pair at up to $250 and the Viagogo site had a ticket as high as $389.01. Tickets through the museum cost 16 pounds, or about $25. "Leonardo Da Vinci: Painter at the Court of Milan" runs through Feb. 5.

The year 1962 produced two debuts: the establishing and formal naming of Amnesty International as a permanent human rights advocate, according to its official history, and Bob Dylan's first album. Nearly 50 years later, those two facts will become indelibly joined when a benefit recording project of Mr. Dylan's music is released. More than 80 performers are covering four CDs' worth of his songs, numbering about 75, Amnesty said. The album is called "Chimes of Freedom: The Songs of Bob Dylan Honoring 50 Years of Amnesty International" and will be released in North America on Jan. 24 and elsewhere on Jan. 30. The performers include Sting, Patti Smith, Pete Seeger, Miley Cyrus, Joan Baez, Jackson Browne, Maroon 5 and Elvis Costello. Most of the recordings are being released for sale for the first time, except for "Chimes of Freedom," recorded by Mr. Dylan in 1964, Amnesty said.

Remember the days when Keds shoes were seen primarily on moms and preteens? Nowadays, the shoes, worn by trendsetters like Chloë Sevigny and Natalie Portman, have once again become cool. As of Friday, the brand's first clothing line hits the racks at Opening Ceremony, further confirming its place in hipster wardrobes. Inspired by its classic all-American look are pieces like women's varsity-style sweaters, $200, and flower-print tennis dresses, $185. And not to leave out the boys, there are men's slim-cut pants, $125, and dog-print sweaters, $325.

Forget the less-is-more trend - tis the season to load it on. And in the makeup artist James Kaliardos's capable hands, full makeup looks glamorous, not glitzy. "I went with a tough, sexy look inspired by Jodie Foster and Debbie Harry," Kaliardos says. "It's the idea you can go rock 'n' roll for holiday and not always be glitter-crazed." Leaving skin practically bare ("Just a touch of Armani Luminous Silk Foundation in the center zone of the face, minimal powder and a hint of contour under the cheekbones"), he focused on serious eyes and lips. After dabbing concealer onto lids, he used M.A.C.'s 213 fluff brush to apply Nars Lhasa, a chic gray shadow, to the top lid, and Nars Underworld Duo Eyeshadow under the lower lashes. "Really feel your shape and bones so you get subtle contour and an emphasis on the crease of the lid," Kaliardos advises. He curled lashes and added a lick of inky Givenchy Phenomen'Eyes mascara. For the festive red lip, he used Nars Velvet Matte Lip Pencil in Dragon Girl. "It's so easy to draw on and fill in," he says. "Apply, and into the night you go!"

The word "sandal" has Hellenic origins. So it makes sense that the Greek native Christina Martini chose the island of Crete for embarking on her first footwear line, Ancient Greek Sandals. "Our idea was to make our sandals look like they were archaeological finds but with a modern twist," says Martini, who spent a number of years designing shoes at Balenciaga and Louis Vuitton before branching out on her own. With subtle nods to the goddesses - Persephone, Aphrodite and Athena - the sandals' vegetable-tanned leather and handmade construction will merit compliments of mythic proportions.

Digital version of textbooks are gaining as publishers take advantage of the popularity of tablets like the Kindle and iPad, expanding their catalogues and offering products like rental digital books that expire after a semester or two, reports Christopher F. Schuetze. The potential for digital growth is leading publishers to experiment with products that stretch the boundaries of traditional textbooks, slowly turning away from static text and images toward a multimedia, intuitive approach.

Wednesday's drop in Groupon's stock price below its I.P.O. offer is a disturbing signal for technology investors and other start-ups waiting to go public, reports Evelyn M. Rusli. "In the environment we're in right now, investors are wary of risk, and so these less-seasoned companies will naturally face more selling pressure."

To soap opera fans facing the biggest cliffhanger of all - the death of their favorite programs - Jeffrey Kwatinetz and Rich Frank seemed like heroes. In July, two months after ABC canceled ''All My Children'' and ''One Life to Live,'' the two men swooped in, licensed the shows and promised to bring them back to life on the Internet. With the fans' help, they were determined to prove that online advertising could sustain high-quality TV shows.

An article on the Square Feet page on Wednesday about a proposal from a Columbia University research group to link Governors Island to Lower Manhattan with a land bridge referred incorrectly to the source of landfill that created Battery Park City. Twenty-four acres of the project were filled with material excavated during construction of the World Trade Center some 40 years ago -- not all 92 acres.

Desktops can get quickly littered with stray icons for files and folders, but there is a quick way to tidy things up. In both Windows 7 and Mac OS X, just right-click on the desktop (or hold down the Control key while clicking with a one button Mac mouse) to see your options on the contextual menu. In Windows, select View from the contextual menu and choose ''Auto-arrange icons.'' You can also make the screen icons line up in rows with the ''Align icons to grid'' menu command. All the icons clumped around the screen snap into precise alignment--which also makes it easier to see which ones can get re-filed or tossed in the Recycle Bin to further sweep up the desktop. Right-clicking on the desktop and choosing Sort By lets you arrange the desktop icons based on name, size, type or date modified.

Were the 1970s the most boring decade in history? In 1972, The New York Times reported on the Ford Motor Company's plan to fight boredom on the job and an alternative boredom-reduction plan put forward by the United Auto Workers. The Washington Post, meanwhile, fretted that boredom might be fueling interest in the occult. In 1976, Reader's Digest declared boredom ''the disease of our time.''

A film review on Wednesday about ''Hugo,'' the new Martin Scorsese movie, misstated its rating in some copies. It is PG (parental guidance suggested), not PG-13 (parents strongly cautioned). And a listing of credits with the review misstated the film's running time. It is 2 hours 6 minutes, not 2 hours 30 minutes.

An article on Wednesday about a spirited debate over foreign policy by the Republican presidential candidates in Washington on Tuesday night misidentified, in some copies, the candidate Representative Michelle Bachmann of Minnesota called ''highly naïve'' after he suggested cutting off American aid to Pakistan. She was criticizing Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, not former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania.

An article on Nov. 15 about the waning enthusiasm of many young voters for President Obama's re-election campaign misidentified the university attended by Jolie Glaser at the time she campaigned for Mr. Obama in 2008. It is Stanford University, not the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. The article also described incorrectly a nonprofit organization for which she does volunteer work. The group, Candlelighters Childhood Cancer Foundation, is a children's cancer foundation that holds an annual golf tournament to raise money; Ms. Glaser does not do volunteer work at ''a golf charity.''

An article on Tuesday about mounting financial problems at the United States Postal Service misstated the decline in annual mail volume in the last five years. It is down by some 40 billion pieces, not 40 million.

More than a half-century after ''The Sound of Music'' immortalized the von Trapp family's flight from Austria on stage and screen, the first-ever Salzburg production of that Rodgers and Hammerstein musical has made audiences (if not the hills themselves) come alive with approval, The Associated Press reported. Despite Salzburg's central role in the story of the real-life von Trapps as home to the Nonnberg Abbey, which took in Maria, as well as the estate of Captain Georg von Trapp and his irrepressible children, and as the setting for many scenes in the 1965 ''Sound of Music'' film adaptation, a theatrical production of the musical had not been presented in there until this year. Residents of the city - also known as the birthplace of Mozart and home to the Salzburg Festival - had tried to halt efforts to turn the von Trapp family home into a hotel, and in the words of The A.P., regard tourists who come to town searching for ''Sound of Music'' photo ops with ''benign disdain.''

Group shots are always a challenge, but family holiday gatherings present a special set of problems. You can't hold a group together long amid the distractions of bowl games, family Xbox tournaments and sweet-potato pie. Andrew Boyd, a photojournalist and educator, has written extensively about group shots on his blog, The Discerning Photographer. Here's his recipe for getting it right. Grab the Spotlight ''Attention span is the issue,'' said Mr. Boyd. You have to engage attention long enough to get your shot. ''It's critical that you be entertaining,'' he said. ''I'm not a standup comic by any stretch, but I am going to joke around.'' He has a routine of patter, in which what you say isn't as important as some brisk chat . ''Let's all get in a little closer. Too tight, John, you're too tall! Back row,'' demonstrated Mr. Boyd. ''I am talking the whole time, giving direction, and not giving them too much time to think.''

BEIJING -- It is rare that marquee international film events take place in China. That is partly because of the censorship imposed by the government. And tight limits on importing and screening foreign movies cast a shadow on efforts to bring new films to the nation. But last week's arts and culture forum organized by Asia Society and the Aspen Institute sought to broaden the dialogue concerning films from the United States and China.

John Landis, below, secured a place in the pop-culture canon by directing a series of blockbusters in the late 1970s and '80s that often starred some of the country's biggest comedians. His films were zany, sometimes outrageous: ''Animal House'' (1978), ''The Blues Brothers'' (1980), ''Trading Places'' (1983), ''Three Amigos'' (1986) and ''Coming to America'' (1988). Earlier this week the Brooklyn Academy of Music's BAMcinématek began a retrospective of his work called See You Next Wednesday. Mr. Landis talked to Mekado Murphy about his motivation for making films, working with actors and mining a script for laughs. Q. Did you set out to make movies that had broad appeal?

The Yankees have agreed in principle to a one-year deal with the veteran right-handed pitcher Freddy Garcia, according to a person who was briefed on the agreement. The deal is pending the completion of a physical. The Yankees offered Garcia arbitration before Wednesday's deadline, but that was a formality that will most likely be superseded by the new contract.

Four Fridays ago, Doug Schwartz spent the morning as he has most Fridays for more than a decade: stacking rocks and bits of ruin into pillar-like sculptures on a desolate stretch of the South Shore of Staten Island. That afternoon, he got a phone call from a regional supervisor of natural resources for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. The official, Steve Zahn, had a somewhat tortured message to relay, Mr. Schwartz said, but it boiled down to a single word: stop.

Packers at Lions Thursday, 12:30 p.m. Line: Packers by 6.5. The Lions have a 33-79 record entering their Thanksgiving game since 2001, but that does not mean you have to go back to the days of Bobby Layne to find a time when they were relevant. In 2007, the Lions reached Thanksgiving with a 6-4 record, an exciting offense built around receivers Calvin Johnson - then a rookie - and Roy Williams, and a stingy defense coached by Rod Marinelli. That team was poised to render Lions punch lines obsolete until they allowed Brett Favre to throw three touchdowns in a 37-26 loss that was not as close as the final score. Instead of using their traditional holiday appearance to launch a playoff run, the Lions collapsed: they went 3-30 between that day and Thanksgiving of 2009.

Why bother with die-cast cars that you have to push with your fingers, adding your own sound effects? Mattel has created a lifelike Lightning McQueen, the star of the Disney Pixar ''Cars'' movies, that does it all for you. Lightning McQueen Alive is a 1:55 scale animatronic version of its movie counterpart that, with the help of microtechnology, performs its own maneuvers and makes its own noises. It looks, moves and sounds like the real thing, and it fits in the palm of your hand.

He transformed non-profit management by professionalizing institutional development at Lincoln Center in the 60s and his alma mater Princeton ('57) in the 70s, and was managing director at Brakeley, Inc., specializing in cultural institutions and higher education. He and Louise, his wife of 52 years, loved to travel, collect contemporary art and spend time with family in New York City and Marthas Vineyard. Services, 11am Saturday, November 26, St. Ignatius of Antioch, 552 WEA. Contributions to Vineyard Conservation Society.

This week on the pop music charts, Drake has a big opening and Adele breaks a record set by Michael Jackson. Drake, the rapper and singer, who acted in the teenage television show ''Degrassi: The Next Generation,'' sailed to No. 1 with 631,000 copies of his latest release, ''Take Care'' (Young Money/Cash Money/Universal Republic), sold. That was less than the 700,000 that some chart-watchers had been expecting (or hoping for), but it was still the third-biggest opening of the year, behind Lady Gaga and Lil Wayne.

An article on Monday about stepped-up amenities in first-class air travel misstated the availability of first class on Qatar Airways. While the carrier's Boeing 777s, which serve the United States market and other destinations, do not offer first class, there is a first-class cabin on some of its planes, including Airbus A340s and some A330s. It is not the case that the airline has no first-class seats.

COHEN--Sidney M.,M.D., born in Morristown, NJ on May 26, 1919, raised in Brooklyn. He died in his sleep at his home in NYC on November 22, 2011. He earned his B.S. degree at Columbia University in 1939 and his M.D. at Long Island (Downstate) College of Medicine in 1943. From 1944-46 he served his country with distinction as Chief of the Neuropsychiatric Section, 98th General Hospital, Munich Germany, and Psychiatric Consultant to the Dachau War Crimes Board. He completed a residency in Neurology at Mt. Sinai Hospital in 1947, conducted and published extensive original scientific research on brain physiology and central nervous system disease, and practiced most of his medical career of over 63 years at the Neurological Institute at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. A man of extraordinary intelligence, character, humor and humanity, he was revered and adored by his wife and soul mate of 57 years, Lea, his children, Ron (Amy), Navah and Oren (Claire), his nine grandchildren, Aaron, Yonatan, Ilan, David, Rebecca, Arielle, Ilana, Rachel and Alexandra, his extended family, many friends and the countless patients he served. He continued to practice medicine to age 87. He lived a magnificent life, sharing with Lea a passion for their family, the arts, Jewish culture and the state of Israel. He touched indelibly the lives of those fortunate enough to know him--a light has gone out in the world. Family and friends will gather on Friday, November 25th at 10:45 a.m. at the Kensico Cemetery chapel, Valhalla, NY (www.facebook.com/ events/246673068721284/). For those wishing, In Memoriam donations may be made to the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel.

JERUSALEM -- Eli Hurvitz, who began his career washing lab equipment at a drug company and went on to build Teva Pharmaceutical Industries into the largest generic drug maker in the world, died on Monday night. He was 79. His death was announced by Teva. No cause was given, but in an interview with the newspaper Yediot Aharonot earlier this year he said he had cancer. ''I am not the type to surrender,'' he told the paper. ''That is how it was in business, and that is how it is with the illness.''

''The very nicest thing Hollywood can possibly think of to say to a writer,'' Raymond Chandlerwrote, ''is that he is too good to be only a writer.'' Chandler may have been only a writer himself, but he was a singularly influential one, whose body of work includes the classic detective novels ''The Big Sleep'' and ''Farewell, My Lovely'' and contributions to the screenplays for ''Double Indemnity'' (written with Billy Wilder) and ''Strangers on a Train.'' Now a sale of books and papers from Chandler's personal collection offers a unique look at his legacy and literary influence, not to mention his uneasy relationship with that ''showman's paradise,'' as he called it, known as Hollywood. On Dec. 13 Sotheby's will sell at an auction in New York a collection of Chandler's books and other works from the library of Jean Vounder-Davis, who was the author's fiancee and secretary until his death in 1959, the auction house said on Wednesday. Among the items in the sale is a copy of ''The Big Sleep,'' the first novel to feature his detective character Philip Marlowe, inscribed to Chandler's wife, Cissy. (The dedication reads in part, ''For my Cissy who wants something much better, but was pleased even with this.'') Another copy of ''The Big Sleep'' also for sale at the auction is dedicated by Chandler to himself, with the inscription, ''For me without my compliments.''

DES MOINES -- Mitt Romney on Wednesday defended his campaign's first television commercial, which takes President Obama's words out of context over his handling of the economy, gleefully telling reporters, ''We obviously got under their skin.'' On a campaign visit to Iowa, Mr. Romney used a Thanksgiving analogy to push back against a torrent of criticism from Democrats and independent fact-checkers who said the advertisement distorted Mr. Obama's comments from the 2008 campaign when he said, ''If we keep talking about the economy, we're going to lose.''

BALKIN--Seymour S.,M.D., passed away peacefully in his sleep at home in Miami, Florida, on November 22, 2011, just short of his 101st birthday. Dr. Balkin, a distinguished internist and cardiologist, practiced medicine in Forest Hills, New York, until his retirement at 75 years of age in 1986, when he moved to Boca Raton, Florida. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sylvia, of 69 years, three adoring children, Jeffrey, Dr. Ronald, and Cindy (Alan) Lewin, seven grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren. He emigrated from Russia with his parents at the age of ten. Upon completion of medical school at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, and a residency at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City, Dr. Balkin served as a physician in the US Army during World War II rising to the rank of Major at the time of his honorable discharge. While establishing his private practice, Dr. Balkin worked for the United Nations and the Veterans Administration. We love you and will greatly miss you Poppy. Funeral services on Thursday, November 24, 2011 in Miami, Florida.

Werkmeister--Janet Mary (Fillit). Born June 22, 1950 in Linden, NJ to Paul and Lucille Werkmeister, cherished wife of Howard Fillit, MD and beloved mother of Marielle and Michael Fillit. Janet attended Fordham University at Lincoln Center, received her medical degree and training in pediatrics and allergy from Cornell Medical College. She practiced medicine in Manhattan for 27 years, and cared deeply about her patients. Janet was a loving, independent soul, with a good heart and a loyal and deep commitment to friends and family. She will live in our hearts, and we will miss her, forever. Funeral: Friday, November 25, 2011 at 11am, Eden Memorial, 327 Main St, Fort Lee, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Alzheimers Drug Discovery Foundation, 57 West 57th Street, Suite 904, NY, NY 10019(www.AlzDiscovery.org). Howard Fillit and Family

A lawsuit filed by 44 survivors and the families of 4 people who were killed when a stage collapsed in August at the Indiana State Fair has named the country band Sugarland in the suit, along with producers and other organizers of the concert, The Associated Press reported. Sugarland, the country music duo of Jennifer Nettles and Kristian Bush, was minutes away from performing at the fairgrounds in Indianapolis on the evening of Aug. 13 when a gust of wind that exceeded 60 miles per hour caused the stage to collapse. The accident, which occurred hours after a severe thunderstorm watch was issued, resulted in the deaths of seven people and injuries to dozens more, and video of the frightening scene spread rapidly across the Internet. The lawsuit, filed Tuesday in Marion Superior Court in Indianapolis, says that Sugarland and the other parties involved in the concert had a duty to make it a safe environment and were in breach of reasonable care. Mario Massillamany, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said that the band had the final decision about whether the show should go on, adding: ''Unfortunately, this tragedy could have been prevented if the responsible parties had been concerned about the concertgoers that night.'' Sugarland did not immediately comment on the lawsuit; the band played a free concert in Indianapolis on Oct. 28 to make up for the missed show and to help raise money for victims of the accident.

Black Friday, the busiest shopping day of the year, is just around the corner, but a free iPhone app called TapBuy can help you get a jump on the other holiday shoppers. TapBuy, like dozens of other apps, aggregates deals - in this case from roughly 100 companies like The Gap, Target, eBay, Groupon and Wal-Mart. What sets TapBuy apart is how easy it is to set up and use.

Though I'm often reluctant to begin reading a series several volumes in, there are two arrivals on the manga list this week that have me reconsidering that stance. At No. 9 on the list is vol. 5 of "Arisa," by Natsumi Ando, about Tsubasa who impersonates her twin sister Arisa at her school and remains undercover to find out why she attempted suicide. Apparently everyone in Arisa's class has a secret and it involves mysterious text messages to someone named King. At No. 10 on the list is vol. 5 of "Until the Full Moon," by Sanami Matoh. That series follows Marlo, a half-werewolf-half-vampire, who becomes something else in the light of a full moon: a girl. Adding to the complications is the fact that David, a vampire playboy, is interested in Marlo's female form. And Marlo's parents are not the least bit frazzled: if their doctor friend can't help Marlo, their son, they seem fine with David marrying Marlo, their daughter.

Mr. Wicker, a New York Times correspondent, editor and columnist who was on the scene at both the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and the Attica prison uprising, died on Friday at his home near Rochester, Vt., Robert D. McFadden writes in an obituary. On Nov. 22, 1963, Mr. Wicker was "part of the presidential motorcade as it wound through downtown Dallas, the lone Times reporter on a routine political trip to Texas." Mr. McFadden writes that, "The searing images of that day - the rifleman's shots cracking across Dealey Plaza, the wounded president lurching forward in the open limousine, the blur of speed to Parkland Memorial Hospital and the nation's anguish as the doctors gave way to the priests and a new era - were dictated by Mr. Wicker from a phone booth ..." Before you devour your second (third?) slice of Mom's leftover homemade pumpkin pie, opt for a still seasonal but healthy alternative: an organic, sugar-free pumpkin pie smoothie. Created by Dr. Frank Lipman, the founder and director of the Eleven Eleven Wellness Center in Manhattan -- which promotes "good medicine," like lifestyle changes through diet, nutrition, exercise and stress management -- this dessert complies with his challenging but not impossible 14-day-long "Be Well" food-and-shake cleanse ($200). The gluten-free treat substitutes unsweetened vanilla almond milk for cream and calls for organic pumpkin and a little raw honey or cinnamon in place of sugar. "When you eat sugars, your body gets an initial surge of energy, your body scrambles to process it, and then you crash," Lipman says about sugar, a depression-linked carbohydrate. "This process triggers the body to crave more sugar, and a vicious cycle of craving, eating and crashing begins." Sounds alarmingly familiar, eh? On the bright side, Lipman does promote a lot of sleep to combat sugar cravings around the holidays. The easy-to-follow recipe is below, so you can nap and have all the taste of pumpkin pie you want this holiday season.Pumpkin Pie Smoothie - Serves 1

Even if you can't remember who James Bond's adversary was in a given movie or what Agent 007 was supposed to be saving the world from, you can probably recall the nifty, surreptitious and often lethal gadgets provided to him by Q, the pseudonymous tech wizard of Her Majesty's Secret Service. The character's Q division was named in Ian Fleming's novels, and a forerunner of the character, called Major Boothroyd, appears in the inaugural Bond film, "Dr. No." But the avuncular Q is most closely associated with Desmond Llewelyn, the actor who played the role in 17 Bond movies beginning with "From Russia With Love" (in 1963) and ending with "The World Is Not Enough." John Cleese took over the character briefly, and Q has so far made no appearances at all in the rebooted Bond films starring Daniel Craig. But all of that - cue that jazzy theme music - is about to change.

A fifth concert has been added to a four-day festival early next year in honor of the 75th birthday of Philip Glass. The new concert will feature works by Nico Muhly, Tania Léon, Vijay Iyer and Zack Glass, Mr. Glass's son. The concerts will take place from Feb. 23 to 26 at the Park Avenue Armory, and constitute its second Tune-In Music Festival - the latest example of how the armory is playing an increasingly important role in the New York performing-arts scene. Most of the works during the festival will be by Philip Glass, below. But in the additional concert, scheduled for noon on Feb. 26, Mr. Muhly will perform his own compositions for piano and will be joined by the violist Nadia Sirota; Ms. Léon will play original piano works; Mr. Iyer will perform with the South Indian guitarist Prasanna (who goes by the one name) and Nitin Mitta, a tabla player; and the guitarist and vocalist Zack Glass will perform songs of Ruben Gonzalez, a singer-songwriter, with Mr. Gonzalez.

Readers who want to borrow Penguin e-books from libraries through their Kindles have won a reprieve. Penguin on Wednesday reversed course and said its e-books on the devices would be available at least through the end of the year, The Associated Press reported. Earlier in the week Penguin said that it would halt the availability because of security concerns. Publishers have grown increasingly nervous that the checking out of e-books remotely from libraries would hurt sales.

An apartment with graffiti by Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols is an important historical and archaeological site, according to a paper published in the journal Antiquity, the BBC reported. Rotten, born John Lydon, drew on the walls of the band's London apartment in 1975 because he disliked a recent redecoration. "The tabloid press once claimed that early Beatles recordings discovered at the BBC were the most important archaeological find since Tutankhamen's tomb," wrote John Schofield and Paul Graves-Brown, archaeologists at the University of York. "The Sex Pistols' graffiti in Denmark Street surely ranks alongside this and - to our minds - usurps it." The graffiti mainly consists of eight cartoons drawn in black marker in the upper room of the apartment, now used as offices. The authors say the drawings are "a direct and powerful representation of a radical and dramatic movement of rebellion." The art depicts Mr. Lydon and other members of the band, including Sid Vicious and their manager, Malcolm McLaren. The current occupants of the house have said they have no plans to remove the graffiti.

PUT down the drumstick. Put on ''The Little Drummer Boy.'' And then thumb through this handy guide to holiday gift-giving in the world of the arts. Music, movies, theater, books, art, television and video games. It's all here, in a selective list from this year's deep pool of offerings. Maybe your baby brother likes Berlioz or your hip-hop mom moves to M F Doom. For cinephiles, ''Citizen Kane'' is now on Blu-ray. And there has to be a book for everyone on your list. It could be the one about rubber ducks lost at sea. Or an 18-pounder between covers that calls itself an art museum. They're here too. Take a look. The critics of The New York Times have some suggestions for you, below, and on Pages 4-42, with an expanded list at nytimes.com.

The fat lady hasn't started singing yet, but she's holding the mikeand the band is about to play. CRAIG MOFFETT, an analyst at the investment research firm Sanford C. Bernstein, on the unraveling of the proposed merger of cellphone giants AT&T and T-Mobile USA. [A3]

A man slapped a senior Indian minister in New Delhi on Thursday, shouting ''All are thieves, I will kill them all,'' while brandishing a ceremonial dagger. He claimed that he slapped Sharad Pawar, the country's agriculture minister, because he was angry about corruption and rising prices. The entire episode was captured by a television news crew that had been covering an appearance in the capital by Mr. Pawar. The 70-year-old Mr. Pawar was walking toward a staircase after attending a function when the man accosted and slapped him. Media reports identified the man as Harvinder Singh.

AMBITION IN A LOWER KEY THE BEACH BOYS: 'THE SMILE SESSIONS' The 1966-67 recordings of ''Smile,'' the attempted masterwork that Brian Wilson couldn't finish, have finally been rescued from the bootleg netherworld, and they sound more innocent and more experimental than the ''Smile'' album Mr. Wilson reconstructed and rerecorded in 2004. ''Smile,'' as completed in 2011 from the old tapes, is nearly as lightheaded as it is lofty, merging vast musical and literary ambitions with the whims of a songwriter who loved vocal-harmony nonsense syllables like ''la-oonga-dada.''

''Crazy Wisdom,'' Johanna Demetrakas's documentary about Chogyam Trungpa, a Tibetan who was instrumental in bringing Buddhism to the West, clearly loves its subject well. Too well. Ms. Demetrakas's film bathes in Trungpa's glow and spends much time with his followers, who talk about his teachings and his impact on their lives. (He died in 1987, at 48.) But the movie goes mushy when it should be critical, and leaves you with questions that it's not prepared to answer. Trungpa escaped from Tibet in 1959 after the Chinese invasion. He studied at Oxford and opened a Tibetan center in Scotland, where he gave up his monastic vows, married a 15-year-old British girl and was partially paralyzed in a car accident. (He was probably driving drunk.) In 1970 he moved to the United States, eventually founding the Naropa Institute (now Naropa University) in Boulder, Colo.

SIMON--Ellen R.,stained glass artist, died at 95. Raised in Toronto, Ontario, she worked as a stained glass artist in Manhattan, providing commissioned windows for churches, synagogues and universities.

Brooks Brothers returned this month to Broadway in the East 20s, near Madison Square Park, after 96 years away. Don't go back looking for butlers' livery with buttons bearing your family crest, however. The new 7,200-square-foot Brooks Brothers Flatiron Shop is intended more for the collegiate set than the carriage trade. In the casually chockablock showroom at 901 Broadway, on the corner of East 20th Street, sack suits are paired with ski vests and Harris tweed jackets are shown next to blue jeans or sweat pants. The store occupies part of what was Lord & Taylor's flagship long ago.

The year 1962 produced two debuts: the establishing and formal naming of Amnesty International as a permanent human rights advocate, according to its official history, and Bob Dylan's first album. Nearly 50 years later, those two facts will become indelibly joined when a benefit recording project of Mr. Dylan's music is released. More than 80 performers are covering four CDs' worth of his songs, numbering about 75, Amnesty said. The album is called ''Chimes of Freedom: The Songs of Bob Dylan Honoring 50 Years of Amnesty International'' and will be released in North America on Jan. 24 and elsewhere on Jan. 30. The performers include Sting, Patti Smith, Pete Seeger, Miley Cyrus, Joan Baez, Jackson Browne, Maroon 5 and Elvis Costello. Most of the recordings are being released for sale for the first time, except for ''Chimes of Freedom,'' recorded by Mr. Dylan in 1964, Amnesty said.

ARE collectors and music nerds now the only people buying albums? Apparently that's the judgment behind many of this year's gargantuan boxed sets. Back when recording companies began seriously repackaging their catalogs, they turned themselves into curators, thoughtfully summing up careers and pop movements in boxed sets that strove to put history in perspective or, perhaps, put a better face on it. A box could be both the introduction to, and the distillate of, a body of work. Among this year's harvest of boxed sets, compilations and reissues, some still make an effort to be selective, with musicians like Paul Simon and the members of R.E.M. winnowing their own careers, and collector-historians at labels like Now-Again and Tompkins Square organizing their greatest finds.

An article on Saturday about the reopening of the investigation into the death of the actress Natalie Wood after 30 years referred imprecisely to the status of the movie she was making at the time. Though Ms. Wood had finished filming her scenes in the film, ''Brainstorm,'' the movie itself was still in production; it had not been completed.

And at the beginning of this month, Mr. Wien, vice chairman of Blackstone Advisory Partners, said he was maintaining his 5 percent allocation to gold for next year.

KOENIG--Jane Schimel, on November 24, 2011 after a long and valiant fight with cancer. Graduated from The Dalton School and University of Michigan. Jane was an Assistant Director and past National Vice President of The Directors Guild of America. Recently she was a realtor in New Jersey. Daughter of the late Muriel and Adolph Schimel. Survived by her loving husband Arthur, her devoted sister Judy and dear cousin to Stephen Jacobs and the Schaffman family. Graveside service today Old Mount Caramel Cemetery, Glendale, NY at 12:30pm. Donations can be made to The American Cancer Society.

BALTIMORE (AP) -- The Baltimore Ravens tied a franchise record with nine sacks and beat the San Francisco 49ers on Thursday night, 16-6, giving John Harbaugh reason to celebrate after the first N.F.L. game featuring brothers as opposing head coaches. The Ravens (8-3) chased, hindered and battered Alex Smith for much of the night despite playing without middle linebacker Ray Lewis, the team's leading tackler and vocal leader. Lewis was inactive for a second straight game with a foot injury.

An article on Saturday about the opening of an REI outdoor equipment store in Manhattan misidentified the river that is visible from Highbridge Park, one of the areas used for employee training. It is the Harlem River, not the East River.

Hamilton III and Margot Hamilton, and grandmother of Joel Hamilton, Elizabeth H. Dixon, and Jason Spaar. A Memorial Service will be held at a future date. Services by Boston Harborside Home of J.S. Michael Grandage, director of the Donmar Warehouse theater and known to New York audiences this season for his Metropolitan Opera production of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' is striking out on his own. Mr. Grandage is leaving the Donmar in London at the end of the year, and in an interview with that city's Evening Standard said he would form his own commercial company, without a home base. After 15 years running established companies, ''It seems entirely appropriate to think about what I can take from those years, form a company that's buildingless and go out and make work,'' he told the newspaper. ''It feels right at 49.'' The Evening Standard said that he and his executive producer at the Donmar, James Bierman, have formed Michael Grandage Productions. Mr. Grandage said he also hoped to make an independent movie. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ARLINGTON, Tex. -- Tony Romo looked and sounded like a veteran quarterback finally ready to shed his image as a gunslinger with superficial numbers. Style points apparently no longer matter to the surging Dallas Cowboys and Romo. As the players trotted toward the star emblazoned at midfield on Thursday after a last-second 20-19 victory over the Miami Dolphins, they appeared more calm than celebratory.

TURI--Dr. Edith A.,93, on November 6, 2011. A research coordinator at the Hungarian National Academy of Sciences, she survived Nazi occupation and escaped to America after the failed Hungarian uprising in 1956. She earned a Ph.D. and became one of the founding figures and leading experts in the field of thermal analysis. Winner of the Mettler-Toledo Award, her textbook The Thermal Characterization of Polymeric Materials is a classic in the field. She was President of the North American Thermal Analysis Society and the long time regional editor of the Journal of Thermal Analysis and Calorimetry. She taught extensively around the world. A Research Professor at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn well into her 80s, where the Professor Edith A. Turi Thermal Analysis Laboratory was established in her honor, she was a networker before there were networks, passionate promoter of her colleagues' careers, enthusiastic traveler, gourmet cook, and doting grandmother. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Paul Turi, revered mother and mother-in-law of Zoltan and Adele, and cherished grandmother of Michael; loved and missed.

In the past two decades, the Mexican population in New York City has grown more than fivefold, with immigrants settling across the five boroughs. Many adults have demonstrated remarkable success at finding work, filling restaurant kitchens and construction sites, and opening hundreds of businesses. But their children, in one crucial respect, have fared far differently.

An article on Monday about the men's basketball team at Chaminade University of Honolulu, which hosts the annual Maui Invitational tournament, misstated the month in 1982 in which the team upset Virginia. It was December, not January.

A picture caption on Saturday with a theater review of ''The Infernal Comedy: Confessions of a Serial Killer,'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, rendered incorrectly the surname of the director of the Vienna Academy Orchestra, which provided music. He is Martin Haselböck, not Haselbock.

The National Gallery in London says it is cracking down on ticket-scalping for a major exhibition of the works of Leonardo da Vinci, which opened on Nov. 9. BBC News reports that the gallery will enforce warnings that resold tickets ''will be cancelled without refund and admission will be refused to the bearer,'' and is asking resale Web sites to halt the practice. The museum declined to say how it would identify scalped tickets, according to the BBC. The show has drawn large crowds, and on Thursday, the U.K. eBay site listed the starting bid for a pair at up to $250 and the Viagogo site had a ticket as high as $389.01. Tickets through the museum cost 16 pounds, or about $25. ''Leonardo Da Vinci: Painter at the Court of Milan'' runs through Feb. 5. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SILBERBERG--Ruth. (nee Schlesinger). Ruth died at home on November 23, 2011. Born November 9, 1912 in Berlin, Germany to Frieda and Georg Schlesinger, predeceased by her husband of 49 years, Rudi, mother to Eve Naomi (Thomas) and David (Skipper), loving grandmother to Nicole, Claude and Genevieve and five great-grandchildren. A great spirit and traveller, she lived in Tel Aviv, New York City and ended her days peacefully at home on Cape Cod.

A fifth concert has been added to a four-day festival early next year in honor of the 75th birthday of Philip Glass. The new concert will feature works by Nico Muhly, Tania Leon, Vijay Iyer and Zack Glass, Mr. Glass's son. The concerts will take place from Feb. 23 to 26 at the Park Avenue Armory, and constitute its second Tune-In Music Festival - the latest example of how the armory is playing an increasingly important role in the New York performing-arts scene. Most of the works during the festival will be by Philip Glass, below. But in the additional concert, scheduled for noon on Feb. 26, Mr. Muhly will perform his own compositions for piano and will be joined by the violist Nadia Sirota; Ms. Leon will play original piano works; Mr. Iyer will perform with the South Indian guitarist Prasanna (who goes by the one name) and Nitin Mitta, a tabla player; and the guitarist and vocalist Zack Glass will perform songs of Ruben Gonzalez, a singer-songwriter, with Mr. Gonzalez. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A music review on Monday about ''Cotton Club Parade,'' at New York City Center, misstated part of the title of one of the Duke Ellington songs performed. It is ''Creole Love Call,'' not ''Creole Love Song.''

With the other networks taking a holiday from their regular prime-time schedules, ABC emerged as No. 1 in all ratings categories on Wednesday thanks to its usual comedy lineup. A new episode of ''Modern Family'' led the way, with 12.6 million total viewers, followed by ''The Middle,'' at 9.1 million, according to Nielsen estimates. Elsewhere, a special Wednesday live results episode of ''The X Factor'' drew 8.5 million total viewers and put Fox in second place for the night in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic. CBS was in third place with a slate of repeats and a recap episode of ''Survivor: South Pacific.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Miller--Steven Allen, 66, of NYC, beloved husband of Pam Elgar, brother of Doreen Perry and step-father of Magnolia Grossman, died November 18 in Israel with his Adamit family. He was predeceased by his son Jonathan Miller. Steve was President of Plymouth Management Group, Inc., a lover of jazz, language and a Mets fan (except this year). Steve was a proud grandfather to Lilac and August. His gentleness, warmth and integrity will be missed by his family, his many close friends, including his poker buddies, and Max.

DENVER -- They call him Big Mountain Jesus: a six-foot statue of Christ, draped in a baby-blue robe and gazing out over the majestic Flathead Valley from his perch along a ski run at the Whitefish Mountain Resort in Montana. He has been there for more than 50 years, erected by the local Knights of Columbus chapter in honor of the soldiers from the 10th Mountain Division who told of seeing similar shrines in the mountains of Italy during World War II.

Readers who want to borrow Penguin e-books from libraries through their Kindles have won a reprieve. Penguin on Wednesday reversed course and said its e-books on the devices would be available at least through the end of the year, The Associated Press reported. Earlier in the week Penguin said that it would halt the availability because of security concerns. Publishers have grown increasingly nervous that the checking out of e-books remotely from libraries would hurt sales. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

His legacy lives on in his beautiful family - His loving wife Roslyn, his devoted children, Sheila and Bill Lambert, Erica and Martin Frederick, Andrew and Linda Sonabend and his adoring grandchildren. Rebbetzin Esther Jungreis and The Hineni Family

SONABEND--David, Dr.,died November 22, 2011 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL at age 88 after a brief illness. David was a dedicated and brilliant physician, a philanthropist and active participant in Jewish causes in the US and Israel, and a caring and generous friend to so many. He is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Roslyn; his children whom he adored, Erica, Martin, Sheila, Bill, Andrew and Linda; his grandchildren Ben, Stephanie, Phineas, Daily, Shara, Andy and Jessica; and his great-grandchildren, Sam, Jordan, Oscar and Zelde Rae who gave him such pleasure. He has left all of us an extraordinary legacy of learning, commitment to service and loving kindness. He will always be in our hearts. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, November 27, 2011, 12 noon at Temple Emanuel, 455 Neptune Blvd, Long Beach, NY.

Enough with the cultural imperialism, already: World music no longer means fetishistic collections of traditional sounds untouched by time or modernity. Decades of syncretism have created all sorts of hybrids. The secret, though, is that those hybrids have been there all along, undernoticed by those in search of the falsely authentic. Several recent compilations prove the point, showing especially the vitality of the 1970s as an era in which funk slithered easily across borders. That's not a surprise in India, where Bollywood soundtrack music has long been one of the world's most versatile sounds. Some thundering examples are collected on ''Psych-Funk Sa-Re-Ga! Seminar: Aesthetic Expressions of Psychedelic Funk Music in India 1970-1983.'' There's lithe funk, creepy incidental music, astral singing by Asha Bhosle, and a handful of spooky, swinging R. D. Burman compositions.
WALTERS--Helen, 94, a leader of New York Hadassah, beloved sister, aunt, great-aunt, great-great-aunt. Services, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Sunday, 1pm.

As stock markets continue on their roller-coaster ride, even investors who profess to be buy-and-hold types have become eager users of mobile technology that allows them to track their portfolios almost on a minute-by-minute basis. That tendency, apparently, goes double for private banking clients, who investment managers say demand more information than the average investor and are embracing smartphone use at a fast clip.

An apartment with graffiti by Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols is an important historical and archaeological site, according to a paper published in the journal Antiquity, the BBC reported. Rotten, born John Lydon, drew on the walls of the band's London apartment in 1975 because he disliked a recent redecoration. ''The tabloid press once claimed that early Beatles recordings discovered at the BBC were the most important archaeological find since Tutankhamen's tomb,'' wrote John Schofield and Paul Graves-Brown, archaeologists at the University of York. ''The Sex Pistols' graffiti in Denmark Street surely ranks alongside this and - to our minds - usurps it.'' The graffiti mainly consists of eight cartoons drawn in black marker in the upper room of the apartment, now used as offices. The authors say the drawings are ''a direct and powerful representation of a radical and dramatic movement of rebellion.'' The art depicts Mr. Lydon and other members of the band, including Sid Vicious and their manager, Malcolm McLaren. The current occupants of the house have said they have no plans to remove the graffiti. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
WIENER--A. Walter 11/25/11 - 5/27/11. Today would have been his 100th birthday. We will never ever forget him. His adoring family

CAIRO -- Egypt's interim military rulers and the masses of protesters demanding their exit dug in Thursday for a prolonged standoff as the generals vowed to forge ahead with parliamentary elections despite a week of violence that is certain to tarnish the vote. State news organizations reported that at least one political party -- the Social Democrats, perhaps the best established of the liberal parties founded in the burst of hope after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak nine months ago -- would boycott the elections as a sham intended to prop up military rule.
A view of the day in sports, from golf amid the lush foliage of southern China to soccer on the sands of Dubai.

Four people in the Philippines hacked into the accounts of AT&T business customers in the United States and diverted money to a group that financed terrorist attacks across Asia, according to police officials in the Philippines, Somini Sengupta of The New York Times reports.
An interview with John Riccitiello, chief executive of Electronic Arts, provides insights on what he thinks about management.

Researchers have come up with an intriguing option for the wasted heat in data centers: using them as "data furnaces" in people's homes, writes Randall Stross in his Digital Domain column in The New York Times. He writes that two researchers at the University of Virginia and four at Microsoft Research explored this possibility in a paper that examined how corporate servers could be placed inside homes and used as a source of heat.

What's new in the baby-naming game is the level of complexity that Google and other search engines have brought, reports Allen Salkin of The New York Times. He writes that some parents want names that are unique so their child will rise to the top of future search results. Others want names that are uncommon enough to bestow uniqueness, but not so exotic that they would be considered weird on the playground. A rare few want their child's name to get lost in a virtual crowd.

Jo-Wilfried Tsonga held off Tomas Berdych, 6-3, 7-5, to book his spot in the final of the ATP World Tour Finals in London, the Frenchman's biggest final since his improbable run to the Australian Open final in 2008.

Some Rangers old-timers who will skate Dec. 31 in the Rangers-Flyers alumni game at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia as part of the Winter Classic festivities were on hand at the Garden on Saturday. Mike Gartner, looking trim at 52 after a career in which he scored 708 regular-season goals, was asked if he still had his legendary speed. "If I did, I'd still be playing," he said.
A woman who escaped from the back of a police car on Friday after being arrested for robbing a cabdriver in Brooklyn was recaptured by the police a day later, the authorities said.
Bills (5-5) at Jets ( 5-5), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS
Rivalries mark the last big weekend of the regular season, with Michigan defeating Ohio State, Auburn battling Alabama and Kentucky notching its first win against Tennessee in 26 years.

Congressional leaders from both parties will gather Sunday to examine the collapse of the deficit deal, which could lead to significant cuts in military and domestic programs. Contenders for the Republican presidential nomination and a leader from the Congressional Progressive Caucus will also discuss the political fallout from the deal's collapse.

SUNDAY'S PUZZLE - First things first: What a gorgeous grid! Jeff Chen returns to us today with what I consider to be a kind of masterpiece: not only has he set the grid swirling with Yin and Yang, but some of the entries/elements themselves exhibit Yin and Yang characteristics. I'll explain.

My Sunday column argues that President Obama is, in market terms, oversold; as we approach an election year, let's look at other candidates and remember the context. Sure, we have our disappointments with Obama, but he also has legitimate achievements that tend to be overlooked in this economic downturn. And he's tacking against unbelievable headwinds, economic and political: no president is going to be popular with 9 percent unemployment. All in all, I think he's been better than many critics on left and right acknowledge.

A bit more on the subject of whether there's significant money to be raised through higher taxes on the very rich. As it happens, there's a recent analysis from the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center that bears quite closely on this subject.
