An article on Thursday about Frank Wildhorn, composer of the music for the Broadway show ''Bonnie & Clyde,'' which opens Thursday, erroneously attributed a distinction to ''Jekyll & Hyde,'' an earlier Broadway musical for which he wrote the music. While it did receive four Tony nominations, it did not receive one for best musical. The article also misspelled the given name of a country music singer for whom Mr. Wildhorn has written. She is Trisha Yearwood, not Tricia.

An article on Wednesday about a Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night misidentified, in some copies, the candidate referred to as ''highly naïve'' for suggesting that the United States cut off aid to Pakistan. And a correction in this space on Thursday misspelled -- because of an error by the corrections editor -- the given name of the candidate who made the comment. She is Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota (not Michelle) and she criticized Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, not former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania.

It might be the longest-standing spoiler alert in theater history: ''The Mousetrap,'' the London stage production of the Agatha Christie mystery that still asks its audience not to reveal the killer's identity, began its 60th year on Friday and announced a tour of Britain among other special events to mark the murderous milestone. ''The Mousetrap,'' which was first presented as a radio drama in 1947, made its West End debut at the Ambassadors Theater on Nov. 25, 1952, in a production that starred Richard Attenborough and Sheila Sim, his wife, as Detective Sergeant Trotter and the innkeeper Mollie Ralston. It was there that Mr. Attenborough first made the speech urging audiences to keep the play's secret. (A controversy ensued last year when the ending was posted on Wikipedia.)

Schizophrenia is the best thing that ever happened to me. I know a lot of people with the diagnosis don't feel that way, but the experience changed me, for the better. I was so arrogant, so narcissistic, so self-involved, and it humbled me. MILT GREEK,of Athens, Ohio. [A18]

Setting foot into a screening of ''The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1,'' the latest installment in the hit film series about the romance between a mortal girl and a sparkly vampire boy, may induced an unexpected kind of overstimulation: a few viewers say they have experienced epileptic seizures that, The Guardian reports, could be a result of rapidly changing colors in the film's climactic childbirth scene. Brandon Gephart of Roseville, Calif., who attended a showing of ''Breaking Dawn'' with his girlfriend, Kelly Bauman, was taken to a hospital following the scene in which the newlywed Bella (played by Kristen Stewart) delivers the daughter of her vampire husband, Edward (Robert Pattinson), as red, white and black strobes flash on the screen. ''He was convulsing, snorting, trying to breathe,'' Ms. Bauman told the Sacramento affiliate of CBS News.

Based on the early Nielsen ratings Lady Gaga may not become a Thanksgiving mainstay like Charlie Brown, but ''A Very Gaga Thanksgiving'' still posted solid numbers on Thursday night for ABC with a total audience of 5.7 million viewers. The 90-minute special, where Gaga performed a handful of songs and showed off some curious wardrobe choices, was ABC's highest-rated show in that time period - 9:30 p.m. to 11 - in four years. CBS finished first in prime time over all and a repeat of ''The Big Bang Theory'' was the No. 1 program of the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and in total viewers, with 11.2 million. Earlier in the day the audience for NBC's broadcast of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade was down - according to Nielsen's preliminary overnight estimates - by about 3 percent compared to last year, when 22.1 million viewers tuned in. Final audience figures were not available on Friday.
GROSS--Sidney. November 26, 1986. The passage of 25 years has not dimmed our longing for your love, laughter and care. In our hearts always. Zenith & The Family

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about retailers' pressing the Federal Reserve for lower fees on debit card transactions misstated part of the name of the trade organization at which Mallory Duncan, who commented on the issue, is a senior vice president and general counsel. As the article correctly noted, he is with the National Retail Federation, not the National Retail Foundation.

For the South Dakota native David Hallberg his appearance on the storied main stage of the Bolshoi Ballet last Friday was, he said beforehand, probably the most important appearance of his career - a stress-filled test of whether the Bolshoi's artistic director, Sergei Filin, had made a good bet in bringing him to Moscow as the company's first American principal dancer. The stakes had been ratcheted up four days before Mr. Hallberg's performance in ''Sleeping Beauty'' by the news that Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev, two of the Bolshoi's young stars, were leaving for the Mikhailovsky Theater, a lesser-known house in St. Petersburg financed by the billionaire Vladimir Kekhman. The news came as a blow to Mr. Hallberg, who said that the opportunity to dance with Ms. Osipova was ''15 percent'' of the reason he had joined the Bolshoi. Mr. Kekhman, gloating over his success, told the Independent that he would poach Mr. Hallberg ''in the next year or so.''
Sonabend--Dr. David. The JCC in Manhattan expresses condolences to board member Sheila Lambert and her family on the death of her beloved father. May his memory be a blessing.

This year's award for ''best performance in an insurance education video'' goes to -- William Shatner. In an inspired choice, State Farm recruited him to record a video about the perils of turkey frying. Apparently Mr. Shatner is a fan of fried turkeys, and also was a victim of a propane fryer-related inferno - so his words of warning and wisdom flow from experience. That makes him an ideal narrator for State Farm's educational campaign, aimed at preventing potentially damaging house fires caused by inept fryer chefs.
WALTERS--Helen, 94, a leader of New York Hadassah, beloved sister, aunt, great-aunt, great-great-aunt. Services, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Sunday, 1pm.

12:30 A.M. (Oxygen) DUPLICITY (2009) She -- Julia Roberts as the long-legged Claire, standing around a garden in a flowery dress, looking bored -- is C.I.A. He -- Clive Owen (above, with Ms. Roberts) as Ray, on whom a suit becomes a brazenly sexy uniform -- is MI6. Five years after meeting over frozen drinks at a Middle Eastern Fourth of July barbecue and ending up in bed, they decide to abandon their respective governments and go to work on opposite sides of the global market beauty-product battlefield, with puffed-up generals portrayed by Paul Giamatti and Tom Wilkinson. ''It's a caper movie, a love story,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film written and directed by Tony Gilroy, ''an extra-dry corporate satire. However you describe it, 'Duplicity' is superior entertainment, the most elegantly pleasurable movie of its kind to come around in a very long time.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York discusses the ''proper principles of governance'' and argues for the banishment of capital punishment in the United States.

Does the fee have any relationship whatsoever to the cost of the service? Do companies understand that they don't have much leeway if we already are angry with them? Is a company telling the whole truth when it imposes a new fee? Are we getting something really neat in return? And are we worrying too much about the wrong types of fees -- and not enough about ones that are truly consequential? These are the five questions I posed in this weekend's Your Money column. In the wake of the Bank of America debit-card fee fiasco, it sure seems as if we need a new set of standards for what constitutes a reasonable fee. So this week, I asked some of the smartest consumers I know to weigh in on the question.

Even if you can't remember who James Bond's adversary was in a given movie or what Agent 007 was supposed to be saving the world from, you can probably recall the nifty, surreptitious and often lethal gadgets provided to him by Q, the pseudonymous tech wizard of Her Majesty's Secret Service. The character's Q division was named in Ian Fleming's novels, and a forerunner of the character, called Major Boothroyd, appears in the inaugural Bond film, ''Dr. No.'' But the avuncular Q is most closely associated with Desmond Llewelyn, the actor who played the role in 17 Bond movies beginning with ''From Russia With Love'' (in 1963) and ending with ''The World Is Not Enough.'' John Cleese took over the character briefly, and Q has so far made no appearances at all in the rebooted Bond films starring Daniel Craig. But all of that - cue that jazzy theme music - is about to change. Ben Whishaw, a star of the television miniseries ''The Hour'' and Julie Taymor's film adaptation of ''The Tempest,'' will play Q in the coming 23rd installment of the James Bond franchise, BBC News reported. Mr. Whishaw, who is also slated to play Richard II for the BBC, is a mere 31 years old to Mr. Craig's 43, marking the first time in the film series that Q will be younger than Bond. None of Q's new gadgets were immediately announced - a murderous iPhone, perhaps? - though producers have said that the new Bond movie will be called ''Skyfall,'' a decision whose implications this blog has previously addressed.

STEINBERG--Natalie, 88 years old, died on November 24, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted and cherished mother of Leigh, Ellen and the late Neil Steinberg. Adored grandmother of Brandon, Haley and Ashley Finkelstein. Dedicated teacher to many students in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Her love for life and family will never be forgotten. Services: Sunday, 1pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

If you haven't flown through La Guardia Airport in recent months, you're in for a surprise. Whether it's a pleasant surprise or an unhappy one depends on your feelings about curvaceous, eccentric, whimsical architecture that looks as if it could have been built for the 1964 World's Fair - which, in a sense, La Guardia's air control tower was. (Had it been in Flushing Meadows, it would have made an excellent Swiss Cheese Pavilion.)

WILLIAMS--John M. PR Newswire mourns the passing of pioneer and visionary, John M. Williams, 66. John challenged each of us to do better, to think bigger and to be the best that we could be. His contributions to the media and communications industry were tremendous and he will be missed by all who knew him. Our heartfelt condolences go to his wife Donna, sisters Julia and Sarah and the rest of his family and friends.

The holidays are coming, and right on cue, my mailbox is filling up with catalogs. I like getting some of them because it's fun to browse for gift ideas. (Hmm. I'd spring for the $35 golden Hufflepuff Cup for my Harry Potter-loving children, but the fine print in the catalog from the Noble Collection warns it ''cannot be used as drink ware.'') But the trade-off for a few minutes of amusement is that our recycling bin is overflowing with catalogs from Lands' End, L.L. Bean, Pottery Barn, Restoration Hardware and the other usual suspects. Do I really need all of them, when I can just go online and see what's on the menu?

Louis J. Freeh, the former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was asked on Friday to become the trustee for MF Global as it seeks to unwind itself in bankruptcy court. The choice of Mr. Freeh, 61, comes as MF Global faces inquiries by several government agencies, including the F.B.I., into its demise. Investigators are still searching for hundreds of millions of dollars in missing client funds, which by one estimate now totals $1.2 billion.

An article on Friday about six voters in the Harris Interactive College Football Poll, which helps determine the Bowl Championship Series matchups, referred imprecisely to the military record of Pete Dawkins, one of the voters and a retired brigadier general who won the 1958 Heisman Trophy as a halfback at Army. While he fought in the Vietnam War and commanded a battalion in Korea from 1971 to 1972, he did not fight in ''the Korean and Vietnam Wars.''

EDELSTEIN--Robert D. Beloved husband of the late Claire Edelstein. Loving father of Eddie and Sandy, grandfather and great-grandfather. Died November 22 at age 94. He left a legacy of community service and a loving and devoted family.

FIEDERLEIN--Dennis Eugene, Jr.,died November 24, 2011. Born in New York City on May 19, 1931, he was son of Dennis E. and Florence Muller Fiederlein. On June 14, 1962, he married Grace Fogarty. Dennis served in the US Army. He was a High School Teacher for New York City Board of Education until his retirement in 1990. Dennis is survived by his wife, Grace; daughter, Denise O'Shea; granddaughters, Christie and Danielle O'Shea; and many cousins, nieces, nephews, and friends. Calling hours on Sunday from 2-6pm at McHoul Funeral Home, Inc., Hopewell Jct. Funeral Mass on Monday at 10am at St. Columbia Church, Hopewell Jct. followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne with military honors. Memorial donations to USO or Wounded Warrior Project. Visit mchoulfuneralhome.com.

It also represents a blow to Mitt Romney, who had led all polls of the state.

Walls are back in fashion. Walls and fences. Not long ago, you may recall, Republican presidential candidates expressed their devotion to them. In October Michele Bachmann  signed a pledge to support the construction of a fence that would run the entire length of the United States-Mexico border. Not to be outdone, Herman Cain voiced his support for an electrified border fence, one juiced up enough to be lethal: Touch it and die. As someone who grew up behind the Iron Curtain, I happen to know how the device works; in a certain way, we invented it (we should have copyrighted it). The ability to cross  the "lethal fence" used to be part of the East-European survival kit.

McCLURE--Douglas Bryan. Douglas Bryan McClure Pioneer in the Art of Incentive Negotiation for U.S. Corporations, dies at 63. Bryan McClure of Figure Eight Island, NC, the consummate family man, prominent civic leader, accomplished businessman, and former football standout, passed away at his beloved beachfront home with his family by his side. Bryan was a true renaissance man with a 40+ year career that spanned banking, real estate, education, and economic development. While he found success in all of these endeavors, it was in economic development a field he joined in the late 1980's as an economic development director for Northampton County, NC where he was to make his imprint, first in a series of increasingly prominent public sector jobs, including as the Chief Development Officer for the Michigan Jobs Commission, and then in the private sector as the founder of the Blair Group and ROI Consultants. A 1995 profile in the Wall Street Journal described Bryan as a "New Breed of Site Consultant", later capturing his essential spirit in a quoted response to a question about his aggressive negotiating style: "When I see someone without a job, I just ache for them I want to do everything in my power to help." Bryan's work helped create tens of thousands of jobs and billions of dollars of investment. Well known for his vocabulary, sharp wit, and ability to articulate, Bryan was a sought after public speaker at many national forums. In 1991 he gave the keynote speech at the Global Economic Forum in Sao Paulo, Brazil. While his accomplishments in business, civic leadership, and football will long be remembered, his greatest legacy will be his commitment to family. Bryan was born in Valdese, NC, the son of the late Eris Louise Benfield McClure and Julius Plato McClure. He received a B.A. degree in Geography from East Carolina University and later studied at the Harvard-Kennedy School of Government, focusing on public administration. At East Carolina University, Bryan was the captain of the football team and upon graduation he was invited to play for the Miami Dolphins. Bryan was a former President of the Cape Fear Red Cross, founder of the McClure School of Real Estate, Appraiser, Broker, and active member of the Episcopal Church. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Kathryn Walters McClure; two sons; Douglas Bryan McClure, Jr. and wife, Anne of Bluffton, SC, and English Blaine McClure and wife Colby of Raleigh, NC; three daughters, Blair McClure Husain and husband Fazle, Sara McClure Peters and husband Ryan, and Sloan McClure Overstrom and husband Alex, all of Manhattan, NY; three brothers, Bruce McClure of Anderson, SC, Greg McClure of Southport, SC, and the late Gary Scott McClure; two sisters, Judy Middleton and Deborah Randal, of Atlanta, GA; eleven grandchildren, Elizabeth, Sara, Charlotte, and Trice McClure of Bluffton, SC; Sloan, Blaine, Walker, and Shields McClure of Raleigh, NC; Harris, Hannah, and Asher Husain of Manhattan, NY; and one more on the way. A private funeral service was held at his family farm, Sweetbriar Farm in Morganton, NC on Friday, November 25. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the St. Jude's Children's Hospital, PO Box 1000, Department 142, Memphis, TN 38148 http://www.stjude.org/

The ''Streetscapes'' column last Sunday, about the construction of Dexter Hall at the New-York Historical Society, misstated the fate of original plans for making the hall a vaulted triple-height space. They were indeed carried out. (The hall was cut down to its current double-height space in 1938.)

THE girls are so little that some still have round toddler bellies. But their faces are grave and focused during ballet lessons in the storied Vaganova tradition, imported to Brooklyn, along with most of the teachers, from Russia. At the Brighton Ballet Theater School of Russian Ballet, most of the 400 students are children and grandchildren of Russian-speaking immigrants from the former Soviet Union. But Irina Roizin, the director, said the school's Brooklyn environs brought a diversity not yet seen onstage at Lincoln Center: There are children with roots in Africa, China and India, not to mention a Haitian-American girl, dancing since the age of 2, who speaks fluent Russian that she learned in school.

The $15.5 million sale of an apartment at the Carlyle Hotel on the Upper East Side, that cynosure of all things civilized and repository of secrets for presidents and starlets alike, was the most expensive of the week. Like the rest of the 68 private residences at the Carlyle, the four-bedroom four-and-a-half-bath apartment is a co-op. The asking price was $17.5 million, according to Streeteasy. The sale price was confirmed by the listing agency, Brown Harris Stevens. Kathy Sloane, who brokered the sale for Brown Harris, declined to comment.

For travelers in Canada seeking the midnight sun, native wood carvings or the best mountains to ski, there's a new online resource. On Tuesday the Canada Tourism Commission introduced Explore Canada Like a Local, a Web site and companion mobile app for the iPhone and Android devices. Visitors can discover what the residents recommend by activity and type. For example, users can filter by arts or cultural events, outdoor getaways, off-the-beaten-track ideas in the city center or culinary quests. Alternatively, you can search by a list of about 30 popular destinations. For lesser-known or more remote places, you'll need to search in the broader geographical categories. For instance, Kluane Lake in Yukon Territory, can be found under Northern Canada. Destinations and local haunts are posts on a map.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''For Victim 1, a Search for Trust,'' Nov. 23: The only real help for victims of sexual abuse is to be heard and supported by others in their community. They need to tell their stories, not be blamed for what happened, and be supported as they try to heal. It is not uncommon for them to feel they somehow caused the abuse to happen. The guilt and remorse they often feel can linger for years. Some victims never recover, and their lives are often destroyed.

KEITH--Mark Stanford. Died November 21, 2011, after a six year battle with cancer. Born October 21, 1955, in Coral Gables, FL, he grew up in Miami and graduated from Syracuse University in 1978. He was the recipient of the Cressey Award from SU for outstanding research and writing. Mark and his wife ran a successful horse business for 14 years in the 80's and early 90's during which time he held office as the President of the New York Palomino Exhibitors Association. He loved history and geography and was long an advocate of the working class and a stalwart union man. While employed at Monarch Machine Tool (1989-2000) he served as President of United Auto Workers Local 802, From 2000 to 2002 he was a Research Assistant at the School of Industrial & Labor Relations at Cornell University. In 2002 he went to work for Service Employees Int'l Union Local 200 United as the Research & Communications Director. At both Monarch and SEIU he wrote and published an award winning Union newsletter. He is survived by his wife of 34 years Debra, daughters Ashley and Tory, parents Kelvin and Mary Jane, brother Scott. He was predeceased by his sister Sandra. Calling hours: Tuesday, November 29 (3-6pm) at Riccardi Funeral Home, Cortland, NY, followed by a celebration of Mark's life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Relay For Life c/o Tammy McMyne, American Cancer Society, 13 Beech St. Johnson City, NY 13790.

GOLDSTEIN--Geoffrey Alan, 63, died November 23, 2011 at his home in Chicago, IL. At his request, no service will be held. Geoff was born August. 28, 1948, in NYC to Gerald and Syril Goldstein. He was a generous person who loved his grandson Kieran, his family, friends, all New York sports teams plus the Cubs, golf, cooking, Chinese food, Harry Potter fan fiction, Riley the corgi, wrapping presents, and diagramming sentences. In addition in October 2006, we believe Geoff actually surfed to the end of the internet. He didn't accept deliveries before 12 and wanted you to know that Geoff was spelled with a G. Geoff spent his youth in Washington Heights, New York City, went to the Bronx High School of Science, and graduated from Penn State University. He worked for A&S and Prudential but spent the bulk of his career with the Navy Resale System where he rose to become a Senior Manager in charge of the Facilities Division, responsible for worldwide Equipment and Maintenance. Geoff lived much of his life in Freehold, New Jersey until July of 1996 when he suffered a massive stroke. Through the following year he showed remarkable determination in exceeding all expectations to achieve his rehabilitation goal of living an independent life in Chicago. In his post-rehabilitation years service became increasingly important to him and he was very proud in October 2000 to receive the Outstanding Service award from the American Red Cross of Greater Chicago. He is survived by his son Robert, his daughter-in-law Kelly, his grandson Kieran, and his sister, Robin Povell. Donations may be sent to The American Red Cross of Greater Chicago Rauner Center 2200 West Harrison Street Chicago, IL 60612, 312-729-6120.

By air, sea and auto, travelers have new ways to reach and roam the Caribbean this season. This month American Airlines began nonstop flights to Antigua from Kennedy Airport. Also this month JetBlue began departures to La Romana in the Dominican Republic (Altos de Chavon amphitheater, right) from Kennedy, and starting Dec. 15 will fly to St. Thomas from Logan Airport in Boston. From San Juan, JetBlue will also offer connecting service to St. Thomas and St. Croix beginning Dec. 12.

An art review in some editions last Sunday about ''New York, New York! The 20th Century,'' at the Katonah Museum of Art in Westchester County, N.Y., rendered incorrectly the surname of a photographer whose work is included. He is Jim MacMillan, not Macmillan.

WALKER--Julia Armour, of Washington, CT, passed away on November 25, 2011 in New York City. Though gravely ill with pancreatic cancer, she planned and celebrated the 50th anniversary of her marriage to her beloved husband C. Carter Walker Jr. with a September dinner dance for 75 and her 70th birthday on Halloween with 90 of her masked lady friends. Julia was consistent to the end: fully engaged, energetic, loving, a best friend to hundreds, a champion of the arts, education and animals. She was a most beautiful and unique woman, a wonderful wife, mother, 'Gammy', sister, god-mother and friend. Julia transformed all who knew her. She loved people and connected them with each other for the betterment of all and the causes they served and the friendships they grew. Julia was not only smart, caring and capable but wickedly funny, creative and always beautifully dressed. She spread her loving, connective energies to the considerable benefit of many arts, educational and community service organizations. She joined the Board of Trustees of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Foundation, Inc., in 1973, serving for 38 years. She was also a member of the Boards of Lincoln Center Theater, The Museum of the American Indian/Heye Foundation, George Washington's Fredericksburg Foundation, Adirondack Museum, Ausable Club, Foxcroft School, and Bradford College. She was a partner of The Elements Gallery of Contemporary American Crafts, New York City. Born Julia Biddle Armour in Chicago, she attended Chicago Latin, Foxcroft and Bradford, then moved with husband Carter to New York City where their two children were born, C. Carter Walker III of Albuquerque, NM and Julia W. Robinson of Waterbury Center, VT. She is survived by her husband, children, grandchildren, Cole and Hart Walker and Julia and Christopher Robinson, and brother, Philip D. Armour III of San Francisco. The family requests in lieu of flowers, that donations be sent to The Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation; The Adirondack Museum, Blue Mountain Lake, NY; The North Country SPCA, Westport, NY. Written by her brother, P.D. Armour III.

PATERSON--Rose Joya Rose Joya Paterson, 85, died in her sleep at her home in Winter Park on November 23, 2011. Joya moved to Florida in 2000, shortly after retiring as President and CEO of S&S Industries in New York City. She had a long and successful career in the fashion and intimate apparel industry in New York. The Under Fashion Club awarded her several Femmy Awards for her achievements in the industry. She grew up in Forest Hills Gardens in Queens, New York, and continued to live there most of her life. She was predeceased by her husband, Stephen Paterson, her brothers, John and Joseph DeLorenzo, and her sister, Marie Lynch. She is survived by her loving son, John Rumpel and his wife, Barbara. Also, nieces, Nina Sygnecki, Victoria Kosey and Nicole Sprout and nephew Rod Tabritzchi. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Jude's Children's Hospital Visiting Monday 2-5 and 7-9 at Fox Funeral Home. Funeral mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills Tuesday 10:30am.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Paterno Passes On Home to His Wife for $1,'' Nov. 16: Joe and Sue Paterno, as joint owners of the home in which they live, could not be forced to turn over the house as an asset unless they both were the subject of a lawsuit resulting in a judgment against them. In terms of shielding assets, Joe Paterno is neither better nor worse off now than he was before he sold the house to his wife. Mary Ann Hanna

In 2008 and 2009, as the American automotive industry foundered, critics often cited Detroit's fixation with light trucks and S.U.V.'s, which had fallen out of favor as gas prices rose, for the industry's agita. A new study authored by Max Warburton of Bernstein Research, a market trends and analysis firm, suggests that automakers' fondness for big iron was, and continues to be, driven by the outsize profit margins generated by the machines. Detroit's light-truck models - namely the Ford F-Series, the Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra pickups from General Motors and Chrysler's Ram - rank first through third among Mr. Warburton's list of the top 12 most profitable vehicles for their makers in the United States.

SAMILOW--Renee, October 31, beloved wife Robert, deceased, cherished Mom, Gary (Dale), Lynn (Jay), Steven (Eileen), adoring grandma of Allison, Rachel, Robyn, Nancy, Jared, and Matthew. In our hearts forever.

SAUL--Franklin Robert. Franklin Robert Saul, 81, passed away Monday November 21, 2011, at 10:25am. Franklin was born in Belleville, New Jersey and resided in Essex Fells, New Jersey. Franklin graduated class of 1947 at Montclair High School and graduated class of 1951 from The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania. He served in the United States Army as a Lieutenant in the Korean War. Franklin married his sweetheart, Elayne December 10, 1954. Franklin was a Vice President at City Bank. He worked at Leaman Brothers and F.S. Smithers. He served as Assistant Secretary of The Treasury, Debt Management, for The United States of America under President Lyndon Johnson. Franklin ended his lifelong financial career as The President of The Emigrant Savings Banks of New York. He retired in 1985 and moved to Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. Franklin volunteered as Treasurer for the Children's Aid Society of New York for 25 years. He was very committed to this organization and was very happy to be a part of this greater good. Franklin was a member of The Essex Fells Country Club in New Jersey, a member of The Union League Club in New York City, and a member of The Ponte Vedra Inn and Club in Florida. He was a member of St. Peters Episcopal Church in Essex Fells in New Jersey and a member of Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. Franklin is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Elayne; his son Franklin Robert Saul, Jr.; his daughter Marilyn Elyane Evanson; and his grandchildren, April Leigh Saul, Alexis Elayne Evanson and Maximilian Franklin Evanson; daughter-in-law Kay A. Saul; and son-in-law Eric S. Evanson. A private memorial service was held in Christ Episcopal Church of Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Children's Aid Society, 105 E. 22nd Street, Room 504, NY, NY 10010. Services by Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL. Please visit our online tribute at: www.quinn-shalz.com.

FOR years, Beirut was a city without a beating heart. Destroyed by a civil war that lasted from 1975 to 1990, the downtown of the Lebanese capital festered like a wasteland and then, as the city began to recover, was taken over by huge construction sites. But a new city center is at last emerging. And while the gleaming high-rises, luxury malls and predictable high-end chain stores have drawn comparisons to Dubai (not always favorably), the transformed landscape also holds a number of alluring new independent art galleries, fashion showrooms, stylish restaurants and cocktail lounges. SETH SHERWOOD

Memorial Mass on Tuesday, November 29th at 10am at Saint Patrick's Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Children's Scholarship Fund: www.scholarshipfund.org.

Browns (4-6) at Bengals (6-4) Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Bengals by 8.5 . The Talking Heads once sang that heaven is a place where nothing ever happens. Heaven, then, is a Browns game, a nonevent between moribund teams with few recognizable stars that ends in a 6-3, 13-12, or 14-10 final score. When not losing convincingly to good teams, the Browns challenge the devotion and attention span of fans everywhere by wasting whole afternoons in slow-motion tugs of war against fellow thrill ascetics. It takes real work to comb through the game tape and play-by-play of an entire Browns-Jaguars game, only to discover that the only quasi-interesting story lines are questions about whether a 38-yard field goal sailed just inside the right upright (it didn't) or if Jack Del Rio could explain the final Jaguars play call that gave the Browns a victory (he couldn't). Bengals games, by contrast, are full of action. The Bengals catch bombs and allow bombs. Andy Dalton completes incredible passes and attempts ill-conceived option pitches on the same drive. Defenders tackle receivers by pulling their hair. Pacman Jones has been on the roster for weeks and has done nothing loopy yet, which means that he is due. The Bengals are just good enough to lose to the Ravens and the Steelers, but they are a cut above the teams that get trapped in the Browns' tar pits. The Bengals' 27-17 victory at Cleveland in Week 1 will repeat itself, if only because the Browns are too boring to try something new. Pick: Bengals.

Pat LaFontaine spoke Monday about Sidney Crosby's return from the concussion that kept Crosby out for 101/2 months for an article in today's Times. But LaFontaine, the scoring star of the 1980s and '90s whose career was marked by a series of concussions, spoke at much greater length and depth on the subject. Today, LaFontaine is known for his charity work, particularly with the Companions in Courage Foundation, an organization he founded in 1997 that builds game rooms in children's hospitals across North America. He is also coaching his son's top-ranked U16 team, the Long Island Royals, which is being chronicled on the weekly NHL Network series ''Making of a Royal.''
MILLER--Susan. A beautiful woman, our dear friend. We will miss you terribly. Sandy & Danny; Sande & Louis; Susan & Clive

JOHNSON--Harold E.,1918-2011. Mr. Harold E. Johnson died at his home in John's Island, Vero Beach, Florida, on November 23, 2011. Mr. Johnson is survived by his wife, Elma Lowry Johnson, and his three children, JoAnn Rampton of Charleston, South Carolina, Patricia Hunter of Buffalo, New York, and Harold E. Johnson, Jr. of Alexandria, Virginia. Mr. Johnson, a native of Utah, graduated from the University of Utah and later received an MBA degree from New York University. Following studies at Dartmouth College, he was commissioned an Ensign in the U.S. Navy and served four years as an officer in several staff commands. As a Lieutenant in the U.S. Naval Reserve, he returned to live on Long Island, and work on Wall Street. Mr. Johnson was the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer as well as a director of Continental Corporation. He also served as a director of Idaho Power Company, Diners Club, Franklin Life, Phoenix Assurance Company (London), Pan American Bank, New York Community Bank, Baltica-Skandia Reinsurance, 1st Insurance of Hawaii, Independence Holding Company and many others. He was an Advisor and Trustee for the American Red Cross' Endowment Fund, the Licia Albanese Puccini Foundation, the Ontario Hospital Association of Canada and the New York State Teachers retirement funds. He also served six years as Mayor of Munsey Park in Manhasset, New York. Services will be held at the Community Church in Vero Beach at 2pm, Monday, November 28, 2011. Interment will be at the John's Island Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Community Church of Vero Beach or the American Heart Association.

LOEB--Fred, 97, died at home in Fort Lee, New Jersey, on November 18, 2011. Whether it was working in his beloved artificial flower business or playing tennis, he did everything with a fierce passion. He lived a long and full life and was the patriarch of a family that extended from the US to Brazil, England and India. A true American success story, he fled Nazi Germany in 1938, spent four years in the Army during World War II and then revolutionized the artificial flower business with his long-time partner and best friend Henry Weitz in the 1970's when they created Magicsilk. Husband of the late Hannah Herzberg Loeb, he is survived by his son Michael, his grandson Jonathan, his sister Ruth, 98, of Rio de Janeiro, and his beloved long-time companion Irma Escoto.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Workers Feeling Squeezed by the N.B.A. Lockout,'' Nov. 25: Now that the players and owners have ended their petulant schoolyard spat, it is indeed time to consider the thousands of workers who have been denied many weeks' pay because of the loss of a major portion of the season.

SANDS--Everett. On November 20, 2011, Everett Sands passed away quietly at home at 87 of cancer. An amazing man, he lived many lives, most in New York City, but even after retiring to Florida in 2000, his heart never left New York. His kindness and generosity touched many people whose days will be just a wee bit dimmer for his passing. He is survived by his son Doug and his wife Naomi, his grandchildren Rian and Eli, and his brother, Bill. What a treat to have known and had him in our lives for so long. Now he is gone and if there is a place to go, then he is with my mom, whom he loved dearly, right up to the very last day.

One of the few discernible fashion trends is the prevalance of spotted cat. It is most often sighted in shoulder bags and scarves. Where do these cats get their spots? Many were photo reproduced; a few come in colors you'll never see in the wild. Occasionally, the spectacle of a shoulder-to-sidewalk presentation suggests that cat really is king.

WEBER--Renee, nee Harrison, of Westbury, NY, passed away on November 6, 2011. Exuberant and adored wife of Stanley Weber for 64 years, Renee was proud of her Bronx upbringing. Renee loved being a part of the WWII USS Baltimore reunions, reading the Style section of the Sunday New York Times, and all things Betty Boop. She was the epitome of what a wife, mother and grandmother should be. Stan, Amy, Marc, Jake, Jesse and Shane hold her in their hearts forever.

Survived by Paul, Adam, Daniel, Daniel, Tyler, Sabina, Talia, Luc and everybody who loved her. Service Sunday, November 27 at 6pm Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. Reception to follow at 21 Raymond Place, Hewlett. The family will also be receiving visitors Monday and Tuesday evenings at 63 Barrow Street, New York City.

Formula One, the open-wheel race series, subsists on high drama. But after the 2011 season concludes with the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday in Sao Paulo, off-track intrigues from a land long shunned by the sport, the United States, await reconciliation by race officials and teams. After a five-year absence, Formula One was expected to return to the United States on Nov. 18, 2012, at the Circuit of the Americas, a racetrack being constructed outside Austin, Tex. The circuit's organizers, however, stopped work on Nov. 15 after not receiving a contract from Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone within the predetermined time frame for the November race, which was to be called the United States Grand Prix.

D'AGOSTINO--Dorothy Bodie, beloved wife of Daniel S. D'Agostino Sr., passed away on Thursday, November 24th, 2011. Cherished mother of Denise, her partner John Scarnecchia, Patricia, Daniel Jr, and his fiance Margaret Nowak. The wake to be held at Riverdale Funeral Home, on Tuesday, November 29th from 2-4pm and 6-9pm. The funeral, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, Riverdale NY, on Wednesday, November 30th at 9:45am. Donations can be made to American Cancer Society.

POLIZOS--Polizoes. The League Treatment Center Board of Trustees, children, adult consumers, families and staff mourn the loss of our cherished Medical Director Emeritus, Dr. Polizoes Polizos. For forty years, Dr. Polizos was devoted to the children and adults of the League Treatment Center. He also embraced all those who needed help, especially the disabled and vulnerable. Dr. Polizos' dedication, compassion and brilliance won the love and respect of all who had the priviledge of knowing him. Our hearts go out to Dr. Polizos' family and friends. Dr. P, as he was affectionately known, will be sorely missed. Hannah Achtenberg Kinn, CEO

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Season Tips Off in Location Unlike Any Other,'' Nov. 12: Given the dire condition of the economy and the level of unemployment in this country, it seems rather frivolous for Michigan State and North Carolina to be opening the college basketball season on the flight deck of an aircraft carrier docked in Southern California at a cost of $2 million. Though apparently taxpayer money was not involved, nothing was said about the source of the funding and one must wonder, with President Obama in attendance and addressing the crowd from center court before the game, whether the event had anything to do with his re-election campaign.

ARVESON--William Barnes, Professor, a longtime member of the mathematics faculty at the University of California in Berkeley, died in Berkeley on November 15 due to complications from anesthesia during surgery. Bill was 76. He was born in Oakland, CA. In his youth, Bill served on an aircraft carrier as a radar technician in the US Navy, and worked at the Naval Undersea Research and Development Center. He was a graduate of the California Institute of Technology and received his PhD from UCLA (both funded by the Navy). Bill was a Benjamin Peirce Instructor at Harvard University, and since 1968 was at UC Berkeley where he was a Professor of Mathematics. He had visiting positions in the US and world-wide, including UCLA, UCSD, Pennsylvania, Newcastle (UK), Aarhus (Denmark), Oslo and Trondheim (Norway), Stockholm, Tel Aviv, Canberra, Rio de Janeiro, Tianjin (China), and Kyoto. He also received two Miller research professor awards at Berkeley. Bill strongly inspired and influenced many researchers through his teaching, writing, and lecturing. An elegant expositor who took great care with his writing, he published 79 scholarly manuscripts and authored eight books on C*-algebras, operator algebras, spectral theory, and noncommutative dynamics. His editorial services included the Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society, Proceedings of the Edinburgh Mathematical Society, Duke Mathematical Journal, and three decades as Editor of the Journal of Operator Theory (Romania). Always generous with his time, Bill was committed to the mentorship of young mathematicians, of whom 29 wrote their doctoral dissertations under his guidance. Many of them went on to be prominent research mathematicians in their own right. Bill was a leading expert and a highly innovative researcher in his field, an area of mathematics that underlies quantum physics and can be traced back to Heisenberg's formulation of quantum mechanics. He made many surprising discoveries, continuing to do so until nearly the end of his life. Some of his early work was only fully appreciated years after its publication. Bill pioneered the exploration of certain mysterious structures that arise in a basic way from the modeling of the irreversible dynamics of quantum systems, for example, the creation and annihilation of particles such as electrons and the strange particles found in cosmic rays. In the 1990's he opened a new front in his research, with highly original ideas for applying seemingly unrelated "abstract" mathematics to the efficient calculation of important quantities in quantum physics. During the past decade Bill's important contributions continued to flow as strongly as ever, and began to include applications of quantum spaces to quantum information theory and quantum computing. Bill loved jazz and the movies. Bill is survived by his wife of 26 years, Lee Ann Kaskutas, by his sons Jeff and Robert from a previous marriage, and by his miniature dachshund Bronco. All will miss him dearly, as will scores of fellow mathematicians who worked with him, learned from him, and were inspired by him.

Zoe Strauss's photographs of poor people don't condescend. She shows us pain (a girl with a black eye), strangeness (an empty lot full of boxes of clothes) and joy in ''Mattress Flip, 2001'' (above). ''Zoe Strauss: Ten Years'' opens Jan. 14 at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and includes some 150 photos. Ms. Strauss says her goal is ''to create an epic narrative that reflects the beauty and struggle of everyday life.'' (philamuseum.org)
Pop Jon Pareles

GARELIK--Sanford (Sandy) D.,passed away on November 19, 2011, 93 years. Devoted husband of 57 years to his wonderful wife Catherine, who predeceased him four years ago. Beloved father and mentor to his son Neal (Brigid) and grandchildren Sarah, Nate and Liam and Rian. Beloved son of Yetta and Nathan, brother of Morty, Bernard and Clarence. Devoted uncle, cousin and family member. Lifelong Bronx native who was involved in all aspects of New York's civic affairs. Growing up, he worked in the family dairy business, before going to college at University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, where he graduated in 1938. Member of renowned class of 1940 from New York City's Police Academy and graduate of FBI Academy. Served in US Army Air Force intelligence overseas in various theaters during World War II. With the New York City Police Department, rose through the ranks from patrolman to Chief Inspector (Chief of Department), in the process becoming the first Jewish Chief Inspector and the then youngest Captain and Chief of the NYPD. Recipient of NYPD's Combat Cross for herosim and Medal of Valor for bravery. With U.S. State Department in early 1950's overseeing Latin American security, where he provided guidance on law enforcement and security to numerous Latin American countries. Elected as President of the New York City Council from 1970 through 1974. Mayoral candidate in 1973. Served as Chief of New York City's Transit Police Department and Director of Security for the MTA from 1975 through 1980. From 1980 to 1994, established and served as Executive Director of the Garment Center Economic Security Council, which served as the pioneer for today's business improvement districts. Head of security for Fashion Center Business Improvement District from 1994 to 2004. In these posts, he was instrumental in the revitalization of Manhattan's garment center and surrounding neighborhoods. A true revolutionary during his six decades in law enforcement who pioneered numerous innovations and reforms that helped to create the modern police, law enforcement and intelligence practices. Served as a professor at, inter alia, West Point Military Academy and John Jay College. He was devoted to making his city and country a better place. Throughout his career, his mantra was to help and better the lives of all who came into contact with him. During all of his years of public duty, he always devoted himself to his wife, son and family. After retiring from public service, Sandy helped his son establish Excel Security, a fully integrated national security firm. A consummate gentleman and statesman, he was admired for his integrity, leadership, honor and accessibility. An extraordinary man, with grace, charisma and kindness. He is dearly missed by his family and friends. Family will be receiving friends on Sunday, November 27th at 17 Pound Ridge Rd., Bedford, NY. Memorial donations preferred to the Sanford D. Garelik Memorial Fund at the NYPD's Captains Endowment Association, 233 Broadway, Suite 1801, New York, NY 10279.

WHEN it comes to what they wear, men seem to be sandwiched between fashion and nostalgia. At least they have been for the last decade or so. And it gets worse in a culture that seeks to make a commodity of virtually everything or turn the minor into the remarkable. I was glad to read Friday's article about Mitt Romney's hair, because it confirmed what I suspected: his barber knows what he's doing. People notice Mr. Romney's hair, not because it's resplendent or the style is conservative (gee!), but rather because it's consistent.

WILLIAMSON--William Landram, 91, Professor Emeritus, University of Wisconsin-Madison, died on Saturday, November 19, at Agrace HospiceCare Center. Dr. Williamson was born in Lexington, Kentucky and raised in Atlanta, Georgia. He received degrees from the University of Wisconsin, Emory University, Columbia University and the University of Chicago. After service in the U.S. Army as troopship transport commander in World War II, he worked as a librarian at Baylor University, Montclair (New Jersey) State College and at Columbia University, where he served as Nicholas Murray Butler Librarian from 1954-1964. He was Professor of Library Science at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, from 1966 until his retirement in 1987. He was a library consultant in Indonesia on three occasions, from 1960-62, in 1970 and in 1986. Author of the biography of William Frederick Poole, he was a scholar of American library history and wrote also about international library relations. He served for four years as editor of International Leads, a publication of the International Relations Round Table of the American Library Association. Professor Williamson was married to Daisy Levy for 40 years. She died in 2002, bequeathing to him a loving step-daughter, Andrea Irizarry and her husband, Elvin, of Fresh Meadows, NY, three grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his devoted wife of five years, the former Gertrude Wright, whom he treasured, and by many loved nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

A review on Oct. 30 about ''Pauline Kael: A Life in the Dark,'' by Brian Kellow, and ''The Age of Movies: Selected Writings of Pauline Kael,'' edited by Sanford Schwartz, erroneously attributed a distinction to the Berkeley, Calif., radio station KPFA, which in 1955 recruited Kael to contribute film reviews. KPFA, which went on the air in 1949, was not ''the first listener-supported radio station in America.'' (One earlier station that relied for a timeon listener contributions was little WEVD in New York, which began broadcasting in 1927 as a Socialist station.)

GOLD--Herbert Z. (1915-2011), adoring husband and father, and mensch to all who knew him, died in the early morning after Thanksgiving at the age of 96. Born in Brooklyn, Herb, graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, where he played piccolo in the marching band, and then from NYU Law School. He later joined his father's business building homes and apartment buildings in Rockville Centre and Hewlett Harbor. He was appointed redeveloper as a partner of the firm of Stackler, Frank and Gold to build and complete the Urban Renewal Program for the Village of Rockville Centre, New York, and other projects on Long Island. In 1941 he met Rita Weinstein and when he asked which street he should take to drive her home, she told him to take the long way, and they did: He was married to Rita for 67 years before her passing in 2008. Together, they raised their beautiful son Richard, who sadly passed at the age of 35. Herb was a generous benefactor to countless organizations and individuals throughout the world. He established the Rita Gold Early Childhood Centers at Columbia University's Teachers College and in Tel Aviv. Herb funded many scholarships for young Opera singers, as well as for underprivileged students making it possible for them to go on to higher education. He was also a generous donor to The New York City Opera, Julliard, and The Sarasota Opera. Herb lived life to the fullest, inspiring those around him to strive to fulfill their highest potential. He was a kind, soft-spoken man of keen intellect and quick wit. Herb was a philanthropist and active participant in Jewish causes in the US and Israel, and a caring and generous friend to so many. He has left all of us an extraordinary legacy of learning and commitment to service. He will always be in our hearts. He is survived by his brother Ronny and loving cousins in America and Israel. Services will be held graveside on Monday, 12 noon, at The Old Montifiore Cemetery, located off Springfield Blvd. in St. Albans, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

Miller--Steven Allen, 66, of NYC, beloved husband of Pam Elgar, brother of Doreen Perry and step-father of Magnolia Grossman, died November 18 in Israel with his Adamit family. He was predeceased by his son Jonathan Miller. Steve was President of Plymouth Management Group, Inc., a lover of jazz, language and a Mets fan (except this year). Steve was a proud grandfather to Lilac and August. His gentleness, warmth and integrity will be missed by his family, his many close friends, including his poker buddies, and Max.

ENGEL--Marjorie, 76. A beacon of compassion and fairness, lifetime advocate of the potential of all children, and fashionable figure outfitted in signature black coat and slacks, Marge Engel died on November 23rd of lung cancer. Outspoken in gratitude for her wonderful life, she approached dying with equanimity and peace. A longtime preschool teacher, she enriched the lives of hundreds of young children. Marge's life was made extra special by eight grandchildren, Lauren and Jeremy, Hannah and Gabriel, Dylan and Lia, and Maya and Jade: the children of her sons, John and Peter, and their wives, Yung Yung and Cheryl; and of her niece and nephew, Nancy and Michael, and their spouses, Michael and Maria. All of us will forever miss her grace and unconditional love. Sister of the late Elizabeth (Bitsy) Greenfield, Marge is survived by her devoted brother, Robert Conner, and his wife, Ann; her ex-husband, Stephen Engel; cousins Judy Saccucci, Ruth Modlin, and Kim Dana Kupperman; and a legion of loyal and loving friends. A Memorial will be on Saturday, December 10, 5pm, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Marge's name to a charity to be announced at the memorial.

The $15.5 million sale of an apartment at the Carlyle Hotel on the Upper East Side, that cynosure of all things civilized and repository of secrets for presidents and starlets alike, was the most expensive of the week. Like the rest of the 68 private residences at the Carlyle, the four-bedroom four-and-a-half-bath apartment is a co-op. The asking price was $17.5 million, according to Streeteasy. The sale price was confirmed by the listing agency, Brown Harris Stevens. Kathy Sloane, who brokered the sale for Brown Harris, declined to comment.

NEWMAN--Martin Joel, beloved son of the late J. Moe Newman and Frieda Orenzow Newman, passed peacefully away on Friday, November 25, 2011 at the age of seventy. He is mourned and survived by his siblings, Phyllis Charash, Herbert Newman and Toni Sachs. Many nieces and nephews and grandnieces and grandnephews. He will be remembered for his fondness of music, his artistic ability and his sweet and loving nature. Funeral services are private. Contributions may be made to the Gurwin Jewish Healthcare Foundation or to the charity of one's choice.
O'CONNOR--Don & Smitty. 25 & 27 yrs gone. We miss you but you live in us always, love Leslie Louise Lyle Don & family.

Havana, April 1, 2011 I was on a humanitarian mission in Cuba, and we met some locals who took us around to various spots, including this senior day care center. Though they appear mellow here, they were actually a fun and spirited group. A few sang for us. One lady even asked me to dance. JOHN L. KRAUSS, Indianapolis

Looking for inexpensive holiday-time getaways? Go for the dead zones: the weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas, or right after New Year's. Early December is often overlooked when it comes to vacation planning. But because business travel ebbs and children are in school, it is one of the best times of year to travel, with airlines, hotels and car rental companies offering deals to spur demand. (There are a few exceptions: New York, for example, is just as expensive.)

''IT'S a mix of raided grandma's closet and classic punk with a little bit of boudoir on the side,'' said Lyndsey Butler, the designer for VEDA reclaimed leather, which has collaborated with Reformation by Yael Aflalo on a holiday collection. The 10 pieces channel Kate Moss and Johnny Depp circa 1994 and all things grunge: downtown motorcycle jackets paired with silk burgundy pajama pants and camisoles; festive red leather vests with indigo-blue slip dresses, and denim miniskirts. In other words, a very Courtney Love Christmas. Prices start at $145. Go to thereformation.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

CABOT--Francis H.,died peacefully at home in La Malbaie, QC on November 19, 2011 at age 86. Founder of The Garden Conservancy, author of "The Greater Perfection", and one of the world's great gardeners, he is survived by his wife Anne of 62 years, his children: Colin, Currie, and Marianne, and their spouses, nine grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Funeral Services private. Contributions to the Garden Conservancy, the Quatre Vents Foundation, or the charity of your choice.

FLYNN--Amy Mazzola. Died when hit by an automobile while out for a walk after Thanksgiving dinner with her family on November 24, 2011. She was the wife of Terence "Tad" Flynn, mother of James Davis Flynn and Christina Pleasant Flynn; sister of Alison Mazzola; and daughter of Sylvia and John Mazzola. She attended the Brearley School as well as the School of American Ballet, and graduated with honors from Harvard College in 1985. Amy was Woody Allen's script girl at age 17 with Bea Arthur as her chaperone. Amy was a vice president of JPMorgan & Co until 1995. She was active with the School of American Ballet and other organizations. She was a member of the Board of Directors of the American Friends of the Paris Opera and Ballet, member of the Watch Hill Yacht Club (RI), the Misquamicut Club (RI) and Doubles in New York. She will be missed dearly by all who knew her. Her friends were many, her talents were abundant, and her storytelling was legendary. At Frank E Campbell 5 to 8pm on Monday Nov 28. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, November 29th at 2 at St. Thomas church, 53rd and fifth Avenue, New York, NY.

ON my wish list, where it will remain for all eternity: Francis Kurkdjian's Extrait de Parfum, 200 milliliters. Only 20 sets exist, 10 with gold tops, 10 with platinum. You select your own name for the fragrance, which is then engraved on the bottle; said bottle lies in a box that lights up when the cabinetlike doors are opened. There's a hand-embroidered silk pouch and a gold-threaded booklet explaining how best to deploy the scent. The price is $11,000. I'll name my bottle Zuccotti Park. How does it smell, you ask? Please. This is Francis Kurkdjian, one of the finest noses on the planet. I could deconstruct the scent for you, but that wouldn't begin to describe the effect of inhaling an $11,000 perfume. Sicilian bergamot, Damascus rose, gurjum balsa (don't ask me), jasmine and the sweat of an Andalusian concubine frolicking in a field of hibiscus and saffron. O.K., I made that last one up, but you get it. Or do you? S.S. FAIR
1953 RAISED RANCH $549,900
Television Neil Genzlinger
